webTitle: Leeds bring yellow fever to the Valley

fields.headline: Leeds bring yellow fever to the Valley
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson has a good grasp of English, but it is hoped that the Swede will not be fooled by the double talk echoing around The Valley after this trench warfare.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson has a good grasp of English, but it is hoped that the Swede will not be fooled by the double talk echoing around The Valley after this trench warfare.

Ever the diplomat, Eriksson would probably put this acrimonious battle down to English "fighting spirit" - the well-worn euphemism for the physicality of the game here. Opposing centre-backs Rio Ferdinand - who subdued his prospective Finland opponent, Jonatan Johansson - and Richard Rufus may have enhanced their England claims, but managers and players alike spoke of manly virtues such as "standing up to it" and "not rolling over". They also claimed the referee and his officials "lost it".

The truth is several players lost control and Clive Wilkes's only fault was not to issue red cards for two of the eight offences punished with cautions.

There are two sides to Leeds - who also won the cautions contest 5-3 - and both were visible at the Valley. On the one hand the quick, flowing, footballing team admired especially for their European exploits. On the other, the over-physical, confrontational team still winning few friends outside West Yorkshire.

No two people see a game the same way. Just ask a pair of Leeds players about this contest. Mark Viduka: "It was a very rough game, one I didn't enjoy playing in." David Batty: "I love these sort of games."

Viduka took only 11 seconds to score his 19th goal of the season but 15 minutes later earned the game's first caution. The striker appeared to elbow the curiously put-upon youngster Scott Parker but claimed it was accidental. Batty was booked as he tried to pull Parker to his feet, while still being treated after the game's worst foul, a lunge from behind by Danny Mills, which earned the Charlton old boy a caution. Time for a euphemism from Charlton manager Alan Curbishley, who said he was "disappointed" with Mills's challenge.

O'Leary was disappointed to have his team's approach questioned. "I don't think anybody was over-physical - there were some strange decisions."

It would surely have been a draw had Wilkes awarded a penalty when Mills chopped Johansson in the 89th minute.

But after this game of opinions, the fact is that Leeds took three points to advance their European hopes while Charlton broke down on the route to the Continent with their first defeat since Boxing Day.

webTitle: Wistful Saints prepare to say goodbye to Hoddle

fields.headline: Wistful Saints prepare to say goodbye to Hoddle
fields.trailText: Amid the pleasure, the pain. Southampton's fans cheered a fifth successive league win for the first time in nine years, all the while muttering under their breath about the presumed departure of their manager. Even while celebrating victory, they were accepting defeat.
fields.body:
Amid the pleasure, the pain. Southampton's fans cheered a fifth successive league win for the first time in nine years, all the while muttering under their breath about the presumed departure of their manager. Even while celebrating victory, they were accepting defeat.

Southampton have not finished in the top 10 since 1990, and have not qualified for Europe for 17 years. Today they are eighth, one win away from fifth and with a game in hand. But if, as the fans fear, Glenn Hoddle is destined for Spurs a return to the bad old days could be close. And the feeling that he will go is not confined to the terraces, but permeates the entire club.

"If Glenn goes he goes but I don't think he will," said Paul Jones. "He's been a big success here and it would be a huge disappointment if he leaves. Several people have just signed new contracts here because of Glenn and we would all be gutted if he goes."

Their defender Dean Richards joined in the plaintive theme. "At the end of the day he's taken us forward and I'm sure he feels he's only just started doing a job and there's a long way still to go. Hopefully that'll be the carrot that keeps him at Southampton.

"It would be a massive achievement for him to get a club like ourselves into Europe. These are good times here and Glenn is very much a part of that. We've got massive respect for him as a coach and we don't want to see him go because things would fall away if he did."

As there has as yet been no approach from Spurs to either Hoddle's club or his agent, everyone was getting a little carried away. Everyone, that is, except for Hoddle himself who said only that "what happens at other clubs is nothing to do with me". Not yet, anyway.

And if - when - the call does come no one can see him staying. "The pull might be too strong," said Richards. "I mean, that's his club. That's where he made his name as a player and he's a legend at Spurs, no doubt about that."

Richards, along with Hassan Kachloul, is also reported to be a Tottenham target and admits that he would be tempted should an offer arrive. "I mean, it's a big club, isn't it," said Kachloul. "You've got to be interested. It's a glamour club, so anybody's going to be tempted to go to Spurs."

It should be little surprise if Spurs were tempted by everyone at Southampton. Four places above the London "glamour club", on Saturday Jones became the first Saints keeper since Tommy Allen in 1921 to keep a seventh successive clean sheet in the league. Their success has been built around the honest principles of organisation and sheer hard work, and in a scrappy game they created the best chances.

Twice Marian Pahars, who has scored jonly once since September, missed gilt-edged opportunities while James Beattie and Mark Draper went close. Everton, despite a sustained period of pressure following the goal, had just one meaningful effort in each half. Scot Gemmill headed wide in the first; Duncan Ferguson tested Jones in the second, both from Thomas Gravesen's crosses.

The goal itself was a delight, Jo Tessem fooling the Everton rearguard into expecting a pass before turning past David Weir and running 30 yards to score. It is another two weeks before the Saints next play. Quite who the manager will be by then no one knows.

fields.headline: Toon's £50m bonus eases derby pain
fields.trailText: They may be skulking in the lower half after this humbling derby defeat with the £40m owed on the redevelopment of their stadium hanging over their heads, but Newcastle are apparently back in the big money, if not the big time.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at St James' Park
fields.body:
They may be skulking in the lower half after this humbling derby defeat with the £40m owed on the redevelopment of their stadium hanging over their heads, but Newcastle are apparently back in the big money, if not the big time.

Boro followed Sunderland's script and dumped the Toon on its backside, even down to conceding a late penalty which United obligingly missed. Now Bobby Robson is to get £50m in the summer to ensure such traumas are not endured again.

"For the first time in a long time, there's cash in the bank," said the United vice-chairman Douglas Hall, who has opted against selling his 47.2% stake in the club. "We are already bigger and more financially stable than Barcelona. Our turnover is not as large as Manchester United's, but we have possibly a larger stockpile of cash because we haven't gone crazy over the last 12 months with transfer fees.

"Rivaldo was always my dream and Newcastle should attract players of his quality. We can attract any player from anywhere in the world. This is where it all takes off again."

After a season of big-name departures, sceptics may need to be convinced that the cream of the continent can be enticed. "This reminds me of John Hall saying exactly what the fans want to hear," said Mark Jensen, editor of the Newcastle fanzine The Mag. "We need action, not words."

Such chequebook clout is required. After their bright start had sparked no more than a disallowed goal from Clarence Acuna, Newcastle laboured in gloomy mediocrity. By the time Carl Cort volleyed past Mark Schwarzer, they trailed to two Alen Boksic goals.

Just five minutes remained when Paul Ince and Steve Vickers sandwiched Cort in the area. Alan Shearer had fluffed an 83rd-minute chance at parity against Sunderland in November; now it was Nolberto Solano who slapped the penalty against the bar. "It would have been a cruel blow to have conceded," said Boro coach Terry Venables, whose side now sit four points above the drop zone. "Maybe they thought so too and let us off."

Boro arrived without a win in eight games and minus their £1m signing Dean Windass who had "put his back out" lifting his kit bag out of the car boot. In his absence, Venables threw Boksic forward in a lone role, supported by a trio of midfielders strung in front of Paul Okon and Ince.

The tactics utterly outfoxed the home side - despite the loss of Phil Stamp for two idiotic offences on the stroke of half-time - yet it needed the brilliant Boksic to earn only Boro's second win on Tyneside since 1953. Having earned a free-kick, the former Lazio striker leapt to nod Christian Karembeu's cross beyond Shay Given.

Five minutes later, Ince's burst through the centre was checked illegally and Boksic curled a mouth-watering free-kick into the top corner. His job done, he was substituted two minutes from time to envious eyes in the stands.

webTitle: Time to bring back vision of Beckham

fields.headline: Time to bring back vision of Beckham
fields.trailText: No one would accuse Sir Alex Ferguson of putting country before club. Sven-Goran Eriksson's first England squad of 31 included eight United players, of whom five took the field against Spain. On Saturday only two who did not, Teddy Sheringham and Nicky Butt, played where they ever might for new England.
fields.body:
No one would accuse Sir Alex Ferguson of putting country before club. Sven-Goran Eriksson's first England squad of 31 included eight United players, of whom five took the field against Spain. On Saturday only two who did not, Teddy Sheringham and Nicky Butt, played where they ever might for new England.

Andy Cole was suspended but Wes Brown was on the bench, Paul Scholes wide on the left, the Nevilles at centre-back and left-back after each played on the right for Eriksson, and David Beckham nowhere. The leader of England's orchestra, left out midweek against Sturm Graz, thus turns up for national duty with his violin out of tune. The last chance to put it right was denied him.

It was a golden chance too. Leicester, nursing the embarrassment of their Cup defeat by Wycombe's internet wanderer but still with an eye to Europe, had no one to contest midfield, so did not try. Instead, in defiance of Trafford borough council, they stood up, were counted in defence - eight, sometimes nine, blocking by numbers - and challenged United's wit.

It was found wanting. Simon Royce made only two saves, the first after the interval, before he was beaten by a grotesque deflection in the 88th minute. The second goal was a natural sequel, indicating the intense level of Leicester's earlier purpose and the extent to which it had dulled United's play.

Ferguson "was pleased with the passing" but it was passing that did not hurt on a pitch that will have the Cup semi-finalists Spurs and Arsenal competing for practice space on Hackney Marshes. Too often the approach was pedestrian, ending in a cross that lacked precision or imagination.

Dr Willi Railo, the sports psychologist working with England, says "the main thing is to clean the players' brains". As Mrs Beeton might say, "First find them." Last month the royal bank opened a unit for footballers on the basis that they have more money than sense. The new royalty was no doubt flattered to think the bank was called Coots.

If Peter Taylor, wearing his national coach's hat, thought to give United's England men a taste of trials to come in Tirana, they failed the test, except Scholes when he came inside. He and Denis Irwin, leading the side in his 500th game for United on St Patrick's Day, deserved the victory.

Fabien Barthez usually saves his pranks for the game. On Saturday he tweaked a thigh in the warm-up, an injury of convenience that let in Paul Rachubka, 19, from California, for his full debut and let himself out of France's friendly activities. He will, of course, be untwinged for United's next game, at Anfield. As for Ryan Giggs playing for Wales, "You must be joking," spluttered Ferguson.

Brooklyn could have done all Rachubka did and would have enabled Daddy to play and be top first-time father. United and England need his first-time vision and fine-tuned passing.

fields.headline: Spurs thrive on shock treament
fields.trailText: After all the calls for George Graham's head, Tottenham fans might have been expected to take their seats clutching champagne as well as bagels. Instead they behaved as if nothing had happened. Not a single banner celebrated the manager's departure, not a solitary song told of delight.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
After all the calls for George Graham's head, Tottenham fans might have been expected to take their seats clutching champagne as well as bagels. Instead they behaved as if nothing had happened. Not a single banner celebrated the manager's departure, not a solitary song told of delight.

Even when images of Glenn Hoddle in his pomp flashed up on the big screen as usual before kick-off there was no surge of excitement. It might be stretching the point to suggest White Hart Lane was in mourning, but had the crowd broken into a chant of "We want Graham in" it would have been no surprise.

If shock was behind the supporters' reaction, those feelings were shared by the players. Youngsters such as Ledley King, Luke Young and Stephen Clemence who have been helped along by Graham described themselves as "disappointed" or "sad" at the Scot's departure. "I think he's a top-quality manager," King said, "and I don't think he did anything wrong."

Clemence's insistence that Graham had the total backing of his squad - "I was right behind the manager and I know the other players were" - has been contradicted by reports of a rift between the Scot and his captain Sol Campbell.

But all the talk was of team spirit reaching new heights and, after that FA Cup victory at West Ham which set up a semi-final against Arsenal, the staff thought there was more chance of Graham riding into training on Shergar than there was of him being sacked.

"Everybody was in a state of shock and I don't think we've come to terms with it yet," said the assistant manager Stewart Houston, who also saw Graham depart in unexpected circumstances at Arsenal and added that his own future had not been discussed. "The body takes a period of time to adapt.

"The place was as high as a kite on Monday, it really was. It was absolutely buzzing. The players were really pumped up on a high and we thought it was terrific, marvellous." Clearly a week is not just a long time in politics.

Not surprisingly, after the remarks from Tottenham's new owners that Graham had to go because he was not a "team player", Houston said there was no problem: "We're not tennis players, we're team players. George Graham is very much a team player."

With or without Graham the team rumbled on. The good news for Spurs fans ahead of their next two games, against Arsenal in the league and Cup, is that there was no negative reaction to Graham's departure. After a hairy start in which Coventry might have scored twice, this was a comfortable, deserved victory.

David Pleat said the team were so focused and well prepared that his wife could have managed them. The director of football changed little, save pushing the impressive King into more advanced positions from midfield and asking Steffen Freund to get forward more often. His decision to retain Steffen Iversen at right wing-back paid off as the Norwegian scored one goal and had a hand in another.

The decision to keep Clemence in his preferred position in the centre of midfield was successful, too. It says much for the instability at Spurs that, at 22, Clemence has seen four managers come and go. But he was a lively figure with his passing, shooting and set-pieces.

It was from his corner that Iversen sent a header past Chris Kirkland and from his free-kick shortly after that Les Ferdinand scored after another Iversen header had been parried. Sergei Rebrov polished things off, scoring from King's neat pass.

Coventry, having wasted early chances and been let down by poor marking, never looked likely to recover. Eight points adrift of safety, their prospects look grim. "We still feel a good run can get us out of trouble," Lee Carsley said.

Graham believed Tottenham's good run might just have been beginning. "We felt we were going in the right direction," Houston said. It will be left to someone else to carry the journey on.

fields.headline: Ranieri reveals Gross delusion
fields.trailText: Chelsea's head coach Claudio Ranieri has often been compared to the former Spurs manager Christian Gross. And though Ranieri is Italian, not Swiss, he clearly has a second home in cloud cuckoo land.
fields.body:
Chelsea's head coach Claudio Ranieri has often been compared to the former Spurs manager Christian Gross. And though Ranieri is Italian, not Swiss, he clearly has a second home in cloud cuckoo land.

As he surveyed the wreckage of another Premiership defeat, Chelsea's hopes of a Champions League place and possibly, his long-term prospects in south-west London, he cheerfully announced: "I've always said that the best time to judge me will be in three years' time."

If Ranieri has been led to believe that he will get that long to assemble a winning team, then the improvement in his English skills has been grossly, or even Grossly, exaggerated.

Managers at Chelsea last about as long as paint on the Forth Bridge. Ranieri is the 14th manager in the past 27 years and only one of those, John Neal, has lasted beyond three years.

The only person guaranteed to be at Stamford Bridge in three years is the chairman Ken Bates, assuming he is in more robust health than Mark Bosnich. The Australian is still trying to achieve fitness after recovering from injury, which will apparently include shedding more weight than Vanessa Feltz.

Ranieri says he will be "interested" to see Bosnich in action in the Premiership. Chelsea fans will be delighted, after a lamentable performance from Carlo Cudicini.

As an Italian, Cudicini was perhaps only demonstrating his fondness for comic opera when he failed to clear a back-pass from the substitute John Terry for the final goal by Kevin Phillips and instead tried to trap it. Or perhaps he was pretending to be Fabien Barthez.

Not that he should be the only can-carrier in the Chelsea defence. Marcel Desailly and Frank Leboeuf, often such an immaculate partnership, were run ragged by Don Hutchison and Gavin McCann. And by way of a change, it was Desailly and Graeme le Saux who starred in the comedy duet which allowed McCann to sidestep their entwined legs to roll the third goal past a static Cudicini.

Chelsea, who led twice and were ahead 2-1 at the interval, must have thought they were on course for another routine home win, having lost only one game at the Bridge all season and that to Leicester back in September.

Eidur Gudjohnsen brilliantly set up Desailly's header for the first and then gave another demonstration of his beautiful left foot by clipping one in off the underside of the bar. Hutchison scored in between those efforts but Sunderland were leaving so many gaps in defence that they seemed certain to be punished again on the break.

Sunderland had not won at Stamford Bridge since 1957. But their players clearly agree with Henry Ford's statement that history is bunk, since they delivered the half-time talk to their manager Peter Reid.

Hutchison, who scored the second equaliser as well and was man of the match by a country mile, said: "The gaffer didn't have to say anything because we were insisting to him that we could win it. We've had a poor run of results recently but now we're back on track and hope this is the start of a run that will take us into the Champions League. That is the logical next step for us."

Chelsea thought that was almost a God-given right for them but now they may have to take the logical step backwards by playing in the InterToto Cup.

At least Stamford Bridge now looks more like a football ground than a building site, with all the cranes having been removed since the previous home game five weeks ago. Pity, really, since they might have been used to lift the players' spirits.

webTitle: Owen day of hits and misses

fields.headline: Owen day of hits and misses
fields.trailText: The less patient among the Liverpool support who jeered at the final whistle should perhaps remember that rollercoasters spend as much time going down as going up.
fields.body:
The less patient among the Liverpool support who jeered at the final whistle should perhaps remember that rollercoasters spend as much time going down as going up.

Yes, as their pursuit of a Champions League berth enters a crucial phase, this was a most disappointing result for the Merseysiders, but Gérard Houllier's team have travelled so far in such a relatively short time that it is inevitable they will occasionally stumble when expected to stroll.

In truth, Liverpool were so wretched before the interval that it was a little surprising they eventually emerged with anything tangible.

In the end, though, they could - probably should - have won by a country mile, Michael Owen rescuing a point in front of the watching England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson but then missing chances he would normally be expected to accept.

With Ipswich, Sunderland and Leeds all having registered victories away from home the previous afternoon, Houllier was not best pleased.

"My side showed me two different faces today," he said. "In the first half we were just not at the office. We improved greatly after the break and we could well have won the game. We showed pride and we showed determination.

"It is disappointing not to collect all three points but we are still up there; we have games in hand on those around us," he added.

Those who find little merit in squad rotation were sporting smug smiles during the first half of what was a curiously over-polite game, which at times appeared to have been stripped of its competitive edge.

Mindful that his team had succumbed to battle fatigue almost exactly 12 months earlier, Houllier omitted four of the men who had been instrumental in the Uefa Cup defeat of Porto.

He brought on one of them, Steven Gerrard, after 55 minutes with Houllier admitting: "Steven has had some niggling injuries, he was not entirely fit, and he was only put on in an emergency situation. If I had played him for the full match he would probably not have been okay to join up with England."

The rotation was a typically bold ploy by a man who has always extolled the virtues of the managerial gamble. But, for once, there was to be only limited payback.

For all the effort of Owen, for all Jari Litmanen's sweet interventions, there was nothing to excite and very little to covet in the first half.

Having arrived in the north-west intent on ring-fencing the single point they held at kick-off, Derby could hardly believe their good fortune.

Not that Jim Smith's side lacked discipline or adventure; they simply produced smart football and then gratefully accepted the gifts their generous hosts laid before them.

Initially, Liverpool enjoyed almost all the possession and never looked like scoring while Derby gorged themselves upon crumbs and were in front after only nine minutes.

In keeping with the afternoon, it was an unconvincing goal, Deon Burton hooking home the scruffiest of shots after Horacio Carbonari touched on Seth Johnson's corner.

Until the substitute Thordur Gudjonsson saw his low drive halted by goalkeeper Sander Westerveld with just six minutes remaining, that was to be Derby's only effort on target.

Liverpool were altogether more dangerous in the second period and after Owen steered home at the second attempt after a neat exchange with Litmanen, they seemed likely to win.

Three times Owen found himself beautifully placed inside the Derby penalty area, three times he steered his shot across the face of goal and wide of the far post.

He probably will not do that again between now and the end of next season but he did it yesterday and, sadly for Houllier, it was to cost his side two points.

fields.headline: Ipswich near fairyland
fields.trailText: Liverpool, Newcastle, Middlesbrough, Coventry, Charlton, Manchester City, Derby; anyone who still doubts that third-placed Ipswich Town can hold on for a Champions League place in their first season back in the Premiership should look at the relative ease of their run-in.
fields.body:
Liverpool, Newcastle, Middlesbrough, Coventry, Charlton, Manchester City, Derby; anyone who still doubts that third-placed Ipswich Town can hold on for a Champions League place in their first season back in the Premiership should look at the relative ease of their run-in.

They may well earn enough points to keep at bay a chasing pack of five clubs separated by only five points. Even so George Burley continues to refuse to tempt fate by agreeing that his team have a chance of winning the race.

"Our aim is to finish in the top six," he insists. "Talk of a Champions League place is fairyland." It is a tone reminiscent of David O'Leary's famous underplaying of Leeds's chances early in the season. And no one believed him either.

It is team spirit which underpins the Ipswich dream, and Saturday's victory was testament to that. Despite losing six of their previous eight games in all competitions, confidence remained high as they arrived at Upton Park.

This was in stark contrast to West Ham. A run of one win in their previous nine league games, plus George Graham's last pitch-side act as Tottenham manager, had shot their confidence to pieces. "Everyone was devastated when Spurs beat us in the Cup," admitted Harry Redknapp. "Honestly I've never known a group of players so low. Against Ipswich our confidence was zilch."

Certainly West Ham were unrecognisable from the side that romped home at Old Trafford in the fourth round. But this is the danger of Redknapp's approach, which relies on individual genius as much as team ethic.

The side can only cope with the unbalancing affect of two free spirits such as Paolo di Canio and Joe Cole so long as the pair compensate with spells of magic. But both are badly out of sorts at the moment, young Cole to the extent that he was replaced at half-time. With Frédéric Kanouté also struggling - he last scored in the league in December - Redknapp suddenly finds himself looking over his shoulder at the relegation pack.

Ipswich on the other hand have been better served by a more conservative approach. They too like passing the ball but are better balanced and boast vital width and more overall solidity. Certainly they were well worth Saturday's victory after dominating all departments and finding the net through Martijn Reuser's 18-yard bending free-kick after a foul inside the area which should have been a penalty.

Scoring does remain a problem for Ipswich but Burley is on the case and is currently being linked with Southampton's James Beattie.

webTitle: Grimandi red card adds colour to grey day

fields.headline: Grimandi red card adds colour to grey day
fields.trailText: A match that kicked off in a blizzard and ended in the pale sunshine of a beckoning spring certainly appeared to occupy the span of a season for most spectators.
fields.body:
A match that kicked off in a blizzard and ended in the pale sunshine of a beckoning spring certainly appeared to occupy the span of a season for most spectators.

We had to wait until the 82nd minute for the first decent off-the-ball run. It was performed by a streaker. He might have been simply bored although, given the bitterness of the weather, a suicide attempt could not be discounted.

The most significant feature of the game took place in the secvond minute of added-on time when the Arsenal defender Gilles Grimandi was shown the red card for his second bookable offence.

Grimandi, whose late foul on Darius Vassell followed a yellow-card challenge on Julian Joachim in the 65th minute, will now miss the FA Cup semi-final against Tottenham Hotspur at Old Trafford on April 8. This was the 32nd time an Arsenal player has been sent off in Arsène Wenger's five seasons at Highbury.

"It was harsh," said Wenger last night. "If the referee had remembered that he had already given Gilles a yellow card, he might not have given him a second one," he said.

Wenger has informed the England management that his goalkeeper David Seaman, who missed yesterday's match with an inflammation of the back, is not definitely out of next weekend's match against Finland at Anfield.

"It doesn't look really bad," he said. "He was OK on Friday and Saturday but he felt sore when he woke up this morning. There must be a doubt about the weekend but we will know more within the next 48 hours."

This was such an awful game that anyone who missed it was truly fortunate. When Villa beat Ipswich nine days ago it was their first league victory at home since November. On this form they might have to wait until next November for another win.

That triumph over Ipswich probably confirmed Villa's immediate future in the Premiership. But this is a club that appears to be going nowhere.

"I am neither deaf nor blind to the thoughts of all sections of our support," the chairman Doug Ellis said in the programme, though there were times yesterday when he probably wished he was. David Ginola, on the left, did nothing to discount the doubts his manager has about him while Paul Merson, on the right, was less creative than he can be.

Arsenal are shambling through Europe like an overladen backpacker and now their form in the Premiership is just as unconvincing. Yesterday Sylvain Wiltord was paired with Dennis Bergkamp but they were easily swallowed up by Villa's tight back four.

Wenger blamed the pitch. "It is the worst in the Premiership," he said. "There was no grass and today it was hard and bumpy. I thought we were very concentrated today. But we lacked sharpness around the box."

Villa's John Gregory did not disagree with Wenger about the pitch. "I think he's right - it's not a particularly good surface. But it will be relaid.

"Talking to some people today you would have thought that we had drawn at home to Basingstoke. But Arsenal are an outstanding club; an outstanding football team. They are littered with internationals.

"We didn't play particularly well but I'm glad we got something out of it. We have one of the best defensive records in the league and David James, who has proved one of my better signings, can take a lot of credit for that,"

Perhaps a match between a side that is just about safe from relegation and another that has already been beaten for the championship did not promise riches. But this barren stalemate was still a terrible disappointment.

Arsenal did go close in the 68th minute when Ray Parlour crossed from the right and Bergkamp did not get quite enough boot on the ball. Grimandi also went close in the 86th minute, but by then everyone had decided that this game did not deserve to be garnished with a goal.

fields.headline: Dark days loom for Royle
fields.trailText: As Manchester City celebrated their second successive promotion last summer, the story was recounted of how, during one of their bleak spells a few years earlier, a rather corpulent thirtysomething fan had walked into their training ground holding a pair of battered boots. It turned out he was after a trial, complaining he could not do any worse than anyone actually employed by the club. His message came across loud and clear.
fields.body:
As Manchester City celebrated their second successive promotion last summer, the story was recounted of how, during one of their bleak spells a few years earlier, a rather corpulent thirtysomething fan had walked into their training ground holding a pair of battered boots. It turned out he was after a trial, complaining he could not do any worse than anyone actually employed by the club. His message came across loud and clear.

On Saturday the culmination of a bone-chilling afternoon - even Andrei Kan- chelskis wore gloves - would appear to be that Joe Royle's team are returning to those days of Mancunian maudlin. The names and faces may change but there is just something about City, a genetic defect that yanks them back every time they seem to be making progress.

To stand a realistic chance of survival they will need four wins now from their remaining eight games and, though that might not sound incredibly much, it cannot be overlooked that they have won only two of their last 21 league matches.

Anything but an away victory at Valley Parade these days should be construed as a setback, yet there were times here when Bradford threatened to embarrass their guests. Confidence is clearly a lost commodity at Maine Road and what should have been a humdrum victory once Gerard Wiekens had scuffed them into the lead became an undignified toil when, for no apparent reason, their customary butterflies suddenly developed into full-blown jitters.

Suddenly Bradford began playing with something curiously reminiscent of confidence and self-belief. Robbie Blake and Ashley Ward turned the game on its head with a goal apiece at the start of the second half and if the referee Steve Dunn had awarded any of five fair-to-middling Bradford penalty appeals the damage might well have been irreparable. The vagaries of officialdom have dealt Royle a poor hand in recent weeks but at the end of a match full of incident it would not have been inappropriate for the visiting manager to name Dunn as his man of the match.

As it was, Shaun Goater equalised with 20 minutes to go but a draw did not suit anyone save Middlesbrough and, no one particularly happy, the fans shuffled away like a scene from an old LS Lowry print. For both clubs there are testing times ahead.

 Four Manchester City fans were charged with singing racist abuse at the game, believed to be the first charge under the Football Offences Act, and 26 people were arrested for alleged public order offences.

fields.headline: Nationwide League round-up
fields.trailText: John Aldridge's five-year reign at Tranmere Rovers came to an end when he resigned after the 3-2 home defeat by Barnsley. Tranmere, who threw away a two-goal lead, remain bottom of the First Division and despite their FA Cup run, Aldridge decided the time was right to go. His assistant, Kevin Sheedy, will take charge for tomorrow's trip to Gillingham.
fields.body:
John Aldridge's five-year reign at Tranmere Rovers came to an end when he resigned after the 3-2 home defeat by Barnsley. Tranmere, who threw away a two-goal lead, remain bottom of the First Division and despite their FA Cup run, Aldridge decided the time was right to go. His assistant, Kevin Sheedy, will take charge for tomorrow's trip to Gillingham.

Preston moved up to fifth place after Sean Gregan's amazing winner at Norwich . The captain spotted Andy Marshall off his line and chipped the goalkeeper from almost 50 yards.

Huddersfield leapt above QPR after the two sides had contrasting home games. Lou Macari's Terriers beat play-off chasing Sheffield United 2-1, while Rangers were beaten 1-0 at home thanks to Paul Groves' winner for Grimsby . However, both sides remain in the bottom three.

Rotherham closed the gap on Millwall , who lost on Friday, to a single point at the summit of the Second Division after a 3-0 home victory against Bristol Rovers . Ronnie Moore's side can go top if they win their game in hand at Wycombe tomorrow night. Rovers remain in deep relegation trouble.

The play-off positions remain unaltered. Only Reading could manage victory, Martin Butler's two goals seeing off Wrexham. Lee Trundle's reply was his seventh goal in just five starts for the north Wales side.

At the bottom of the section, Oxford's clash with Luton was postponed, leaving only Swansea of the bottom four to gain. However, their 1-1 draw at Swindon , themselves just above the danger zone, still leaves the Welsh club 11 points from safety.

At the top of the Third Division, Chesterfield needed a late equaliser from Jon Howard to take a point from their game at Saltergate against Rochdale , for whom their record signing Paul Connor scored.

Cardiff moved second after beating Carlisle 4-1, with Jason Bowen scoring a hat-trick. Brighton have the same number of points as Sam Hammam's club and both are 10 ahead of fourth-placed Hartlepool , where the Seagulls drew 2-2 .

A 4-2 defeat at Cheltenham means Halifax stay 92nd in the league, with the Conference looming.

webTitle: Ndah's revenge strikes leave Megson fuming

fields.headline: Ndah's revenge strikes leave Megson fuming
fields.trailText: Dave Jones took a significant step in his wooing of Wolverhampton Wanderers supporters by masterminding victory in his first Black Country derby yesterday.
fields.body:
Dave Jones took a significant step in his wooing of Wolverhampton Wanderers supporters by masterminding victory in his first Black Country derby yesterday.

Wins for Wolves over their neighbours, and vice versa, are always sweet but this was sweeter than most. It was their first in eight attempts over their oldest and bitterest rivals and also represented a high spot in another season of underachievement.

Out of the play-off running but free from relegation worries, at least Wolves supporters have some consolation to cheer them until August, and with Joleon Lescott solid in defence and another teenager Adam Proudlock full of intelligent running up front, there is also plenty to anticipate. With a little more composure against an Albion defence that looks as stable as a henhouse in a hurricane, Proudlock could have capped a promising performance with a couple of goals.

Instead George Ndah made his mark in an act of direct retribution given that in his previous game against Albion he sustained a broken leg and had to sit out the next year. That injury followed an old-time challenge by Matt Carbon and Jones warned Ndah not to take the law into his own hands.

Ndah, heeding the advice, opted for a legitimate method of revenge and was rewarded with two goals and was named man of the match.

"He fully deserve it, and the rest of my players were not far behind," the Wolves manager confirmed. "They worked tremendously hard and this represented another stage in our rebuilding."

Jones's quite satisfaction came in stark contrast to the undisguised rage of his Albion counterpart, Gary Megson. "If anybody says I'm disappointed they would be badly wrong," he said. "I'm furious, and not one of my players can expect to be in the team next week.

"We were sadly lacking and it's a huge embarrassment to have brought 3,000 of our supporters here and performed like that. There was no verve, no zest, no passion and no desire. We are sixth in the table but looked as though we were at the bottom. It could have been eight."

It could well have been, and if Albion do reach the Premiership via the play-offs, Messrs Henry, Owen and Yorke will be licking their lips at thought of taking on such a flimsy defence.

Easy pickings will be on the menu as Ndah discovered in the 23th minute. Put clear at the left edge of the penalty area by Carl Robinson's through ball, the striker went past the Albion goalkeeper Russell Hoult before guiding the ball inside the far post between the retreating Carbon and Tony Butler.

Hoult did get a touch to prevent Wolves increasing their lead in the 36th minute when, diving to his right, he diverted Ludo Pollet's well-struck volley on to a post.

But he was left helpless when the game was put out of reach following two set-pieces. The first came in the dying seconds of the half when, after a short corner, Andy Sinton crossed from the right for Ndah to head home. Sinton was again the provider for the third, again from a corner. This time he delivered the ball long and Pollet headed home from distance.

Neil Clement volleyed home a consolation goal in the dying minutes, but it did nothing to assuage Megson's fury.

webTitle: Eriksson given Finnish warning as Kuqi strikes

fields.headline: Eriksson given Finnish warning as Kuqi strikes
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson is unlikely to have dispatched one of his many scouts to Edgeley Park for this game, but the England coach may now be scurrying through his files to read up on Stockport's match-winner Shefki Kuqi.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson is unlikely to have dispatched one of his many scouts to Edgeley Park for this game, but the England coach may now be scurrying through his files to read up on Stockport's match-winner Shefki Kuqi.

Kuqi, the Kosovo-born Finn who has been named in the Finland squad for Saturday's World Cup qualifier against England at Anfield, displayed a powerful aerial presence as he headed two stunning goals to secure Stockport's first League victory since New Year's Day.

The 24-year-old, a £150,000 purchase from FC Jokerit in January, has already been dubbed the Baltic Bomber by County followers.

Trevor Francis, the Birmingham manager, can certainly vouch for Kuqi's commanding presence in the air after witnessing two headed goals from the Finn that would have made Tommy Lawton proud.

Francis said: "Kuqi won the game for Stockport because of his prowess in the air. He showed an ability to pick up the flight of the ball much quicker than any of our defenders."

Bought as a replacement by the Stockport manager Andy Kilner for Ian Moore, sold to Burnley for £1m, Kuqi could become yet another Edgeley Park example of turning water into wine.

On four occasions this season, Kilner has been forced to sell his best players to balance the books. On each occasion, a sizeable profit has been made. Only last week, Kilner had to watch helplessly as midfielder Kevin Cooper was sold to Wimbledon for £1m.

To compound Kilner's problems, he was told by chairman Brendan Elwood on Friday morning to speak to the former Liverpool manager Roy Evans about a coaching role at the club.

The job offer was news to Kilner, who admitted that he had to telephone Evans to withdraw his chairman's offer.

Kilner said: "I have no qualms with Roy Evans, he is one of the most honest people I have ever spoken to.

"We just agreed that it wasn't right for him to come to Stockport. I'm sure he has plenty of knowledge that he could impart on me, but he's only a phone call away."

This victory, marred by a neck injury to the young Birmingham forward Andy Johnson, lifted Stockport out of the bottom three and allowed Kilner, one of the most genuine men in football, to celebrate a rare victory.

He also found time to warn Eriksson about the perils of underestimating the ability of Kuqi.

Kilner said: "I'm sure Shefki can give England a few problems. If he does come into the equation, I'm sure he'll do well. I've rarely seen a forward work as hard as he does.

"He's 6ft 3ins, strong, has great pace, is very good in the air and he is excellent at upsetting defences."

fields.headline: Burton fears for his diamonds
fields.trailText: Wimbledon have mined yet another diamond in the imposing shape of Patrick Agyemang but their manager Terry Burton is already worried he may lose his 20-year-old striker once the new transfer regulations are in place next season.
fields.body:
Wimbledon have mined yet another diamond in the imposing shape of Patrick Agyemang but their manager Terry Burton is already worried he may lose his 20-year-old striker once the new transfer regulations are in place next season.

Agyemang harried Blackburn from the start and Craig Short was glad to see the youngster go off five minutes from the end of a game the visitors might easily have won.

However, Burton fears he may be bringing players through only for other clubs to benefit, and described the transfer change as "frightening."

"It's a real concern for a club like ours. We don't want to be a showcase for other clubs to pick up players on the cheap," he said. "We need protection."

Agyemang is in a direct line of fearsome, fast front-men bred by Wimbledon over the years and his partnership with Jason Euell may yet lift the Londoners into the play-offs. Euell threatened Rovers with their second league defeat in 16 games when he ghosted in for his 18th goal of the season after 50 minutes. And only the home goalkeeper Brad Friedel prevented further damage to Blackburn's chances of an automatic promotion spot before Matt Jansen salvaged a point in the 73rd minute.

Graeme Souness had an explanation for Blackburn's distinctly off-key display: "I suspected it might happen. The [midweek] game at Birmingham drained a lot out of the players and for the first time this season they looked tired."

The manager criticised the FA for ordering his injured midfielder David Dunn to link up with the England party even though he has no chance of playing. "I'm angry about it," he said. "Don't they believe us?"

webTitle: Boa Morte answers his critics at the double

fields.headline: Boa Morte answers his critics at the double
fields.trailText: Fulham's footballing roadshow trundled across town to its latest stopping point, put on the usual slick exhibition and then packed up and headed for home with the feeling of a job well done.
fields.body:
Fulham's footballing roadshow trundled across town to its latest stopping point, put on the usual slick exhibition and then packed up and headed for home with the feeling of a job well done.

Thankfully for the rest of the First Division, the bandwagon will roll out of sight before next season, ending the envious glances and freeing up a promotion spot for the bottle neck of big boys trying to reach the big time.

In the end-of-season reckoning, the day the Cottagers stormed the Palace will scarcely be remembered by anyone other than Luis Boa Morte, who now starts a three-match ban for spitting in the face of Bolton's Robbie Elliott.

He spat in the face of his critics on Saturday, by twice rolling the ball past the Crystal Palace goalkeeper Aleksandrs Kolinko, after neat passes from John Collins and Steve Finnan, to garner three more points.

The Fulham midfielder Lee Clark swatted away the weekly question about complacency and proved that his claim - "we've just got to keep focused" - was not empty rhetoric by revealing the team would be spending the week off, because of the upcoming internationals, in the company of Marseille, Milan and Benfica at a friendly tournament in France.

Jean Tigana intends to hit the Premiership ground running, and his £4m defensive recruit Alain Goma, snapped up from Newcastle ahead of the transfer deadline but not named for this match, will play his part. "The manager just wanted to leave time for him to bed in," explained Clark.

Such schemes are luxuries for the Palace manager Alan Smith, who rushed in his £1.5m signing from Bradford, David Hopkin, for his second spell at the club, but though Palace pressed in the second half, there was a lack of conviction up front, until Simon Rodger hit the post in the last minute. It meant for the second time this season that Palace had lost six games in a row and are just two points above the drop zone.

It was Smith who jumped off Fulham's bandwagon last summer, leaving his job as academy director to replace Steve Coppell in the Palace hotseat. "I know what every Fulham player earns and the difference [between them and us] is ginormous," he said, conceding that this battle was never really part of the war against relegation. "John Collins and Lee Clark should not be playing in Division One and I think Sean Davis will play for England one day."

Charlton won the title with 91 points last year; Fulham already have 85 with nine games left. But there is no finishing tape in sight - this is only just the warm-up.

webTitle: Eriksson puts faith in red brigades

fields.headline: Eriksson puts faith in red brigades
fields.standfirst: Liverpool's Steven Gerrard is named in England squad but Kevin Phillips must bide his time
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson put his cards on the table last night and to no-one's great surprise has placed an abundance of faith in red suits. In other words the teams England's Swedish coach fields for the upcoming World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania will seek inspiration mainly from the hearts and diamonds of Manchester United and Liverpool.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson put his cards on the table last night and to no-one's great surprise has placed an abundance of faith in red suits. In other words the teams England's Swedish coach fields for the upcoming World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania will seek inspiration mainly from the hearts and diamonds of Manchester United and Liverpool.

Half of the 26-man squad Eriksson announced yesterday evening are from Old Trafford or Anfield and at least half-a-dozen players from the two clubs are likely to face Finland at Liverpool on Saturday.

For his first game as England coach, the 3-0 victory over Spain in a friendly at Villa Park a month ago, Eriksson used 18 players from an original squad of 31. In reducing the party by five for England's opening two qualifiers in foreign hands he has omitted, most notably, Sunderland's Kevin Phillips, who is still an outstanding finisher but has not repeated his prolific form of last season.

Ugo Ehiogu, the Middlesbrough centre-back who delighted his old Villa fans by scoring England's third goal against Spain, has also been left out along with Arsenal's Ray Parlour, one of those forced out of that game through injury. Gareth Southgate, now playing again for Aston Villa, has been ignored by Eriksson which bodes ill for his future international chances.

The team against Finland is likely to reflect the side that played the first half against Spain, after which Eriksson made seven changes. In all probability, therefore, Andy Cole will once more lead the attack with Michael Owen dropping off him, while Paul Scholes will operate in central midfield with David Beckham again used in his normal club position wide on the right.

There will, however, be two important differences. Neither Steven Gerrard nor Steve McManaman was fit for the Spain match but both will surely perform crucial roles as England seek the World Cup points to repair the damage of a poor start to their attempts to reach next year's tournament in Japan and South Korea.

Even now Gerrard's is a fragile talent. When Liverpool beat Porto 2-0 on Thursday in the Uefa Cup the power, speed and perception of this gifted 20-year-old midfielder recalled images of Alan Mullery. But Gerrard's muscular problems continue to make him a risk for two matches in four days and it was with reluctance that his manager, Gerard Houllier, brought him after 55 minutes as Liverpool sought salvation in yesterday's Premier League game against Derby.

"Steven has had some niggling injuries and he was not entirely fit," Houllier admitted. "If I had played him for the whole match he would probably not have been OK to join up with England."

Eriksson, then, now has to decide if Gerrard will be more use at Anfield on Saturday or in Tirana on Wednesday week. In all probability he will take the first option with Nicky Butt primed to take over against Albania.

McManaman, has recovered from the knock which forced him out of the Spain game and is in good form on the left flank for Real Madrid. With Nicky Barmby ruled out through injury McManaman is virtually certain to fill a similar role against Finland and Albania.

Beckham will, of course, keep the captaincy but with Gerrard and Scholes earmarked for midfield Eriksson is not going to rush into experimenting with Beckham in a more central role. In any case the Swede has already made it clear that he does not believe in using players out of their normal club positions.

Emile Heskey was an exception to this rule in the Spain game when he came on after half-time and operated on the right wing. The role, however, is not alien to the big Liverpool striker who often moves wide and impressed Kevin Keegan when he did so against Argentina at Wembley.

One of the most encouraging aspects of Eriksson's first squad for competitive games is that the younger bloods will feel their chance of World Cup experience is not far away. The West Ham midfield trio of Joe Cole, Michael Carrick and Frank Lampard are still there along with Wes Brown, Jamie Carragher and Ashley Cole.

Charlton's Chris Powell is no spring chicken but obviously impressed the England coach at Villa Park before he picked up a calf strain. With the inexperienced Ashley Cole the only other left-footed left-back in the squad - Michael Ball and Gareth Barry are in the England Under-21 party - Powell may well find himself an important part of England's World Cup aspirations; not bad for a 31-year-old who was once on loan to Aldershot.

Eriksson's choice in goal may be simplified by the news that David Seaman has suffered a recurrence of a back injury. David James started against Spain but it was Nigel Martyn who saved a penalty.

fields.headline: Larsson hat-trick clinches first trophy
fields.standfirst: Larsson  47, 74, 81
fields.trailText: One down, two to go. Finally, the treble predictions being said of Celtic are beginning to come true. With this CIS Insurance cup win over Kilmarnock, drawn-out phony war is beginning, at last, to be replaced by fact: prognostications - even uttered by opposition managers - are being supplanted by silverware.
fields.body:
One down, two to go. Finally, the treble predictions being said of Celtic are beginning to come true. With this CIS Insurance cup win over Kilmarnock, drawn-out phony war is beginning, at last, to be replaced by fact: prognostications - even uttered by opposition managers - are being supplanted by silverware.

In a season that has held such promise - with the Scottish Premier League title almost assured and a Tennents Scottish Cup semi-final in the offing - the architect of this win had to be the Swede, Henrik Larsson, his hat-trick taking his personal tally for the season to 47 goals.

So central has Larsson been to what is shaping up to be an unstoppable march to all the domestic honours, to have had anyone else's name on the scoresheet would have bordered on sacrilege. Not that Chris Sutton, his strike partner, had much opportunity to challenge Larsson for a place among the goals.

By his own standards, Sutton kept his own counsel when the victim of Kilmarnock's physical game plan, but it seemed to make little impression on the referee Hugh Dallas who, at the first sign of Sutton losing patience, brandished a red card.

Kilmarnock began with a general policy of heavy man-marking and a seemingly specific intention to get Bobby Petta.

With Celtic's starting options reduced by the absence of Didier Agathe, Robert Douglas, Alan Thompson, Jackie McNamara and Stilian Petrov (the first pair cup-tied, the second pair suspended and Petrov injured), Petta was about all Celtic had to maintain their predilection for wide play.

But a heavy challenge within seconds of the whistle by Gus MacPherson, followed by a second clatter on him shortly after by Alan Mahood, suggested a deliberate ploy by the underdogs.

Impossible as it was to assess what the loss of Petta in the 12th minute through injury meant for Celtic, the departure of Ian Durrant for Kilmarnock in the 38th was all too evident. With Celtic successfully shackled at that point Durrant had assumed a magisterial pose in midfield, strutting the stage with an assurance that belied the fact he was returning from a four-month lay-off because of a knee injury.

With his departure went Kilmarnock's best hope of confounding the formality most had anticipated before kick-off. "I was feeling great," he said. "My foot slipped and the knee just gave way. I heard a wee crack and that was it." His manager Bobby Williamson was to the point: "Once he went off, we were struggling. We never cut Celtic open."

For all their concentration in the first half, Kilmarnock undid their good work at the start of the second when Lubomir Moravcik's corner was won in the air by a combination of Sutton and Ramon Vega for Larsson to volley at close quarters just two minutes after the resumption.

And then came Sutton's sending-off, for a rash challenge on Gary Holt. While Dallas had previously indulged some hefty aerial assaults by Kilmarnock's Chris Innes, he was less sanguine towards Sutton. "It was a bit hard," said Celtic's manager Martin O'Neill. "A yellow card perhaps. I've seen it since and I'm disinclined to change my mind."

An exchange of two questionable offside decisions - to deny Kilmarnock's Christophe Cocard and Celtic's Larsson - helped bring the first half to a goalless conclusion, plus a decision favouring Garry Hay when he robbed Larsson of the ball in the Kilmarnock box with a risky challenge from the side.

O'Neill believed his side's mental strength came to the fore following Sutton's dismissal and the evidence was delivered with two goals in seven minutes, the first again showing Kilmarnock's weakness on the left, Larsson's shot taking a huge deflection off Innes. The coup de grace was both energetic and delicate, Larsson running half the pitch with the ball before dragging Marshall out of position deliciously before finishing.

fields.headline: 'Wounded' Bolton come back fighting
fields.trailText: Reports of Bolton's demise appear to have been greatly exaggerated. Poor form of late, culminating in the haphazard 3-3 home draw against Gillingham nine days ago, provoked many to write off their chances of winning the race for the second automatic promotion place. But their detractors were answered in style on Saturday with an impressive win against Nottingham Forest, whose play-off hopes waned.
fields.byline: Christopher Stocks at the City Ground
fields.body:
Reports of Bolton's demise appear to have been greatly exaggerated. Poor form of late, culminating in the haphazard 3-3 home draw against Gillingham nine days ago, provoked many to write off their chances of winning the race for the second automatic promotion place. But their detractors were answered in style on Saturday with an impressive win against Nottingham Forest, whose play-off hopes waned.

Second-half goals from Dean Holdsworth and Gareth Farrelly brought the visitors their first win in seven games and their first success at the City Ground for 25 years. And with Blackburn and Birmingham, their main rivals for that all-important runners-up spot behind Fulham, both dropping points at the weekend, Bolton breathed new life into their promotion challenge.

Holdsworth, who claimed his 200th career goal when stabbing in a Ricardo Gardner centre after a brilliant run by the Jamaica international, said that the criticism in recent weeks had been a major motivating force.

"We came out today like a wounded animal. We've been wounded by the criticism and have come back fighting for our lives because we badly want to be in the Premier League," he said.

The former Wimbledon striker had a defiant message for rival clubs: "They don't know what beasts we are. We're going to be all right. There's a good spirit within the team and we'll always bounce back. We've got the make-up and the quality to go up."

As for Forest, Farrelly's superb injury-time chip over Dave Beasant, which sealed the points for Bolton, condemned David Platt's side to their second successive defeat and severely dented their play-off ambitions.

Platt questioned the mental attitude of the Forest players after a poor display and lamented: "Maybe one or two players are too sure of their place in the team, which can't be good. It's difficult because we have injuries and suspensions but we can't bring anyone in. We need to get people out."

With news that the new England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson is sounding out Platt as the next England Under-21 manager, what price the latest managerial merry-go-round stopping some time soon on the banks of the River Trent?

webTitle: Zenith of a mania, when even judges had to reckon with Gazza

fields.headline: Zenith of a mania, when even judges had to reckon with Gazza
fields.trailText: It is difficult to believe it is all of 10 years ago that England was in thrall to a diverting cultural phenomenon. They called it "Gazzamania".
fields.body:
It is difficult to believe it is all of 10 years ago that England was in thrall to a diverting cultural phenomenon. They called it "Gazzamania". A nine-month frenzy reached its high-water mark in the spring of 1991 when the exuberant appeal of the gifted and tautly-strung 23-year old international inside-forward Paul Gascoigne engaged the nation as he inspired his club, Tottenham Hotspur, to reach the FA Cup final with a series of bespoke and spectacular passages.

In the fifth and sixth rounds, against Portsmouth and Notts County, Gascoigne had injected desultory Tottenham performances with thrilling personal interventions. He turned the semi-final against Arsenal at Wembley at once with an audacious free-kick from 35 yards, his sixth goal in Tottenham's five matches of the competition. The Spurs manager Terry Venables called it "the finest free-kick in the Cup's history".

Certainly the bravura stroke intensified the aura around the young player, although Tommy Docherty warned: "The poor boy is a talented enough footballer, sure, but he is in mighty danger of becoming nothing more than the fairy on top of the Christmas tree."

The summer before, at the World Cup finals in Italy, Gascoigne's public tears had announced him to those not in the least bit moved by his footballing talents. The young man from Tyneside was taken up at once as a national figure. In no time his wax model was a main attraction at Madame Tussaud's. One of Mrs Thatcher's last Downing Street photo-calls had her being hugged by Gascoigne ("she was nice and warm and cuddly-like").

He switched on the Christmas lights in London's Regent Street. He was voted overwhelming winner of the BBC Sports Personality of the Year. When Lazio offered £8m for him - which helped bail out his debt-ridden club - the MP Dennis Skinner pointed out in the House of Commons that Gascoigne's worth was £2m more than Britain's total aid to Bangladesh.

On his television show, Terry Wogan introduced Gascoigne as "literally the most famous and probably the most popular man in Britain today". When the high street jeweller Gerald Ratner was desperate to atone for calling his own products "crap", he hired Gascoigne to appear in advertisements insisting, "It's world-class stuff, man." In the first week of the Gulf War, the Sun cleared its front page for the boldest of headlines: GAZZA & FIANCEE SPLIT UP.

When Arsenal that spring paraded the League Championship trophy to Islington Town Hall, every speech from the balcony was drowned by the throng chanting: "Gazza is a knobhead." Gascoigne recorded Fog on the Tyne, which reached the top 10.

In the High Court that winter, Gascoigne sued Penguin Books for publishing an "unauthorised biography". His counsel Michael Silverleaf began: "Mr Gascoigne is a very well-known footballer," at which Mr Justice Harman interjected (to laughter, as they say): "Rugby or Association?" Later, during evidence, the judge again interrupted: "Isn't there an operetta called La Gazza Ladra?" "I could not say, my lord," replied Silverleaf.

When Judge Harman asked, "Do you think Mr Gascoigne is more famous now than the Duke of Wellington was in 1815?" Silverleaf replied: "I have to say I think it possible." Reporters reckoned this revelation turned the case in Penguin's favour.

Acres of newsprint were devoted to the footballer. The highbrow reviews waded in. Salman Rushdie soared to ridiculous, exclamation-mark heights in the Independent magazine. Granta published a Gazza treatise running to thousands of overblown words. In the London Review of Books, editor Karl Miller saw Gascoigne as "fierce and comic, formidable and vulnerable, orphan-like, waif-like... tense and upright, a priapic monolith". Poet Ian Hamilton noted the player's "odd elfin humours, an over-eager version of Lear's Fool". The opera and film director Franco Zeffirelli wrote how enchanted he was "when Gazza smells the referee's armpits".

The voluptuous free-kick in the semi-final at Wembley, wrote Colin Gibson in the Daily Telegraph, "flashed 35 yards past the ruin of Arsenal's defensive wall and David Seaman could only help it into the roof of the net. Thereafter Gascoigne remained drunk on the euphoria of the moment, wanting to collect every free-kick, collect every ball from the goalkeeper, and run at every defender".

Back at Wembley for the final, Gascoigne lasted less than 15 minutes, severely injuring himself in the second of two crazily uncontrolled, adrenalin-charged fouls. "Gazzamania" changed tack. A vintage, ruinous Rake's Progress took shape. In the next 10 years, injury and unsavoury exposure taking equal turn, Gascoigne played with ever diminishing grandeur for Lazio, Rangers and Middlesbrough.

This month, as Tottenham prepare to play Arsenal in another FA Cup semi-final, Gascoigne returned after injury for 19 minutes as a substitute for Everton against Newcastle. It was reported that the 33-year-old meaningfully touched the ball but once.

fields.headline: Splashing out
fields.standfirst: True to his promise of last week, Sam goes white water rafting on the Zambezi - and ends up spending far more time in the water than he does in the raft
fields.trailText: Week 16, Victoria Falls to Livingstone True to his promise of last week, Sam goes white water rafting on the Zambezi - and ends up spending far more time in the water than he does in the raft
fields.body:
Opening my eyes I found myself struggling underwater. I kicked for the surface but my head banged against something soft. Looking up I could see what looked like rows of yellow tubes - I realised that I was under the inflatable raft. I pushed myself sideways and came up spluttering. Someone grabbed my lifejacket and hauled me back into the raft just as we smashed into another wave.

This was my introduction to white water rafting on the Zambezi.

We had put in at rapid number 11, just below Victoria Falls. The river was at full flood and the high water meant the upstream rapids were too dangerous: if you went overboard there, you might get sucked into a whirlpool. In fact, there were only a few days left before they were going to have to close the river for the season.

I was in a raft with four Dutch guys and our guide. Tamiba was a huge, powerful lad who steered at the back using two long oars. We paddled down the first few rapids smoothly enough and I was beginning to think it was quite easy - when my world turned upside down.

Shooting over rapid 16 we hit a wall of water. One of the Dutchmen was plucked out. All we could do was hang on for dear life. The raft was flipped up on its end and I went flying through the air. Bodies barrelled into me, and that's when I found myself underwater and under the raft.

Safely back inside and with a bellyful of the Zambezi, I realized we had lost half the crew. The guy who fell out first was miles away clinging onto one of the rescue canoes that paddled with us. After picking him and the others up, we headed off again.

I went in twice more before we reached the shore and started the long climb out of the gorge. Despite all the safety precautions, I really did feel I had put my life in danger. It was an immensely exhilarating experience, but not one I'll be quick to repeat.

The town of Victoria Falls is pretty commercial. It's a bit like an African version of New Zealand's Queenstown: lots of operators offering all sorts of adrenalin activities. The only difference is that you are constantly hassled by money changers, curio sellers and drug dealers. The fact that there are very few tourists in Zimbabwe at the moment means I get these guys' undivided attention. And boy, are they persistent.

In Bulawayo I had perfected a response of "No thank you, my friend," said in my deepest, most authoritative voice. This was supposed to indicate that I was an experienced traveller who was not to be messed, with and that in my case, "no" meant no.

It didn't wash with this lot. As far as they were concerned, "no" meant "If I wave my wooden mask/animal/stick in your face and shout at you for long enough, then maybe you'll buy it."

So I crossed the river and the border and travelled to Livingstone in Zambia for a few days. Everyone calls Zambia the real Africa, and Livingstone was much more like a normal working community. The wide streets were full of people milling about, everyone seemed friendly, and lots of people smiled and said hello to me.

Reading the local newspaper (more of a monthly parish newsletter), I discovered that there had been a cholera outbreak here three weeks back. I also noted that Mr Mugati had been fined for slaughtering his goat in the street rather than in his shop.

There were a lot more backpackers here, and the hostel I stayed in was almost full. People are obviously avoiding Zimbabwe and travelling up and down Africa through Zambia instead.

I wandered around the National Museum, which had some interesting David Livingstone memorabilia, including his first-aid kit and some of his letters home. I also went on a game drive round the local park. This wasn't exactly a wilderness experience, as it was only a few miles from town, but I did see white rhino, zebra and warthogs. We were taken round by Don, an ancient English hippy who had bought a truck in Portugal and driven down through Africa in the seventies.

Don certainly knew how to find the wildlife, but it was his driving I was more worried about. Stopping ten metres from a grazing rhino, he asked us to shout out if it charged the landrover. "Now where's reverse on this thing," he said.

I had planned on travelling overland from Zimbabwe up through Mozambique to Malawi. However, I was told that the recent terrible flooding in Mozambique had washed away the bridges and the buses weren't running. Obviously I was sorry for the poor people who were stuck in the middle of this disaster, but on a more selfish level this was a bit of a blow as it meant I would have to fly from Harare at great expense. Then, after buying the ticket, I kicked myself when I realized I could have gone overland through Zambia for about half the price.

Mind you, it's probably just as well I didn't since, if I had, you wouldn't be reading this. When I was there, the email service was down across the whole country. Someone had rung up to find out what was wrong, and had been told that the satellite was broken and it would take a couple of weeks to fix. I had a vision of pot-smoking Zambian spacemen staring at the satellite and shaking their heads sorrowfully.

See you by the shores of Lake Malawi.

fields.headline: Lord Falconer
fields.standfirst: Lord Falconer of Thoroton (life peer cr. 1997)
fields.trailText: Well fed, middle aged and prosperous, Lord Falconer is the sort of chap prime ministers love to have nearby, particularly when there are hot potatoes such as the Millennium Dome to hand out. A clever fixer without ambitions in the House of Commons, he has known Tony Blair for years and shares much of his background. But he can still be a pompous twerp.
fields.body:
Well fed, middle aged and prosperous, Lord Falconer is the sort of chap prime ministers love to have nearby, particularly when there are hot potatoes such as the Millennium Dome to hand out. A clever fixer without ambitions in the House of Commons, he has known Tony Blair for years and shares much of his background. But he can still be a pompous twerp.

On the day in 1998 that he inherited responsibility for the dome from Peter Mandelson, he reportedly told a friend how thrilled he was with his new responsibility. "But Charlie," his university chum is said to have protested. "You're a barrister - you've never run anything in your life!" "Not true," retorted Lord Falconer. "I organised the May Ball at Cambridge!" "Yes, and you forgot to book the band," his friend shot back.

This friend presumably smirked in November 2000 when the national audit office complained that Lord Falconer had apparently misled parliament by claiming that the dome was solvent when it was effectively bankrupt. Jennie Page, the dome's first chief executive, had tried to alert him to the danger.

Less well connected ministers might have fallen from office over this debacle - and the papers called for him to go - but instead the prime minister defended his friend. He will probably have to do so again: the poisoned chalice of the dome continues to make him an easy target for an otherwise impotent Tory opposition.

Like Tony Blair, Charles Falconer was born into an Edinburgh legal family. The two met while Charles was at Glenalmond school and the future prime minister was attending Fettes college. Their friendship started poorly because he pinched young Tony's girlfriend, Amanda Mackenzie-Stuart. They met again as young barristers in London, and Mr Blair moved into his house in Wandsworth. The two families later intertwined as Islington neighbours.

While Mr Blair went into politics, Mr Falconer remained in the law, earning large sums while retaining his moderate Labour sympathies and an enthusiasm for pop music.

As New Labour developed, Charles Falconer's political appetite sharpened. Before the 1997 election Blair tried to shoehorn him into a safe Labour seat, Dudley West. Mr Falconer would have sacrificed almost half a million pounds in annual income to become an MP, but he was rejected for the shortlist, partly for refusing to take his children out of private schools.

The Labour leader's alternative was to elevate his able and articulate friend to a life peerage. After the 1997 election victory, Charles Falconer served as solicitor general, and became minister of state in the Cabinet Office when Peter Mandelson was forced to resign over his home loan in 1998. He was placed on 14, then 18, cabinet committees - both for his legal eagle efficiency and to serve as the eyes and ears of the PM.

Until the dome fiasco, some thought he was likely to follow Lord Irvine as Lord Chancellor. Now that looks unlikely, but as a member of the upper house he will remain at hand to serve the prime minister for as long as his old friend at Number 10 wants.
