webTitle: Double room with fries: John Crace stays in the first McHotel.

fields.headline: Double room with fries
fields.standfirst: There's a huge McDonald's M above the beds. And you can't get room service. But  John Crace, in Zurich, finds the first McHotel surprisingly tasteful . . . until he fancies something to eat
fields.trailText: There's a huge McDonald's M above the beds. And you can't get room service. But John Crace, in Zurich, finds the first McHotel surprisingly tasteful . . . until he fancies something to eat.
fields.body:
Drive towards Ramlüng along the perimeter fence of Zurich airport and the first thing you notice is the bright yellow neon M burning through the grey mist. Chicago, Paris, Delhi, Streatham High Road - the logo is instantly recognisable throughout the world. But as you get nearer, it becomes apparent that the iconography is not all it seems. Along with several more giant Ms and a general smearing of yellow and red, there are a number of truncated Ms that turn out to be rather more tastefully sized Hs. Also in yellow.

The Golden Arch is the world's first McDonald's hotel. Profits have been flat in the fast-food burger business, so brand diversification is hardly unexpected. What is surprising is the way it came about. Zurich was not chosen as the result of a massive global focus group or boardroom horse-trading, but on one man's whim. Urs Hammer, McDonald's 52-year-old multi-millionaire chairman and CEO in Switzerland, is a hotelier and architect manqué, and the Golden Arch is his brainchild. When he first suggested the idea three years ago to Jim Skinner, McDonald's European supremo, he was told to "stick to hamburgers".

But he didn't. In two weeks' time, Hammer opens his second hotel in Lully, and has plans for a third in Geneva. Meanwhile, the rest of the corporation holds its breath to see whether the McHotel will bankroll the business for the next few decades or turn out be an expensive midlife crisis.

The McDonald's yellows and reds dominate the lobby and bar area, and much of the furniture has been designed to reflect the company logo. But where the burger bars are all plastic, the hotel is maple and leather, with feng shui waterfalls and scattered rose petals. And that's not the only difference. When I go to check in, the woman behind the counter asks, "Can I help?" in a voice that sounds uncannily as if she means it.

Not that you need to check in, mind. Along with its determinedly modernist design, the hotel is equipped with all the latest hi-tech gadgets, which allow you to check in and out with the swipe of a credit card, and surf the net and pick up email from the TV. At least you can if you are able to operate the controls. The same goes for the light switches, which work with a smart card. Or idiot card, perhaps as it takes several minutes of scrabbling around in the dark to locate the holder. Even the beds, which cost £3,500 apiece, are interactive. They are fashionably low-slung, and can be moved around so that you can lie down with your feet or head in the air. Or both.

Once you can see, it's clear the room is not your conventional hotel box. Two items dominate: an M-shaped headboard and a mauve satin sash with the ubiquitous yellow H laid across the bed. Which is a pity, because if neither were there you could quite forget you were in McDonald's.

The sleeping area has a hardwood floor, while the washing area contains the nearest you get to traditional McDonald's values with a not-unattractive green Styrofoam floor covering. Or rather, I assumed it was Styrofoam, but was later politely informed that it was state-of-the-art anti-bacterial non-slip tiling. By the way, the words sleeping and washing areas are used advisedly as there are no separate rooms; the circular power shower - the hot water is generated by heat given off from the restaurant chip pans - is discreetly boxed into one corner of the bedroom. Or possibly it's the other way round.

To complete the image overhaul, there is no sign over the hot tap warning you that hot water might come out of it and nor are the walls coated in migraine-inducing primary colours. It's all surprisingly tasteful and unpretentious.

Inevitably, there is a downside, and at the Golden Arch it comes when you want to eat. Room service is off the menu, so your options are the Aroma coffee shop (one of McDonald's recent more upmarket acquisitions, along with its 33% stake in Pret a Manger) which will do, at a push, for breakfast, and - you've guessed it - a McDonald's.

As McDonald's go, the one at the Golden Arch is better than most. Although there's the airport on one side, there are open fields on another where the cows keep an understandably nervous eye on proceedings, and the food offers better possibilities than any British Mickey D. There are even bagels and croissants for breakfast. But, whichever way you cut it, it's still a McDonald's. So why does a man who has just spent more than £12m building this slick hotel go out of his way to remind his punters at every turn of its downmarket associations?

"We argued at length about how closely the two operations should be combined," Hammer admits. "Some felt we should have a more upmarket restaurant but I felt very strongly that we should make use of the branding that wins us 45m customers a day worldwide."

Even though he never undertook any market research before embarking on the project, Hammer is confident he will be proved right. "Before we opened last week, an American family from Fort Worth turned up out of the blue. The son had spotted the hotel and said to his father, "Look, a McDonald's hotel. Let's stay there."

Hammer goes on to say that bookings for the 211-room hotel are on target, and that 15% of guests will be flying in specially from Asia to stay there. The hotel's main target market, though, is business - hence the nine conference rooms in the basement; but whether business men and women reckon that staying in a hotel whose primary symbol is an annoying oversized clown will send the right messages to their clients, must be open to question.

"We only charge 174SF (roughly £75) per night," Hammer continues. "Other comparable four-star hotels charge between 200SF and 300SF so we expect to win business on price."

The Swiss appear to enjoy a healthy love affair with McDonald's. The country's 7m inhabitants make a combined total of 85m visits per year, and it's hard to find anyone who has a word to say against the place. Even though the hotel had yet to open, the taxi driver knew exactly where it was and what the room rates were; Petra, a Ramlüng local, said she was looking forward to staying there. Even the new Mogadon jingle for the hotel is performed by Switzerland's answer to Celine Dion and gets played on national TV and radio. Don't be surprised to hear it at the next Eurovision Song contest.

Much as one might long for any new McDonald's venture to go belly up, it's hard to maintain too much malevolence, as the hotel so clearly tries to embody values - notably good taste - that are lacking elsewhere in its operations. If a similar range of mid-price hotels were to open - with or without the restaurants - in the UK, the share price of Travelodge et al would tumble. Unless it was a Pizza Hutel.

A recent US book, Fast Food Nation, accuses McDonald's, among others, of turning America into a graveyard of obesity and rural poverty. If the burger giant is doing the same in Switzerland, the least that can be said is that it's doing it in style.

fields.headline: Digging, but no grave
fields.standfirst: Investigative reporting is an essential skill, and a thrilling one, says  Nick Davies  - and despite what you may have heard, it's very much alive
fields.trailText: Investigative reporting is an essential skill, and a thrilling one, says Nick Davies - and despite what you may have heard, it's very much alive
fields.body:
When a group of veteran journalists gathered one weekend last year to teach the skills of investigative reporting to a group of working journalists and students, there was an air of excitement. For all that, the event had the whiff of the cemetery about it, because we were enthusiastically embracing a craft that is widely thought to be dead. It may be thrillingly satisfying for those involved, essential in a modern democracy and the finest form of reporting, but it has been suffocated by outrageous legal restraints and by the creeping commercialisation of the media.

On the face of it, the year since that first course has seen few signs of life for investigative reporters. Peter Mandelson might look like Fleet Street's scalp but, in truth, he was brought down by the eagle-eyed Lib Dem Norman Baker. The reporting was embarrassingly weak: we still don't know what Mandelson did to deserve to lose his job; nor do we know the wider truth about contacts between the government and the Hindujas.

In the same way, we still don't know - as random examples - why George W Bush really bombed Iraq last month (military necessity or post-electoral politics?); why the last commissioner of the Metropolitan Police suddenly became so alarmed about corruption in his ranks; what the prime minister says to the Queen when they meet; or what civil servants say to their ministers. We do finally know what the former chief inspector of schools thought about the education secretary - but only because the chief inspector turned reporter and told us himself. We still suffer from the Official Secrets Act, absurd libel laws, the culture of secrecy in government and the failure to introduce a decent Freedom of Information Act; and it looks as though we are about to suffer a new privacy law, created by unelected judges at the behest of unedifying celebrities.

For all that, the art of investigative reporting is hanging on to life. The greatest single lesson of last year's course at the University of Sussex was the scale of enthusiasm that survives for the idea of the reporter as troublemaker. Within a fortnight of the course being announced, about 500 people had applied for the 200 tickets - from as far as Shetland, Dublin and Hong Kong, all of them would-be journalists or working journalists wanting to break free and use their job to make a difference. One rising star threatened to sell her kidney to get a place on the course. At the end of the final day, two TV presenters confided that they were going to resign to become "real reporters", and even some of the veterans confessed that they had learned from each other.

So this year, we're doing it again, this time at the University of Sheffield, and we're giving away 50 places to students through a national contest (see below for details).

If the course works, it does so partly because the teachers inspire. Paul Foot did so last year. Phillip Knightley is likely to this year. He is the only print journalist to win the award of Journalist of the Year twice, with an extraordinary track record through some of the most devastating scandals of the past 30 years - the Philby affair, thalidomide, Profumo, the whole long season of classics from the old Sunday Times Insight team.

The course should work, too, as a disclosure of technique - the daily nuts and bolts of investigation. So, Don Hale, currently Journalist of the Year, is going to relive the old-fashioned, door-stepping, clue-sifting detective work that - despite death threats and judicial lethargy - led to his securing the release of Stephen Downing after 27 years of wrongful imprisonment. A lot of this work involves side-stepping legal obstacles, and we'll look specifically at the Official Secrets Act from the point of view both of the reporter and the whistleblower: Mark Hollingsworth, who broke the story of MI5 officer David Shayler will share a platform with Shayler himself (unless someone in heavy boots is stupid enough to stop him).

John Troup, who ran the Bruce Grobbelaar match-fixing story for the Sun, will talk about covert filming and his seven-year libel marathon. I'll talk at alarming length about first principles and techniques, and there will be sessions on the internet and on the use of public records to expose corruption. And, with luck, at the end of the weekend, several hundred investigative reporters will emerge, alive and looking for trouble.

 The course is being held at the University of Sheffield on June 16 and 17. Tickets are £200 for the weekend. Fifty students can win free tickets by sending a proposal for a real story - no more than 400 words, including an outline of the story and how it could be researched. Include a photocopy of a student card, or similar evidence of enrolment. Deadline: April 16. Contact: 01273 205590, or email: info@reporterscourse.co.uk

webTitle: Private health care: the issue explained

fields.headline: Private health care: the issue explained
fields.trailText: Despite the government's ongoing commitment to increase investment in the NHS, the private and independent health care market is buoyant. It is estimated to provide about £15bn in health services.
fields.body:
Despite the government's ongoing commitment to increase investment in the NHS, the private and independent health care market is buoyant. It is estimated to provide about £15bn in health services.

In some areas, the private or independent sector is dominant. For example, it provides the bulk of residential provision for elderly and physically disabled people. With some 70 independent mental health hospitals, more than half the health service's medium-secure places for seriously mentally ill are now provided independently. But, even in the acute or hospital-based health care market, the private sector is surprisingly active.

There are about 230 independent hospitals, with more than half of them run by the three main providers - General Healthcare Group, Bupa and Nuffield Hospitals. The UK's private sector performs about 20% of all non-urgent surgery, although, in some areas, it has a particularly prominent role. One-third of all hip replacements and almost half all abortions are done in the independent sector. The dividing line between public and private health care is made even less distinct by the presence of about 3,000 "pay beds" in the NHS, about half of which are in dedicated private patient units.

Funding comes mainly from private medical insurance, which accounts for 70% of the market. A further 20% comes from direct payments by patients and about 5% is from treatment funded by the NHS.

Despite the rhetoric, health policies from both Labour and the Conservatives rely on a mix of public and private sector provision.

Labour's high profile concordat with the private sector last year was a symbolic end to half a century's worth of hostility between the party and private hospitals. Although there are still concerns that a major expansion of the private health market would mean a contraction of the public sector (as, to a large extent, both sectors rely on the same pool of staff), the government is happy to see increases at the margins.

In particular, the government sees a role for private hospitals in easing the traditional NHS problems with capacity during the winter, and in reducing waiting times and lists. Private hospitals are able to help, often at short notice, because they typically run at occupancy levels of between 50% and 60%; this is compared to the NHS, where beds are in almost constant use.

Private providers - which were already performing about 40,000 procedures a year for the NHS - have reported a three-or four-fold increase in NHS-funded activity since the concordat was signed.

However, as part of the proposed new consultants' contract, the government is also committed to banning new consultants from private work for seven years. How this fits in with plans to enhance public-private partnership is unclear. And Labour remains opposed to offering tax inducements for private medical insurance.

The Tories, on the other hand, are keen to see the private sector expand both by pushing the NHS to buy even more care privately and by encouraging a greater take-up of private health insurance.

Total spending on health care in many other European countries is higher than the UK, largely thanks to higher levels of private care. Labour ended tax relief on private medical insurance when it came to power, but the Tories are now proposing a £500m package of tax breaks for firms and individuals buying health insurance if it wins the general election.

It is estimated to provide about £15bn in health services. In some areas, the private or independent sector is dominant. For example, it provides the bulk of residential provision for elderly and physically disabled people. With some 70 independent mental health hospitals, more than half the health service's medium-secure places for seriously mentally ill are now provided independently. But, even in the acute or hospital-based health care market, the private sector is surprisingly active. There are about 230 independent hospitals, with more than half of them run by the three main providers - General Healthcare Group, Bupa and Nuffield Hospitals. The UK's private sector performs about 20% of all non-urgent surgery, although, in some areas, it has a particularly prominent role. One-third of all hip replacements and almost half all abortions are done in the independent sector. The dividing line between public and private health care is made even less distinct by the presence of about 3,000 "pay beds" in the NHS, about half of which are in dedicated private patient units. Funding comes mainly from private medical insurance, which accounts for 70% of the market. A further 20% comes from direct payments by patients and about 5% is from treatment funded by the NHS. Despite the rhetoric, health policies from both Labour and the Conservatives rely on a mix of public and private sector provision. Labour's high profile concordat with the private sector last year was a symbolic end to half a century's worth of hostility between the party and private hospitals. Although there are still concerns that a major expansion of the private health market would mean a contraction of the public sector (as, to a large extent, both sectors rely on the same pool of staff), the government is happy to see increases at the margins. In particular, the government sees a role for private hospitals in easing the traditional NHS problems with capacity during the winter, and in reducing waiting times and lists. Private hospitals are able to help, often at short notice, because they typically run at occupancy levels of between 50% and 60%; this is compared to the NHS, where beds are in almost constant use. Private providers - which were already performing about 40,000 procedures a year for the NHS - have reported a three-or four-fold increase in NHS-funded activity since the concordat was signed. However, as part of the proposed new consultants' contract, the government is also committed to banning new consultants from private work for seven years. How this fits in with plans to enhance public-private partnership is unclear. And Labour remains opposed to offering tax inducements for private medical insurance. The Tories, on the other hand, are keen to see the private sector expand both by pushing the NHS to buy even more care privately and by encouraging a greater take-up of private health insurance. Total spending on health care in many other European countries is higher than the UK, largely thanks to higher levels of private care. Labour ended tax relief on private medical insurance when it came to power, but the Tories are now proposing a £500m package of tax breaks for firms and individuals buying health insurance if it wins the general election.

fields.headline: Eriksson plays down injury fears
fields.trailText: England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson this morning reported a clean bill of health as he continued the build-up to Saturday's World Cup qualifier with Finland at Anfield.
fields.body:
England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson this morning reported a clean bill of health as he continued the build-up to Saturday's World Cup qualifier with Finland at Anfield.

David Seaman and Steven Gerrard are Eriksson's only real concerns, with the coach having spoken to the Arsenal goalkeeper as well as his manager Arsene Wenger yesterday about his back injury.

"I talked to Wenger yesterday and his physio, and also to David," he explained. "He has a back problem, but we have to decided to pick him (in the squad) anyhow. I don't know if he will be fit for the game."

Liverpool midfielder Gerrard, who has been forced to withdraw from international duty on several occasions, will not take part in tomorrow's first training session. But Eriksson remains optimistic the youngster will feature against the Finns at his home ground.

"I saw him play last Thursday, and he seemed very fit - extremely fit and he played a marvellous game. I know he has some problems; he will be in late tomorrow. I agreed with him and his manager Gerard Houllier that he will take special treatment which he's been doing some weeks. But he will miss first practice."

Eriksson also confirmed Beckham will retain the captain's armband despite the Manchester United midfielder's recent absence from the first team. "If (Sir Alex) Ferguson feels it is right for him to rest I am pleased it has happened because it must be important for him," he said.

"I don't think he has been below par. David did very well against Spain, and I am sure he will on Saturday. He will still be my captain because I can't see any reason to change it. I spoke to him after the Spain game and got him to sign a shirt for my daughter but I have not spoken to him since that."

webTitle: Leader: Lib Dems need to rally voter support

fields.headline: Being nice is not enough
fields.standfirst:
Lib Dems need to rally voter support

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats did well in the 1997 election. This time, their new young leader assures them, they are going to do even better.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats did well in the 1997 election. This time, their new young leader assures them, they are going to do even better. True, in 1997 the party's share of the vote was down on 1992; but that had a lot to do with Lib Dems voting tactically to get the Tories out. And that same phenomenon worked hugely to their advantage in the seats they were best placed to win. Tactical support from people who elsewhere would have voted Labour helped give them 46 seats against a mere 18 before.

But what makes Mr Kennedy think their share of the vote is destined to rise this time? In part, it is his own popularity. He is a recognisable human being, good for a chat and a joke, not some stuck-up guy in a suit. He is not a thumper of tubs. It is probably to his advantage that at prime minister's question time, the one bit of the parliamentary battle which most voters see, he is not part of the Punch and Judy double act, but rather the sceptical fellow who comes on at the end and says something sardonic. But to make any great national impact, a third party leader has to do more than just come across as inherently decent and likable. It also requires the power to articulate what the third party stands for, what there is about it which ought to make the electorate reconsider old loyalties and swing behind it.

Charles Kennedy, in his tenancy of his office so far, has barely begun to do that. And it is doubtful if the shop window of his party's spring conference in Torquay this weekend will make very much difference to that. The familiar Lib Dem themes were there: a higher rate of tax for the most prosperous (something Labour now ducks); a firm and enthusiastic commitment to Europe; an electoral system which more fairly reflects the way the nation votes. But he hardly made them sing. His performance was perfunctory. He does not, as Paddy Ashdown did after a very uneasy start, give the impression of being in the thick of the action, finding out for himself, picking up issues the other parties neglect - as Mr Ashdown did with the Balkans or, even more tellingly, with the future agenda for the British centre-left.

That issue is admittedly rather more difficult for him than it was for his predecessor. At the 1997 election and immediately afterwards, Mr Blair believed he needed Mr Ashdown beside him. A broad union of centre-left politics appealed to him more than Labour ruling alone. He was therefore not averse to paying the likely price for collaboration - a change in the electoral system. But Labour retreated. Supporters of first past the post refused to buy even the softened-up form of the alternative vote recommended by the Jenkins committee. The party fell back on a formula - leaving the issue alone until the new constitutional systems in Scotland and Wales were safely bedded in - which offered the Lib Dems nothing. In the light of Labour's vast lead in the polls and the marginalisation of the Conservative party, Mr Blair can safely assume that no great price need be paid for Lib Dem collaboration this time.

Even so, the state of electoral politics ought to have real advantages for the Liberal Democrats. People who liked the look of Mr Blair four years ago, now dislike and distrust his government: its only real virtue, they are coming to think, is that it is not the Tory party. Mr Kennedy is right in scenting a Lib Dem opportunity. But he needs to seize it with far more energy and imagination than he has shown so far. Liberal Democrats should demand much more from Charles Kennedy than he is delivering.

webTitle: Last try by Kennedy for PR deal with Labour

fields.headline: Last try by Kennedy for PR deal with Labour
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy, leader of the Liberal Democrats, will meet Tony Blair tomorrow in a last attempt to get a referendum on voting reform written into Labour's manifesto.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy, leader of the Liberal Democrats, will meet Tony Blair tomorrow in a last attempt to get a referendum on voting reform written into Labour's manifesto.

With an expected general election only weeks away, and manifestos being finalised within days, the Lib Dems seek at least a pledge to restart the stalled process towards considering proportional representation for Westminster.

Without such a commitment, Mr Kennedy will confirm that all formal Lib Dem co-operation with Labour is over. That would kill off the joint cabinet committee set up under the previous Lib Dem leader Paddy Ashdown, which enabled co-operation on constitutional issues such as devolution and PR for elections to the Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly.

It could also mean the Liberal Democrats using their position as holders of the balance of power in the Lords to disrupt legislation. Despite this week's crunch meeting, Mr Kennedy conspicuously steered clear of electoral reform at his party's weekend spring conference in Torquay.

Lib Dem strategists are reluctant to stir up party divisions over co-operation with Labour, though they reject criticism that Mr Kennedy has replaced his predecessor's enthusiasm for the Lib-Lab "project" with inertia on electoral reform. "Charles is not a great proponent of megaphone diplomacy on this," said one aide. "Talks between Charles and Blair have been going on behind the scenes for several months and Charles has repeatedly made clear that without a manifesto commitment all co-operation is off."

Labour's 1997 manifesto promised a referendum during this parliament on voting reform, but the pledge was sidestepped after opposition within Labour. The recommendations of the Jenkins commission on voting reform, which proposed PR for Westminster elections, have also been shelved. Labour policy is now to review the outcome of applying PR to Scottish, Welsh and European elections, before deciding whether to pursue voting reform.

Privately, Lib Dem strategists believe that the cabinet committee has outlived its usefulness as the vehicle of co-operation with the government. It has not met since last summer, and the Lib Dems have been frustrated over their four key constitutional reform priorities: PR for Westminster, elected regional government, PR for local government, and further Lords reform.

Kennedy aides insist that, whatever the result of last-minute PR negotiations, their party will continue to concentrate fire on the Conservatives, arguing that, while Labour has been a disappointment, a Conservative government would be a disaster.

In Torquay, Mr Kennedy offered a direct invitation to "one nation" Conservatives to defect to his party. In an informal conference speech, delivered in shirt sleeves while pacing the conference stage, he sought to make a virtue of accusations of a lack of dynamism, saying: "It's said I'm laid back. Well, that's true. But that's because I'm tolerant, and because I'm a Liberal. I'm proud of that."

However, some critics say he is failing to make an impact with voters. He has pledged to increase both parliamentary seats, 47, and share of the vote, 17%, at the last election.

Mr Kennedy said the Liberal Democrats would fight the election on a promise to raise the basic rate of income tax by 1p to increase spending on education.

fields.headline: Election leaflets might be pulped
fields.trailText: Millions of general election leaflets printed by the Tories and Liberal Democrats may have to be pulped after the parties failed to spot the significance of a change in the laws governing elections.
fields.body:
Millions of general election leaflets printed by the Tories and Liberal Democrats may have to be pulped after the parties failed to spot the significance of a change in the laws governing elections.

Officials at Conservative Central Office contacted the electoral commission last week after receiving legal advice that their leaflets breached the Political Parties, Elections and Referendums Act 2000.

The two parties printed their leaflets under the old rules, which required parties to publish the names of the printer and the publisher, who is usually the election agent.

Under the rules that came into force last month, parties have to add the candidate's name to the formal list at the bottom of leaflets and posters. The act says the name and address "of any person on behalf of whom the material is being published" must be added.

The Lib Dems' lawyers told them they did not need to worry about the new rule because the name of a parliamentary agent would make it clear that the leaflet was being published on behalf of a candidate.

Alarm bells started ringing last week, however, when the Tories' lawyers said leaflets printed under the old rules would be in breach of the new law.

When David Prior, Conservative MP for Norfolk North, who is chief executive of the party, asked the electoral commission for clarification, it said it would provide an answer within a week.

One Tory MP, who was about to have his leaflets printed locally under the old rules, said: "I have telephoned my printer and told him to stop the presses.

"I have already printed my posters, and hope I will be able to add stickers to all 1,500 of them, if the commission rules against us."

Labour has abided by the law, which it introduced to make it clearer to voters who is publishing election literature.

The law will also make it easier for the electoral commission, which has to monitor spending by the parties, to check whether accounts submitted by candidates tally with the numbers of posters and leaflets printed.

The confusion over the leaflets came as the Conservatives faced an embarrassing leak from their election advertising agency, Yellow M.

In a series of internal memos the agency said the public had an "ingrained distrust" of the Tories, who were seen to "govern for themselves and people like them".

Labour will step up its attacks on the Tories by releasing an election video which likens their leader, William Hague, to Damien, the devil's son in The Omen II. The video, which is to be handed out to voters, opens with footage of Margaret Thatcher accompanied by the soundtrack from the film.

The video warns people who rejoiced at her downfall: "They forgot one thing: there was a son," then shows Mr Hague's notorious teenage speech to the Tory conference in 1977.

webTitle: Blair's £100m fund to head off GP revolt

fields.headline: £100m to head off GP revolt
fields.standfirst: Blair's £100m fund to head off revolt by GPs
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today unveil a £100m fund to boost GPs' surgeries as the government tries to head off a damaging doctors' revolt in the run-up to the general election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today unveil a £100m fund to boost GPs' surgeries as the government tries to head off a damaging doctors' revolt in the run-up to the general election.

In an attempt to sweet-talk angry GPs, the prime minister will announce that every surgery in England and Wales will be entitled to an an extra £10,000 a year if doctors sign up to a modernising contract to improve primary care.

Doctors will receive an immediate payment of £5,000 which will be doubled by the end of the year if they meet a series of targets drawn up by local primary care trusts. These could include extending surgery opening hours, providing better care for coronary or cancer patients or becoming better GP training centres.

Mr Blair's gesture comes in the face of warnings from doctors' leaders of a new confrontation with the government during the general election campaign. The British Medical Association is to produce a patients' dossier that will show the suffering caused to patients when doctors in the hard-pressed NHS are forced to cut corners.

The prime minister will attempt to calm the atmosphere today when he tells the Royal College of General Practitioners in London of his determination to direct more cash and more powers directly to "frontline" doctors. But the prime minister will make clear that he will not hand out cash indiscriminately as he highlights the new £100m GPs' fund.

"I want to reward effort and enterprise wherever it is found in public service," Mr Blair will declare. "I know that teachers, police officers, nurses and NHS staff do not come into public service primarily to make money. They are motivated by a sense of vocation. That is something beyond price. The public and the government value their commitment, but I see no reason why staff who do a good job for the public should not be rewarded."

The speech comes days after the health secretary, Alan Milburn, unveiled a series of initiatives to persuade GPs to remain in the NHS. Lump sums of £5,000 are to be paid to every new GP, while an additional £5,000 will be paid to any GP willing to work in a deprived area. The government pledged in last year's NHS plan to appoint an extra 2,000 GPs in England by 2004, although the BMA demanded 10,300.

Mr Blair will attempt to meet some of the BMA's complaints by announcing that the government will dramatically increase the number of GPs between 2004 and 2010. Mr Milburn will announce an extra 550 GP training places and an extra 400 GP trainers.

The prime minister will also announce plans for a cut in red tape faced by doctors. GPs will no longer have to sign pensioners' driving licence forms, passport applications and postal vote applications. This will free up 750,000 GP working hours, which works out at one appointment a day for every doctor in the country.

Mr Blair will also make clear that Labour will hand more power and more money to "frontline" primary care groups if it wins a second term. He will point out that GPs will be responsible for 75% of the NHS budget by 2004, compared with 15% in 1997.

In his speech today Mr Blair will go out of his way to lavish praise on NHS workers as he attempts to show how all sides have moved on since the government's tortuous negotiations with the BMA in 1999 prompted him to complain of "scars in my back". He will hail a report into the health service's performance this winter as a sign of the dedication of NHS staff.

The report, which is to be published today by the NHS chief executive, Nigel Crisp, shows that the NHS avoided a repeat of last year's winter crisis thanks to a 40% increase in the number of flu vaccinations. More than 10m people were vaccinated, including nearly two-thirds (65%) of people aged over 65. This meant that fewer people in this age group had flu than in the population as a whole.

Hospitals experienced a massive increase in admissions over the winter, but avoided a crisis thanks to the "huge amount of personal effort and commitment" by NHS staff, Mr Blair will say. The report compares the pressure on the NHS during a 22-day period over Christmas and the new year this year and a year earlier. On 18 of the 22 days this year, there were more admissions to hospitals than in the same period last year. On 15 days, more people went to accident and emergency departments, while on 14 days there were more 999 calls.

webTitle: Comment: Standards in public life matter

fields.headline: No going forward without going back to put things right
fields.standfirst: Standards in public life matter. Even politicians must know that
fields.trailText: Standards in public life matter. Even politicians must know that.
fields.body:
It is the case of the dog who is still clearing his throat. We are back - the ides of May 3 - in one of our periodic paroxysms over sleaze, in the season of Vazillations; and there is silence at the centre of our defences. Sir Nigel Wicks has nothing to say. How could he? His feet are barely under the desk yet.

New sleazebusters start here. Sir Nigel (in case you missed his appointment a few weeks ago) is the third chairman of the committee on standards in public life. He succeeds Lord Neill of Bladen (who succeeded Lord Nolan) and he is interestingly different. Nolan was a distinguished judge; Neill was a distinguished lawyer/ academic; Wicks is the supreme civil service insider.

He was a private secretary to Harold Wilson and Jim Callaghan in Downing Street. He was economic minister in the Washington embassy and our man at the World Bank and IMF. He was Margaret Thatcher's principal private secretary, chairman of the European Community monetary committee and Gordon Brown's point-man through Group of Seven meetings. He was second permanent secretary at the Treasury.

You don't, in public life, come much more influential than that. Wicks was a powerful man in the most powerful ministry, an ultimate mover and shaker. When Tony Blair nominated him as the defender of standards, he seemed to say something important - that the job itself was as important as ever, perhaps more so, that trust and confidence in the system remained vital.

But note the change of perspective. Nolan, summoned in extremis by John Major, was the judicial outsider. Neill followed that pattern. Both knew about public life from a (very decent) seat in the stalls. They came in from the cold to examine and codify conduct which seemed to have fallen into slack disrepair. Wicks operates from a totally separate standpoint. He has always been in the kitchen. He either thinks it still an honourable place, from personal experience - or he senses the grime round the stove, the dirty washing left in the sink.

Let's assume, with some confidence, that he belongs to the honourable tendency. He hasn't devoted three decades to propping up a rotten body politic. He still believes that, at root, most of the people he worked with, following most of the codes in place, were good administrators doing a good, selfless job. Of course, this doesn't mean that some things - and some men and women - don't go off the rails, or panic in a jam. But the essential task is reassurance, not doubt-clouded invigilation. The task is revealing the true world he knows, or thinks he knows, to a watching populace.

This is not, perhaps, so very different from the role Nolan and Neill came eventually to see for themselves. When Neill, 14 months ago, published his re-review of the committee's first five years, he hailed "great achievements" in raising ethical standards - and basked in the opinion of the leader of the House, Margaret Beckett, who told him "that things are a great deal less fevered". But ... there is always a but. "The subject of conduct in public life can return to newspaper front pages and the public eye very rapidly."

Dismally true. Enter, in a fevered rush, Messrs Mandelson, Reid, Hinduja and Vaz (pursued by our old mate, Wafic Said). Public eyes open wide. Whether or not it changes election results - and the evidence is that it doesn't unless a reviled government is on the way out anyway - the issue of sleaze is back, and so are its handmaidens, cynicism and apathy. It would be wrong to declare seven years of toil gone to waste, but the headlines are still awful and yesterday's poll results still damning. If Sir Nigel Wicks believes in reassurance, he suddenly needs it by the tonne.

Pre-ballot blues? In part, naturally enough. Some of the current stuff is mere political putrescence. When Archie Norman delivers Asda memorial lectures on planning permission purity and puts the boot into Margaret and Mark Thatcher's moneyed mate, Wafic, he makes himself ridiculous. Indeed, the Tories, prancing high on the platform built for them by Lord Ashcroft of Belize, are constantly ridiculous here. But that doesn't mean that the Hammond report on the Hindujas or the Filkin report on Keith Vaz (or even the sheepish privileges committee report on Dr John Reid) don't matter. They do, greatly. They are symptoms of reforming zeal running into the sands.

How, if you're Wicks, do you turn this tide? How do you and your team find a role at the heart of the action, as Lord Nolan once did? The committee stands at the apex of regulation. But, as we can see from the past few weeks, it can perilously easily drift into forgetfulness. Its chosen (or prescribed) modus operandi doesn't work any longer.

The idea, from the start, was to publish a long series of reports which could be the foundation stones for standards in dodgy areas (which others could police). Mission accomplished. Seven magisterial documents, moving from quango appointments to political advisers, have flowed forth. Yet what happens then? Sometimes the government acts. That's why we have election spending limits and a commission to police them at last. Sometimes nothing happens.

Only once has the committee tramped back across old ground. Sometimes it found grievous flaws (in the procedures of the privileges committee) and recommended change. Nothing happened. Sometimes it slid away from obvious reform - on prime ministerial control of the code of conduct for ministers - and was painfully slow to realise its mistake.

Consider the cases causing current grief. Would Keith Vaz and his eager beaver solicitor have been quite so keen on slithery obfuscation if they'd had to deal, at the last, with a four-person core committee chaired by a high court judge? Would Elizabeth Filkin, gallantly punctilious, have been so let down? Would an ad hoc Sir Anthony Hammond have been pulled off a back shelf to spread his complacent Hinduja balm? Would Peter Mandelson have had a fairer deal - and Vaz a far terser, sterner one?

The problem is not what the Wicks team does next -honours appointments? European connections? - to some annual schedule. It is making sure that what isn't going right is, very publicly, put right. (Just watch the coming election spending debacle.)

Tony Blair called for Sir Nigel because the job still matters. Sir Nigel took it because he agreed. He must know already that prime ministers, ditching colleagues in a tizz or hanging on to them beyond reason, do democracy damage as well as themselves. He must know already that, whatever the weight of the allegations against him, Keith Vaz made a mockery of the procedures Nolan set in place. And he must know, too, that there can be no going forward without going back.

webTitle: Comment: Talk of tension between town and country is absurd

fields.headline: A phoney war, if ever there was one
fields.standfirst:
Talk of tension between town and country is patently absurd

Special report: countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Talk of tension between town and country is patently absurd.
fields.body:
For reasons which only psychiatrists can explain, Homo sapiens love to create the impression of conflict where none really exists. The desire to exaggerate antagonisms is strongest in television journalists. But even normal human beings feel an urge to promote bogus confrontation. That unhappy inclination has marred much of the debate on the best way to control the foot and mouth outbreak. And it has been used by fox-hunting enthusiasts as proof that they are a persecuted minority. The notion that town is at war with country is patently absurd.

Baroness Mallalieu, who chairs the Countryside Alliance, promoted the hostility which she claims to deplore by telling the House of Lords last week: "We are dividing our nation and our countryside". All I know of the baroness is that her father was the best journalist to come out of the House of Commons since the war and that she is the author of the remarkable claim that fox-hunters regard the chase as their "poetry, music and literature". In a free country, Baroness Mallalieu is entitled to be a total philistine. But she is not entitled, if we place any importance on truth, to pretend that town is in conflict with country.

Lord Rees-Mogg recently devoted one of his Times columns to the same claim. It was actually headlined "Two nations divided at the farm gate". His lordship often writes of his west country birth and parentage. But he is one of the most metropolitan figures I have ever met. He embodies the way in which Great Britain - in which few of us live very far from either town or country - enjoys a happy partnership of rural and urban communities. I hope that, in my more modest way, I represent the same union of interests and instincts.

The village in which I was born has now been totally absorbed into the city of Sheffield. But the bedroom where I once did my homework still looks out onto the beginning of the moors. Now, I spend the happiest times of my life further west along the Derwent valley. But the idea that I have to take sides in a battle between my workdays and weekends is palpable nonsense. If I had to fight in the phoney war, I would offer my sword to the country. But I would still believe that the hostilities were the unnecessary invention of people who hope to improve their image by posturing as saviours of Arcadia.

There is something about fields and forests which make the middle classes feel that living in the country is proof of social superiority. It is, I suppose, a relic of the industrial revolution. The landless peasants were driven into the towns to mind the engines of Victorian Britain while the gentry remained on the enclosed land. In its way, the desire to be conspicuously associated with rural life is a perverse version of Cobbett's backward glance. There was a time when a man could ride from London to Winchester and never see a forge or a mill. That was the age of innocence, the time before the Fall. The country is the Garden of Eden from which we were all ejected.

The farmers I know best have no time for such rubbish, or for propaganda about urban Britain being indifferent to their problems. It is the suburbs and the inner cities which buy what they produce. Even Tess of the D'Urbervilles realised that the late night trains which belched fire across Wessex were taking milk to London hotels. Sensible farmers know that town and country live in partnership. And the fox-hunters among them do not pretend that it is only townies who would prohibit blood sports. How could they suggest anything so stupid when there are abolitionists living in every village?

The farmers who are embarrassed by the "sympathetic" stories which are now being told about them would happily do without Prince Charles's talk of family suicides and pictures of weeping at byre doors. They read Bel Mooney's description of her Herefords' "sweet, curly topknots" and realised at once that a lady journalist who tells her cows "out loud how sweet they are" does not farm for a living. A year ago I watched - for as long as I could bear it - while a vet assisted in the difficult delivery of a calf. I was immensely impressed by the care and concern displayed by the farmer who owned the reluctant mother. But I did not expect him to sing the new-born baby to sleep.

Because I am at home in the country I feel no obligation to suggest that it is entirely populated by noble yeomen who, like their fathers and grandfathers, represent all that is best in the British character. Many of them do. Some of them do not. All of them would be best served if, at their time of trouble, newspapers were supportive without being maudlin. Farmers are remarkably like the rest of us - which is why they deserve our help.

webTitle: Comment: The west wants free movement of capital, but not labour

fields.headline: Penalising the poor
fields.standfirst:
The west wants the free movement of capital, but not of labour. It is illogical and immoral

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The west wants the free movement of capital, but not of labour. It is illogical and immoral.
fields.body:
One of the most pernicious aspects of the former eastern bloc - and there were many - was the restriction placed on people's right to travel. Understandably it was also one of the west's favoured propaganda weapons. Our governments actively encouraged people to defect. Those who managed to dodge the snipers on the border or who could face not seeing their families again were welcomed with open arms.

Before they even opened their mouth, each new arrival was living evidence of the wickedness of communism. The very fact that they had to escape and could not return marked a violation of their basic human right to the freedom of movement.

Last week the British government spearheaded a European Union proposal to send immigration officers to Bosnia and Croatia to teach them how to put a stop to the traffic of the world's "undeserving poor". "The Balkans' route is the single most important source of illegal immigration into western Europe," said Jack Straw. "If we can close it or restrict it, we are on the way to winning the battle." The Berlin wall has collapsed; welcome to Fortress Europe. Politics used to keep people in; now economics keeps them out.

Even as the west encourages the former communist states to open up their markets to foreign investment, it is teaching them how to close their doors to foreign people. For what was once hailed as a human right is now opposed as an economic liability. Our governments are trapped in a morally warped and ideologically unsustainable paradigm. They applaud the free movement of capital; they abhor the free movement of labour.

Lay off workers here and move your factory to the other side of the world, where labour is cheaper, unions are weaker and regimes are more brutal and you are hailed as an entrepreneur. Arrive at Waterloo clinging to the Eurostar or in Dover on the back of a lorry with the intention of working long hours for low pay and you will be branded "bogus" and labelled a scrounger.

The two are inextricably related. For it is the increasingly unfettered free movement of capital, championed by the west, that helps create the poverty which prompts the economic migration from the developing world. Structural adjustment programmes, imposed on countries by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in return for loans, generally lead to swingeing cuts in health, education and welfare spending and mass privatisation. The effects can be devastating. Take Zambia: IMF-imposed reforms forced the government there, among other things, to charge for healthcare and privatise the copper mines. GNP dropped 16%, the mortality rate of under-fives almost doubled and 60,000 workers were laid off in two years.

Norman Tebbit's dad should have counted himself lucky; he only had to get on his bike to look for work. These people take planes, trains and boats. But when they arrive the response of the wealthiest nations is not to rethink the policies which are creating this havoc but to build higher walls, train more border guards and target new arrivals with racist rhetoric.

That does not mean that Britain has turned its back on economic immigration - far from it. It is one of the paradoxes of recent years that as the vitriol against asylum seekers has increased so has the number of economic immigrants. According to the Home Office the number of work permit holders and their dependants has risen by more than a third since Labour came to power. The sharpest increase has been from Africa which indicates that we are not only hammering their weakest, we are cherry-picking their strongest too.

So it is not foreigners per se our government loathes; it is poor people. Asylum seekers, with their tales of torture, rape and solitary confinement, can get to the end of the queue and wait for their vouchers. Britain wants professionals with IT skills, teaching qualifications and nursing certificates.

As a further round of trade talks begin today in Geneva these contradictions are set to be brought into sharp relief. The World Trade Organisation's general agreement on trade in services (Gats) aims to liberalise everything from health and education to water and tourism. "I suspect neither governments nor industries have yet appreciated the full scope of these guarantees or the full value of existing commitments," the former WTO director- general, Renator Ruggiero, has said.

Campaigning organisations, such as the British-based World Development Movement, take this as an ominous warning. Gats, they believe, will undermine democratic sovereignty throughout the world, strengthen the hand of the multinationals and wealthy western nations and weaken the developing world by forcing countries to privatise essential services and then forbidding them from reversing these decisions.

The WTO insists these concerns are either exaggerated or fabricated. Gats, they say, neither obliges countries to privatise, nor open markets and does enable them to reverse decisions, negotiate waivers and override commitments when health and safety is at stake.

But their assurances wilfully ignore one golden rule - whoever has the gold makes the rules. The agreement is for free trade, not fair trade. Any rich nation or huge multinational with an eye for a new market has access to lawyers and lobbyists that poorer countries cannot afford, who will find loopholes and twist arms to get what they want.

That is more or less how "free trade" works at the moment. With considerable persuasion from the Chiquita banana company, which funds both the Democrats and Republicans, the American government sought to make an example of small Caribbean island producers. It is difficult to imagine Dominica, which has a population smaller than Fargo, North Dakota, taking on the US over its farm or sugar subsidies.

The WTO's position at present amounts to asking poor nations to trust them as honest brokers. Given their record, this is a bit like the big bad wolf telling Little Red Riding Hood: "Sorry about your granny. Why don't you pop over for lunch?"

At a meeting with non-governmental organisations on Friday, one EU negotiator explained wearily that American domination was "a fact of life". As with joining the euro, which most Britons do not want but believe is going to happen anyway, an air of destiny had grown up around globalisation. Governments from the developing world have, in the past, seen little alternative to trying to get the best they can from a bad deal.

But there is nothing inevitable about this round of talks giving the west or the WTO what they want. For what the big guns cannot buy is public approval. Their agenda is unpopular in the west too. An NBC-Wall Street Journal poll last April revealed that by 48% to 34%, Americans think that foreign trade is bad for the US economy.

The failure to reach an agreement in Seattle last year was a sobering moment for them. Mike Moore, the WTO director, insists this will not happen when the WTO roadshow moves to Doha, Qatar, in November: "We will not fail this time, because if we aren't sure of success by September we will redefine the goal."

This gives the NGOs and developing world everything to play for but also, potentially, an awful lot to lose.

But their assurances wilfully ignore one golden rule - whoever has the gold makes the rules. The agreement is for free trade, not fair trade. Any rich nation or huge multinational with an eye for a new market has access to lawyers and lobbyists that poorer countries cannot afford, who will find loopholes and twist arms to get what they want. That is more or less how "free trade" works at the moment. With considerable persuasion from the Chiquita banana company, which funds both the Democrats and Republicans, the American government sought to make an example of small Caribbean island producers. It is difficult to imagine Dominica, which has a population smaller than Fargo, North Dakota, taking on the US over its farm or sugar subsidies. The WTO's position at present amounts to asking poor nations to trust them as honest brokers. Given their record, this is a bit like the big bad wolf telling Little Red Riding Hood: "Sorry about your granny. Why don't you pop over for lunch?" At a meeting with non-governmental organisations on Friday, one EU negotiator explained wearily that American domination was "a fact of life". As with joining the euro, which most Britons do not want but believe is going to happen anyway, an air of destiny had grown up around globalisation. Governments from the developing world have, in the past, seen little alternative to trying to get the best they can from a bad deal. But there is nothing inevitable about this round of talks giving the west or the WTO what they want. For what the big guns cannot buy is public approval. Their agenda is unpopular in the west too. An NBC-Wall Street Journal poll last April revealed that by 48% to 34%, Americans think that foreign trade is bad for the US economy. The failure to reach an agreement in Seattle last year was a sobering moment for them. Mike Moore, the WTO director, insists this will not happen when the WTO roadshow moves to Doha, Qatar, in November: "We will not fail this time, because if we aren't sure of success by September we will redefine the goal." This gives the NGOs and developing world everything to play for but also, potentially, an awful lot to lose. gary.younge@theguardian.com

fields.headline: £400m to ease schools crisis
fields.standfirst: Labour gives GPs £100m
fields.trailText: The government will today unveil £500m of extra spending for the NHS and education as ministers move to head off damaging revolts from doctors and teachers in the run-up to the general election.
fields.body:
The government will today unveil £500m of extra spending for the NHS and education as ministers move to head off damaging revolts from doctors and teachers in the run-up to the general election.

In an attempt to sweet-talk angry GPs, the prime minister will announce the setting up of a £100m fund that will hand every surgery in England and Wales an extra £10,000 a year if doctors sign up to a modernising contract to improve primary care.

At the same time the education secretary, David Blunkett, will announce a £400m package to train and recruit teaching assistants in the classroom. Amid fears of industrial action over teacher shortages, the Mr Blunkett will pledge the extra money until 2004.

The minister will say that teaching assistants have played a crucial role in raising standards in literacy and numeracy. "Teaching assistants enable pupils to work in smaller groups, help tackle their specific problems and assist teachers to raise standards," he will say.

In a sign of the government's determination to concentrate on health and education in the run-up to the election, Tony Blair will use a speech today to the Royal College of General Practitioners to outline how more cash and more powers will be directed to "frontline" doctors.

Doctors will receive an immediate payment of £5,000 which will be doubled by the end of the year if they meet targets drawn up by local pri mary care trusts. These could include extending surgery opening hours, providing better care for coronary or cancer patients or attending GP training centres.

Mr Blair's gesture comes in the face of warnings from doctors' leaders of a new confrontation with the government during the general election campaign. The British Medical Association is to produce a patients' dossier that will show the suffering caused to patients when doctors in the hard-pressed NHS are forced to cut corners.

The prime minister will attempt to calm the atmosphere today, but he will make clear that he will not hand out cash indiscriminately.

"I want to reward effort and enterprise wherever it is found in public service," Mr Blair will declare. "I know that teachers, police officers, nurses and NHS staff do not come into public service primarily to make money. They are motivated by a sense of vocation. That is something beyond price. The public and the government value their commitment, but I see no reason why staff who do a good job for the public should not be rewarded."

The speech comes days after the health secretary, Alan Milburn, unveiled a series of initiatives to persuade GPs to remain in the NHS. Lump sums of £5,000 are to be paid to every new GP, while an additional £5,000 will be paid to any GP willing to work in a deprived area. The government pledged in last year's NHS plan to appoint an extra 2,000 GPs in England by 2004, although the BMA demanded 10,300.

Mr Blair will attempt to meet some of the BMA's complaints by announcing that the government will dramatically increase the number of GPs between 2004 and 2010. Mr Milburn will announce an extra 550 GP training places and an extra 400 GP trainers.

The prime minister will also announce plans for a cut in red tape faced by doctors. GPs will no longer have to sign pensioners' driving licence forms, passport applications and postal vote applications. This will free up 750,000 GP working hours, which works out at one appointment a day for every doctor in the country.

Mr Blair will also make clear that Labour plans to hand more power and more money to frontline primary care groups. He will point out that GPs will be responsible for 75% of the NHS budget by 2004, compared with 15% in 1997.

In his speech Mr Blair will hail a report into the health service's performance this winter as a sign of the dedication of NHS staff. The report, which is to be published today by the NHS chief executive, Nigel Crisp, shows that the NHS avoided a repeat of last year's winter crisis thanks to a 40% increase in the number of flu vaccinations. More than 10m people were vaccinated, including nearly two-thirds of people aged over 65.

fields.headline: Farmers accused of cheating
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Unscrupulous farmers may have spread foot and mouth by borrowing sheep from dealers to cheat European Union quota schemes, it emerged yesterday, as the number of confirmed cases of the disease rose well above 300.
fields.body:
Unscrupulous farmers may have spread foot and mouth by borrowing sheep from dealers to cheat European Union quota schemes, it emerged yesterday, as the number of confirmed cases of the disease rose well above 300.

The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food is concerned by reports that some farmers might have boosted their subsidies under the common agricultural policy by claiming to have more animals than they actually had.

They are said to have leased extra sheep from dealers, or bought them for cash without declaring the acquisitions, when inspections were due. These animal movements would not be recorded, making it difficult to trace infections spread in this manner.

A Maff spokesman said: "We have heard reports of 'out of the ring' trading of animals which has not been recorded.

"The key point is to eradicate this disease in the interests of the livestock farmers, regardless of why people have been acting as they have.

"Maff urges any farmers to come forward if they may have bought sheep from an infected source - for whatever reason."

But farmers may be unwilling to admit to such deals because of the heavy fines they face. The ministry insisted there was no question of an amnesty should individuals admit to breaking the rules.

"We will take any movement of animals against the rules very seriously," it said. "Restrictions on movement are obviously the key to eradicating the disease. It would be for Maff to prosecute and Maff can and do prosecute."

Peter Morris, policy adviser for the National Farmers' Union in Devon, said: "If a farmer doesn't have enough livestock to qualify for his quota he can buy some in to make up numbers. This is perfectly legal and proper and acceptable to Maff as long as they are informed.

"However, it is fair to say there is a degree of temptation for farmers to get animals in on loan rather than buying them. The penalties for farmers without enough animals for their quota are very harsh and often mean huge financial loss."

Anthony Gibson, south-west regional director of the NFU, dismissed the claims as unsubstantiated "pub talk".

"It has never been a big problem because the penalties are very draconian," he said. "Most people actually claim for fewer animals than they have in case they lose a few."

Maff officials also fear that farmers are breaking movement restrictions. According to the Observer yesterday, nearly 200 breaches of the rules have been reported.

According to the newspaper, Cumbrian trading standards officers plan to prosecute two farmers who they believe deliberately moved healthy sheep to fields close to an outbreak, hoping that they could claim compensation if the animals contracted the virus.

Maff said: "If that were the case it would be an extremely foolish thing to do." The local veterinary office would be in touch with trading standards.

The allegations came as the tally of outbreaks reached 323 in Britain, with 25 cases confirmed yesterday. On Saturday there were between 25 and 31 cases. The previous daily record was 25 new cases on March 11.

"Just three weeks into this outbreak we are already looking at 278,000 animals affected," said Jim Scudamore, the chief veterinary officer. "In the six months the 1967 outbreak lasted, only 400,000 animals were affected, which shows the severity of this."

fields.headline: Labour MP's 'web summit' vision collapses
fields.standfirst:
More net news
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: A web project founded by the Labour chairman of the parliamentary internet group has gone into liquidation, writes Stuart Millar.
fields.body:
A web project founded by the Labour chairman of the parliamentary internet group has gone into liquidation amid allegations that creditors were given false assurances about its financial position.

The World Internet Forum, launched in 1999 in a blaze of publicity by Derek Wyatt, the MP for Sittingbourne and Sheppey in Kent, has collapsed with debts of more than £830,000.

At WIF's launch two years ago Mr Wyatt, a former England rugby union international with a background in the computer industry, billed his vision as the world's first global summit bringing together political and business leaders to thrash out ways of improving use of the web by governments and industry.

But in a development that will be hugely embarrassing for Mr Wyatt, who has set himself up as parliament's internet visionary, the Guardian has established that at least one large creditor has complained to the liquidator that it was misled by WIF about its financial position.

The creditor, according to sources, voiced concerns about the project's finances but was persuaded to continue working with the organisers only after being assured that its bills would be met.

Anthony Supperstone, of BDO Stoy Hayward, the liquidator, confirmed that he is looking into allegations that creditors were falsely assured that their bills would be paid.

A leaked copy of his initial report to creditors, seen by the Guardian, reveals that HSBC bank is owed £250,000 which it gave as sponsorship. Among the other creditors is the public relations consultancy Firefly, which is understood to be owed more than £190,000.

The first three-day forum was to take place at the Metropole hotel in London last November. More than 500 delegates were expected to sign up, paying up to £1,625 each for their seats. An impressive list of speakers had been arranged, including Chris Smith, the culture secretary, Patricia Hewitt, the e-commerce minister, Paddy Ashdown, the former Lib Dem leader, and David Bell, chairman of the Financial Times.

But 72 hours before the event was to begin, it was cancelled because only 63 delegates from around the world had signed up. Instead of the £550,000 of delegate fees WIF had budgeted for, only £8,757 had been banked. It was at this stage, the creditor alleges, that the false assurances were given to persuade it to continue working for WIF.

The collapse of the event was seen as a setback for the prime minister's campaign to place Britain at the leading edge of internet development. The Department of Trade and Industry had given its support to the project. It was more humiliating for Mr Wyatt, however. He had resigned as a director of WIF the previous May, because his other commitments - as well as being an MP, he is involved with several hi-tech broadcasting and communications companies - were interfering with the planning. Control was handed to Integrated Consultancy Projects, a London firm that had been acting as the project manager.

Mr Wyatt retained a half-share in WIF and was closely involved in the forum's organisation, although there is no suggestion that he gave false assurances to creditors. His long-term aim had been to plough profits from the project into establishing a permanent WIF internet portal for governments and businesses to share information.

But the liquidator's initial report reveals that the company was beset by financial problems from the start. In October 1999, barely a month after the launch, Motorola was due to sign a £500,000 sponsorship agreement. The deal and the budgets had been approved but at the meeting, David Brown, managing director of Motorola Europe, changed his mind.

"This was a major setback and meant that the event missed an opportunity for early credibility and financial security," the liquidator's report concludes.

Mr Wyatt could not be contacted for comment yesterday. But Robert Blaney, WIF's company secretary and an executive at ICP, which is still owed £104,000, denied that any creditors had been misled.

fields.headline: Protesters ready for battle of Hastings
fields.standfirst:
Environmentalists warn of major obstacles to road building scheme as government gets a chance to prove its green credentials

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Environmentalists warn of major obstacles to road building scheme as government gets a chance to prove its green credentials.
fields.body:
The lines have been drawn in the mud and the heavy artillery is about to arrive in what has been dubbed "the second battle of Hastings". Today the country's leading environmental groups will launch a united front to try to stop the most controversial road building schemes since Twyford Down and Newbury from going ahead.

Friends of the Earth, the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds and English Nature are among the environmental heavyweights demanding John Prescott block two bypass schemes around the East Sussex town, which they claim will devastate some of the country's most important wildlife sites.

The South East Regional Assembly formally approved the roads last month and the decision about whether or not to go ahead now lies with the deputy prime minister.

If he gives his consent the protesters have promised that Hastings will become Labour's very own Twyford Down or Newbury bypass - where middle Englanders stood shoulder to shoulder with ecowarriors in an unlikely alliance against roadbuilding schemes sanctioned by the Conservatives.

"We thought Labour had learnt their lesson from the Tories that building roads through middle England is a deeply unpopular thing to do," said Tony Bosworth, FoE's transport campaigner. "But it appears they are determined to learn the lesson the hard way.

"Hastings is the new line in the sand, the new test of the government's pledge to protect wildlife sites in the countryside and to reduce traffic levels."

The controversial bypasses are supported by many in the local area, including the local Labour MP, Michael Foster, who said the roads will help to regenerate the decaying seaside resort, ranked 28th in the list of poorest towns in Britain.

But the Hastings Alliance, which also comprises the Council for the Protection of Rural England, Transport 2000, WWF, Wildlife Trusts and the Council for National Parks, claim that the schemes could have a negative impact on employment figures in the area. They say a consultant's study reported that building the bypasses and developing an out-of-town business park near Bexhill could lead to 300 jobs being lost in Hastings.

The roads are also opposed by English Nature and the Countryside Agency, who warn they would increase traffic in surrounding towns and raise pressure for more road building in the Brede Valley and the new South Downs National Park.

Gillian Bargery, joint co-ordinator of the Hastings Alliance said: "These destructive bypasses aren't the answer to Hastings traffic problems.

"The schemes are another piece in the jigsaw towards a south coast motorway. They will attract traffic from the M25, threatening conservation towns like Rye and the new South Downs National Park with more congestion and road building.

"The £130m earmarked for these roads would be far better spent on local transport and regeneration initiatives to bring Hastings the revitalisation it so badly needs."

The bypass schemes threaten to destroy a number of Sites of Special Scientific Interest (SSSIs).

In Doleham plans for the eastern bypass involve levelling out the valley to enable the road to pass above the Hastings-Ashford railway line. The area is home to rare species of plants, and the streams provide vital breeding grounds for sea trout. The streams will be encased in concrete culverts underground if the plans go ahead, transforming the valley.

Meanwhile plans for the bypass to the west of Hastings include a 12-metre concrete viaduct running through Combe Haven, a wildlife reserve and a potentially important archeological site.

Steve Gilbert, RSPB senior conservation officer for South East England, said: "The Hastings bypasses will cause damage and disturbance to designated Sites of Special Scientific Interest which are nationally important wildlife sites, as well as harming ancient woodlands and causing wider, unacceptable harm to the environment.

"We urge the secretary of state to find alternative solutions for Hastings."

webTitle: Rape law challenge to all-male lords

fields.headline: Rape law challenge to all-male lords
fields.trailText: The law lords who make up Britain's highest court will face an unprecedented challenge this week to their right as an entirely male court to decide whether women who accuse men of rape should face questions in court about their past sex lives. There has never been a female law lord.
fields.body:
The law lords who make up Britain's highest court will face an unprecedented challenge this week to their right as an entirely male court to decide whether women who accuse men of rape should face questions in court about their past sex lives. There has never been a female law lord.

A leading QC from Matrix chambers, where Cherie Booth is a founding member, will argue that five male judges cannot be an impartial court in deciding where the balance lies between the right of male defendants to a fair trial and the rights of their female accusers to privacy and dignity.

Murray Hunt QC, for the Fawcett Society, a campaigning group for women's rights, is due to make the argument in the form of an application to intervene in a landmark case going to the lords next Monday.

The lords must decide whether a "rape shield" law which came into force in December, making evidence of a woman's sexual past inadmissible in deciding whether she consented, violates a defendant's right to a fair trial.

The case concerns a man, who cannot be named, who was due to stand trial the day after the new law came into force. His counsel argued he would be denied a fair trial, as guaranteed by the Human Rights Act, if he could not bring out evidence that his accuser had willingly had sex with him the week before.

Dozens of rape cases in England and Wales are on hold pending the outcome of this case.

Home Office ministers introduced the law, part of the Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act 1999, because crown court judges were thought to be too freely exercising their discretion to allow defence counsel to cross-examine rape complainants.

Ministers believed women were regularly asked questions about their sex lives which were humiliating and irrelevant to the issue of consent but made juries more likely to acquit the accused.

Mr Hunt argues that a fair-minded member of the public would fear that a court without a female voice would unconsciously favour the interests of male defendants.

Now that the Human Rights Act is in force, the law lords can expect to see a growth in the number of cases involving sensitive social issues.

When challenges to rape shield laws were twice mounted before the supreme court of Canada, women judges were on the bench. The Fawcett Society is calling on the law lords to ensure that two women sit on the five-strong panel for the case.

But the 12 law lords are all male, and so are the other 15 peers - current and former lord chancellors and retired law lords - entitled to sit on House of Lords cases.

Mr Hunt argues that the simplest solution would be to appoint two female law lords. That decision would be for the government, but the law lords could make the suggestion.

The most senior female judge in England and Wales is Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the high court's family division. There are two female appeal court judges, Dame Brenda Hale and Dame Mary Arden. Appointments can be made to the lords direct from the high court, though it is rare.

The law lords have already agreed to receive written representations in defence of the law from women's groups, led by Justice for Women. The home secretary, Jack Straw, has also briefed lawyers to defend the law and to try to dissuade the judges from making a finding that the law is incompatible with the European convention on human rights.

Baroness Kennedy of the Shaws - Helena Kennedy QC, a Labour peer - said: "We are one of the few countries with no women in the supreme court. Canada, Australia, New Zealand, the United States all have women."

She urged the law lords to read a 1991 judgment by Canada's first woman chief justice, Beverley McLachlin, who said male judges were often influenced by their experiences and attitudes to sexuality.
