fields.headline: Safety fears stall tube deal
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Livingstone's London
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A new batch of 204 safety problems, including cracked escalators that could lead to "multi-passenger fatalities", have been identified on the London underground by the health and safety executive - problems that could delay the government's partial privatisation of the tube.
fields.body:
A new batch of 204 safety problems, including cracked escalators that could lead to "multi-passenger fatalities", have been identified on the London underground by the health and safety executive - problems that could delay the government's partial privatisation of the tube.

The new batch, which takes the total of unresolved safety issues to 273, could hold up the proposed public-private partnership for at least three months, even if the government and London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, settle their differences on how the tube should be managed.

The joint system would see the public sector operating the trains and stations, while upkeep and improvements to track and signalling fell to three private construction and engineering groups, but under the direction of Bob Kiley, the transport commissioner appointed by Mr Livingstone.

The new HSE checklist, sent to London Underground and the rail unions, also criticises the lack of information for passengers trying to get out of the underground in an emergency.

Bob Crow, deputy general secretary of the Rail Maritime and Transport Union, said: "This report should be the death knell for the PPP." Ideology was being put before safety, he said. "It is time that Tony Blair intervened to prevent a Hatfield on the tube."

HSE sources said yesterday that the 273 problems had to be resolved before the PPP could go ahead.

Mr Kiley and his negotiating team played down suggestions from the government that a deal had been reached. Talks are still going on, with Mr Kiley insisting that any deal must give him the authority to order emergency work without seeking permission from any of the three operating companies.

Government sources said the Treasury is prepared to guarantee an average subsidy of £600m a year for seven and a half years. The money would be paid to London Underground as part of a £15bn overhaul of the capital's transport network. The remainder would come from private contractors and ticket revenues.

 The Labour party yesterday admitted that a lobbyist who works for a company bidding for the PPP contracts will work as a public relations man for John Prescott in the coming election, writes Nicholas Watt .

Mike Craven runs Lexington Communications, which acts for Metronet, a bidder for two of the three tube contracts.

fields.headline: Labour in new sleaze allegations
fields.standfirst:
Former paymaster general Geoffrey Robinson joins Keith Vaz in the firing line

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour was further engulfed by sleaze allegations last night with the publication of a book attacking the former paymaster general Geoffrey Robinson.
fields.body:
Labour was further engulfed by sleaze allegations last night with the publication of a book attacking the former paymaster general Geoffrey Robinson.

As the embattled minister for Europe, Keith Vaz, fights to save his political life, the government will be embarrassed by allegations in the book by the investigative journalist Tom Bower that Mr Robinson accepted money from the late Robert Maxwell in 1990.

The allegations in the book, which is being serialised in the Daily Mail, also claims that the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, "buried" an official report into the affair , but the claim was dismissed early today as "absolute rubbish" by the Department of Trade and Industry.

"There is no foundation in these allegations," a DTI spokesman said. "Throughout the whole of this affair, secretary of state Stephen Byers has accepted the advice of his permanent secretary and followed the procedures laid down in law."

The Labour party declined to comment on the book last night, saying it was a personal matter for Mr Robinson, who is a close ally of the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

The allegations about Mr Robinson come as Mr Vaz faces intense pressure to resign, after the Tories announced they would call on the parliamentary standards watchdog to reopen her investigation of the minister.

As three Labour MPs called on Mr Vaz to consider his position, the shadow minister for the Cabinet Office, Andrew Lansley, said he would ask Elizabeth Filkin, parliamentary commissioner for standards, to examine a claim that the minister had failed to declare an alleged financial link with the Hinduja brothers.

The Sunday Times disclosed yesterday that in 1995 the Hinduja Foundation had paid nearly £1,200 to Mapesbury Communications, a company set up by Mr Vaz. The money helped to pay for an Indian spiritual leader's visit to the Commons.

Mr Lansley said he would refer the matter to Mrs Filkin because Mr Vaz had told her he had never received any financial support from the Hindujas.

A spokesman for Mr Vaz dismissed the allegation, first made last month in the Mail on Sunday. At the time Mr Vaz said Sir Gordon Downey, former standards commissioner, had advised him that he did not have to declare his involvement with Mapesbury if he did not receive any benefits. The 1995 donation fell into this category because Mapesbury is run by his wife. Mr Vaz is facing intense pressure from within his party to stand down as minister. Mrs Filkin was unable to complete her inquiry into eight out of 18 complaints when Mr Vaz's solicitors refused to answer further questions last December.

Eric Illsley, MP for Barnsley Central, said: "If you don't cooperate, how can you be exonerated? If we are not going to cooperate with these bodies it puts us in the same boat as [the Tories]. It leaves a sour taste in my mouth."

His remarks were echoed by Bill Olner, MP for Nuneaton, and by Peter Kilfoyle, MP for Liverpool Walton.

Mr Vaz faced added pressure yesterday after it was disclosed that he has overturned immigration officers' decisions on up to 50 occasions since he took charge of overseeing visa applications to Britain in 1999.

fields.headline: Private health care: the basics
fields.trailText: • UK health care system is already a mix of public and private hospitals.
fields.body:
 UK health care system is already a mix of public and private hospitals.

 One in five non-urgent operations are carried out by the private sector.

 Political differences are no longer over whether to use private health care, but how much?

 The new "concordat" is specifically aimed at easing winter pressures and reducing waiting lists.

 Tories want tax breaks reintroduced to encourage greater use.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Lynsey
fields.trailText: I was particularly inspired by your travel journal in India and am now thinking of going there myself before I land in Australia at some time near the end of this year. Did you found it less daunting travelling in India with a company than if you'd backpacked independently yourself?
fields.body:
Dear Sue,

I was particularly inspired by your travel journal in India and am now thinking of going there myself before I land in Australia at some time near the end of this year. Did you found it less daunting travelling in India with a company than if you'd backpacked independently yourself? I have to add that I am slightly "nervous" about doing this on my own and therefore I value any tips you have on the matter for lone travellers. In spite of my apprehension, however, I feel this could possibly be the best thing I could ever do, despite never having done anything like this in my life - is it as daunting as I think it may be?

PS any budgeting tips would be greatly appreciated!

Much respect to you.

fields.headline: Popstars get 70,000 hits
fields.trailText:
5.30pm: More than 70,000 fans deluged the Popstars' website last night to take part in a live web chat, writes Amy Vickers.
popstarsonline
fields.body:
Popstars' band Hear'Say continued their record-breaking run last night when more than 70,000 fans deluged their website to take part in a live web chat.

ITV servers groaned as more than 60,000 questions were thrown at the pop phenomenon within minutes of finding out they had reached number one.

The figures for the latest live video chat eclipses those set by the band's first public appearance following the episode in which the final five were revealed to the nation.

More than 48,000 took part in that live video chat on February 3, which at the time was acclaimed as the most successful online video chat for a UK TV programme.

The Popstars post-number one chat has also managed to eclipse the BBC News Online web chat with Russian President Vladimir Putin, who racked up a total of 24,000 questions from readers.

Hear'Say fans that couldn't get onto the web chat were able to console themselves by listening to a live phoneline version of the chat, which notched up some 349 hours listened to.

Questions asked of the Popstars included: "Can you do a cover of I've Got A Brand New Combine Harvester" and "If you were a kangaroo, what would you have in your pouch".

Even "Nasty" Nigel got involved, sending Hear'Say a message from Borneo where he is currently working on Survivor.

webTitle: Privy Council rejects Bolton Institute for university status

fields.headline: Privy Council rejects Bolton Institute for university status
fields.trailText: The staff of Bolton Institute for Higher Education have expressed 'bitter disappointment' that a four year struggle to become a university has been rejected by the Privy Council.
fields.body:
The staff of Bolton Institute for Higher Education have expressed 'bitter disappointment' that a four year struggle to become a university has been rejected by the Privy Council.

The institute, which offers its own undergraduate and higher degrees, was denied university status after advice to David Blunkett, the Education Secretary, from the Quality Assurance Agency.

Dr. Brian Iddon, MP for Bolton South-east who has been lobbying the Privy Council on behalf of the institute in his constituency, said he thought that Bolton had been treated very badly by the agency.

Relaying his conversation with the president of the Privy Council, Margaret Beckett, Dr. Iddon said: "I told her the institute was top of the league when it comes to access to higher education and that several quality assessments of its various departments had received very high marks since the QAA overall assessment. I pleaded with her to take independent advice before reaching a final decision in view of the facts that I laid before her."

Such pleading seems to have been futile, as the Council not only rejected the institute's application, but left little room for redress - there is no system for appeal within the application process.

A spokesperson for the QAA said: "The agency offered its advice against criteria for university title that are necessarily rigorous. Not every aspirant institution will be able to meet the criteria. But setting high standards safeguards the standing and reputation of United Kingdom universities generally."

Commenting on the decision, institute principal, Mollie Temple said: "Our staff and students are outraged and disappointed as the work they are doing is absolutely comparable with that of their peers across higher education and they and the institute deserve the recognition which comes with the university title."

She went on: "A particularly disappointing, and ironic, aspect of the decision is that Bolton Institute is exactly the kind of higher education institution which the government wants to see in the university sector: innovative, entrepreneurial, recruiting a high proportion of students from backgrounds where there is no tradition of higher education, and with a proven record of excellence in our teaching and standards."

The principal maintained that the institute will continue 'business as usual' because in practical term's, the Privy Council's decision will 'make no difference'.

She said, "We are already recognised by our peers and partners as a university in all but name, we are proud of our achievements, and we are more than content to let our track record speak for itself. We are happy to be judged by what we do, rather than by what we are called."

webTitle: Aussie universities battle to cope with digital copyright laws

fields.headline: Aussie universities battle to cope with digital copyright laws
fields.trailText: A raft of sweeping changes to Australia's copyright act has had lawyers from the nation's 39 universities scrambling to develop new guidelines on electronic communication for their institutions.
fields.body:
A raft of sweeping changes to Australia's copyright act has had lawyers from the nation's 39 universities scrambling to develop new guidelines on electronic communication for their institutions.

"This is like the millennium bug all over again," sighs Gillian Dempsey, a lawyer at the University of Queensland's TC Beirne School of Law. "There's going to be a lot more running around and pulling of hair before people realise that there's not too much to worry about."

Which isn't to say, she adds quickly, that her institution doesn't have more than a few concerns of its own.

Among the more notable amendments to the law is the bestowal of full copyright protection for works created or transmitted in digital form, which until now have not enjoyed the legal status of their hard-copy based counterparts.

The Digital Agenda Act, which came into force on March 4, recognises what it calls a "technology-neutral right of communication" for the authors of any written work, whether it be created with a quill pen or computer keyboard.

The law also imposes new civil and criminal penalties on the manufacture, importation and supply of so-called circumvention devices - which is to say, software designed to get around password protection or software locks.

Exceptions to the new rules include the "fair dealing" of material for the purpose of scholarly review or teaching, the right of library and archive copying for document for the purpose of supply and preservation, and the educational statutory licences which allow copying and communication of material for teaching purposes.

These and other changes impose new obligations on academics wishing to copy existing graphic works or broadcasts. In particular, it places restrictions on teachers using email to transmit copies of these works to their fellow staff members or students.

If, for example, a lecturer communicates one part of a licensed educational work by making it available online, no other lecturer at a university will be permitted to make another part of the same work available online until the first part is taken down.

"Administrators here are certainly concerned," says Neill Grant, a lawyer at the University of Southern Queensland, who has been working for the past three months on deciphering the implications of the legislation. "What I don't think they fully appreciate yet is the full extent of the problems we could be facing."

Earlier this month, the government's attorney general Daryl Williams warned Australians that they could even be breaking the law if they forwarded emails without the author's permission. His technical adviser told Australia's Sunday Telegraph that this might now constitute a technical infringement of copyright, as would be the publishing of material on a website without the author's consent.

The law makes no distinction in this respect between emails containing material crafted with obvious skill and labour, and plainly intended for commercial sale, and humdrum messages containing office gossip or holiday plans.

In addition, all material in online form will be deemed at the end of every 12 months to be a fresh reproduction and a fresh communication, and as such will require the fresh permission of its creator if it is to remain, for example, on a university's website.

"This is a very wide issue," says Rachel Vance, the legal officer at the Australian National University, in Canberra. Nevertheless, she adds, in the case of email communication "the new law doesn't change things as much as define them, by granting copyright to anything communicated."

One of the major concerns at ANU, and other institutions of higher learning, is the prickly, and as yet unanswered, question of what the new communication right will mean in monetary terms.

Universities in Australia currently pay considerable fees to collecting societies in order that they may access material. These societies could well use the law change to seek further remuneration from universities wishing to communicate the material, according to Ms Vance.

Little matter, says the University of Queensland's Dr Dempsey, for whom the most pressing concern is what she considers to be the technological illiteracy among her country's lawmakers.

As she explains it, the major problem with the recent changes to the Copyright Act is that the drafters "were attempting to deal with technologies with which they were not familiar".

"The real issue that exists, not only for academics but also for the general populous, is that the definitions within the Act are flawed."

In Dr Dempsey's view, the legislation reveals an ignorance of how modern computer programs work - as revealed, for example, in the fact that it is now illegal for Australian students to tweak or improve a firm's code - in other words, iron out bugs - in the interests of making a system run more efficiently and effectively.

The question now arises whether anybody at a university posting home-made "fixes" to sites are going to be caught for breach of copyright, she says.

"The law should offer a defence to prevent otherwise honest persons from liability in such cases."

fields.headline: VAT 'error' may mean entry charges
fields.trailText: The tradition of free admission to some of the oldest museums in England is under threat, because the university museums have been left out, apparently inadvertently, from the concession allowing non-charging museums to reclaim VAT announced in the Budget.
fields.body:
The tradition of free admission to some of the oldest museums in England is under threat, because the university museums have been left out, apparently inadvertently, from the concession allowing non-charging museums to reclaim VAT announced in the Budget.

Chancellor Gordon Brown's move was intended to introduce universal free admission to major collections, ending an anomaly that penalised free museums and dissuaded others from ending charges. Only the charging museums were regarded by customs and excise as operating a business, and therefore allowed to reclaim VAT. This cost the free museums millions - the British Museum faced a VAT bill of £5m for its Great Court development.

The vice chancellor of Manchester University has privately informed the government that he would consider introducing charges at Manchester Museum, which has one of the world's finest Egyptology collections, if the university museums were not given the same concession.

Other universities would be certain to follow. The list caught by the anomaly includes the world's oldest public museum, the Ashmolean in Oxford, the Fitzwilliam in Cambridge, and 15 others with collections designated as of national importance.

The director of the Manchester Museum, Tristram Besterman, who is leading the campaign to persuade the government to extend the provision, said: "If my vice chancellor introduces charges it would be a personal tragedy. I have spent my whole career in museums campaigning for free admission. But it would be intolerable if we alone were left unable to reclaim VAT."

At the Ashmolean, director Christopher Brown pointed out that since local authority museums could reclaim VAT through their councils, the university museums would be left as the only free museums in the country unable to reclaim VAT.

Related article
Fear for museums as lottery 'golden age' ends

fields.headline: Curious tale of the author and his two lovers who do not exist
fields.standfirst: Iris Murdoch's widower admits sexual partners were 'composite'
fields.trailText: Iris Murdoch's widower admits sexual partners were 'composite'.
fields.body:
It is a very peculiar sort of controversy. In an episode that turns the standard sex scandal on its head, the author John Bayley, husband of the late novelist Iris Murdoch, stands accused of not having sex with two women whose not entirely unwelcome advances he describes in the latest volume of his memoirs.

In Widower's House, an account of his life since the death of his wife in 1999 to be published on Wednesday, Bayley, 75, describes being hounded by two women, Margot and Mella, both of whom successfully press themselves upon him. Last week the Daily Telegraph ran extracts from the book, illustrating them with photographs of actresses knocking at the author's front door and mopping his kitchen floor. A footnote to the extracts reads: "Some names and minor details have been changed to protect the identities of those concerned."

The first two volumes of the memoir, which chronicle Murdoch's six-year struggle against Alzheimer's disease, reaped commercial success and critical acclaim. The first volume, Iris, was a surprise bestseller in 1998, while the sequel Iris and Friends, a distressing chronicle of her last days, was described by one critic as "the greatest love story of our age".

Yesterday, however, Bayley acknowledged that in Widower's House he had strayed into the realms of fiction, conceding that the amorous pair, a 30-something undergraduate (Mella), and a family friend (Margot) do not exist. Rather they are "composites" of real people.

Speaking from the Oxford home he shared with Murdoch and now with his second wife Audi, Bayley defended his decision to employ the techniques of the novelist when writing Widower's House.

Vulnerable

"It's simply that they are composite characters, they are both real and unreal. I obviously can't make a faithful portrait of people I know so I combined these various persons in the same way a novelist would," he said. "Characters are made up of people and things you observe. The two characters have their own sort of reality. They just sort of come to you. Most novelists will tell you it just happens, that they find themselves with a character who obviously has features of real people.

"I don't think of this being a novel. It is intended as a comedy on the theme of bereavement and what happens when one is all at sea, when the certainty of one's existence comes to an end.

"The point is to show what it is like to be in this very vulnerable situation. One is not allowed to get over it in one's own time... people always want to help," he said. "If you have been looking after someone for five or six years it is like being in a monastery, and when you are let out into the big wide world you hardly know what's happening. It is that situation I am trying to describe."

In the book Bayley writes of the unwanted attention he received after Murdoch's death, and the loss of the protective cloak of marriage. "Out of the ground had sprung a host of well-intentioned persons who wanted to make life nicer and less lonely for me... Widowers are prey to the whims of kindly women," he writes.

Chief among the predatory ladies, according to Widower's House, is Margot, whose first act is to cook him a casserole - "I have always disliked casseroles. During our 44 years Iris and I never made a casserole" - and later joins him under the duvet in the spare bedroom after inviting him to her Norfolk home for the weekend. "I remained as immobile as a spider trapped in an empty bath and uncertain in which direction to run. Margot's ample presence, now she had settled down, was indeed comfortable rather than the reverse, but not exactly comforting," he writes.

Mella, an undergraduate who "marks her territory" by cleaning the house, is more direct. "Slight and straight" in contrast to the "dark, ample, dynamic" Margot, Mella lures the innocent academic into her arms by feigning a dizzy spell and going to lie down upstairs. When he looks in to see how she is, she pounces.

"She sprang up, threw her arms around my neck and gave me several kisses at random. She continued to hug me, and I I did my best to detach myself. She pulled me down beside her on the bed. At least we were both fully clothed... A couple of hours later we were not."

Reflecting, Bayley writes: "It was ridiculous to have been manhandled as I had been by a slip of a girl. But there I was, an old gentleman who had never been particularly strong at the best of times."

While acknowledging that Mella and Margot were in essence fictional, Bayley yesterday remained coy about the practicalities and key events of the relationships on which they are based.

"It is true to say that I did have some sort of relations of that kind. The practicalities are made up but the relationships existed. The relations described and the people do exist, but they are changed." He added that he had not remained chaste after Murdoch's death. "Lots of people have sexual relations do they not?" he said.

Corinna Honan, assistant editor (features) of the Daily Telegraph, said: "We went ahead with the serialisation of John Bayley's new book after receiving categorical assurances that all major events in it actually took place. It was always understood - as both Jan Moir's interview with Prof Bayley and our extracts last week made plain - that certain details including names had been altered in order to protect the identities of 'Mella' and 'Margot'. "

John Bayley: a life in letters

 Born 1925

 After Eton, serves in the army from 1943-47 before gaining a first in English from New College, Oxford

 Member of St Antony's and Magdalen colleges 1951-55; tutor at New College 1955-74

 In 1956 meets and marries the love of his life, Iris Murdoch, at that time herself an academic with a fledgling literary career

 Appointed Wharton professor of English in 1974, a post he holds until 1992

 In the 90s Bayley writes widely for newspapers and becomes a highly regarded critic, but in 1994 Murdoch is diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease and Bayley devotes himself to her care

 After her death in 1999 he marries Audi Villiers, a widow and friend of Murdoch. "Audi and I talk incessantly about Iris; never stop, really. It's our favourite subject," he has said

 His greatest success comes with the memoirs Iris (1998) and Iris and Friends (1999), and he has written 15 other books including five novels and academic texts on Tolstoy, Pushkin and Shakespeare

webTitle: Fear for museums as lottery 'golden age' ends

fields.headline: Fear for museums as lottery 'golden age' ends
fields.standfirst: Over-expansion creates £29m a year in extra bills as rival attractions lure visitors away
fields.trailText: Museums will close and have their collections warehoused or scattered as the "golden age" of lottery-backed expansion comes to a halt, according to a report published today .
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Museums will close and have their collections warehoused or scattered as the "golden age" of lottery-backed expansion comes to a halt, according to a report published today .

The huge expansion, bringing science, environment and art-based attractions and extensions to museums, left the sector with an extra £29m a year bill for increased costs in a static or declining market, the author, Adrian Babbidge, suggested.

The most spectacular casualties so far are the Faith Centre in Bradford, the Centre for Popular Music in Sheffield and the Centre for the Visual Arts in Cardiff, but more closures are predicted for the next few years among the traditional museums.

Museums also face increased competition, from rival attractions and from innovations such as Sunday trading. Mr Babbidge, director of the East Midlands Museums Service, said that in his area the opening of Ikea, the furnishings store, has had a perceptible impact on museum visiting on Sunday, formerly the busiest day.

Mr Babbidge, who has also worked at museums in Essex and Wales, has published his grim forecast in Cultural Trends, the journal of the Policy Studies Institute.

He suggested that the museum sector had been expanding unsustainably since the 1960s. The lottery had provided a unique opportunity for funding to catch up.

However, his analysis shows that the bulk of the lottery money spent on museums since 1995, 55% of more than £500m, has gone on new museums, extensions or renewal of existing buildings.

Just under half the money went to national museums, but cash for the regionals, more than £300m, could have solved the problems of decades of underfunding, particularly the backlog of collections' care and documentation. Instead he calculated that the new spaces created would cost an extra £29m a year to maintain, making the problem worse.

The report shows a startling division in the government's regional spending on museums, from 6p per head of the population in the east midlands and 15p per head in the west midlands to £9.59 per head in the south-east, where most of the national museums, directly supported by the government, are concentrated. The north-west is in second place, at £2.63 per head.

The gap should be filled by local authority spending, but Mr Babbidge's figures show that after a slow rise until 1995 overall spending on revenue and capital support has been falling. The fall is steepest in the south-west: 6% down between 1994 and 1999.

His study suggests that part of the regions' problem is the rapid growth in the 1960s, when dozens of branch museums opened in libraries and other public spaces. Thirty-nine of these have closed, and he predicted more to come.

Wages in the sector were not only well below other public sector wages (in turn considerably lower than the private sector), said Mr Babbidge, but the gap was widening. In 1973 an average museum professional, with a degree and usually a post-graduate qualification, earned £2,178, compared with £2,464 for a graduate school teacher. The comparative salaries were now £16,771 and £23,193.

"Financial prospects for entrants are limited, at a time when most will have to begin to pay off overdrafts and student loans.For many, and especially for those from poorer families, a museum career is highly unattractive."

Mr Babbidge challenged the government to formulate a genuine national policy for all English museums, in which coherent decisions could be taken.

"Instead we get interventions in the market, like the recent announcement on VAT, which could make it cheaper for people to get on a train and go to the Science Museum in London, if it becomes free, than to visit their local museum if it charges.

"If museums are going to close, and I believe they will, there has to be a policy in place in which sensible decisions can be taken about the fate of their collections."

A Department of Culture spokesman dismissed the findings as unduly alarmist. "The problems of regional museums are precisely the remit of the task force recently announced by the government, and it would be wrong to prejudge their findings.

"Resource [the museums, galleries and archives council] is considering long term policy for museums and will also be deciding the best allocation of the £20m extra announced last year for regional museums."

Concepts that took the cash and failed

 The Life Force Centre, beside Bradford Cathedral, which cost £5m including a £2.2m millennium grant, closed last month after seven months. It was projected to attract 40,000 people a year, but in its first week had 62 paying visitors.

 The National Centre for Popular Music, in Sheffield, closed last August after 16 months. It cost £15m, with £11m in lottery grants. The spectacular building was projected to attract 400,000 people a year, but drew fewer than a quarter of that.

 The Centre for Visual Arts in Cardiff closed in November, after attracting 47,500 instead of 220,000 visitors in its first year. The transformation of a listed former library building cost £9m, including a £3m lottery grant.

Related article:
VAT error may mean entry charges

It was projected to attract 40,000 people a year, but in its first week had 62 paying visitors.  The National Centre for Popular Music, in Sheffield, closed last August after 16 months. It cost £15m, with £11m in lottery grants. The spectacular building was projected to attract 400,000 people a year, but drew fewer than a quarter of that.  The Centre for Visual Arts in Cardiff closed in November, after attracting 47,500 instead of 220,000 visitors in its first year. The transformation of a listed former library building cost £9m, including a £3m lottery grant. Related article: VAT error may mean entry charges

webTitle: Much about doing your nut in

fields.headline: Much about doing your nut in
fields.standfirst: It wouldn't be La Liga without someone going a bit doolally. This week it was Real Mallorca coach Luis Aragones and, as usual, Sid Lowe was there to see it
fields.trailText: Mallorca boss Luis Aragonés, who's known in Spain as The Wise Man of Hortaleza (and for "wise" read "mad"), is at it again.
fields.body:
Mallorca boss Luis Aragonés, who's known in Spain as The Wise Man of Hortaleza (and for "wise" read "mad"), is at it again.

At what? Doing his nut? Destroying the big-boys? Well, both: Real Madrid were in Mallorca on Sunday and Aragonés was on top form - whichever way you look at it. Having already taken four points off Depor and Barça this season, The Mad Man of Hortaleza completed the set by notching Mallorca's second victory over the league leaders this season.

The islanders were worthy winners, comfortably protecting the lead they got five minutes before half time when Miguel Soler - who seemed to be wearing a fan-belt round his head - swung in a far post cross for Luque to head home. Mallorca really should have won more comfortably, too - Samuel Eto'o, on loan from Madrid, appeared to be under orders not to upset his Real paymasters: he couldn't score to save his life.

But what of Aragonés's nut? Fear not, he was doing that, too. All game long, in fact. And then came the crowning glory. When the Mallorca boss substituted Albert Luque with Leonardo Biagini, the unhappy San Moix crowd proceeded to whistle the hapless Argentinian. The Mad Man of Hortaleza put his finger to his lips to shut the fans up. Fair enough, but when they didn't, Aragonés went all-out and produced that classic Spanish "gesture" - a "Corte de mangas" (a "Sleeve cutter"). That's an Up Yours to you and me.

Aragonés seems a bit confused - first he insisted he didn't do nuffink, Sir. "I touched my forearm", he explained, digging furiously, "but I didn't mean to make a gesture and if I've annoyed anyone I humbly ask for forgiveness as it wasn't my intention". Erm, OK, but then, realising that no-one believed him, Aragonés switched stories - "I want to apologise for my gesture, which was wrong", he said, "but I won't accept people jeering the players." Then came his second inspired excuse - "I was telling the fans to shut up and then I told them that the way they were going on if Biagini scores he'd give them a corte de mangas" he explained before helpfully adding "And that's the truth". Ah-ha.

1,500,000,000 and counting

Real weren't the only Big Boys losing in holiday destinations. On Tuesday Las Palmas were given fifteen days to find 1.500 million pesetas (about £6 million) or face liquidation. Things weren't looking too good on Thursday, with only 400,000 pesetas raised and club president Manuel García Navarro bizarrely blaming the press for discouraging investment with "negative reporting" (so it's their fault that two Las Palmas players held false passports?).

As the weekend approached, so did the saviours - in the form of a local business consortium which will invest between 700 and 800 million pesetas, with a view to making the club sad. Honest - S.A.D. is the Spanish version of Sports PLC.

What better way to celebrate than with victory over champions Deportivo La Coruña? Two Vinny Samways corners were Depor's undoing - Josico got the final touch to the first and Alvaro headed home the second just before half time. Depor manager Javier Irureta threw on four strikers (and this from a man who normally refuses to play two), but to no avail. Las Palmas, led by Paqui - who, with his coiffeured locks, really should be called Hunter or Warrior or something - defended resolutely, and were always dangerous on the break: the pace and directness of Turdó (wahey!), Guayre and Jorge was a constant threat.

They were loving it in the Estadio Insular, with Mexican waves, quality songs and three fans with going-home presents. Thank God for cash injections - three times the match ball (hardly cheap at 50-odd quid a go) reached the crowd. Three times it was sensationally caught (Iker Casillas take note). And three times it was stuffed up jumpers, never to be seen again.

Managerial merry-go-round Barcelona also stumbled at the weekend. Patrick Kluivert put them 1-0 up against Numancia, but the struggling sorianos grabbed an equaliser through Ruben Navarro. Serra Ferrer again whinged about bad luck, but he's not fooling anyone - it's no longer a question of whether or not he stays, it's more a case of when he goes.

And rumours abound that Barça's new boss will be the unloved Héctor Cúper after he announced this week that there's "a high percentage chance" that he'll leave Valencia. Cúper's probable departure might spark a game of managerial musical chairs (albeit one with enough chairs for everyone). If Cúper goes to Barça, his seat could go to Depor boss Javier Irureta, although he still might stay at Depor.

Irureta's job could then go to Aragonés, which'd leave a vacancy in Mallorca. And guess what? Lorenzo Serra Ferrer is a mallorquino, keen to go home. That's all sorted, then. Unless you're a Mallorca fan, that is - somehow I doubt they'll be over the moon with the seating arrangements when the music stops.

Back in black

Just in case you thought the refs have been disappointingly quiet this week, fear not. Even though Valeri Karpin scored a hat-trick and Vagner got a red card and an own goal, it was referee Arturo Dauden Ibáñez who stole the show as Valencia lost 3-2 to Celta de Vigo. He flashed nine yellows and gave three penalties - two that weren't and one that only might have been. There was a sneaky suspicion that he knew he'd gone wrong, too - Valencia's last minute penalty, which Kily González missed, had compensation written all over it.

No penalties (or red cards) but plenty of fun in Pamplona, where Osasuna came from 2-0 down to lead 3-2 against Málaga, only for Ariel Zarate to get a late, late equaliser for the malagueños. Six goals, too, between Villarreal and Racing de Santander, with the Yellow Submarine running out 4-2 winners.

Elsewhere

Espanyol's Sergio is a suspicious bloke. Either that or his team-mate Jordi Lardín is an evil prankster. José Antonio Camacho called up Sergio for the national squad in mid-week, but it was Lardín who broke the news. Not that Sergio believed him - "I told him that making up a call from Camacho just isn't on" he said, before discovering that the Spanish manager really did want him.

One man Camacho didn't want was Sergio's hamster-faced, driving-test-dodging team-mate Raúl Tamudo. Perhaps he should reconsider - Tamudo was decisive again, scoring the only goal of his side's clash with Valladolid.

There were also score-draws this weekend between Zaragoza and Athletic Bilbao (2-2) and Real Sociedad and Alavés, 1-1.

Finally, time for a spot of gloating. Something truly amazing happened in Vallecas this weekend - Real Oviedo won away for the first time all season. Frederic Danjou opened the scoring and Oli - a man who runs like he's got a pole up his arse - got the second as Oviedo stunned fans with a 2-0 win over Rayo. Bizarrely enough, the last time Oviedo won away, ten months ago, the victims were - you guessed it - Rayo Vallecano. Now then, what's the Spanish for Can we play you every week?

webTitle: Mark Lawson on Channel 4's Teachers and BBC2's Happiness.

fields.headline: Mark Lawson
fields.standfirst: Teachers, Channel 4's public-sector answer to This Life, is a risky proposition - classroom drama is notoriously unpopular with viewers. Can it make the grade?
fields.trailText: Teachers, Channel 4's public-sector answer to This Life, is a risky proposition - classroom drama is notoriously unpopular with viewers. Can it make the grade?
fields.body:
While it is normal for viewers to graduate from Newsround to watching News At Ten, drama about education has rarely been able to exploit its catchment group in the same way. The children's series Grange Hill is one of the longest-running TV dramas ever, but there have often been difficulties in persuading the audience to move up from little school to big school. Lucy Gannon's Hope And Glory, with Lenny Henry as a headmaster, was less popular than her other series; another TV writer, Jimmy McGovern, was also critically marked down for a show about teachers; and Steven Moffat, writer of the triumphant sit-com Coupling, preceded it with Chalk, a widely disliked comprehensive comedy.

The most likely explanation for this is that classroom fiction - from Jennings and Mallory Towers through to Grange Hill - has mainly been aimed at children. Adult licence-payers, on the other hand, find it regressive to look at rooms in which more than one character is sitting at a desk.

Teachers (Channel 4) is the latest attempt to take the form into long trousers. After the lessons learned from television history mentioned above, the advance publicity for the series has been careful to suggest that the action begins when the hometime bell goes. Channel 4 has implied an NUT version of This Life, one of the stars of which, Andrew Lincoln ("Egg"), plays Simon, the main teacher in this.

But, while Simon's sex life is intensely studied, his professional existence scores a good 60% of the air-time. Tim Loane's script is strongest when you feel you're getting staff room gossip, as, for example, in a scene where Simon bribes colleagues in the pub with drinks to mark his pupils' exercise books for him.

The first episode also contains a running discussion about teaching methods. In common with the heroes of all adult school dramas on TV or in cinema, Simon is an inspirational maverick who wins the respect of the students by breaking the rules. The kids address him by his first name and, teaching Romeo And Juliet, he effortlessly relates it to the world of hip-hop and condoms. Envious colleagues try to turn him into a bore at the blackboard. In other words, Simon is yet another fictional member of the Dead Poets Society.

If Teachers were a set text in TV Studies, you'd start your class by chalking up the words "Comedy Of Inversion". The main gag here is that the teachers do what students would usually be expected to do. Drunk after a party, the staff break in and vandalise the school; when asked by their pupils if they've finished marking the homework, they prevaricate with ridiculous excuses; they break the smoking ban in the lavatories and, eventually, Simon and a colleague are called to see the head after a fight. This back-flip gag makes a funny introduction to the series, but a car driven in reverse can only make a short journey.

There was once a television Head Of Comedy who marked prospective scripts like a teacher, acknowledging each joke with a large red tick. Only when the sheets of paper looked like the exercise books of the Head Boy fast-tracked for Oxbridge could the programme be commissioned. If Happiness (BBC2) were subjected to this process, the script's parents would be called in for urgent talks and the sit-com threatened with detention. But I am happy to act as the show's social worker.

Its truant humour and surly refusal to yell out punchlines when asked is all to a purpose. Starring Paul Whitehouse - who also co-wrote the series with David Cummings - this is a strange and bold attempt to make a sit-com about subjects traditionally confined to the coffin-shaped box of tragedy.

A Dr Freud of television comedy might surmise that Whitehouse, his pathway to success accelerated by The Fast Show, had come to worry that he was winning laughs too easily. Psychologically he needed to go for the hard laughs. The point of catch-phrase comedy is that the audience knows exactly when to laugh. The speeches of leading politicians are typed out with white spaces between phrase called "applause gaps". Sketch shows and traditional sit-coms are written with cackle gaps.

The writing in Happiness offers no such guidance. The opening scenes are admittedly skittish. Whitehouse's character, Danny, is a comedian who provides the voice of a popular children's character, a cuddly toy who combines martial and medical arts, called Kung-Fu Nurse Bear. We cut from this convincing silliness - the bear was made by Aardman, creator of Wallace & Gromit - to Danny waking bleakly alone in a double bed, then drinking whisky for breakfast. You guess divorce, but are surprised when the large chauffeur-driven car to which he walks in the next scene has the appearance of an undertaker's vehicle. It is. His wife has died.

It's not unprecedented for a sit-com to begin with a funeral - Penelope Keith's To The Manor Born did - but, where the Keith vehicle used the scene to introduce a merry widow, Whitehouse is a genuinely grief-stricken widower. Some people will object that it's mislabelling to call this a comedy, that it's like an advertised pop concert that turns out to consist of a piano concerto. But the gap between the pain of Danny's condition and the inanity of his profession serves as an extreme expression of the performer's dilemma. The project does feel psychologically motivated - a slow show after The Fast Show - but there's a pleasure in the risks it takes with sit-com.

 Teachers, Wednesday, 10pm, Channel 4. Happiness, Tuesday,10pm, BBC2.

fields.headline: £400m to ease schools crisis
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: The teacher shortage
fields.trailText: The government will today unveil £500m of extra spending for the NHS and education as ministers move to head off damaging revolts from doctors and teachers in the run-up to the general election.
fields.body:
The government will today unveil £500m of extra spending for the NHS and education as ministers move to head off damaging revolts from doctors and teachers in the run-up to the general election.

In an attempt to sweet-talk angry GPs, the prime minister will announce the setting up of a £100m fund that will hand every surgery in England and Wales an extra £10,000 a year if doctors sign up to a modernising contract to improve primary care.

At the same time the education secretary, David Blunkett, will announce a £400m package to train and recruit teaching assistants in the classroom. Amid fears of industrial action over teacher shortages, the Mr Blunkett will pledge the extra money until 2004.

The minister will say that teaching assistants have played a crucial role in raising standards in literacy and numeracy. "Teaching assistants enable pupils to work in smaller groups, help tackle their specific problems and assist teachers to raise standards," he will say.

In a sign of the government's determination to concentrate on health and education in the run-up to the election, Tony Blair will use a speech today to the Royal College of General Practitioners to outline how more cash and more powers will be directed to "frontline" doctors.

Doctors will receive an immediate payment of £5,000 which will be doubled by the end of the year if they meet targets drawn up by local pri mary care trusts. These could include extending surgery opening hours, providing better care for coronary or cancer patients or attending GP training centres.

Mr Blair's gesture comes in the face of warnings from doctors' leaders of a new confrontation with the government during the general election campaign. The British Medical Association is to produce a patients' dossier that will show the suffering caused to patients when doctors in the hard-pressed NHS are forced to cut corners.

The prime minister will attempt to calm the atmosphere today, but he will make clear that he will not hand out cash indiscriminately.

"I want to reward effort and enterprise wherever it is found in public service," Mr Blair will declare. "I know that teachers, police officers, nurses and NHS staff do not come into public service primarily to make money. They are motivated by a sense of vocation. That is something beyond price. The public and the government value their commitment, but I see no reason why staff who do a good job for the public should not be rewarded."

The speech comes days after the health secretary, Alan Milburn, unveiled a series of initiatives to persuade GPs to remain in the NHS. Lump sums of £5,000 are to be paid to every new GP, while an additional £5,000 will be paid to any GP willing to work in a deprived area. The government pledged in last year's NHS plan to appoint an extra 2,000 GPs in England by 2004, although the BMA demanded 10,300.

Mr Blair will attempt to meet some of the BMA's complaints by announcing that the government will dramatically increase the number of GPs between 2004 and 2010. Mr Milburn will announce an extra 550 GP training places and an extra 400 GP trainers.

The prime minister will also announce plans for a cut in red tape faced by doctors. GPs will no longer have to sign pensioners' driving licence forms, passport applications and postal vote applications. This will free up 750,000 GP working hours, which works out at one appointment a day for every doctor in the country.

Mr Blair will also make clear that Labour plans to hand more power and more money to frontline primary care groups. He will point out that GPs will be responsible for 75% of the NHS budget by 2004, compared with 15% in 1997.

In his speech Mr Blair will hail a report into the health service's performance this winter as a sign of the dedication of NHS staff. The report, which is to be published today by the NHS chief executive, Nigel Crisp, shows that the NHS avoided a repeat of last year's winter crisis thanks to a 40% increase in the number of flu vaccinations. More than 10m people were vaccinated, including nearly two-thirds of people aged over 65.

The public and the government value their commitment, but I see no reason why staff who do a good job for the public should not be rewarded." The speech comes days after the health secretary, Alan Milburn, unveiled a series of initiatives to persuade GPs to remain in the NHS. Lump sums of £5,000 are to be paid to every new GP, while an additional £5,000 will be paid to any GP willing to work in a deprived area. The government pledged in last year's NHS plan to appoint an extra 2,000 GPs in England by 2004, although the BMA demanded 10,300. Mr Blair will attempt to meet some of the BMA's complaints by announcing that the government will dramatically increase the number of GPs between 2004 and 2010. Mr Milburn will announce an extra 550 GP training places and an extra 400 GP trainers. The prime minister will also announce plans for a cut in red tape faced by doctors. GPs will no longer have to sign pensioners' driving licence forms, passport applications and postal vote applications. This will free up 750,000 GP working hours, which works out at one appointment a day for every doctor in the country. Mr Blair will also make clear that Labour plans to hand more power and more money to frontline primary care groups. He will point out that GPs will be responsible for 75% of the NHS budget by 2004, compared with 15% in 1997. In his speech Mr Blair will hail a report into the health service's performance this winter as a sign of the dedication of NHS staff. The report, which is to be published today by the NHS chief executive, Nigel Crisp, shows that the NHS avoided a repeat of last year's winter crisis thanks to a 40% increase in the number of flu vaccinations. More than 10m people were vaccinated, including nearly two-thirds of people aged over 65.

fields.headline: Scots fear new exams fiasco
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: A repeat of last summer's exams crisis is feared with news that the Scottish qualifications authority has fallen behind in preparing for this year.
fields.body:
A repeat of last summer's exams crisis is feared with news that the Scottish qualifications authority has fallen behind in preparing for this year.

With less than two months to go before pupils sit exams, the authority has missed a deadline for sending information to schools, is behind in preparing exam papers, and is short of 2,000 experienced markers despite recruiting early on improved pay.

Tests of its computer also found a higher error rate than last year, and the date for issuing results has been put back by a week to August 15. Ministers will question the authority's chief executive, Bill Morton, tomorrow in the Scottish parliament.

First minister Henry McLeish promised last year there would be no repeat of the fiasco that saw 17,000 pupils sent late, incomplete or erroneous results. Some appeals over grades have yet to be decided.

A report concluded that failures at board and management level within the authority were to blame. It was restructured, and the day after being confirmed as Labour leader in Scotland last December, Mr McLeish said the problems of 2000 would "never happen again". The delay this year is over forms the authority should have sent out a week ago that schools have to complete before March 31 to estimate a pupil's performance and expected exam grade.

"This shows the authority is struggling to keep abreast," said Ronnie Smith, secretary of the main teaching union, the Educational Institute of Scotland.

"The more slippage there is, the more schools will lose confidence."

The authority said the delay was to ensure the estimate forms were accurate.

webTitle: Vaccination may be alternative to slaughter

fields.headline: Vaccination may be alternative to slaughter
fields.standfirst:
Farmers are dismayed by government plans to contain foot and mouth by destroying healthy animals. Could inoculation be the answer, asks environment correspondent Paul Brown?

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Farmers are dismayed by government plans to contain foot and mouth by destroying healthy animals. Could inoculation be the answer, asks environment correspondent Paul Brown?
fields.body:
The current policy of slaughter to eradicate the foot and mouth outbreak is being reconsidered by the ministry of agriculture as the number of cases reaches epidemic proportions and the idea of using vaccines becomes more attractive.

Influential vets, some with experience of using vaccination to combat the spread of the disease in other countries, have been increasingly vocal as the difficult task of carcass disposal has dismayed both farmers and the public.

Vaccination would end the need to immediately slaughter healthy animals in who have come in contact with the disease. It would also end the problem of decomposing carcasses in fields being eaten by rats and crows - although there is scant evidence that this spreads the disease, since the rats and crows would have to carry infected meat to other farm animals.

But vaccination is no easy answer either, because of the commercial penalties it imposes. There are two alternatives: either vaccinating millions of farm animals, or just vaccinating those in the immediate area of an outbreak, creating what is termed a "fire break", to prevent the disease spreading to new areas.

The idea of vaccinating everything has immediate appeal, because after all that is how humans eradicated smallpox, and the move is favoured by animal welfare groups. However, commercially the idea does not make such sound sense.

The world is divided into places that have foot and mouth and those that are disease free - and until four weeks ago the UK and the whole of the EU came into the latter category.

A disease free status has enormous commercial advantages because it means meat, animal products, live animals, bull semen, and high value pedigree stock can be exported anywhere in the world. Once stock becomes contaminated by foot and mouth, export bans automatically follow and cannot be restored until the disease has been eradicated.

If a country has vaccinated animals, then the disease free status is lost even if there are no active outbreaks. To regain it then, the animals that have been vaccinated in the "fire breaks" have to be slaughtered. Only then when all the diseases and vaccinated animals are dead can exports begin again, and then only after an interval of three to six months, depending on the rules of the importing country.

Vets in favour of vaccination are divided on whether it is necessary to slaughter the vaccinated animals or let them live out their lives "normally", having young free of the disease and so continuing pedigree lines that might otherwise be lost. This latter course would mean a much longer period before the disease free status could be regained.

The good news is that plenty of vaccine exists: 10m doses in the EU, and plenty readily available in the UK. There are three types because there are three strains of foot and mouth, but type O vaccine, of the type the UK would need, is available.

So the issue is not whether vaccination works - it does. The argument is whether it is the best method of eradicating the disease in the quickest time and returning the farming industry to "normal".

As the number of outbreaks continues to increase, the pro-vaccination lobby is gaining ground. So far the ministry is not convinced, although a contingency plan is actively being worked on.

The likely outcome of the great vaccination debate is too close to call. The decision rests mainly on whether the current policy of containing the disease works. If it fails, then vaccination is the only remaining option.

webTitle: John Sutherland: How America's roads became safer thanks to a bunch of Madd women.

fields.headline: John Sutherland
fields.standfirst: How America's roads became safer thanks to a bunch of Madd women - and where the US goes, we follow
fields.trailText: How America's roads became safer thanks to a bunch of Madd women - and where the US goes, we follow.
fields.body:
If he is keeping a chart, Peter Noble is two weeks into his jail-time. He is the driver, you will recall, who drank 13 pints, killed six people and got 15 years. Lobbyists hailed Noble's record-breaking sentence as a breakthrough. A welcome sign that the bench was, at long last, getting serious about drunk drivers.

Serious drinkers (10% of the male population, by the latest estimate) furtively touched wood when they read the verdict. Historians of penology will see Noble's sentence as evidence of Britain falling into line with the US. As, after a few years, we invariably do.

Twenty-one years ago a drunken hit-and-run driver knocked down and killed a little girl on the quiet California street where she lived. He was just out of jail on bail (another hit-and-run offence) and had two previous drink-drive convictions.

Despite his record, the driver and his lawyer plea-bargained the charge down to "vehicular manslaughter". The judge determined that this was no murderer but a pathetic alcoholic and merely insisted, by way of penalty, that he go and live in a halfway house, get treatment and stay off the public highway in future. A judicious and humane verdict, you might think.

Women friends of the bereaved mother thought otherwise. They were so incensed by the sentence (guys going easy on guys) that they formed a protest and pressure group, Mothers Against Drunk Drivers - Madd. There was no question about the "drunk drivers" they had in mind. It was a gender thing. A war of sex against sex.

Madd's core belief is that "Driving under the influence is not an 'accident'. DUI is a crime!" Screw "understanding". Throw the book at the drunken bums, jail them, and lose the key.

The group's name was inspired. Mad mothers terrify even the hardest men. Bloodstained Medea is Madd's matron saint. At the same time, the group's name was politically canny. No (male) American politician is going to oppose anything with motherhood in the title. He might as well spit on the voter's baby.

Madd's growth since 1980 has been spectacular. Reagan couldn't wait to give them their own "Presidential Task Force". Congress fell over itself to sign a "National Drunk and Drugged Driving Awareness Week" into law. By 1985 there were 350 chapters, countrywide. With fame and success, Madd mellowed a tiny bit. They changed their target words from "drunk drivers" to "drunk driving". It wasn't quite as personal any more. But the flavour of the group remains, to this day, militantly feminist. Drunk driving, as Madd sees it, is essentially violence against women.

Following the example of other women's groups they have set up educational, volunteer, and victim-support programs. They operate 24-hour telephone hotlines. Madd organises write-ins to get state and federal laws changed and passed. Currently, they are agitating for the Victims of Crime Fairness Act ("fairness", like "motherhood", is a word that grabs the American politician by the goolies).

Madd is credited with the federal imposition of a .08 blood alcohol content standard of drunkenness and the passing, in 1984, of the "21" drinking-age bill. It is strictly enforced and has made the adolescents of America very mad.

After the Kentucky bus crash which killed 27 people in 1988, Madd got random tests made mandatory for all drivers of public transport vehicles. It was Madd who, in 1995, popularised the term "zero tolerance", Jack Straw's stale mantra. Its most striking effect has been on enforcement and punishment. In America, judges and police chiefs are elected by their local communities. Thanks to Madd, no more soft cop for DUIs. If you test positive it's handcuffs, the drunk tank and big-stick punishment. Draco was the law-giver who invented zero tolerance. I've often meant to look up the sources to see if his draconian regime actually worked.

America's streets are safer. Madd claims to have cut alcohol-related road deaths by a quarter. Its members aim to reduce them a further third (from 16,000 to 11,000 a year) by 2005. At which point Peter Noble will still have 10 years left on his chart. Let's hope his mother, at least, loves him.

webTitle: Teachers threaten to step up action on shortages

fields.headline: Teachers threaten to step up action on shortages
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Industrial action by teachers over staff shortages is to be extended around the country over the next few days, with the results of further ballots due at the end of the week.
fields.body:
Industrial action by teachers over staff shortages is to be extended around the country over the next few days, with the results of further ballots due at the end of the week.

Members of the two largest classroom teaching unions - the National Union of Teachers and the National Association of School Masters/Union of Women Teachers - have so far voted in 10 areas of England to refuse to cover for unfilled posts or absences of more than three days. Hundreds of schools could be forced to introduce shortened timetables and send children home against the wishes of their parents.

The first threats of the so-called "cover to contract" action - effectively a work-to-rule - affected schools in London and Doncaster at the end of last week.

On Thursday Rangefield primary in Lewisham, south London, for example, was forced to send home 27 pupils when staff refused to cover for a sick colleague, and the headteacher said she did not know what would happen this week.

Schools in Manchester, Middlesbrough, Leicester, Southampton, Portsmouth, Reading, Nottingham and Kent could be affected later this week. Results from ballots in Birmingham are expected at the end of the week.

Ministers have been critical of teachers for agreeing to take part in the action, claiming they will damage their pupils' education in the run-up to national tests and public exams.

Employers have already threatened to dock the pay of teachers who take part in the action by up to £250 a day.

Yesterday NASUWT leader Nigel de Gruchy went further by claiming the Department for Education and Employment was putting intense pressure on heads and local authorities to cut teachers' pay in these cases.

"The DfEE is phoning up headteachers and local education authorities warning them that if they don't impose excessive pay deductions, they will have to watch themselves in future," he said. "I've never known such a brazen-faced and cowardly attempt to browbeat employers."

A spokesman for the DfEE rejected those claims. "No one at the DfEE has even remotely made the threats described.

"We are doing everything possible to ensure schools don't send pupils home. We are acting responsibly in the interests of pupils. The fact is that most schools are getting the supply staff that they need. Local education authorities will act as employers to deal with contractual obligations - teachers have to cover where all other avenues have been exhausted," he said.

 The Independent Schools Council, the umbrella body for more than 500 fee-paying schools, will publish a consultative paper today to stimulate "public debate" on how places at private schools can be funded from the public purse.

webTitle: Ferrari perform a hot Schu shuffle

fields.headline: Ferrari perform a hot Schu shuffle
fields.trailText: The world champion's tyre switch leaves the other cars standing Michael Schumacher's amazing ability to walk on water left the rest of the formula one paddock bedazzled and sceptical in equal measure, as the Ferrari team leader romped to his second successive win of the season in a Malaysian grand prix thrown into turmoil and confusion by a tropical downpour only two laps into the 55-lap race.
fields.body:
The world champion's tyre switch leaves the other cars standing Michael Schumacher's amazing ability to walk on water left the rest of the formula one paddock bedazzled and sceptical in equal measure, as the Ferrari team leader romped to his second successive win of the season in a Malaysian grand prix thrown into turmoil and confusion by a tropical downpour only two laps into the 55-lap race.

This was Schumacher's 46th career win and his sixth successive triumph since Monza last year, achieved behind the wheel of his spare Ferrari F2001, which he took shortly before the start after traces of a possible oil leak were detected on his No1 machine.

It was a stunning performance which saw the German at one point lapping 6.3sec faster than the third finisher David Coulthard's McLaren-Mercedes on a track which was still patchy damp as it dried out in the sweltering heat.

However, the performance of the Italian cars inevitably rekindled the distrust and suspicion that has existed in the formula one fraternity over the past few years over the possible use of traction-control systems which, although now illegal, will be allowed for the fifth race of the season.

These systems, which can effectively reduce the power delivery to the rear wheels when they detect any possibility of wheelspin, can be duplicated legally by complex electronic engine-mapping which anticipates wheelspin.

Within the formula one regulations there is a fine but very specific dividing line between the two systems, and there is no doubt that Ferrari's system - deemed legal by the FIA - does a remarkably effective job. Yet such was the magnitude of Schumacher's victory that many faces wore a quizzical expression at the end of the afternoon.

But in reality the outcome of the race was decisively influenced by an inspired strategic call from the Ferrari team management. They gambled to switch their cars on to intermediates rather than full rain tyres when they splashed into the pits at the end of the fourth lap as the heavens opened and cars spun in all directions.

However, it was a nerve-rackingly close call for the famous Italian team. On lap three both Ferraris had flown off the road on a patch of water at the point where Olivier Panis's BAR-Honda had spun off after its engine expired. And the pit stop was botched when Schumacher had to queue behind Barrichello after a dithering pit crew put a full wet tyre on the Brazilian's right front before quickly replacing it with an intermediate to match the other three wheels.

But Ferrari were immeasurably assisted by a safety car which stayed out from lap three to lap 10, enabling Barrichello and Schumacher to catch up the tail of the queue led by Coulthard. And once the pack was unleashed again the Ferraris simply stormed into fast-forward action, Schumacher slicing ahead of his team-mate on lap 12 to take sixth place.

"It was a very exciting race," he said. "It was my decision to fit intermediate tyres, which we knew would be difficult at first but would be better when the rain eased.

"After the pit stop I asked if the team had made the right changes to the car because it was difficult to drive, but it got better as the race went on. The conditions were atrocious and undriveable, and at times the safety car was quicker than us."

Coulthard kept manfully ahead until lap 15 but it was a lost cause. He was on full wets, grappling with incipient understeer, while the Ferraris were using their intermediates to brilliant, some would say scarcely credible effect.

Barrichello went through into second at the end of lap 16 and from then on the Ferrari team-mates waltzed away with the race, which strengthened their grip on the points table.

Not that the race finished with unconditional love and kisses between the Ferrari drivers. Barrichello said the uncompromising manner in which Schumacher had passed him was "a bit sad". The Brazilian, who had already collided with Schumacher's younger brother Ralf on the first corner, had just told Ferrari's technical director Ross Brawn over the radio that there was a lot of dirt on the circuit and that Michael needed to take care. But clearly the champion had his own ideas. "Michael took a chance," said Barrichello. "It was not what you would expect a team-mate to do."

Schumacher countered: "We're team-mates, we respect each other, we leave each other room not to hurt each other, but I was on a better go and I was faster as well. We are in equal situations so you fight for the position; I don't think that's unreasonable."

McLaren's chief executive Ron Dennis criticised what he saw as Ferrari's massive gamble of switching to intermediates. "There was absolutely no way we would have put our drivers on to intermediates," he said. "David was complaining that conditions were impossible at 100mph. In rain like that you can't take the decision to put drivers' safety at risk in conditions like this."

Both McLarens came home in the points, Mika Hakkinen coming sixth, unable to pass Ralf Schumacher's Williams-BMW despite rattling off four consecutive fastest laps on new rubber after a late second pitstop; both finished behind Heinz-Harald Frentzen's fourth-placed Jordan and ahead of Jos Verstappen, a superb seventh in the Arrows A22. But Dennis put a gloss on the result. "I felt we were in good shape, but they were in a difficult situation and they took a calculated risk. But I think these things reverse themselves over time."

Coulthard's assessment of the McLaren situation was more downbeat. "We know we've still got a long way to go," said the Scot. "We were one second a lap off the pace in Australia and two seconds a lap away here. Yes, it's pretty grim."

fields.bodyText: The world champion's tyre switch leaves the other cars standing Michael Schumacher's amazing ability to walk on water left the rest of the formula one paddock bedazzled and sceptical in equal measure, as the Ferrari team leader romped to his second successive win of the season in a Malaysian grand prix thrown into turmoil and confusion by a tropical downpour only two laps into the 55-lap race. This was Schumacher's 46th career win and his sixth successive triumph since Monza last year, achieved behind the wheel of his spare Ferrari F2001, which he took shortly before the start after traces of a possible oil leak were detected on his No1 machine. It was a stunning performance which saw the German at one point lapping 6.3sec faster than the third finisher David Coulthard's McLaren-Mercedes on a track which was still patchy damp as it dried out in the sweltering heat. However, the performance of the Italian cars inevitably rekindled the distrust and suspicion that has existed in the formula one fraternity over the past few years over the possible use of traction-control systems which, although now illegal, will be allowed for the fifth race of the season. These systems, which can effectively reduce the power delivery to the rear wheels when they detect any possibility of wheelspin, can be duplicated legally by complex electronic engine-mapping which anticipates wheelspin. Within the formula one regulations there is a fine but very specific dividing line between the two systems, and there is no doubt that Ferrari's system - deemed legal by the FIA - does a remarkably effective job. Yet such was the magnitude of Schumacher's victory that many faces wore a quizzical expression at the end of the afternoon. But in reality the outcome of the race was decisively influenced by an inspired strategic call from the Ferrari team management. They gambled to switch their cars on to intermediates rather than full rain tyres when they splashed into the pits at the end of the fourth lap as the heavens opened and cars spun in all directions. However, it was a nerve-rackingly close call for the famous Italian team. On lap three both Ferraris had flown off the road on a patch of water at the point where Olivier Panis's BAR-Honda had spun off after its engine expired. And the pit stop was botched when Schumacher had to queue behind Barrichello after a dithering pit crew put a full wet tyre on the Brazilian's right front before quickly replacing it with an intermediate to match the other three wheels. But Ferrari were immeasurably assisted by a safety car which stayed out from lap three to lap 10, enabling Barrichello and Schumacher to catch up the tail of the queue led by Coulthard. And once the pack was unleashed again the Ferraris simply stormed into fast-forward action, Schumacher slicing ahead of his team-mate on lap 12 to take sixth place. "It was a very exciting race," he said. "It was my decision to fit intermediate tyres, which we knew would be difficult at first but would be better when the rain eased. "After the pit stop I asked if the team had made the right changes to the car because it was difficult to drive, but it got better as the race went on. The conditions were atrocious and undriveable, and at times the safety car was quicker than us." Coulthard kept manfully ahead until lap 15 but it was a lost cause. He was on full wets, grappling with incipient understeer, while the Ferraris were using their intermediates to brilliant, some would say scarcely credible effect. Barrichello went through into second at the end of lap 16 and from then on the Ferrari team-mates waltzed away with the race, which strengthened their grip on the points table. fields.headline: NHS plan: the basics
fields.trailText: • The NHS plan, published in July 2000, is the government's blueprint for reform of the NHS.
fields.body:
 The NHS plan, published in July 2000, is the government's blueprint for reform of the NHS.

 It promises to maintain the NHS as a universal public service, free at the point of delivery, with access based on clinical need rather than ability to pay.

 It insists on radical changes to improve the quality of NHS care, drive up efficiency and make the health service more patient-centred.

 Massive investment is promised to recruit more staff and improve staff pay and working conditions, build more hospitals and health centres, buy more medical equipment and cut waiting times for treatment.

 A range of measures to carry forward the plan's aims have followed its publication, including the setting up of the NHS modernisation agency, and the publication of the health and social care bill.

fields.headline: Treasury backs down over press proposals
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: The Treasury has conceded self-regulation is the best option for the financial journalism, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Treasury has caved in to pressure from the Press Complaints Commission and the newspaper industry and agreed the proposed rules on financial journalism are "unworkable".

The proposals were dropped after the PCC and individual newspaper executives persuaded the Treasury the plans would be "wrong in principle and unworkable".

And the Treasury has conceded self-regulation is the best option for the industry.

"We're always pleased when there's some threat of statutory control and that threat is seen off," said PCC director Guy Black.

The commission has issued a "best practice note" to supplement the guidelines.

The note makes some concessions to the proposed guidelines by recommending journalists and editors should make "external disclosure", that is, they should publish details of their financial interests.

The note says this should be done "where appropriate or, if in doubt, it should be considered best practice".

The commission also recommends journalists should disclose any interest - however small - to their managers.

The note clarifies some previously hazy terms in the code of practice on financial reporting.

On example is the definition of the term "securities", which it specifies includes not just stocks and shares but derivatives and spread bets.

The PPC also recommends editors and managers should order a journalist to "unwind a transaction" if an interest is disclosed.
