fields.headline: Hear'Say
fields.standfirst: The winners of TV's Popstars have confounded their critics with a record-breaking debut single. Here's our guide to the best sites on the pop sensation of the year
fields.trailText: The winners of TV's Popstars have confounded their critics with a record-breaking debut single. Here's our guide to the best sites on the pop sensation of the year.
fields.body:
1. It was one in the teeth for critics of manufactured pop bands last night, as the first Hear'Say single went straight to the top of the pop charts.

2. Having beaten off the challenge of thousands of other wannabe celebs in a series of TV auditions, the band was unveiled in February, and now has a No 1 hit with Pure & Simple. The song was (don't tell anyone) originally going to be released by teeny pop rivals GIRLthing.

3. The winners of the smash TV show Popstars - Noel, Suzanne, Myleene, Kym and Danny - can hardly believe their sudden success, but you can already get odds of 6-1 on them having the 2001 Christmas No 1.

4. It wasn't just a traumatic time for the pop hopefuls, however, as Ian Johnson, PR for the ITV show, describes in his diary of the TV event.

5. Not that any of this is exactly a new idea. Like Big Brother and Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, Popstars is a global franchise.

6. You can check out the progress of girl band Eden's Crush in the US, or see how the show is doing Down Under, where it produced girl band Bardot.

7. In the US, Popstars was an all-female version of the show Making the Band, which created you guessed it, an all-boy popular beat combo.

8. But not everyone loves the idea, with one American journalist berating the producers for the sartorial image of the young female pop singers.

9. Life's different in the UK though. According to today's Sun, it's more than just hear say that none of the band's female contingent are happy with a certain part of their anatomies too large, too small, too near the ground. Will this mean a boon for cosmetic surgeons?

10. Ah well, if all this brings forth complaints about the state of modern music and manufactured bands, then check out details of The Monkees' 2001 reunion tour Who said pop ain't what it used to be?

fields.headline: Margaret Ewing
fields.standfirst:
Moray (1987- )
Dunbartonshire East (1974-79)

Ask Aristotle about Margaret Ewing
fields.trailText: The Scottish National party's Margaret Ewing bears a surname that is famous, at least in Scottish politics. Her husband, Fergus Ewing, is the MSP for Inverness East, and her strident mother-in-law, Winnie Ewing, has been both an MEP and MP and is now the MSP for the Highlands and Islands. Margaret Ewing, too, has a place in the front rank of the history of her party.
fields.body:
The Scottish National party's Margaret Ewing bears a surname that is famous, at least in Scottish politics. Her husband, Fergus Ewing, is the MSP for Inverness East, and her strident mother-in-law, Winnie Ewing, has been both an MEP and MP and is now the MSP for the Highlands and Islands. Margaret Ewing, too, has a place in the front rank of the history of her party.

She first entered Westminster at the age of 29 when, as Maggie Bain, she became MP for East Dunbartonshire. The MP for Moray (until the 2001 election) and now also the seat's MSP, Mrs Ewing remains a parliamentary force to be reckoned with, although today her work is done in Edinburgh rather than Westminster.

The daughter of a ploughman, she joined the SNP as a 20-year-old at Glasgow University where she was training to be a teacher. Nine years later, in October 1974, she won Dunbartonshire East by just 22 votes - one of 11 SNP MPs elected that year, to the terror of the Scottish Labour party.

That victory may have put out of joint the nose of her first husband Donald Bain - who failed in his own effort to become an SNP MP - and certainly her first marriage became hot news during the 1995 Perth and Kinross byelection, when the SNP candidate, Roseanna Cunningham, temporarily stood down because of false accusations that she had broken up the Bains' marriage. Mrs Ewing responded by saying that "foolish, prurient" stories 18 years after a non-event had "no present relevance" and insisted that there was no animosity between her and Ms Cunningham; Ms Cunningham subsequently won selection and the May 1995 byelection.

After losing her Dunbartonshire East seat in 1979 after campaigning on the need for an oil revenue fund to save the Scottish economy, she was mentioned as a possible contestant for Glasgow Hillhead in 1982 and contested Strathkelvin and Bearsden in 1983. But it wasn't until June 1987 that she returned to Westminster to represent Moray, her mother-in-law's former seat, beating Alex Pollock on a 6% swing from Tories to the SNP.

Although a seasoned and extremely able parliamentarian, Margaret Ewing was overshadowed by Alex Salmond's provocative political attacks, which enabled him to defeat her in the 1990 contest for the SNP leadership. Normally a deft parliamentarian, she burnt her fingers in 1993 when an attempted deal with the Conservative Scottish secretary, Ian Lang - which would have given Scotland representation on the EU's regional committee in exchange for SNP votes for the Maastricht treaty - fell through.

She has excelled as an abnormally active constituency MP for two beautiful counties on Scotland's distant north-east coast. Because of their chilly climate, she became one of the original crusaders for extra winter heating payments and better insulated housing. She has also campaigned for lighter taxation for whisky on behalf of the 40 distilleries in her constituency.

She has had lots of friends outside the SNP, not only in the press gallery, but among Labour MPs. She is against nuclear weapons and capital punishment, and tolerant of homosexuality. But she has to walk softly on abortion because of the puritanism of many of her smalltown voters.

fields.headline: Frank Field
fields.standfirst:
Birkenhead (1979-)

Ask Aristotle about Frank Field
fields.trailText: Frank Field, the priest-like Labour MP for Birkenhead, is treated with respect by his Tory opponents, if not always by his own party. This is not because of his deeply held Christianity. It is because of his working class parents, who imbued him so strongly with the spirit of hard work and self help that he sits at odds with the philosophy of his own party. His "unlovely truths" have often been closer to the thinking of Tory Peter Lilley than to any Labour colleagues.
fields.body:
Frank Field, the priest-like Labour MP for Birkenhead, is treated with respect by his Tory opponents, if not always by his own party. This is not because of his deeply held Christianity. It is because of his working class parents, who imbued him so strongly with the spirit of hard work and self help that he sits at odds with the philosophy of his own party. His "unlovely truths" have often been closer to the thinking of Tory Peter Lilley than to any Labour colleagues.

Mr Field is also a relentless egalitarian, a crusader for the poor to better themselves. "He has no doubt that we are all endowed with the divine capacity of self improvement," said Roy Hattersley.

He carries this strange certainty with mixed political baggage. A one time supporter of the alternate vote system of electing MPs, he has many Tory friends and, like many Tories, he is against German domination of Europe and against the euro.

Born into a London Tory family in 1942, he joined the Young Conservatives at 16. But he left for the Labour party the next year because of his aversion to apartheid in South Africa.

He made his reputation as an uncomfortable crusading pamphleteer while director of the child poverty action group, then the low pay unit. His well leaked report that the poor had got poorer under Harold Wilson played some part in helping Labour lose the 1970 election.

When Mr Field inherited his Birkenhead seat from Edmund Dell in 1979, it came with endangered shipyards. It also came with a nest of zealous local activists who tried to oust him. But he held firm and refused their pressure to support Tony Benn for deputy leader in 1981. A year later he urged Michael Foot to stand down as leader.

At one point the hard-left local activists even managed to deselect him as the Labour candidate. After a struggle he had the decision overturned by the NEC and was restored to fight the 1992 election.

Mr Field worked as opposition front bench spokesman on education and then became the respected chairman of the social security select committee (1990-1997). As such he made his mark as the only British politician prepared to question the basic principles of the welfare state.

In 1997 Tony Blair sent him to the Department of Social Security. Field wanted a Cabinet job running the department and initially had the prime minister's backing in this. But Blair was talked out of it instead asked him to serve under Harriet Harman as minister for welfare reform, asked by the prime minister to "think the unthinkable".

His appointment brought high expectations. They were not to be realised partly, as Field suggested in his Commons resignation statement a year later, because of a civil war which broke out between his department and Gordon Brown's Treasury over his plans for compulsory private pensions.

For good measure, he also fell out with Harriet Harman: insiders at the Department of Social Security said that the pair were barely on speaking terms. It was reported at one stage that they had met formally just once.

After just 15 months both were sacked, with Mr Field protesting that "there was long effort to make sure I was neutered and sidelined in the Department of Social Security. This was led by Harriet Harman and her accomplices."

In true new Labour style he was savaged in the Sunday newspapers following his departure. He has since harboured understandable grudges and become a candid friend of the government.

fields.headline: Dr Julian Lewis
fields.standfirst:
New Forest East (1997- )

Ask Aristotle about Dr Julian Lewis
fields.trailText: To everyone's surprise, the parliamentary career of scholarly, eccentric Dr Julian Lewis has been outstripped by his streetfighter friend John Bercow, now deputy to Ann Widdecombe as Conservative spokesman for the Home Office. Mr Lewis and Mr Bercow shared the helicopter which enabled them on the same day to be selected for safe Tory seats: New Forest East and Buckingham and both were elected for the first time in 1997.
fields.body:
To everyone's surprise, the parliamentary career of scholarly, eccentric Dr Julian Lewis has been outstripped by his streetfighter friend John Bercow, now deputy to Ann Widdecombe as Conservative spokesman for the Home Office. Mr Lewis and Mr Bercow shared the helicopter which enabled them on the same day to be selected for safe Tory seats: New Forest East and Buckingham and both were elected for the first time in 1997.

Dr Lewis was thought better qualified for a front rank career, as the respected, even feared, former deputy director of the Conservative research department who resigned in 1996 because the Major government had been inadequately opposed to the single currency.

But his encyclopaedic knowledge of the cold war, which made him such a feared opponent of CND leaders, seemed dated by the time he reached the Commons in 1997.

His almost paranoid fear of a federal Europe might have made him the philosopher king of the Europhobes who crowded the Conservative benches after 1997. But this missed the emotional core of his fear: that a federal Europe will be dominated by Germany.

This comes from the eastern European roots of his family, many of whom were killed by the Nazis. When Tony Blair authorised British force to rescue Kosovars from Serbian genocide, Dr Lewis was one of only four Tory MPs to back him fully, in contrast to the little Englanders in his party who opposed intervention.

If he misses the press plaudits won by his old ally Mr Bercow when slugging it out with Jack Straw, he doesn't show it. Dr Lewis seems happy enough in parliament, serving on the defence select committee, boiling arguments down in letters to the press opposing a European army and defending America's role on this side of the Atlantic.

These scholarly arguments do not produce the fanfare of publicity he achieved in the 1980s as the Tories' "witchfinder general" and "scourge of the CND". Then, he saw proponents of unilateral nuclear disarmament as fools who would happily hand the USSR a monopoly of nuclear weapons.

The strength of his opinions is belied by his baby face and soft voice with its remnants of a Welsh accent. He was born in Swansea in 1951, the son of a tailor. From Dynevor grammar school he progressed to Balliol College, Oxford and then to St Anthony's College where he achieved a DPhil in strategic studies.

He broke on the political scene in Newham North East in 1976-77, when he infiltrated the local Labour party to fight leftwingers trying to oust its Labour MP, Reg Prentice, later a Tory MP and minister.

Forming the coalition for peace through security, he then harried Bruce Kent, the CND's leader. In 1982 he drowned out an anti-Falklands war demonstration led by Tony Benn and Arthur Scargill by playing the national anthem. He had a banner, "President Reagan Is Our Friend", fly over another CND demonstration. Those were his days.

He broke on the political scene in Newham North East in 1976-77, when he infiltrated the local Labour party to fight leftwingers trying to oust its Labour MP, Reg Prentice, later a Tory MP and minister. Forming the coalition for peace through security, he then harried Bruce Kent, the CND's leader. In 1982 he drowned out an anti-Falklands war demonstration led by Tony Benn and Arthur Scargill by playing the national anthem. He had a banner, "President Reagan Is Our Friend", fly over another CND demonstration. Those were his days. Ask Aristotle about Dr Julian Lewis

fields.headline: Francis Maude
fields.standfirst:
Horsham (1997-)
Warwickshire North (1983-1992)

Ask Aristotle about Francis Maude
fields.trailText: Francis Maude is not a happy warrior. Mournful earnestness is more his style. This figures. As shadow chancellor in 1998 he did not lay a glove on Gordon Brown except for coining the phrase "stealth taxes" and lost credibility for claiming a "recession made in Downing Street" when none took place.
fields.body:
Francis Maude is not a happy warrior. Mournful earnestness is more his style. This figures. As shadow chancellor in 1998 he did not lay a glove on Gordon Brown except for coining the phrase "stealth taxes" and lost credibility for claiming a "recession made in Downing Street" when none took place.

Nor has the Eurosceptic Tory done better against Robin Cook as shadow foreign secretary. Mr Cook has a habit of reminding him how much he gave away to the EU when negotiating the Maastricht treaty with John Major.

Then there was an almost tearful radio interview in 2000 when Mr Maude seemed bitter about his unknown detractors, said to be Michael Portillo's supporters, who have destroyed his chances of succeeding William Hague. Alan Clark confirmed Mr Maude's mournful personality in his Diaries: "tearful" Maude, with "puffy eyes" had turned cry baby when denied promotion.

That is unfair. He is a profound man, and far from the moralistic mould of Ann Widdecombe. Clever and hardworking, he went to school in Australia, where his father edited the Sydney Morning Herald. He won prizes at Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, and the Inns of Court School of Law and practised as a barrister before moving into politics with his election to Westminster in 1983.

His father Angus, also an MP, was one of Margaret Thatcher's earliest supporters. She promoted Francis to the Department of Trade and Industry, as minister for corporate and consumer affairs. Controversially, he resisted the early ban in furniture of intensely flammable polyurethane and his department relicensed Barlow Clowes, a fund management company which, it emerged later, was fraudulent.

Under John Major Mr Maude rose to become financial secretary to the Treasury, where he co-signed the Maastricht treaty in place of a sceptical Norman Lamont - an embarrassment for one who backed Eurosceptic Michael Howard in 1997.

On the brink of entering the cabinet his career took a blow. In 1992, he lost his marginal North Warwickshire seat, despite winning more votes than at the election before. Until then he had seemed one of the brightest, hardest working, deft and reasonable sounding of the younger radicals.

In his wilderness years outside parliament he found a lucrative job as managing director of the US investment bank, Morgan Stanley, as head of their privatisation division. Newly prosperous, he returned to parliament after winning the safe seat of Horsham in 1997. But his 1992 setback seems to have unnerved him and, despite holding two frontrank jobs under William Hague, he has kept a low profile. For instance, during his time as shadow culture spokesman in 1997-98, he effectively twitted Christ Smith on becoming a convert to the success of the national lottery, but was much more cautious in criticising the Millennium Dome. In the Commons he wanted to rewrite the very Maastricht treaty he had negotiated.

Former Tory MP and Times sketchwriter Matthew Parris thought he had "lost his nerve in the House". Mr Maude admits he is "a classic, buttoned-up middle class Brit", "not at all clubbable", and that he bought himself a Jaguar XJS "during my midlife crisis". And his ears still go pink when he is embarrassed.

fields.headline: Ken Livingstone
fields.standfirst:
Brent East (1987-)

Ask Aristotle about Ken Livingstone
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's Labour party is in trouble. London mayor Ken Livingstone has promised to "support" Labour in the looming election, presumably like the hangman's noose "supporting" a condemned man. This is no wild guess. After I wrote in an earlier profile that Ken was "plotting to inherit Labour's leadership when the Brown-Blair economic plans crash", he shouted to me across the Lords' lobby: "You read my mind!"
fields.body:
Tony Blair's Labour party is in trouble. London mayor Ken Livingstone has promised to "support" Labour in the looming election, presumably like the hangman's noose "supporting" a condemned man. This is no wild guess. After I wrote in an earlier profile that Ken was "plotting to inherit Labour's leadership when the Brown-Blair economic plans crash", he shouted to me across the Lords' lobby: "You read my mind!"

Born in Lambeth in 1945, Ken's parents were working class Tories: his father, Robert, a merchant seaman who came ashore as a window cleaner, his mother, Ethel, a dancer, usherette and shopworker.

At 11 he opposed the 1956 Suez invasion, was an anarchist in his twenties, and by 1969 became secretary of the Young Socialists in Norwood, a centre of Trotskyite infiltration. That same year he made his first contacts with Irish republicans, committing himself to the "Troops Out" campaign by 1972.

By then already committed to "municipal socialism", he had been elected to Lambeth council, along with John Major. In 1973 he was returned to the Greater London council, representing Norwood. He failed to win the Hampstead parliamentary seat in 1979 but was re-elected to the Greater London council, this time for Paddington, in 1981. That year he established himself as a devious manipulator by organising his successful campaign to lead the GLC behind the back of the designated moderate, Andrew (later Lord) Mackintosh.

Also in 1981 he became joint editor of the semi-Trotskyite Labour Herald with "Red Ted" Knight. The Labour Herald derided the Labour leadership of Neil Kinnock and Roy Hattersley as the rightwing "Haddock ticket", inferior to its Bennite leftwing rivals.

Having decided on multi-ethnic Brent East as a safe Labour seat, in 1982 he won a runoff against Gerry Byrne, the socialist organiser, to try to oust Brent East's mainline Labour MP Reg Freeson. His controversial candidacy was delayed a few years, but he took the seat - with a reduced majority - in 1987.

He was treated as a leper by most other Labour MPs for having made the Labour party unelectable through actions such as sponsoring Peter Tatchell as the homosexual leftwing candidate for Bermondsey, which was lost to the Liberals.

Throughout his parliamentary career, which will end at the next election, he used his platform to make accusations, including, in his maiden speech, labelling the IRA-murdered Airey Neave as a co-conspirator with MI5 and MI6.

Mr Livingstone has been a consistent thorn in the side of the Blair administration. He was overwhelmingly elected on an independent platform as London's mayor after the party leadership resorted to Tammany Hall-style vote rigging to stop him winning the Labour candidacy.

His latest confrontation is over the financing of the tube. Exploiting the public's post-Hatfield suspicion of even part-privatisation, Mr Livingstone demanded that John Prescott - who still has control over the tube until public private partnership deals are signed - make tube boss Bob Kiley privy to all Mr Prescott's negotiations with his part-privatisation partners, even before Mr Kiley signed his contract. Since the mayor assures us that Mr Kiley is the "best expert on this planet", this may seem reasonable to Mr Livingstone's adoring public.

Even before the mayoral ballot, anyone who has ever travelled with Ken learns how well his humorous, "cheeky-chappie" approach enthuses fellow Londoners. Travelling home together from Westminster on the Jubilee line, it has long been impossible to have a discussion with him without being interrupted repeatedly by his adoring public wanting to greet him.

The adoration of those enthused by his image is in sharp contrast to those leftwingers who have been closest to him in his political home, the hard-left Campaign group of the parliamentary Labour party. Whether it be Dennis Skinner, Tony Banks or Brian Sedgemore, they all have words of scorn. This is because he has treated the Commons as a personal convenience, only turning up when he could speak. So unpopular was he that when he sought to imitate Tony Benn and challenge the Smith-Gould leadership in 1992 in tandem with Bernie Grant, he could only secure 13 instead of the needed 55 sponsors from the PLP. Just before his death, Bernie Grant also turned on Mr Livingstone as "an opportunist, he's got his own agenda."

If Mr Livingstone has lost his chance of becoming the "Red Knight" of the hard-left, he has won his battle to become Londoners' "cuddly Ken". He encouraged this again by proclaiming that Bob Geldof would stage London's greatest New Year's Eve party, before ensuring the availability of enough police or transport workers to bring Londoners safely into the centre and back home again.

Mr Livingstone has been incredibly lucky in getting away with holding contradictory and flawed views. He switched from being an opponent of an elected mayor to becoming its leading beneficiary. He was able to oppose US participation in evicting Saddam Hussein from Kuwait in 1990-91 as "imperialist", while later calling on Washington to send 25,000 troops to evict Slobodan Milosevic from Kosovo. He blamed Labour's 1992 defeat on its proposal of higher taxes, but when he opposed John Smith for the leadership his platform backed higher taxes on the rich.

Nobody seems to have noticed the failure of his prediction that Gordon Brown's economic policies would produce an economic crash in 1999-2000. Occasionally, it seems, his early Trotskyite sympathies re-emerge to dominate his thinking.

fields.headline: Alan Milburn
fields.standfirst:
Darlington (1992- )

Ask Aristotle with Alan Milburn
fields.trailText: Alan Milburn's detractors enjoy recalling his time spent in Newcastle's political bookshop Days of Hope - locally tagged 'Haze of Dope' - as an agitator against local shipyard closures. More than 17 years on, as health secretary, he is entrusted with the job which many think the Labour government's future overwhelmingly depends on: improving the NHS with the extra money allowed by Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
Alan Milburn's detractors enjoy recalling his time spent in Newcastle's political bookshop Days of Hope - locally tagged 'Haze of Dope' - as an agitator against local shipyard closures. More than 17 years on, as health secretary, he is entrusted with the job which many think the Labour government's future overwhelmingly depends on: improving the NHS with the extra money allowed by Gordon Brown.

A north-east native, he studied at John Marlay school in Newcastle and Stokesley comprehensive in Cleveland, before going to Lancaster University for his BA in history. He never finished a PhD at Newcastle University, on 18th century radicalism in the north-east, but his commitment to the left was clear enough. He sold Marxist literature, was active with the local CND and also worked for local trade unions.

Elected for Darlington in 1992, he was an active Commons questioner, especially on matters relating to the NHS. As a Blairite, he was quickly identified after 1997 as one of the higher fliers in the government's middle ranks.

His promotion to the cabinet was constantly touted and came about in 1998 when he became chief secretary to the Treasury. A year later he replaced Frank Dobson as secretary of state for health.

He is noted for his punchy Commons debates and for slugging it out with Jeremy Paxman on Newsnight. But refreshingly, when he does not know the answers, such as when he was asked about the first of the £2m contributions to Labour's kitty, he openly proclaimed his ignorance.

In paying tribute to the warmth of Tow Law, the county Durham mining village in which he was brought up, he talks of its "staunch Labour environment". Born to a single mum who worked as a secretary in the local NHS, it can't have been an easy life. He appears to be strengthened by the experience.

fields.headline: Michael Martin
fields.standfirst:
Glasgow Springburn (1979-)

Ask Aristotle about Michael Martin
fields.trailText: If genius is the capacity for taking infinite pains, then Michael Martin, the first Catholic Speaker since the Reformation, is a genius - despite sneers about his lowly Glasgow origins and accent. With two years of hard slog in the tearoom and some highly skilled tactical planning, Mr Martin outclassed a dozen others the contest for the Speaker.
fields.body:
If genius is the capacity for taking infinite pains, then Michael Martin, the first Catholic Speaker since the Reformation, is a genius - despite sneers about his lowly Glasgow origins and accent. With two years of hard slog in the tearoom and some highly skilled tactical planning, Mr Martin outclassed a dozen others the contest for the Speaker.

His planning was illustrated by an incident in January 1999 when the first story emerged that Betty Boothroyd was thinking of standing down.

A group of Labour MPs were in Australia on a parliamentary visit when one pretended that he would stand, as a drastic reformer. All but one of his colleagues promised to support him - the exception said he could not back him because he was "already part of Mick Martin's campaign team".

This long planned campaign had tactical brilliance. From the start, Mr Martin recognised his own weakness as an orthodox, rather old-fashioned Roman Catholic, opposed to abortion and to lowering the age of consent for homosexuals. He had been one of only six Labour MPs to voted against legalising homosexual sex at 16. These two stands put him against new young women Labour MPs, who universally backed both reforms.

Two years ago he set about neutralising all these expected antagonisms by "working the tearoom". This meant cultivating new young women MPs who would otherwise disagree with them, helping in his genial fatherly way to solve their problems as new MPs and congratulating them in handwritten letters on their maiden speeches.

When the speakership election finally took place in October 2000, not only was he flanked by young women MPs on either side, but he was nominated by Ann Keen, the icon of the "gay sex at 16" brigade for having led the crusade.

The upshot of Mr Martin's two-year campaign was that he defeated all his 11 opponents, including the highly-qualified one nation Tory, Sir George Young, for whom Tony Blair indicated his preference and for whom Commons leader Margaret Becket, parliamentary Labour party chairman Clive Soley and dozens of other Labour MPs voted. Mr Martin to beat this highly articulate Old Etonian by 317 to 241.

Virtually all the Tory MPs abstained from the final vote to endorse him, with eight even voting against him - although this risked being ignored when, in the future, they wanted to catch his eye and speak in debates.

Their hostility was an expression of class-based detestation towards Glaswegian machine politics. This was echoed by journalists who recalled his role in barring hacks unaccompanied by MPs from the Commons' riverside terrace, an attractive place on warm summer evenings.

Michael Martin emerged from the "lost generation" of Labour MPs - so tagged by former prime minister James Callaghan - who were elected in 1979, just as the Tories took over for 18 years.

He represents Springburn, the safest Labour seat in Glasgow, with among the highest concentration of council housing in Britain. Its inhabitants are mostly poorly-paid and the number of its unemployed is among Glasgow's highest.

Mr Martin shared his constituents' background. His father was a merchant navy stoker (his ship was torpedoed three times during the war). His mother, a school cleaner, had to bring up five children on her own after her husband's death.

Mr Martin himself had to leave St Patrick's boys school at 16 to start an apprenticeship at a local train-repairing workshop. He moved on to become a sheetmetal worker at Rolls Royce Aero Engines, becoming an AUEW shop steward.

It was as a union organiser for NUPE that he got into his political stride. In congratulating him on his election as the Speaker, Charles Kennedy, leader of the Lib Dems, recalled when Mr Martin had organised a very welcome NUPE strike at young Charles's school.

In 1973 Mr Martin was elected to Glasgow corporation and to Glasgow district council the next year. In 1978 he was selected to replace Richard Buchanan as the candidate for Springburn.

Once in the Commons, the closest he got to power was as parliamentary private secretary to Denis Healey in 1981-83. He failed to shine as a parliamentary orator and was never promoted to Labour's front bench.

Instead he made his way up the parliamentary ladder, dutifully serving on committees. He earned brownie points as chairman of the administration committee, organising childcare vouchers for the Commons staff. After serving for 10 years on the chairmen's panel, he became deputy speaker in 1997. This whetted his appetite for the top job.

As Speaker, he has started by being tough, cutting short wordy MPs if they cannot formulate an intelligent question within a minute. He even invited one Tory, John Butterfill, to leave the chamber when he challenged the Speaker privately for not calling him in a debate on the Middle East. Genial, but with claws, he lacks Speaker Boothroyd's showgirl charm.

fields.headline: John Bercow
fields.standfirst:
(Buckingham 1997-)

Ask Aristotle about John Bercow
fields.trailText: If anyone deserves the title of "son of Tebbit" it is John Bercow, the Tory MP for Buckingham. A pint sized chap with short arms and endless ambitions, his biting Commons performances and his win in 1997 against the grain of Tory losses catapulted him from the backbenches into Ann Widdecombe's home affairs team, despite his record as a former member of the far-right Monday Club.
fields.body:
If anyone deserves the title of "son of Tebbit" it is John Bercow, the Tory MP for Buckingham. A pint sized chap with short arms and endless ambitions, his biting Commons performances and his win in 1997 against the grain of Tory losses catapulted him from the backbenches into Ann Widdecombe's home affairs team, despite his record as a former member of the far-right Monday Club.

There is one difference between Norman Tebbit and John Bercow. John's father did not need to "get on his bike" because he was a minicab driver. Otherwise, everything Mr Bercow does reminds old timers of Mr Tebbit: a savage political streetfighter, ever ready to slug it out with his opponents, unafraid to land low blows. And more than Mr Tebbit, Mr Bercow researches before he attacks, a trick learned at Essex University and from his friend Dr Julian Lewis, a fellow rightwinger in the 1997 Tory intake. Mr Bercow remembers what he discovers, using the information in hardhitting speeches which are written out and then committed to memory. This tactic enabled him to reach the frontbench in July 2000 as a home affairs spokesman, eclipsing Dr Lewis, who has performed below expectations in parliament.

fields.headline: Gordon Brown
fields.standfirst:
Dunfermline East (1983-)

Ask Aristotle about Gordon Brown
fields.trailText: Known as the iron chancellor, Gordon Brown possesses the evangelical sincerity of a Scottish puritan and at times resembles a latter-day John Knox.  He became notorious during Labour's first two years in office for sticking to Conservative spending plans Since then he has opened the government's purse strings a little while developing vast budget surpluses and spreading a little joy.
fields.body:
Known as the iron chancellor, Gordon Brown possesses the evangelical sincerity of a Scottish puritan and at times resembles a latter-day John Knox. He became notorious during Labour's first two years in office for sticking to Conservative spending plans Since then he has opened the government's purse strings a little while developing vast budget surpluses and spreading a little joy.

He has retained his gloomy, brooding dominance, stomping about the Treasury while shaping the nation's finances, planning his party's election strategy and plotting - perhaps - his eventual acquisition of the highest political job of all.

Mr Brown learned his oratorical mixture of Presbyterian doom and self-satisfied righteousness at the feet of his Labour-voting father, a Church of Scotland minister, who descended from Dunfermline farm labourers. At the age of 12 he volunteered to canvas against Sir Alec Douglas-Home at the 1963 Kinross and West Perthshire byelection.

His ambition was evident from the time he reached Edinburgh University, where he chaired its Labour club and became the second student to win election as rector of its student court. By 1977, at 26, he was elected to Labour's Scottish executive and in 1983 he was elected to super-safe Dunfermline East. In the Commons he came of age in 1988 when, in the absence of John Smith, he made mincemeat of the then chancellor, Nigel Lawson.

His increasing commitment to politics suppressed his other interests, including rugby. As a schoolboy he lost the use of his left eye during a game - blighting his hope of becoming a professional footballer.

Until his 2000 marriage to public relations executive Sarah Jane Macaulay, his workaholic tendencies had hindered romance although his previous girlfriends included Sheena Macdonald, Marion Calder and, above all, Princess Margarita, the eldest daughter of exiled King Michael of Romania. She said: "It was a very solid and romantic story. I never stopped loving him but one day it didn't seem right any more, it was politics, politics, politics, and I needed nurturing."

At Labour's Brighton conference in September 2000 it became clear he is a scrooge-santa, one who can only be "generous" in a way he dictates. Only the poorest and next-poorest pensioners can benefit from increases, says Mr Brown. Pensions cannot be linked to national income because he dislikes giving to the one-sixth of pensioners already receiving more than £20,000 annually.

His unbending belief in his own judgement has placed him under enormous pressure, not merely in September 2000 when he was publicly attacked by Barbara Castle MP, John Edmonds from the GMB and Rodney Bickerstaffe of Unison after he defied the wishes of the majority of Britain's 11m pensioners.

But Mr Brown's frugality has also helped him gain a praetorian guard of admirers, led by close adviser Ed Balls. These, plus the fine-tuned treasury machine, keep him in touch with complex world financial movements, helping him to avoid blunders like that of August 1992. Then, in opposition, he resisted all efforts by Labour colleagues to advocate lowering the alignment of sterling in the ERM, only to see Britain ignominiously expelled.

He can win favour as the "red chancellor" with brilliant, tongue-chewing, Tory-baiting speeches that, more often than not, manage to hit opponents in the solar plexus while amusing his own side with wit.

His classic hit in 1991 was sneering at the Tory finances as dependent on "a Greek millionaire moving his money out of [Greek] colonels into Majors". John Major was so upset by this baiting that he tagged him "a specialist in personal abuse."

For his career to move up another notch he must manoeuvre successfully to win allies among the rival fiefdoms which make up the Labour cabinet. He was very accomplished in building such links until Tony Blair slowly twigged that he was surrounded by Brownite allies and neutered Nick Brown, one of the chancellor's major supporters, by moving him from chief whip to agriculture minister in the 1998 reshuffle.

But Mr Brown still has Alistair Darling at social security, Clare Short at international development and Andrew Smith backing him up as chief secretary.

The biggest longterm battle that he faces concerns the euro. Although at heart a pro-european, Mr Brown was the first disciple to become ultra-cautious about the timing of joining the euro. This has since been justified by the currency's tumbling value and its rejection by the Danes. He imposed his caution on the Blair government through a typically cunning manoeuvre, spelled out in Andrew Rawnsley's recent book.

In October 1997 he encouraged Philip Webster, political editor of the Times, to run a story which said he did not want to enter the euro for the lifetime of the 1997 parliament, having only discussed it cursorily with the PM for five minutes. This stunt, fog-horned by his spokesman Charlie Whelan down a mobile phone in a pub, was designed to outflank Blair, Peter Mandelson, and Robin Cook, the foreign secretary - are all advocates of entering the euro.

Mr Brown reserves special strength of feeling for Mr Mandelson, who switched horses from Brown to Blair in the 1994 Labour leadership campaign, following John Smith's death. Mr Mandelson, quite accurately, judged Mr Blair was more likely to radically change the party. Faced with this betrayal, Mr Brown reluctantly agreed to give Mr Blair a free run for leader, provided he was offered shadow chancellor and chancellor.

But his ambition for the top job has never waned. With Mr Mandelson now in exile on the backbenches Mr Brown has the opportunity to gain more allies by running a good election campaign. He will use this as a platform to build a warmer relationship with the public and party staff. If he is able to secure support for his longterm succession in the country and in Millbank then he will be on his way to capturing the job he wants. He'll then be able to move from No 11 Downing Street to his dream house - No 10.

fields.headline: Charles Clarke
fields.standfirst:
Norwich South (1997-)

Ask Aristotle about Charles Clarke
fields.trailText: Bearded, thickset Home Office minister Charles Clarke is one of the hottest tips for promotion to the cabinet if Labour retain power at the next general election. If he makes it, it will be thanks to his abilities outweighing his slightly unfashionable past: Mr Clarke was Neil Kinnock's top aide when the carrot-haired Welshman was Labour's leader.
fields.body:
Bearded, thickset Home Office minister Charles Clarke is one of the hottest tips for promotion to the cabinet if Labour retain power at the next general election. If he makes it, it will be thanks to his abilities outweighing his slightly unfashionable past: Mr Clarke was Neil Kinnock's top aide when the carrot-haired Welshman was Labour's leader.

Mr Clarke's friends, hearing him in the Commons and increasingly in the media, know how long his past with Mr Kinnock has kept him on the outside. Only in October 1996 did he become a last minute replacement for the ailing John Garrett in Norwich South, making him one of the multitudinous and ambitious "class of 97". Along with Patricia Hewitt, another former Kinnock aide, he was one of the first of the intake promoted to office, initially as parliamentary secretary for education in July 1998.

Appointed as minister of state for the Home Office in July 1999, he has become a buttress for Jack Straw, because he has the brains to master his full brief and is articulate enough to argue it against his political opponents without losing his cool. He also put up an impassioned defence of Tony Blair's much derided on the spot fine policy - showing that he is now well and truly among the New Labour fold.

The only thing which seems to have gone is the smiling humour which characterised his beer-drinking days in the post-Kinnock, pre-Norwich wilderness years.

Mr Clarke's genes were provided by his father, Sir Richard Clarke, KCB, former permanent secretary at the ministry of technology, and his psychologist wife. Charles was educated at Highgate school and King's College, Cambridge, where he became president of the union in 1972. Between 1975 and 1977 he was president of the NUS.

As a student radical he fought with communists as well as Conservatives, working with Peter Mandelson, Paul Boateng, Fiona Mactaggart and even Nigel Evans, now a Tory frontbencher, to block extreme leftwing motions. Alongside Mr Mandelson, he visited Cuba to organise a world youth festival. For both it was a potent training ground for their later political careers.

Back in Britain, after working in Hackney and being elected a Hackney borough councillor, he worked for Neil Kinnock, first as researcher, then as his trusted chief of staff. As such he was Mr Kinnock's intermediary and support in the trickiest situations. With Patricia Hewitt, he helped write Mr Kinnock's famous 1985 conference speech attacking Liverpool's Militants.

When Mr Kinnock failed to win the 1992 election and stepped down, Mr Clarke learned swiftly how out of favour become the aides of former leaders. He had to become the chief executive of a consultancy advising the association of district councils.

However good his contacts, his pursuit of parliamentary seats proved difficult. Before he found Norwich South, he was shortlisted for Newham North East, but lost out in a controversial, and rerun, selection contest.

After winning in Norwich in 1997, with a comfortable 14,239 majority, he took up where he had left off with Neil Kinnock - heading for the top.

fields.headline: Frank Dobson
fields.standfirst:
Holborn and St Pancras (1979- )

Ask Aristotle about Frank Dobson
fields.trailText: Bearded, chubby Frank Dobson must rue the day in 1999 he agreed to leave the Department of Health to run as Labour's first candidate for mayor of London. He failed badly against Ken Livingstone and has been something of a lost soul ever since.
fields.body:
Bearded, chubby Frank Dobson must rue the day in 1999 he agreed to leave the Department of Health to run as Labour's first candidate for mayor of London. He failed badly against Ken Livingstone and has been something of a lost soul ever since.

He had reluctantly given up a job he loved and was doing well, in order to help out the prime minister. Instead, Mr Dobson's campaign, which he said "could scarcely have been handled worse" by Millbank, led to defeat. In May 2000, he crawled in third behind the independent frontrunner, Ken Livingstone and Tory Steve Norris. This humiliating result effectively ended his career as a frontline politician.

That made his partial recall to Labour colours as a campaigner welcome news for colleagues who felt he had been treated very badly.

His new role, from December 2000, was to lead counterattacks against Conservative political offensives. It plays to his strength as a partisan with bluff common sense and a knockabout style that appeals to ordinary Labour supporters. As a jolly Yorkshireman with an old left outlook, he may well attract just those voters in the northern working class whom Millbank fears may not turn out on polling day. Only smaller private audiences, though, will hear his unrivalled collection of dirty jokes.

The return of such a figure is all the more important since Mo Mowlam, who filled a similar role, decided to retire. Yet Mr Dobson's efforts to bounce back may be shortlived. Nearing 61, he cannot count on returning to the cabinet of an ageist prime minister, especially not as the head of a great department such as health.

That is a pity because he was an impressive health secretary between 1997 and 1999, appointing more women and ethnic minorities to trust boards while nudging suspicious consultants and warmly encouraging nurses. What he lacked was the inside track connections with the Treasury exemplarised by his successor, Alan Milburn.

Mr Dobson is a committed politician who gave up a well paid, secure job in the electricity industry, initially becoming a Camden councillor and then leader of Camden council in London. He became MP for Holborn and St Pancras in May 1979.

He had come to London from Donnington, Yorkshire, where both his grandfather and father were railwaymen. Young Frank was the first from his village primary to pass the 11-plus exam and make it to Archbishop Holgate's grammar school in nearby York. Although his father died of kidney failure as he finished, a council grant enabled him to go on to London School of Economics.

At 27 he married Janet Aker, Hackney council's well paid assistant director of education. The couple raised two sons and a daughter in their Great Russell street mansion flat.

He made his name in the Thatcher era as a punchy partisan, opposing President Reagan's address to parliament, exposing "ripoffs" and fighting apartheid in South Africa, which later earned him touching thanks from Nelson Mandela.

In the 1990s he consistently received a large vote in the annual shadow cabinet elections. This was in part because he swept up the votes of both London and northern MPs and more importantly because of his successful campaigns against the privatised utilities.

After the election came his high profile role at the health department, before final defeat in the London mayoral elections. Mr Dobson will easily secure re-election for as long as he chooses to stay in the Commons. The question will be whether he wants to. Humiliated in the London mayoral elections, he has become something of a spectre, a rare reminder of a New Labour defeat. He will be fortunate indeed if Tony Blair allows him the chance to end his career on a high.

fields.headline: Urban regeneration: the basics
fields.trailText: • Urban regeneration refers to the various attempts to reverse the decline in cities that have been worst hit by the demise of Britain's industrial and manufacturing economy.
fields.body:
 Urban regeneration refers to the various attempts to reverse the decline in cities that have been worst hit by the demise of Britain's industrial and manufacturing economy.

 Numerous funds have been launched over the past 20 years.

 The main funds now available for regeneration are the new deal for communities and the neighbourhood renewal fund, plus several other funding streams that can be used to support regeneration objectives.

 The regional development agencies have taken over much of the responsibility and funding for regeneration.

 The effectiveness of regeneration schemes has yet to be proved as there are doubts over how much impact it has, particularly on the difficult area of economic and social renewal.

fields.headline: Urban regeneration - the issue explained
fields.trailText: The collapse of Britain's industrial and manufacturing economy has left many inner city areas blighted by unemployment, riddled with poor housing and socially excluded from more prosperous districts.
fields.body:
The collapse of Britain's industrial and manufacturing economy has left many inner city areas blighted by unemployment, riddled with poor housing and socially excluded from more prosperous districts.

Urban regeneration is the attempt to reverse that decline by both improving the physical structure, and, more importantly and elusively, the economy of those areas. In all regeneration programmes, public money is used as an attempt to pump prime private investment into an area.

Over the past 20 years a bewildering array of government programmes have been launched, usually as the result of a ministerial walkabout in an inner city area. Some years later programmes have tended to be quietly dropped or replaced. Because regeneration schemes often take years to complete, by the time they have finished the government programme that initially funded them has usually been replaced. This means that current programmes are often confused with past projects. Estate action, city challenge, the estate's renewal challenge fund and the single regeneration budget (SRB) have all come and gone in the last few years.

One important trend has emerged over the years: the earlier projects tended to focus on physical regeneration, usually housing, whereas later programmes have attempted to stimulate social and economic regeneration. More recently, much of the responsibility for regeneration initiatives, especially economic regeneration, has switched to the new regional development agencies. The RDAs have been given more cash and flexibility to spend on regional priorities, including the money that had been earmarked for the sixth and final round of the SRB.

There are currently two main regeneration funds: the new deal for communities and the neighbourhood renewal fund. But there are also a raft of other funding streams focused on specific activities that used to help regeneration initiatives. These include: lottery funding, cash for the education, employment and health action zones; and the Housing Corporation cash for new social housing, 60% of which has to support regeneration schemes.

The new deal for communities is the Labour government's flagship regeneration scheme. It was launched in 1998 and so far 39 projects have been formed across the country. Over the next three years £1.2bn has been committed to the scheme.

The main goal of the programme is to reduce disadvantages in the poorest areas by focusing on four issues: unemployment, poor health, crime and education. Other issues such as improvement to the physical environment are secondary to these main priorities.

The £800m neighbourhood renewal fund, which starts in 2001-02, will be targeted at the most deprived areas, on the basis of need, as extra help to meet government targets for reducing inequality.

In addition to cash, the government has also introduced a number of tax incentives to help regeneration. These include tax breaks for urban regeneration companies that have been set up to coordinate regeneration in three cities, with another 12 planned. A number of perennial questions remain about the effectiveness of regeneration schemes. How can top-down government programmes gain the backing and involvement of local people that is usually crucial to their success? Can public cash really stimulate local economies and create jobs? How can regeneration schemes prevent displacing problems from one area to another?

The number of separate regeneration funding packages that have been launched and then dropped shows that these questions have still not been satisfactorily answered.

fields.headline: Paul Flynn
fields.standfirst:
Newport West (1987- )

Ask Aristotle about Paul Flynn
fields.trailText: Bearded Paul Flynn is an unlikely Welsh-speaking pixie with bags of Irish charm. The charm coats a tolerant left of centre MP who has served for years as a one-man awkward squad. His well furnished mind enables him to quote poetry in Chaucerian English as well as Welsh. He uses his wit as a cattleprod, pushing for answers to his most persistent questions.
fields.body:
Bearded Paul Flynn is an unlikely Welsh-speaking pixie with bags of Irish charm. The charm coats a tolerant left of centre MP who has served for years as a one-man awkward squad. His well furnished mind enables him to quote poetry in Chaucerian English as well as Welsh. He uses his wit as a cattleprod, pushing for answers to his most persistent questions.

Using the platform as MP for Newport West Paul Flynn asks why healthy people are allowed to poison themselves with tobacco, whisky and painkillers when people suffering from MS cannot ease their pain with cannabis. He uses all his wit, brains, (and professional training as an industrial chemist) to press recent governments to follow the more liberal route of the Netherlands.

Decriminalising dope is only his latest crusade: he has protested against 4x4 bull bars, nuclear weapons and energy and in favour of a Severn barrage. Simon Hoggart dubbed him "the thinking man's Dennis Skinner" but Mr Flynn is more constructive than that.

He is a product of the ethnic mix attracted to south Wales when its working mines drew in manpower from all over British Isles. His Irish father was a postman shot in the first world war and embittered by the pittance allowed him by the War Office. His Welsh-speaking mother, Katherine (Williams), brought him up with the Welsh language so well that he later became a member of the Gorsedd of Bards and a pioneering agitator for a Welsh-language TV channel.

His lack of enthusiasm for abortion is attributable to his having been educated at Catholic schools: St Patrick's school and St Illtyd's college before going on to University College, Cardiff. He was almost deafened working in a nail factory on the Cardiff docks before he went to work for 27 years as an industrial chemist in the south Wales steel industry.

He entered politics at 10, standing guard outside Jim Callaghan's car to prevent the tyres being slashed. At 37 he was elected to Newport borough council, then to Gwent county council. In the three years before winning back marginal Tory-held Newport West in 1987, he worked as a researcher for the fundamentalist leftwinger, Llew Smith, then a MEP.

Once in the Commons, he proved to be one of its most assiduous questioners of the executive. His abilities were recognised as a junior shadow spokesman on Wales and social security.

Mr Flynn never warmed to Tony Blair and "New Labour", deriding them as "a malign alien force [which] could infiltrate a political party with beautiful people reared in public schools [and] fed an idealism-inhibiting diet".

Perhaps the rheumatoid arthritis, which makes him limp, makes it difficult for him to bend the knee in deference to New Labour.

fields.headline: Blair unveils £100m package for GPs
fields.trailText: The prime minister today pushed ahead with his ambitious primary care reforms, announcing plans to boost GP numbers and giving them more money and power in a bid to avert a damaging doctors' revolt in the run up to the general election. David Batty reports.
fields.body:
The prime minister today pushed ahead with his ambitious primary care reforms, announcing plans to boost GP numbers and giving them more money and power in a bid to avert a damaging doctors' revolt in the run up to the general election.

Tony Blair unveiled a £100m package of incentive bonuses for family doctors in England and Wales who meet locally agreed performance targets - an average of £10,000 per GP practice.

He also promised 550 more GP training places - and a hint of more to come later this year - and an extension to the role of primary care trusts (PCTs) which will commission care on behalf of practices.

In a speech to the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) in London, Mr Blair said he wanted to "stimulate innovation" and "tap the energy and creativity of GPs and spread best practice".

Those who agree to the targets will receive an immediate payment of £5,000 to help them provide improved services such as extended surgery opening hours, better care for coronary or cancer patients and training GP specialists.

This money will be doubled by the end of the year if they achieve these aims. GPs can take it as a cash sum for themselves, reward practice staff or put the money back into patient services.

A spokesman for the King's Fund said: "It looks as though the government is finally beginning to realise that primary care is where the real revolution in health care needs to happen. Targets for GP surgeries will put staff under even more pressure to perform, especially with the added incentive of a £5,000 'cash bonus'."

Mr Blair also announced an extra 550 GP training places and a further 400 GP trainers to improve recruitment in the profession.

The role of PCTs, which are responsible for commissioning local care services, will also be extended. By 2004, they will control at least 75% the NHS budget - compared to 15% in 1997.

Some £25m is to be set aside over three years to establish teaching PCTs - equivalent to teaching hospitals - in deprived and under-doctored areas. The first three will be launched on April 1 in Salford, Bradford and Sunderland.

GPs and nurses will also be given funding to improve their knowledge of cancer and provide better support for patients, while every GP will have his or her own desktop PC connected to NHSnet, the health service intranet, by the end of March 2002.

The prime minister announced the appointment of a national director for primary care services to oversee the reforms. He is prominent Labour-supporting GP Dr David Colin-Thome, who is currently director of primary care for the NHS London region.

The British Medical Association has complained GPs are now giving, on average, 10,000 consultations a year - 50% more than when the NHS was founded in 1948.

It has warned that government plans to appoint an additional 2,000 GPs in England by 2004, was still less than one-fifth of the 10,330 it believes is needed to provide a satisfactory service.

The government hopes to placate GPs by reducing the red tape in primary care. A report launched today states they will no longer have to sign pensioners' driving licence forms, passport applications and postal vote applications.

This should free up 750,000 working hours, which works out at one appointment a day for every family doctor in the country.

Dr John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA's general practitioners committee, said: "GPs are struggling to care for patients under an intolerable workload burden. Reducing bureaucracy will help. These are small but welcome first steps but more fundamental action is still needed to improve GPs' working lives and the quality of patient care."

The shadow health secretary, Dr Liam Fox, set out the Conservative's plans to boost general practice, including making all doctors work as a GP for six months after registration.

Liberal Democrat health spokesman Nick Harvey said: "It is absurd that the government is talking about cutting red tape for doctors and at the same time introducing more targets and paperwork."

fields.headline: Peter Kilfoyle
fields.standfirst:
Liverpool Walton (1991- )

Ask Aristotle about Peter Kilfoyle
fields.trailText: Peter Kilfoyle describes himself as a "critical friend" of the Blair government. But with friends like him, the Blairites need no enemies. The first Blair minister to resign on ideological grounds, he is a heavyweight Liverpuddlian bruiser, once seen by many as a likely chief whip.
fields.body:
Peter Kilfoyle describes himself as a "critical friend" of the Blair government. But with friends like him, the Blairites need no enemies. The first Blair minister to resign on ideological grounds, he is a heavyweight Liverpuddlian bruiser, once seen by many as a likely chief whip.

His book, Left Behind, published in November 2000 in explanation of his resignation, deals a series of hammer blows at the Blair government's failures to do enough to help the poor, the unemployed and British manufacturing.

It is above all a sideswipe at the ideology of Peter Mandelson, whose earlier book he slated as showing "a palpable contempt for the victims of the current order", who are decried by the Tories to be "feckless", while the young unemployed "are portrayed as a threat, not as a resource wasted by years of malign neglect."

Mr Kilfoyle can only be understood as a product of the Liverpudlian proletarian underclass who battled fiercely against the efforts of Militant to exploit it, but is as much repelled by the New Labour middle class managerial indifference.

Following the second departure of Peter Mandelson in January 2001, Mr Kilfoyle certainly wasn't shy about sticking the knife in. The MP who famously branded Peter Mandelson "Nobby No Mates" wrote in a Sunday paper: "It is always sad to see a political career implode so spectacularly but in this case it will be for the good of us all."

Mr Kilfoyle can only be understood as the lucky one of 14 children born into an impoverished Liverpool Irish Catholic family. His labourer father died when he was 10. He was clever enough to make it to Durham University, which he left after a year, qualifying as a teacher at Christ's College, Liverpool.

After working on building sites, oil rigs, docks, as a vocalist and guitarist for the Hungry Is - rivals to the Beatles - and as a teacher, he made his political mark battling against Militant as Labour's north-west regional organiser (ironically, working closely with Peter Mandelson). He faced down the left from their heyday in 1985 to their demise following the collapse of communism.

He reached the Commons in 1991as the MP for Liverpool Walton, the former seat of deceased leftwing rebel Eric Heffer, who had been an vocal supporter of Militant. Heffer famously stormed out of the Bournemouth conference hall when Neil Kinnock attacked them from the platform in 1985.

After John Smith died in 1994 Mr Kilfoyle threw his considerable weight behind Tony Blair, being the second to sign his nomination papers and joining his campaign team because he hoped Mr Blair could rescue Labour from languishing in opposition. But he could not stand what he saw as Mr Blair's middle class hangers-on, savaging many like Peter Mandelson and Philip Gould, Blair's pollster, in public and private.

Although he would have liked to become chief whip, after Labour's 1997 win he was given unsuitable ministerial jobs in the Cabinet Office and Ministry of Defence. He was angered by New Labour's preoccupation with "southern middle class" issues such as gay rights. He defended his resignation from office in the March 2000 Budget debate by demanding Labour do more for the "dispossessed" in its heartlands.

But in his own book he showed no clear way of rescuing Labour from its middle class chatterati leaders. Since his resignation he is said to have become closer to the Brownites. If the chancellor ever gets the top job Mr Kilfoyle may yet return to government.

fields.headline: Peter Hain
fields.standfirst:
Neath (1987- )

Ask Aristotle about Peter Hain
fields.trailText: Peter Hain took a bit of a knock when in early 2001 he was moved from Foreign Office minister to energy minister following Peter Mandelson's resignation, but his ambition is unlikely to be held in check for too long.
fields.body:
Peter Hain took a bit of a knock when in early 2001 he was moved from Foreign Office minister to energy minister following Peter Mandelson's resignation, but his ambition is unlikely to be held in check for too long.

Born in South Africa, he arrived in Britain at the age of 16 after his parents had incurred the wrath of the authorities by taking food to Nelson Mandela in prison. When, fresh off the boat in 1970, he ruined rugby, cricket and tennis matches for all-white South African teams by organising mass protests he became enough of an irritation to the apartheid intelligence services for them to try to bring him down. Bizarrely, they devised a phoney bankraid by a lookalike in order to blacken his name.

The Daily Telegraph, named him "public enemy no 1" and rightwing Tory Gerald Howarth launched a "Hain prosecution fund".

In the 70s Mr Hain was sufficiently popular among young Liberals to become their chairman, and then president, but they turned on him as an opportunist "turncoat" when he switched to the Labour party in 1977.

Initially, he was hardly the flavour of the month with Labour either, serving as press secretary to the militant Anti-Nazi League.

He worked his passage for 15 years as a researcher for the union of communications officers and then as their head of research. I often encountered him outside Labour party conferences distributing leaflets, long before he became a delegate or was selected and elected for safe Neath. Mr Hain's problem is that his mixture of radical commitment and personal ambition compels him to try to energise and lead every organisation he joins. Shortly after reaching the Commons by way of a 1991 byelection, he joined the somnolent Tribune group, becoming its secretary in 1992. By the next year it had become so active and influential that Tony Blair and Gordon Brown felt it necessary to organise his ousting from the post.

His many enemies were compensated for by one friend, Nelson Mandela, whom he welcomed in Cardiff in 1998, with his parents.

At the time, he was already under secretary for Wales. In 1999, at Robin Cook's request, he was made a minister for Africa at the Foreign Office, helping give it the most leftwing hue ever.

But his constructive-left approach does not satisfy those who want to end the UN boycott on Saddam Hussein. Robert Mugabe, whom he helped into power, attacks him as a "racist" for backing Zimbabwe's white farmers' rights. He had fewer critics when he helped stop the export of British instruments of torture.

Those who think him over ambitious seem not to notice his tendency to blurt out criticisms of his "automaton" fellow ministers and accuse Tony Blair of neglecting core Labour voters. His time will come but he'll have to use all his energy to turn the energy brief into a useful political platform.

fields.headline: Paul Boateng
fields.standfirst:
Brent South (1987-)

Ask Aristotle about Paul Boateng
fields.trailText: In Paul Boateng's radical days, back when he was the Greater London council's scourge of the Metropolitan police and sympathetic to the "Troops Out" movement which supported British withdrawal from Northern Ireland, he was a favourite speaker at meetings of the left-wing Labour Herald. At one such meeting in October 1983 he urged the left to "have the guts to support all workers who have the guts to fight Thatcher."
fields.body:
In Paul Boateng's radical days, back when he was the Greater London council's scourge of the Metropolitan police and sympathetic to the "Troops Out" movement which supported British withdrawal from Northern Ireland, he was a favourite speaker at meetings of the left-wing Labour Herald. At one such meeting in October 1983 he urged the left to "have the guts to support all workers who have the guts to fight Thatcher."

Although his devout Methodism has not changed, his vocabulary certainly has since he found a safe Labour seat in ethnically diverse Brent South in 1987. London-born, with a Ghanaian father and a Scottish mother, he is a very active constituency MP, speaking for all his constituents.

Paul Boateng gained recognition from Tony Blair as chief architect of Labour's 1995 policy document on the legal profession, and for steering through the family law bill. The first black member of Labour's frontbench, many mistakenly believed that in 1997 he would land a big job under the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine. As a brilliant lawyer with a tough, arrogant core, he has survived many setbacks to emerge first as under secretary for health, and then as Home Office minister under Jack Straw in 1998.

Unhappily, he fights his department's battles in a form of lawyer-speak which makes him sound too much like Michael Howard. But, as the frontbench's snappiest dresser, his suits are sharper.

However, his days as the darling of the left are definitely at an end - he sent one of his five children to a £4,500 per year fee paying school. He also lost many of his former friends when he was wheeled out by the Labour government to help break down support for Ken Livingstone's mayoral campaign.

Ask Aristotle about Michael Meacher

Fearing he might be shelved as too old and too leftwing when Tony Blair formed his government, he was happy to be demoted from the shadow cabinet on the day Mr Blair entered Downing Street and took a minister of state's salary to prove that he could successfully underpin John Prescott in his massive new department. fields.body:
Michael Meacher, at 61, is one of the real ministerial successes of an ageist Blair administration. Fearing he might be shelved as too old and too leftwing when Tony Blair formed his government, he was happy to be demoted from the shadow cabinet on the day Mr Blair entered Downing Street and took a minister of state's salary to prove that he could successfully underpin John Prescott in his massive new department. Since then, John Prescott has utilised his experience and curbed his tendency for hyperbole, while taking credit for Mr Meacher's hard work for the environment.

Mr Meacher attended Berkhampsted, a public school in Hertfordshire, on a county scholarship, before going on to New College, Oxford. He then became a research fellow, lecturer and visiting professor at York University and the London School of Economics.

His ministerial experience dates back over a quarter of a century. Selected for Oldham West in succession to Leslie Hale, he lost it in a byelection but retook it in June 1970, when Edward Heath became prime minister. He was on the left and when Labour unexpectedly took power in March 1974, Harold Wilson named him under secretary for industry (1974-1975), under Tony Benn. Both were demoted a year later.

He worked as under secretary for health and social security (1975-76), then for the trade department (1976-1979) in the Wilson and Callaghan governments.

The pioneer of many advanced ideas, Mr Meacher is seen as a much saner Tony Benn and was once tagged "Benn's vicar on earth" by Neil Kinnock. He pioneered Labour's democratisation as chairman of the Labour coordinating committee, and more than 30 years ago, proposed higher pensions for the over-80s.

He published research showing 35,000 deaths from hypothermia and in 1979 he complained that the defeated Callaghan government had failed to abolish the Lords. He tried a freedom of information bill more than 20 years ago. More recently he was one of the first to see the Bosnian war as "another Spanish civil war."

However, his judgement has not been faultless. His biggest bloomer was to sue Alan Watkins, then a journalist at the Observer, for ridiculing his claim to a modest background - Meacher lost. Mr Meacher has never concealed that his father came from a middle class family. But after his father suffered a nervous breakdown, the family had eked out a living on a rundown family farm where his mother took in lodgers.

He was leftwing enough for the hard left to back him against Roy Hattersley for the deputy leadership in 1983, losing by 67% to 28%. It is curious that Mr Meacher has become soft-left inside a Blair administration while Hattersley has become "outside left", criticising it from varying journalistic perches. He still has a touch of naivety about him, and so, while urging curbs on second homes in rural areas, he was embarrassed in January 2001 when it was revealed that he and his wife own nine properties.

Though having backed Tony Benn and Ken Livingstone over the years it's unlikely that he will be punished for this. Indeed, the prime minister is said to be surprised about Mr Meacher's success in government. He will hope to he promoted to the cabinet after the election, though he shouldn't hold his breath come polling day.

fields.headline: John Gittings @ Shanghai
fields.trailText: The Guardian now has its seal in China: not a great seal, but large enough to "chop" a document when needed.
fields.body:
The Guardian now has its seal in China: not a great seal, but large enough to "chop" a document when needed. It bears police approved wording and must be used with a red ink-pad. Obtaining it was by no means the highest of the bureaucratic hurdles to setting up a new office in Shanghai, but it was the last of a long run.

Shanghai has a reputation for being "easier" than Beijing, especially for foreign journalists seeking to register themselves and their bureaux. The regulations are the same, but the people who administer them don't throw documents at you or ignore your presence. They are as helpful as the system allows - and they smile.

Most helpful of all was Mr He, the senior policeman at the Foreigners Exit-Entry Bureau who issued our resident permits. He smiled when making a very serious point about the need to register with the local police where one is living or staying - and to do it within 24 hours. Likewise for any foreign guests. Such a rigorous control, Mr He admitted, is not found in most other countries, but it is for the best of reasons.

Mr He then cited the following example. A foreigner died in an aircrash at Shanghai and the airline only had his name. But since he was properly registered with the police, the next of kin were soon tracked down and informed of the sad event. We all smiled.

There were common-sense reasons for the other regulations too. Why must journalists always seek permission before covering the visit to Shanghai of a national or foreign leader? Because otherwise the bodyguards may suspect their motives and take vigorous action. Why must journalists never attempt to conduct an interview without pre-arranging it with the authorities? Because otherwise curious people may flock around and create a disturbance.

As we listened to this kindly lecture, an assistant sorted out the paperwork. It consisted of: (a) our passports, (b) a letter of introduction from the Shanghai Foreign Affairs Bureau, (c) my new journalist's card, (d) my organisation card, issued by the Bureau in lieu of business registration, (e) a letter from the hotel certifying our current lodging there, (f) a letter from me asking for the relevant documents to be issued, (g) my curriculum vitae, signed by the editor of the Guardian, (h) two photos each, (i) medical certificates certifying we were free from HIV-Aids and other ailments which foreigners bring to China. (Mr He also asked for our marriage certificate. I think I surprised him as well as myself by being able to produce it.)

In painful retrospect, we had paid five visits to the medical examination bureau to get the certificates. Although required to take the test, we were not allowed to undergo it until we had produced documents (a)-(d). We then had to sign a declaration saying we did not suffer from "mental confusion, or manic/paranoid/hallucinatory psychosis." We should really have ticked the box for mental confusion.

Having stayed the bureaucratic course, we offer this advice to anyone else preparing to run it. First, always carry multiple photocopies of your documents (including the outside covers). Second, remember that all government offices close for lunch at 11.30.

The third piece of advice is from Mr He. In Shanghai, only use taxi companies recommended by him. Their vehicles are white, green and orange respectively. The other colours may not be safe. And last, don't forget the seal. Without it, it is impossible to secure the release of one's goods from customs - but that's another story.

fields.headline: Main points of Blair's plan
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, has announced plans to revolutionise primary care, giving GPs cash incentives to improve services and cutting red tape.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, has announced plans to revolutionise primary care, giving GPs cash incentives to improve services and cutting red tape.

The main points are:

 A £100m cash boost for GPs who improve services - worth £10,000 to every GP practice that agrees to and achieve new performance targets.
 £25m to set up teaching primary care trusts (PCTs) to train GPs in disadvantaged areas.
 An extra 550 GP training places and an extra 400 GP trainers.
 GP Dr David Colin-Thome appointed national director for primary care services.
 GPs will no longer have to counter-sign driving licence applications, sign passport applications, certify immunisation returns or provide certificate to excuse people from jury service.
 The power to certify incapacity for work will be extended to nurse practitioners subject to successful pilots.
 The number of medical reports produced by GPs for life insurance companies will be reduced.
 Sick certification to be integrated into hospital discharge so hospital doctors will not refer patients to a GP just to get a sickness certificate.
 By September 2001 GPs and midwives will be able to sign maternity certificates from 20 weeks before the estimated week of confinement, rather than the existing 14 weeks.
 Guidance to minimise referrals to GPs by the legal profession and the police for recording minor injuries will be issued in July 2001.
