webTitle: Bobby Charlton quizzed about his love life, I'd like to see that

fields.headline: Bobby Charlton quizzed about his love life, I'd like to see that
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
GuardianUnlimited Football
fields.trailText: Anyone in any doubt that Football Man is not what he was needed only watch the Ali G interview on Comic Relief with England's most celebrated player and his wife. I mean, could you imagine Bobby Charlton in his heyday taking his lovely wife on to TV to be quizzed by Dick Emery about their preferred sexual position?
fields.body:
Anyone in any doubt that Football Man is not what he was needed only watch the Ali G interview on Comic Relief with England's most celebrated player and his wife. I mean, could you imagine Bobby Charlton in his heyday taking his lovely wife on to TV to be quizzed by Dick Emery about their preferred sexual position? (Well, you could, but it's probably not advisable.) Nobody, as far as I recall - even for charity - ever thought to ask Billy Wright how many of the Beverley Sisters he had slept with.

Still, autre temps, autre moeurs, as my friend Ron Atkinson would no doubt say. Football has changed irrevocably, and the BBC is currently chronicling this process in a three-part documentary series, The Men Who Changed Football.

On the evidence of part one, the story is well told and makes compelling viewing for those of us who have lived through the seismic ground-shifts of the past three decades. My only quibble - and it is a big one - is that it is being treated entirely as a business story.

Is it my imagination, or has this country adopted and adapted rather too enthusias tically Calvin Coolidge's famous maxim, "The chief business of America is business"? Scarcely a day goes by without another documentary about some 12-year-old dotcom millionaire. Every time I switch on the TV a syrupy voice-over urges me to salt away my wedge in the Leicester and Chester or some such to ensure a comfortable silvery-haired old age playing mini-golf with my grand-kids. Even in the red-top tabloids these days there are hefty money supplements elbowing out important news stories about Jordan's breast implants.

And there were few signs of The Men Who Changed Football departing from the contemporary agenda. The story it told was of the salvation of our national game by "entrepreneurs, self-made men", as it described Irving Scholar at Spurs, David Dein at Arsenal and Martin Edwards at Manchester United, although the process of making Edwards must have been helped along somewhat by his dad's successful meat-style-products business.

The three were presented largely uncritically. The days before they occupied the boardrooms of our top clubs were the bad old days, the narrator Paul McGann solemnly informed us, "a national disgrace".

To illustrate the unpretty pass soccer had reached in its pre-entrepreneurial period, we saw scenes of a riot at Old Trafford in 1974, and I am prepared to concede there were genuine horrors to be seen here. The spoon collars, the unfashionable boots, the flared hipsters. It was as if trouble had broken out at a Slade lookalike convention.

It was disappointing, though, that the programme gave quite such a hearty round of applause to the men who swept away this ugliness, given that the 70s being trashed in this programme were, one assumes, the same 70s the BBC constantly celebrates in programmes such as Soccer In The Seventies, the same decade in which Liverpool won two European cups, Nottingham Forest one, and even Manchester City won a European trophy. Two words: Rodney Marsh.

Part one of the documentary, it is true, took us only as far as 1989, so I shall watch again tomorrow in the hope that the downside of big business's rescue of our national game is covered, or even mentioned.

Someone might even point out that the goal that won the championship for Arsenal in 1989, for which David Dein appeared to be taking personal credit, was actually scored by Michael Thomas.

There are some great stories to be told, and not all of them revolve round the fight for television rights, about which part one of the documentary seemed to be unnaturally obsessed; although the hero of that story, the man who broke the cosy cartel between BBC and ITV denying football a fair price for its product, turned out to be Greg Dyke, which was nice.

At some point, I expect, someone will examine the cross-fertilisation of soccer and showbiz which has brought us such delights as Ian Wright's ITV chat show and reached its apotheosis with Mr and Mrs Beckham's appearance on Comic Relief, the funniest moment of which was Ali G's question to Posh Spice: "Does Brooklyn like your music, or is he getting a bit old for it now?"

For the most part, though, the best way to deal with Comic Relief was to make a contribution at an early stage and then ignore the rest of the dismal, desperate farrago with a clear conscience. Fortunately, relief from Comic Relief - that is, something actually comic - was available on Jumpers For Goalposts on Sky.

With the exception of the reruns of Seinfeld and Larry Sanders, this is the funniest programme on TV at present. I particularly enjoy Simon Day's performance as the Partridge-esque host Clive Graham. "Let's pick up some half-time reports from some of the other quizzes going on around the country," said Clive as he went into the break. "Well, over on Catchphrase they are having great difficulty identifying 'a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush', while on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, some idiot from Worthing doesn't know who wrote David Copperfield."

Come in They Think It's All Over. Your time is up.

Ask Aristotle about Edward Heath
fields.trailText: As the charmless, chubby 84-year-old Sir Edward Heath shuffles into history after 51 years in the Commons, the controversy he invokes will doubtless continue. As the son of a housemaid and a carpenter, he was the Tories' first working class prime minister, from 1970-74. But he lost the February 1974 election because he refused striking miners a wage rise, preferring to suffer a three-day week and then call an early poll, defining the election as a choice between Tories' rule and miners' rule.
fields.body:
As the charmless, chubby 84-year-old Sir Edward Heath shuffles into history after 51 years in the Commons, the controversy he invokes will doubtless continue. As the son of a housemaid and a carpenter, he was the Tories' first working class prime minister, from 1970-74. But he lost the February 1974 election because he refused striking miners a wage rise, preferring to suffer a three-day week and then call an early poll, defining the election as a choice between Tories' rule and miners' rule.

A year later he was replaced as party leader by Margaret Thatcher who was preferred by rightwing Tories opposed to his pro-Europeanism and the abandonment of monetarism. This was followed by "the longest sulk in history", interrupted by occasional powerful, humour-laced backbench speeches, often without notes.

His political obituaries will range widely. He will be recommended for sainthood by federalist Europeans for getting the UK into the EEC in 1971-72, in league with the Liberals and pro-European Labour defectors led by his Balliol friend Roy Jenkins. But by the same token he is the Satan of the Europhobes and Eurosceptics for securing that entry on what they say were false pretences, painting the EEC as nothing more than a trading organisation. They also claim he sold out Britain's fishing grounds.

He counters these charges by saying he made the true nature of EEC membership clear at the time. His admirers will remember him as a liberal internationalist, recalling how at Oxford he supported the republican side during the Spanish civil war and, when Tory leader, opposed Ian Smith in Rhodesia. Critics will cite the way he almost broke up the Commonwealth in 1971 by supplying arms to apartheid South Africa. Also, his enthusiasm for Europe meant he had a cold dislike of the United States, extending to supporting Saddam Hussein against US-backed sanctions. Some also sneer at his close support for Chinese communist leaders, which extended to attacking the west's reaction to the Tiananmen massacre.

Cynical critics will link such tolerance with his unregistered almost annual trips to China, where he also serves as senior adviser to the state-owned China Ocean shipping company. His unspecified income from this, other consultancies, books and orchestra-conducting tours go into his private holding company, Dumpton Gap company, which enables him to pay only 25% tax on profits after expenses.

A lifelong bachelor, Sir Edward has a few close women friends among fellow musicians and actresses, but he prefers the company of men. When I researched my biography Heath and the Heathmen 29 years ago, women soldiers who served in his artillery company said he refused to talk to them. The famous pianist Moira Lympany thought he would marry her, but when I asked about the most intimate thing he had done, she replied, "He put his arm around my shoulder."

fields.standfirst:
Richmond (1989- )

Ask Aristotle about William Hague
fields.trailText: The hair is scantier and infinitely shorter. But the gravelly voice is still the same, belting out the mixture of Tory aggression and barbed humour in south Yorkshire overtones that, 23 years ago, led Mrs Thatcher to tag a 16-year-old as "possibly another young Pitt". This is the voice that, with its Churchillian cadences, has often penetrated Tony Blair's Wednesday afternoon parliamentary platitudes.
fields.body:
The hair is scantier and infinitely shorter. But the gravelly voice is still the same, belting out the mixture of Tory aggression and barbed humour in south Yorkshire overtones that, 23 years ago, led Mrs Thatcher to tag a 16-year-old as "possibly another young Pitt". This is the voice that, with its Churchillian cadences, has often penetrated Tony Blair's Wednesday afternoon parliamentary platitudes.

If his well scripted speeches were the only asset being compared, William Hague would be streets ahead of his rival. But, like an aria from the cells in Beethoven's opera Fidelio, it comes through many bars, few of which can be sawn through soon.

Crucially, the pragmatic if rightwing Mr Hague is imprisoned by the fact that he only beat the europhile Kenneth Clarke for the Tory leadership in June 1997 because his party's crushing May 1997 election defeat left its MPs - who elect the leader - highly anti-European. This makes the agile Mr Hague a tighter prisoner of his party than he would like, and explains why he handcuffed himself to not joining the euro until after the next parliament.

Quite how rightwing Mr Hague really is must be open to question. His friends talk of him as an internationalist with liberal inclinations, but there have been few signs of this side of his character on public display. Certainly he has cause to understand the dilemmas of Euroscepticism. As a former star of the McKinsey management consultancy, he knows better than most Tories that many UK-based big businesses will soon be dealing in euros whether or not the electorate like it. Nissan cars, which decided to reinvest in Britain in January 2001 on such a condition, is just the most prominent of many such companies. But he now looks as blinkered as the men and women by whose votes he was elected, and by whose votes he needs to remain in office if he loses the next general election.

Although colour blind, he is not himself a gimlet eyed zealot. When he became Welsh secretary in 1995, after John Redwood, he showed himself much more deft and willing to be assimilated than his predecessor, even to the point of marrying Ffion, the young civil servant who taught him enough Welsh to avoid badmouthing the Welsh anthem.

In filling his party's frontbench, he prefers to rely on the saner, more reasonable Eurosceptics such as Michael Ancram and, most recently, Michael Portillo. But the prevailing atmosphere of Europhobia has made it impossible for such talents to survive alongside them - and that, surely, has massively hampered his party's chances.

It has also forced two clever ex-ministers, Ian Taylor and David Curry, into internal exile on the backbench. Other MPs, such as Peter Temple-Morris and Shaun Woodward, have fled to Labour, in the latter case because homophobia often joins Europhobia on the Tory rightwing. Mr Hague's election promises have also been tailored to control - rather than lead - his party. The Tories' relative success in fighting the euro at the last European elections meant his mini-manifesto, published in late 2000, was both anti-Brussels and drew heavily on the George Bush policy tent of "compassionate conservatism". It advocated privatised pensions and universities, as well as forcing single mothers to enter work.

He is also constrained by the fact that the Tory party has shrunk from the many millioned broad church mass party it once was to a sectarian group with some 320,000 members, mostly over 60.

After two serious recessions and the forced exit from the exchange rate mechanism, it has lost most of its young and middleaged members, particularly those with business links, who lost confidence in Tory economic competence. This shrinkage in membership and business backing left Conservative central office at the mercy of a single Tory billionaire, Michael Ashcroft. The millions he contributed in 1999 and 2000 were indispensable. In 2000, Ashcroft moved to Britain as required for the peerage Mr Hague secured for him.

In 2001, ahead of the expected election, the financial situation was eased somewhat by a £5m donation from Stuart Wheeler, owner of a gaming website.

All these troubles explain why Mr Hague was initially reluctant to inherit the leadership in the wake of May 1997 and considered becoming deputy to Michael Howard. He even agreed a deal to this effect with the former home secretary, toasting it in champagne. But ambition got the better of him and he broke the pact the next morning.

As his party's fortunes failed to improve dramatically after 1997, he must at times have regretted his decision not to serve as Mr Howard's deputy. Had he done so, he might now be his party's rising star, likely to be elected to the Tory leadership after the next election, not ejected from it.

His early training in adversity, as a young Tory in the overwhelmingly Labour Rother Valley, must be why any such doubts never show in public. Despite foolish boasts of downing 14 pints a day in his youth, Mr Hague's background is sedate. He was born in Rotherham in 1961, the son of a family of local soft drink manufacturers. He went from Wath-on-Dearne comprehensive to Magdalen College, Oxford, where he chalked up first class honours in PPE before obtaining an MBA with distinction at France's Insead business school.

He worked for eight years at top management consultants McKinsey, where his biggest job was advising Oxford on fundraising. This came to an end when he was chosen from among 360 hopefuls for the Yorkshire seat of Richmond, vacated by Leon Brittan in favour of the European commission.

In 1989, Mr Hague narrowly squeaked into parliament thanks to a split third party vote. Once there, he moved fast, becoming parliamentary private secretary to Norman Lamont a year later - and so having a hand in the introduction of the fuel price escalator that has so troubled Tony Blair.

In 1993, at 32, he became under secretary for social security. A year later he was promoted to minister of state to restore relations with the disabled after the cockups of Nick Scott. John Major wanted to promote him to chief secretary to the Treasury, but chancellor Ken Clarke thought him too rightwing.

As leader, his political postures had been mixed. A strong backer of capital punishment, he has also been one of the minority of Tory MPs to vote to reduce the age of homosexual consent to 16, probably converted by his friend and flatmate, Alan Duncan. But his most liberal attitude, of thinking hereditary peers "silly", goes back to a little noted Tory conference speech at 19.

His best asset is his love of combat at prime minister's questions where his repertoire of humour and debating skills regularly see him triumph over Mr Blair. However, his enthusiasm sometimes gets the better of him - as seen after the resignation of Peter Mandelson in January 2001 when Mr Hague was guilty of dancing on the Northern Ireland secretary's grave.

Whether his strong parliamentary skills and love of populist policies will get him through the doors of No 10 remains to be seen.

fields.headline: Robin Cook
fields.standfirst:
Livingston (1983-)
Edinburgh Central (1974-1983)

Ask Aristotle about Robin Cook
fields.trailText: Arrogant but brilliant, Robin Cook does not think Britain is ready for a prime minister resembling a badly shaven squirrel. It is one reason he has never challenged for the party leader's job. As he has said: "I am not good looking enough." Anyway, he doubted he could win, despite the MPs who urged him to enter the Labour leadership contest after John Smith's death in 1994. He must have regretted it months later, when he topped the poll for both the shadow cabinet and the constituency section of the national executive.
fields.body:
Arrogant but brilliant, Robin Cook does not think Britain is ready for a prime minister resembling a badly shaven squirrel. It is one reason he has never challenged for the party leader's job. As he has said: "I am not good looking enough." Anyway, he doubted he could win, despite the MPs who urged him to enter the Labour leadership contest after John Smith's death in 1994. He must have regretted it months later, when he topped the poll for both the shadow cabinet and the constituency section of the national executive.

Having refused to fight, Mr Cook became wholly dependent on the favours of the contest winner, Tony Blair. That soon showed when Mr Cook, who wanted to be shadow chancellor, had to be satisfied with shadow foreign secretary because of Mr Blair's deal with Gordon Brown in an Islington restaurant.

Hoping to regain the inside track, Mr Cook shed the policies that had made him the spokesman of the left: unilateralism, Euroscepticism and Keynesianism. He backed the burying of long dead clause IV. By 1996 he astonished Eurosceptics by proclaiming that a Labour government would probably join the single currency. His new views fell in with the Blair-Mandelson "project". So did his long-standing enthusiasm for PR.

None of his personal repositioning - which lost him friends on the left - interfered with his Tory bashing. He was razor sharp in the 1996 Scott report debate - despite having been allowed only three hours to study the text of the report - describing the Tory frontbench as "limpets" and demanding minister William Waldegrave resign for misleading the Commons. For this performance, he was named the Spectator's "debater of the year."

Although he would have preferred the Treasury, following Labour's 1997 election success Mr Cook took a job at the Foreign Office and used it as his springboard, determined to revitalise its stuffy establishment ethos. In his arrogant self-confidence, he proclaimed it would show an "ethical dimension" before he had assessed the multiple pressures on foreign policy, including Britain's big arms exporting companies. He also courted controversy in May 1997 when he backed the United States' decision to renew China's trade benefits.

But even when he was performing well, as over Kosovo, arrogance barged in. Pressmen were struck by the way the articulate Mr Cook treated George Robertson, then defence secretary, almost as a junior minister in joint press conferences.

And because arrogance invites exposure, Cook's apparent slip-ups have brought ferocious attacks. Accompanying the Queen on her tour to Pakistan he apparently repeated the British mantra of offering mediation on Kashmir and was countered by then Indian prime minister Inder Kumar Gujral's reported retort that Britain was a "third rate power poking its nose in."

In India with the Queen, Mr Cook defused the row by pointing out that he had not spoken on the issue in public. "I gave no interview, press conference or public statement on Kashmir while in Pakistan,' he said.

The blame heaped on him over the Sierra Leone affair was also exaggerated. Trying to reinstall the ousted President Kabbah, he was apparently not informed by local diplomats of the duplicitous role of the Sandline mercenaries, involved in the local diamond industry.

Robin Cook's interest in politics began when he started reading the New Statesman as a 14-year-old. His prickly personality as a loner and insensitive intellectual snob was already evident at Edinburgh University. It probably stems from his treatment as the bright only child of a Lanarkshire headmaster.

As a longtime two-timer, there was nobody else to blame for the public breakup of his 28-year marriage to Margaret, a respected haematology consultant. It was described as "a shotgun divorce" because, as the couple were leaving for a riding holiday, Alastair Campbell phoned to tell Mr Cook that the News of the World was splashing on his longstanding affair with his secretary Gaynor Regan, now his wife. Mr Cook was urged to make up his mind, and he did so telling his wife that he was leaving her. When asked what he would do if she committed suicide, he replied, "I should of course be sorry."

This invited her retribution, including a book which accused him of, in the 1980s, of being drunk and a depressive. She agreed his intelligence and ability was unmatched, but asserted that he had "absolutely no natural courtesy or sympathy and no awareness of his lack of [these] qualities".

Cook responded by describing her book as "vindictive and undignified".

Having been badly wounded, he was lucky and presumably grateful that the prime minister did not sack him. He hailed Mr Blair's "Third Way" as a great new philosophy for the new age of "pluralism". His enthusiasm for Mr Blair, however, did not mean that relations warmed with two of the PM's closest allies, Gordon Brown and Peter Mandelson.

Mr Cook's antipathy for Mr Brown went back to the 1978-79 battle over Scottish devolution, when Mr Brown was on the "pro" side and he was a leading "anti". Mr Cook turned down an early appeal for support to become leader of the Scottish Labour party by future rival Gordon Brown.

Almost a quarter of a century later, his poor relationship with Mr Brown remains one of his "consuming passions", according to the Sunday Telegraph: "Mr Cook is known to go into a depression when the chancellor is doing well, a mood his officials have nicknamed 'Brown Dog'."

fields.headline: Sir Paddy Ashdown
fields.standfirst:
Yeovil (1983- )

Ask Aristotle about Paddy Ashdown
fields.trailText: Sir Paddy Ashdown's fame stems as much from a peccadillo and reports that he lasted nine-and-a-half seconds in the sack as from leading the Liberal Democrats for 11 years.  Now he is party leader no more - whatever next for Paddy?
fields.body:
Sir Paddy Ashdown's fame stems as much from a peccadillo and reports that he lasted nine-and-a-half seconds in the sack as from leading the Liberal Democrats for 11 years. Now he is party leader no more - whatever next for Paddy?

Reports that "Action Man" Sir Paddy has gone cool on becoming the UN's top man in Kosovo encouraged his friends to believe that there is at least one area in which he has recovered his realism. After his forays into the Balkans, he presented many solutions. But it was entirely another thing to spend his sixties keeping vengeful Albanians from the throats of their Serbian enemies.

Admittedly, this reassurance came only after he exposed himself in his published diaries as a hopeless romantic and wishful thinker. He believed that Liberal Democrat dreams of going into government and achieving PR could be realised by secret negotiations with Tony Blair before the 1997 general election. But Mr Blair used him as part of a separate Blair-Mandelson "project" which they hoped would create a pro-European coalition centre party linking the Lib Dems to a Labour party purged of its leftwing. What Sir Paddy did not comprehend was that Mr Blair could not deliver on his own, with only the support of Peter Mandelson and Robin Cook, while most of the then shadow cabinet remained hostile.

Sir Paddy believed he could get Mr Blair to commit a future Labour government to PR and to promise to exclude Jack Straw from the cabinet, because Mr Straw is known to be hostile both to PR and the Lib Dems. I observed his euphoria when we met on Victoria street in December 1996. He was exultant, predicting Blair would purge Labour's 40-odd leftwing MPs after the election and replace their support with Lib Dems. "But Blair can't do that!" was my instant response. "I'm sure you know more about the Labour Party than I do," he conceded. How did he spend his 20 years in politics in friendly rivalry with Labour?

After all, he had been a Labour supporter as a marine, before he joined the Liberal party in 1975 - at which time he is popularly supposed to have been serving with MI6 in Geneva under the cover of being the first secretary to the UK mission to the UN. It was in that cushy but dull job that he made the "crazy, irresponsible, naive" decision to go jobless into Liberal politics in his wife's home town of Yeovil. From the time he was selected as a candidate in 1976, he had to study how to "squeeze" the local Labour vote to enable him to defeat the Tories there, which he only achieved in 1983. "At one time we were down to our last 15p," he recalls.

From his early years as an active Liberal politician, he was on his party's social democratic wing. He favoured the 1977 Lib-Lab pact, crusaded against cruise missiles in 1981-82 and opposed the privatisation of royal ordnance in 1984. In 1986 he criticised the Thatcher government for allowing the US to bomb Libya from UK bases. He campaigned against the loss of rights by GCHQ workers in 1987.

In 1988, he became the first elected leader of the Lib Dems, defeating the more conservative Alan Beith. By that time, after the tortuous struggle to merge the Liberals and most of the SDP, the new party seemed on its last legs - in November 1989 the Lib Dems were down to 3% in the polls.

Then Sir Paddy's Lib Dems captured Eastbourne from the Tories in October 1990, in the wake of the IRA killing of Ian Gow, Mrs Thatcher's parliamentary private secretary. The Lib Dems followed this by taking Ribble Valley from the Tories and Sir Paddy was polled as the most popular leader of a national party. His popularity soared by another 13% when he disclosed that, five years earlier, he had enjoyed a five-month-long affair with his former secretary, Tricia Howard.

His manic energy infused the party. His first general election, April 1992, was not a success, mainly because of John Major's late claim that voting for the Lib Dems would "let in Labour". The Lib Dem vote sagged to 18%. This was decisively reversed in 1997 when a 19% vote produced 46 Lib Dem MPs.

Sir Paddy's career was a strange outcome for an imperial Ulsterman who decided at 18 to become a marine. Born Jeremy in July 1941 in New Delhi, he enlisted in the marines while at Bedford school, which had been attended by his father, grandfather and great-grandfather. It was there he was renamed "Paddy". He became the youngest commander in the special boat squadron and, after learning Malay, he studied Chinese for two-and-a-half years before transferring to MI6 in Geneva.

By that time he was married to Jane (Courtenay), the daughter of a west country Tory councillor. In their first decade in the services, when they had a son, Simon, and a daughter, Katharine, Jane was described as "the complete army wife: loyal, down to earth, supportive". She needed this last quality when her husband had his affair, even more after it was reported five years later with the brilliant, scathing Sun headline: "Paddy Pantsdown".

fields.standfirst:
Linlithgow (1983- )
West Lothian (1962-1983)

Ask Aristotle about Tam Dalyell
fields.trailText: Shambling, ill-dressed Tam Dalyell has been a MP since 1967 and a protesting thorn in every government's side for just as long. His persistent individualism has helped rescue the House of Commons' sense of worth. Currently MP for Linlithgow and a columnist and obituary writer, he must wonder how his own obituaries will depict him: eccentric rebel or something more?
fields.body:
Shambling, ill-dressed Tam Dalyell has been a MP since 1967 and a protesting thorn in every government's side for just as long. His persistent individualism has helped rescue the House of Commons' sense of worth. Currently MP for Linlithgow and a columnist and obituary writer, he must wonder how his own obituaries will depict him: eccentric rebel or something more?

His list of rebellions is long and part heroic, even yielding a recent biography, The Man They Can't Gag. Among other things, he has stood against the Falklands war and the sinking of the Belgrano, against the Gulf war and against devolution, right down to the final referendum. Yet he has opposed every recent British military venture - the Falklands, Iraq, Kosovo - without fully explaining his true reasons: he is effectively a pacifist.

Because he has so often rebelled, some have assumed he is a leftist. For a period he was in the hard-left Campaign group, but was certainly its only member with peacocks on his lawn. He even won a seat on their slate on Labour's NEC 1986-87. However, it was soon realised he was not in that stream. He is a pro-European, a believer in nuclear power and a fierce opponent of devolution, even for his native Scotland.

The problem is that he has sometimes fought his rebellions on thin grounds to rather than speak out about his pacifism. He resisted the Falklands war on the flimsy grounds of a possible Peruvian peace initiative. (Few others took the Peruvian effort seriously.) Similarly, he opposed the liberation of Kuwait allegedly because Saddam's igniting of its oil fields would destroy the Arab world's natural environment.

In fact, he even downplays his name. Rightly he is Sir Tam Dalyell Bt, a hereditary baronet, still the tenant of his family's 17th century mansion, The Binns, at Linlithgow. The house was made over to the national trust for Scotland by his mother.

He is an Old Etonian who became president of the Cambridge University Association in 1954. He joined the Labour party in 1956 in protest against the Tories' invasion of Egypt. By 1961 he had captured West Lothian, and his first outburst, after a 1965 trip to south-east Asia, was to try to stop Britain's war in Borneo.

He went on to warn prime minister Harold Wilson against selling out to Rhodesia's Ian Smith, and then resisted Mr Wilson's secret transfer of the African island of Diego Garcia to the Americans without the approval of the island's residents. But he won fame for his constituency by posing the still unanswered "West Lothian question" about why Scottish MPs should be able to vote on English matters while English MPs lose their right to vote on devolved Scottish matters.

Ask Aristotle about Tam Dalyell

fields.headline: ITV firms pocket cash windfall from new licence deal
fields.standfirst: Table: the digital dividend
fields.trailText:
1pm: Carlton and Granada have been given a multimillion pound windfall by TV regulators, writes Dan Milmo.
Table: the digital dividend
fields.body:
Carlton and Granada were today handed a multimillion pound windfall by television regulators.

They will save millions of pounds a year thanks to a new deal on the cash they pay the government for their right to broadcast.

Shares in the ITV giants rose in early trading after the companies were offered better-than-expected terms to renew their broadcast licences by TV regulators.

However, analysts said all ITV companies will benefit from the new licence terms because the amount they pay in the "percentage of qualifying revenue", or proportion of advertising income, will fall as the network switches to digital.

The deal is part of the government's blueprint for the future of television.

The government has offered a "digital dividend", or rebate based on the number of viewers who watch the network on digital television.

For example, Carlton Communications could save up to £10m a year for every 10% rise in the number of ITV digital viewers.

Granada was today asked to pay £4.9m in cash and 17% of its advertising revenue for its LWT licence, and £4.1m and 15% of advertising income for the Granada franchise.

The company bid £9m for the Granada licence in the controversial ITV franchise auction in 1991.

Carlton's Central franchise was snapped up for a derisory £2,000 a year 10 years ago, but the company has now been offered £7.6m per 12 months.

Analysts said the new terms will add £30m to Granada's revenues this year, sending its shares up 4% in early trading.

"Because some investors look for short-term incomes, the licence renewal should have a positive impact. However, the digital dividend has already been factored in to the long-term calculations, so it should not have a huge effect," said one analyst.

The digital dividend offers a ray of light for beleaguered ITV franchise holders, who have been battered by recession in the TV advertising market.

ITV companies will also receive a one-off boost from last week's deal between ITV and Luxembourg-based SES Astra, which will see the network broadcast on digital satellite by the end of the year.

Renewal terms for the 10-year licences were also offered for Border, owned by Capital Radio; SMG's Scottish and Grampian; Channel, owned by Channel Television; and Carlton's Central licence.

webTitle: Syrians fall victim to racism in Lebanon

fields.headline: Syrians fall victim to racism in Lebanon
fields.standfirst:
After President Hafez al-Assad of Syria died last June, questions about Lebanon's relationship with its neighbour have come into the open, says Brian Whitaker

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: After President Hafez al-Assad of Syria died last June, questions about Lebanon's relationship with its neighbour have come into the open, says Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
Last Wednesday traffic in Beirut - probably the Middle East's most frenetic city - came to a halt. The cause of the chaos, depending how you look at it, was either a student protest against the Syrian presence in Lebanon or the roadblocks set up to control the protesters.

Syrian troops have been in Lebanon since 1976 and remain there ostensibly for security reasons - to prevent a resumption of civil war. They number about 21,000, plus members of the Syrian secret police.

As the Syrians are there by agreement with the Lebanese government they are not, legally speaking, an army of occupation. But many regard this as a mere fig leaf: almost everyone who holds a senior position in Lebanon is, one way or another, in hock to the Syrians and therefore has no option but to accept their presence.

After President Hafez al-Assad of Syria died last June, debate about Lebanon's relationship with its neighbour came into the open. Although the most strident opposition to Syria comes from Christian elements (who were, ironically, supported by the Syrians in the 1970s), others doubt whether Syrian forces are strictly necessary to maintain security.

"There is an argument that it could all fall apart without the Syrian presence," a western in Beirut diplomat said. "But this assumes that the factions would start fighting again. Many Lebanese say not: there is an idea that the civil war was caused by Palestinians and Israelis fighting their battles on Lebanese soil. That is only partly true."

Nevertheless, the average Beiruti these days seems more interested in pursuing a hedonistic lifestyle than in sectarian politics. There is also, some suggest, a growing sense of national identity in Lebanon now that memories of the civil war are beginning to fade.

"We want to be an independent country without Syria influencing every decision we make. That's the gist of it," says Hanna Anbar, editor of Beirut's Daily Star.

Most Lebanese, as well as Syria's new president, Bashar al-Assad, see no harm in reviewing the two countries' relationship as circumstances change. But what ought to be a civilised debate has, at street level, taken a nasty turn. People complain that Syrian workers "come here and take our jobs". The Syrians "flood our markets" with their cheap melons and tomatoes, and, as a result, are "ruining our agriculture".

This is the familiar language of racism the world over. If Syrian workers could afford to buy houses in Lebanon they would no doubt also be accused of bringing down property values by their presence.

The other day a Syrian walked into the lobby of the hotel where I was staying in Beirut and inquired politely if there were any jobs. He had obviously done his best to look smart, but his clothes were so old and unfashionable that he could not possibly be mistaken for a Lebanese. He was told, in the most abrupt terms, to get lost.

One statistic constantly cited by the Lebanese to back up their complaints is that there are up to a million Syrian workers in Lebanon. If they all send a dollar a day back to Syria, that's a million dollars that Lebanon is "losing" every day.

The argument assumes, of course, that Lebanon gets nothing in return for the million dollars - which is patently untrue.

Syrian workers are what, in Britain, would be disparagingly referred to as "economic migrants": uneducated rural folk, desperate for money. They work hard, put up with wretched living conditions, and generally do the sort of jobs that most Lebanese would consider beneath their dignity.

The Lebanese are also quite happy to take advantage of Syria's lower prices. Every week thousands - often the same ones who curse Syrian immigrants - drive to Damascus to buy food and clothing for a quarter or a third of what they would cost in Lebanon.

The Syrian shopkeepers are very obliging. "If you want a designer label saying Polo or Cerruti on your new clothes, they will put one on," Anbar says.

There's also Souq al-Tanabil ("the lazy people's market") in Damascus, specially catering for Lebanese shoppers. You order your vegetables and pick them up in an hour or so - cleaned, peeled and chopped for cooking.

At the root of the problem - as often happens with racism - is an economic issue.

The Syrians are poor but the Lebanese earn higher wages and have a higher standard of living. Lebanon enjoyed an economic boom after the civil war - caused mainly by rebuilding work and the return of capital from abroad.

But now the boom has run out of steam. The government has finally got round to sacking the thousands of employees it never really needed. And it now expects people to pay taxes - something that didn't happen during the war.

Beirut's pre-eminence as the Middle East's financial centre is also facing challenges as other Arab countries open up their banking systems.

In a country where you're a nobody unless you have a cellphone, a car and the latest version of everything, the future looks uncertain, if not downright alarming. And the Syrians are a convenient scapegoat.

Historically, there has always been interaction between Syria and Lebanon and, whatever the racists think, many argue that both countries have a lot to gain if it continues.

"So much cooperation could take place - in banking, water and other areas," Anbar says.

He points out that in the 1930s and 1940s most Lebanese politicians married Syrian women, especially those from Aleppo. "They had beauty and money," he says.

"The biggest businessmen in Lebanon today are of Syrian origin. Many came because of a coup or discrimination. They are hard workers and definitely better businessmen than the Lebanese."

webTitle: Online poll gives Crouching Tiger the people's Oscars

fields.headline: Online poll gives Crouching Tiger the people's Oscars
fields.trailText: Russell Crowe, Julia Roberts and Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon have come out on top in the online poll in which 10,000 movie fans voted in every Academy Award category
fields.body:
With less than a week to go until Oscar night, an online poll of over 10,000 movie goers has revealed that Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is the most popular film of the year.

The People's Choice poll, carried out by the International Movie Data Base and Amazon.co.uk, asked users to vote in each of the Academy Award categories.

In the closest call of all, Ang Lee's Chinese language film beat Ridley Scott's Gladiator to win the Best Picture prize by picking up 37% of the vote, compared with 34% for the Roman epic.

According to the poll, Ang Lee should also pick up the Best Director award, pulling in 43% of the vote, and Russell Crowe should beat Tom Hanks and Geoffrey Rush to receive the Best Actor prize for his role as Maximus in Gladiator.

Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon also won four other categories; Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Art Direction and Best Editing.

There were no surprises in the Best Actress category - 50% of the pollsters believe Julia Roberts should win for her role as the feisty legal assistant Erin Brockovich.

In the Best Supporting Actor category, Benicio Del Toro picked up 42% of the vote for his role as the tough cop in Traffic. His nearest rival was Gladiator's Joaquin Phoenix who pulled in 24%.

Kate Hudson received a healthy 44% for her role as Penny Lane in Almost Famous to win the Best Supporting Actress vote, leaving Brits Judi Dench and Julie Walters trailing behind with 15% and 13%.

If this poll proves an accurate indicator for Sunday, then it will be a bad night for the Brits all round. Steven Daldry's Billy Elliot failed to win in any category at all.

fields.headline: Popstars on song with 7m viewers
fields.trailText: 3.15pm TV overnights: Hear'Say ended their series on a high as 7m tuned in to see them top the charts, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The final instalment of Popstars pulled in more than 7m viewers last night, as Hear'Say discovered their debut single had sold more than half a million and gone straight to the top of the charts.

Popstars was broadcast on ITV between 6.15pm and 7.05pm.

The climax came just before 7pm, when presenter Davina McCall and the five band members heard Pure and Simple had charted at number one.

They did a simultaneous live interview with BBC Radio 1 chart show presenter Mark Goodier.

The final episode of the series had 7.1m viewers and a 32% audience share, according to unofficial overnights.

The show nearly doubled the usual ratings figures for the Sunday night ITV slot.

In the past four weeks, ITV regional programming and Worthington Cup final highlights have averaged 3.8m viewers.

Elsewhere, the drama of Celebrity Big Brother had completely petered out by Saturday night.

The "uncut" version of the show - which showed Vanessa in tears and Anthea talking about cooking a magic-mushroom cake - was watched by just 2.7m viewers on Channel 4.

BBC1's attempt to inject some life into its troubled Sunday 9pm slot also failed to inspire.

Venom, a documentary on poisonous animals, pulled in just 5.2m viewers and a 21% share.

ITV opposition London's Burning trounced the show with an audience of 10.2m at 9pm.

Earlier in the evening, BBC1 drama Ballykissangel continued to flounder against ITV's Heartbeat between 8.10pm and 9pm.

Ballykissangel was watched by just 4.9m viewers while Heartbeat pulled in 12.4m.

Channel 4 last night gave terrestrial premieres to two potentially controversial films, 1990s clubbing movie Human Traffic and long-outlawed 1970s erotic flick the Story of O, from 10pm.

Human Traffic had 1.4m viewers and a 10% share; while the Story of O drew 0.9m and a 22% share between 12am and 1am.

Channel 5's 80s Weekend featured the Hit Factory: the Pete Waterman Story from 8pm last night.

The documentary had 1.1m and a 4% share; tying with the first instalment of the Channel 4 religious documentary series Witness.

fields.headline: Interpublic swoops for True North
fields.trailText:
3.15pm update: Interpublic, whose clients include Coke and Unilever, has confirmed it is to buy True North, writes Claire Cozens.

Mar 19: Interpublic snaps up True North
fields.body:
Interpublic today confirmed it has agreed to buy True North Communications and named David Bell, chief executive of True North, as its new vice-chairman.

The deal, worth £1.39bn, brings together top advertisers including Coca-Cola, General Motors and Unilever.

It means Interpublic has now overtaken WPP as the world's biggest advertising group, with revenues of £4.8bn compared with WPP's £4.6bn.

Under the deal, New York-based Interpublic will swap 1.14 of its shares for each True North share.

Interpublic, which owns advertising agencies McCann-Erickson and the Lowe Group, said the deal would add to its earnings per share this year and in 2002 and yield cost savings of £16.5m annually.

"Interpublic and True North create an industry-leading combination of advertising and marketing services capabilities to offer our clients on a global basis," said John Dooner, chairman and chief executive of Interpublic.

The deal ends months of speculation that Chicago-based True North would be acquired by a larger company.

True North, whose other advertising agencies include Bozell Group, has been seen as a takeover target since FCB lost the multibillion-dollar Chrysler account to rival BBDO Worldwide.

The advertising industry has been consolidating heavily in recent years. Last year France's Publicis doubled its size by acquiring Britain's best-known agency, Saatchi & Saatchi.

webTitle: Long-term care for the elderly: the issue explained

fields.headline: Long-term care for the elderly: the issue explained
fields.trailText: New Labour came into power promising a royal commission into long-term care for the elderly. Matters were in a mess.
fields.body:
New Labour came into power promising a royal commission into long-term care for the elderly. Matters were in a mess.

The previous Tory government had been beleaguered by stories of elderly people having to sell their homes to pay the fees when they went into nursing or residential homes. Newspapers ran articles on elderly homeowners, who had paid tax and national insurance all their lives, and who could now no longer pass the homes they'd worked hard to buy on to their children. It was very bad publicity for a government ostensibly committed to hard-working people and the very British "right to buy" your own home.

And it was a nightmare for many elderly people who didn't have sufficient funds to pay for their care. Those who were cared for in hospitals received free care. But those with conditions such as Alzheimer's disease who were cared for "in the community", including in residential or nursing homes, were means-tested and often ended up paying for their care.

After coming to power, New Labour quickly set up a commission in late 1997, headed by Sir Stewart Sutherland, principal of Edinburgh University. The commission took a year to report.

But the government attracted criticism by delaying its response - it took nearly as long to answer as it did for the commission to hear from interested parties, gather all the evidence, examine the current set-up and future options, weigh up the pros and cons and come up with proposals. Critics felt that ministers had kicked the issue into the long grass in order to avoid a big public spending pledge. Sir Stewart and all but two of his fellow commissioners recommended that nursing and personal care be funded from general taxation and free at the point of delivery - wherever that "delivery" took place - at a cost of roughly £1bn a year.

Finally, the government agreed to fund nursing care - but only that given by a qualified nurse, as opposed to, for example, a healthcare assistant. Personal care, such as help with washing, using the toilet, eating and dressing, would still be subject to means tests and paid for by a client who was judged to have enough money to do so.

Campaigning groups for the elderly were disappointed at this halfway measure. But they were cheered north of the border when the Scottish executive agreed that personal care would be free, as well as nursing care. This was in spite of the pressure said to have been exerted on Scottish Labour leaders by Labour at Westminster.

Now, there will shortly be a situation where older people living just miles from each other in English and Scottish towns will face very different funding arrangements.

And then there's the revolt by independent care home owners. For some time, they have been complaining that local authorities have been keeping the rates they pay for care home places - where they, rather than the individual residents, pay them - unrealistically low. The home owners have lobbied parliament, harangued local councillors and a few have even talked of refusing more council placements.

Some critics argue that it's not the public sector's job to subsidise private care companies - and that private care home owners should have thought about this when they set their own prices low in order to win the business from the councils, during the era of market testing and compulsory competitive tendering. Others say that money needs to be spent increasingly on supporting older people in their own homes, not in institutions.

But some care home owners take pride in their work and offer good quality services - and are horrified that they might be driven out of business by apparently uncaring councillors and a government seemingly deaf to their demands. Small, local care homes will go out of business, they say, to be replaced by big care conglomerates running large homes akin to the huge, old long-stay, geriatric institutions now frowned upon and closed.

It's not quite got to the point where frail or confused elderly people are turfed out of their care homes because of a lack of funds. But the battle is hotting up.

fields.headline: European satellite firm shows its strength
fields.trailText:
3pm: The company which beams BSkyB to millions of UK viewers has tightened its grip on the European market, reports Dan Milmo.
Mar 14: ITV anticipates cash injection
Mar 14: ITV to open negotiations with Sky
Mar 14: ITV under pressure to join Sky
Mar 14: ITV comes in from digital wilderness
fields.body:
Societe Europeenne des Satellites, the Luxembourg-based company that beams BSkyB's channels to millions of UK viewers, has tightened its grip on the European satellite market.

The group sprang to prominence last week when it signed a £100m deal to broadcast ITV programmes on a digital satellite platform, and is set to snap up a US competitor.

But its full-year results today showed the strength of its position in Europe, with its profits rising 21% to £153m for 2000.

SES reaches 87m homes in Europe, and has stakes in companies which operate in South America and Asia.

However, investors will want to know how close SES is to closing a deal with a US rival, believed to be General Electric's GE Americom, which would crown it the largest satellite company in the world.

Romain Bausch, director general of SES, hinted that a deal was close in the company's results statement.

"To further SES's geographical coverage a number of strategic initiatives are currently actively being pursued," he said.

fields.headline: Chief vet meets angry farmers
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, was today meeting farmers in Cumbria whose animals face compulsory slaughter to protect against the spread of foot and mouth disease.
fields.body:
The chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, was today meeting farmers in Cumbria whose animals face compulsory slaughter to protect against the spread of foot and mouth disease.

Three more outbreaks were confirmed in the county yesterday, bringing the total number of cases in Britain to 326.

A cattle farm at Wigton, a cattle and sheep farm at Penrith and a small sheep and cattle holding at Kirkhampton, near Carlisle, were the latest among 89 Cumbrian farms infected with the virus.

The government wants to slaughter up to half a million healthy sheep and pigs in the county and in neighbouring Dumfries and Galloway in Scotland to create "firebreaks" around the affected farms in an effort to contain the disease.

But the decision has proved unpopular among farmers, some of whom greeted Mr Scudamore with a slow handclap when he arrived in Carlisle this morning.

Outside a closed meeting between Mr Scudamore, local vets and the National Farmers' Union, livestock farmers protested against the cull. A number of landowners waited outside with a placard reading "the silence of the lambs for Blair's election?".

Margaret Smith, a farmer's wife from Gretna, said: "Is this based on epidemiology or political thoughts? I've been talking to one boy whose father's farm is 100 yards outside the killing area. So can Mr Scudamore tell me his sheep are not going to catch foot-and-mouth?

"The disease can travel 60 miles, so why don't they kill for 60 miles?" she said.

Retired farmer Arthur Ogle said the plan to slaughter healthy animals was "bloody terrible". He added: "They will never stop the disease until they stop the way animals are transported."

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, has warned that the three-week-old outbreak is likely to persist for several months.

A lack of vets is hindering attempts to speed up diagnosis of the disease and the slaughter and disposal of animals.

But plans were progressing to involve military personnel in the planning of animal movement and slaughter, junior agriculture minister Baroness Hayman said, with Ministry of Defence officials acting as mobile supervisors.

About 120 final-year vet students have also agreed to work alongside trained vets in helping to spot the disease, said deputy chief veterinary officer Martin Atkinson, adding that he hoped that number would rise to about 200.

He revealed that the number of vets from the state veterinary service usually working in the field had dropped from about 400 at the time of the 1967 outbreak to just 220 today.

Mr Atkinson said that the service was facing an "unprecedented challenge", but said that students and vets from overseas were still volunteering to come to Britain.

She said the government was considering making inspectors available for each movement of animals, but added that the farming community had an interest in policing itself to stop the spread of disease.

Mr Brown was today meeting European Union agriculture commissioner Franz Fischler to discuss possible recovery packages for farmers.

He could be ready to make an announcement about aid before the end of the week, Baroness Hayman told a media briefing in London.

She said that the government was still considering a number of options, including the possibility of trying to save some rare breeds from being slaughtered.

Infected animals would still face certain slaughter, she said, but added: "We are looking at ways, in particular circumstances where a unique genetic breed would be lost, if there is anything we can do about it."

fields.headline: Trisha falls foul of ITC
fields.trailText:
2.45pm: The watchdog has upheld viewer complaints against an edition of the ITV daytime talk show, writes Jason Deans.
Useful link: www.itc.org.uk
fields.body:
The Independent Television Commission has upheld viewer complaints against an edition of the ITV daytime talk show Trisha, which featured a woman who fatally stabbed her partner.

The ITC ruled than ITV and Anglia, which produced the programme, had been unfair to interview Diana Butler without allowing the family of the deceased, Roger Carlin, to defend him.

The watchdog ruled the programme had breached its programme code.

"The programme presented Mr Carlin in an unfair light and did not give due consideration to the perspectives of his family," the ITC stated in its February programme complaints and findings report.

The ITC received four viewer complaints about the show, which went out on 23 November last year.

Mr Carlin's family alleged Ms Butler had been allowed to present herself as the victim of a violent relationship without their son's side of the story being heard.

Ms Butler was convicted of murder after fatally stabbing Mr Carlin in July 1996 but the conviction was subsequently quashed on appeal.

During the retrial, Ms Butler accepted a prosecution offer of a plea of manslaughter on the basis of diminished responsibility because she had been a victim of domestic violence.

Anglia had refused Mr Carlin's parents' request to appear in the show because Ms Butler was reluctant to appear with them.

But the ITC accepted Trisha had introduced some challenging elements into the interview with Ms Butler, including two questions supplied by the Carlin family.

Useful link

webTitle: Garcia Marquez joins protest against new visa rules

fields.headline: Garcia Marquez joins protest against new visa rules
fields.trailText: Novelist and Nobel prize winner Gabriel Garcia Marquez yesterday swore never to set foot in Spain again unless the government withdraws new rules obliging Colombian visitors to obtain visas.
fields.body:
Novelist and Nobel prize winner Gabriel Garcia Marquez yesterday swore never to set foot in Spain again unless the government withdraws new rules obliging Colombian visitors to obtain visas.

The author of One Hundred Years of Solitude, the sculptor and painter Fernando Botero and five other Colombian writers have sent letters of protest to Spain's prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar.

Garcia Marquez, who lived in Barcelona in the 1960s and is a constant visitor, said that Colombians grew up thinking of Spain as the "madre patria", or mother country, even though Colombia won independence from Spain in 1820.

The visa restrictions, to be introduced in April, were approved by EU interior ministers in Brussels on Thursday.

Nearly a million of Colombia's 40 million population are estimated to have left the country in the past year, mainly because of poverty, guerrilla warfare and the violence of the cocaine cartels.

webTitle: Youth hostels face losses of up to £6m

fields.headline: Youth hostels face losses of up to £6m
fields.standfirst:
Closures mean association will have worst season ever

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Closures mean association will have worst season ever.
fields.body:
The Youth Hostels Association is facing the worst crisis in its 70-year history after being forced to close almost half its hostels because of foot and mouth disease.

The association could lose almost £6m, a fifth of its turnover, if the outbreak continues until the end of June. Officials are trying not to contemplate the consequences if the countryside remains effectively closed through the peak summer period and into the autumn.

Some 110 out of 230 hostels from Land's End to Wooler in north Northumberland have closed, at a time when wardens (now known as managers) were preparing for the Easter rush. In the Lake District national park alone, 15 hostels have shut.

In a normal year, 350,000 hostellers would have been welcomed in March and April and would have been served 477,000 meals.

About 200 jobs have been lost, either by deferring start dates for seasonal staff or by leaving vacancies unfilled. Another 200 jobs are threatened.

Cancellations have poured in from school groups intend ing field studies or outdoor pursuits trips, and from tourists in countries such as Germany, Norway and Ireland.

Bookings at city hostels, including those in London, have also been hit.

"This is the biggest crisis that has hit the association in its entire existence," said Margaret Whaley, a YHA director. "By the end of April, we will face a net loss of £2m. If it continues to the end of June, we are talking about an additional £3.8m.

"Everything that we earn we put back into our properties, and we do not have extensive reserves. Our investment programme has already been cancelled. We have some new hostels coming on line, and we cannot stop those projects; but plans for badly needed refurbishments in the coming autumn and winter have been halted.

"We are talking about a very serious position for us and for our future.

"We are not going to close down, but we are going to be very severely hit."

Ms Whaley was among representatives from organisations with a stake in the rural economy who met Tony Blair at Downing Street last week for crisis talks which led to the setting up of a task force chaired by the environment minister, Michael Meacher.

"The priority is to get the countryside open again ,but then we are going to need help to rebuild," she said.

"We will be looking for help with capital investment, and we support the British Tourist Authority's bid for funds for marketing overseas. We will need to raise tourists' confidence in coming to the UK."

The YHA, which has 300,000 members in England and Wales, is uncertain whether some hostels will have to close permanently. "We are reviewing the situa tion on a day to day basis," said Ms Whaley.

At Gradbach Mill hostel on the Staffordshire-Derbyshire border in the Peak District national park, manager Graham Ives is spending his days on maintenance work.

"Five footpaths meet at my front door, and normally by this time of day I would have seen 40 or so walkers," he said. "But I haven't seen anyone."

Gradbach is a stone-built former flax mill with 87 beds and a TV lounge and bar. Usually during the week it is busy with school parties and with ramblers at weekends. One staff member has been laid off, one has moved to a hostel which remains open, and a third is on unpaid leave.

fields.bodyText: The Youth Hostels Association is facing the worst crisis in its 70-year history after being forced to close almost half its hostels because of foot and mouth disease. The association could lose almost £6m, a fifth of its turnover, if the outbreak continues until the end of June. Officials are trying not to contemplate the consequences if the countryside remains effectively closed through the peak summer period and into the autumn. Some 110 out of 230 hostels from Land's End to Wooler in north Northumberland have closed, at a time when wardens (now known as managers) were preparing for the Easter rush. In the Lake District national park alone, 15 hostels have shut. In a normal year, 350,000 hostellers would have been welcomed in March and April and would have been served 477,000 meals. About 200 jobs have been lost, either by deferring start dates for seasonal staff or by leaving vacancies unfilled. Another 200 jobs are threatened. Cancellations have poured in from school groups intend ing field studies or outdoor pursuits trips, and from tourists in countries such as Germany, Norway and Ireland. Bookings at city hostels, including those in London, have also been hit. "This is the biggest crisis that has hit the association in its entire existence," said Margaret Whaley, a YHA director. "By the end of April, we will face a net loss of £2m. If it continues to the end of June, we are talking about an additional £3.8m. "Everything that we earn we put back into our properties, and we do not have extensive reserves. Our investment programme has already been cancelled. We have some new hostels coming on line, and we cannot stop those projects; but plans for badly needed refurbishments in the coming autumn and winter have been halted. "We are talking about a very serious position for us and for our future. "We are not going to close down, but we are going to be very severely hit." fields.headline: Dos and don'ts for tourists
fields.standfirst:
Ros Taylor offers practical advice to anyone wanting to travel in Britain while foot and mouth restrictions are in place

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Ros Taylor offers practical advice to anyone wanting to travel in Britain while foot and mouth restrictions are in place.
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.body:
Should you cancel a holiday in Britain in the light of the foot and mouth outbreak? That really depends on what you are planning to do. Staying in London, with perhaps a few days in Edinburgh or another city, presents very little risk.

Foot and mouth, though highly infectious, poses no threat to humans - the danger lies in the possibility that you will spread it as you travel around the countryside.

Apart from Richmond Park in south-west London and the Giraffe and Elephant Houses at London Zoo, visitors to London will find that they can travel anywhere within the city without a problem. Nevertheless, an open park only a few minutes outside a city may well be out of bounds.

Similarly, if you plan to take the train to Oxford or Cambridge for the day, or hire a car and drive to a town, you are very unlikely to encounter difficulties as long as you stay in the city centre. However, you should avoid walking along the parts of the River Cam in Cambridge where sheep and cows graze, or venturing into a deer park.

However, if you are planning to explore the countryside on foot - or you had intended to do some hillwalking - it would be better to cancel the trip. Not only is there a £5000 fine for walkers who try to follow a closed path, but people living in rural communities will not take kindly to visitors who seem not to care if they are spreading the virus. Most zoos outside London are shut.

Driving along a public road in a rural area is usually perfectly acceptable. However, walking on farmland, moorland, footpaths and bridleways, where sheep, cattle, pigs, deer, goats and other livestock may be grazing, is most definitely not. Unfortunately, this includes many areas used for climbing and mountaineering.

The British Mountaineering Council has an up-to-date list of out-of-bounds places. All of the National Parks, including the Norfolk Broads, the Lake and Peak Districts, Snowdonia and Exmoor, have been closed.

Additionally, all Forestry Commission land is closed. Not all woods and forests are owned by the Commission but, unless you want to make yourself very unpopular, it is better to steer clear of them.

Many rights of way, or footpaths, have been closed by local councils - a list of them can be found here. National Trust houses in the countryside - including Blenheim Palace - are all shut, too. But a number of town properties are still open.

The British Tourist Board has a useful page of advice for those visitors in any doubt. Sadly, the disease is spreading so fast that it looks as though the current restrictions will be in place at least until the end of March, and quite possibly later.

The president of the National Farmers' Union, which represents the agricultural community in Britain, recently begged the public: "Remember the disease could be anywhere - not just in the restricted zones. I implore everyone once again: please, please stay away from the countryside".

Finally, you should seek advice from your own government about their restrictions. Imagine what the consequences might be if you inadvertently bring foot and mouth into your own country.

fields.headline: Government defies foot and mouth with tourist campaign
fields.trailText: 2pm: The government is considering an advertising campaign urging tourists to visit the countryside despite the foot-and-mouth crisis.
fields.body:
The government is considering launching an advertising campaign urging tourists at home and abroad to visit the countryside despite the foot and mouth crisis, Downing Street said today.

Tourism minister Janet Anderson is to visit the US tomorrow to hammer home the message that rural Britain is not closed for business.

The decision came out of talks held today between Tony Blair, agriculture minister Nick Brown and environment minister Michael Meacher, who chairs the rural recovery task force.

The spokesman said the government was considering a major public information campaign. He said this would focus on the UK, but that the government was also keen to convey its message abroad.

webTitle: CYPU head pledges to be tough over funds

fields.headline: CYPU head pledges to be tough over funds
fields.trailText: The recently appointed director of the government's new Children and Young People's Unit has warned she will be "tough" in ensuring the £450m children's fund is used for genuine local partnership.
fields.body:
The recently appointed director of the government's new Children and Young People's Unit (CYPU) has warned she will be "tough" in ensuring the £450m children's fund is used for genuine local partnership.

Althea Efunshile told a London conference organised by the CYPU that years of talk about partnership between local authorities, voluntary and community groups had too often failed to change practice on the ground.

"People will think this [partnership] is old hat - we have been talking about partnership for a long time but I don't think we have been working in partnership mode."

Asked what she would do if local administration of a children's fund allocation appeared to be dominated by one organisational or personal agenda, Ms Efunshile said: "I am prepared to be tough on behalf of children and young people."

She signalled that her unit would rigorously scrutinise arrangements for spending the £450m fund over three years. The CYPU administers the fund, which gives grants to community initiatives aimed at benefiting children living in poverty or at risk of poverty.

"It won't be good enough for local authorities, for example, to decide who the partners should be, what the priorities should be and where the money should go. We intend to make sure there is a proper partnership at the start: a partnership that involves faith groups, voluntary groups and business groups."

She repeated warnings from ministers that although local authorities would have a facilitating role they must be prepared to surrender hands-on leadership.

"We want to see communities leading the partnerships where possible. It is not our intention that the statutory sector must lead the partnership. It is difficult for statutory groups and large organisations to give over that power but it is increasingly the role of local authorities to provide leadership not from the front but from the side."

She said the fund, together with a raft of other government initiatives, provided an "unprecedented opportunity" to rescue those at risk and transform the often negative image of young people.

webTitle: Film world fears another Oscars theft

fields.headline: Film world fears another Oscars theft
fields.trailText: What do Citizen Kane, High Noon, Bonnie and Clyde, Dr Strangelove, Raging Bull and LA Confidential have in common? They did not win Oscars as best film. With barely a week to go until this year's ceremony, the traditional examination of "stolen" Oscars is soon to be under way again.
fields.body:
This time last year the talk was of the stolen Oscars which mysteriously went missing before the ceremony only to be found by Willie Fulgear, a freelance scrap dealer who briefly became a hero and received a $50,000 (£35,000) reward and a ticket to the awards ceremony.

The happy ending turned out to have a sting in its tail when it transpired that Mr Fulgear's half-brother was under investigation for receiving the Oscars, and the reward money later went missing. But as next Sunday's ceremony approaches, the talk is of a different kind of robbery.

What do Citizen Kane, High Noon, Bonnie and Clyde, Dr Strangelove, Raging Bull and LA Confidential have in common? They did not win Oscars as best film. And with barely a week to go until this year's envelopes are opened, the traditional examination of "stolen" Oscars is under way again.

Everyone has a favourite complaint about a film or actor overlooked in favour of some temporary dross, but this year the seemingly endless stream of awards ceremonies has focused attention more closely on why certain dull but worthy films succeed while more innovative and original ones fail.

Peter Rainer, critic of New York magazine, said yesterday that Robert Altman stood out as one director who had been unfairly ignored. "He has never been embraced by the Hollywood establishment," he said. "He still hasn't made it into the club and I guess he never will." Among others ignored for top prizes are Cary Grant, Fred Astaire and Charlie Chaplin. "My favourite [omission] is Laurence Olivier for one of the greatest performances ever in Othello in the year that Lee Marvin won for Cat Ballou," he said.

Emanuel Levy, the Variety film critic, in the latest book on the subject, Oscar Fever, concludes that "in years of fierce contest, the winning performance is not necessarily the strongest; at times it is the weakest."

He cites amongst conspicuous omissions Greta Garbo in Anna Karenina and Liv Ullman in Cries and Whispers, and notes that some actors have been consistently passed over, most notably the late Edward G Robinson. "Bette Davis was denied an Oscar for the greatest performance of her career as Margo Channing in All About Eve .. errors of omission are particularly visible in years in which the nominated achievements are mediocre compared with the excellence of those overlooked."

This year, the LA Times published its own list of controversial and innovative films that lost out to worthy films on "important" subjects. It cited Citizen Kane which lost to How Green Was My Valley in 1941; High Noon which lost to The Greatest Show on Earth in 1952; Bonnie and Clyde which lost to In the Heat of the Night in 1967; All the President's Men which lost to Rocky in 1976; Raging Bull which lost to Ordinary People in 1980; and Goodfellas which lost to Dances with Wolves in 1990.

Some esteemed directors apart from Altman have never won an Oscar for best director. Alfred Hitchcock was one, Martin Scorsese another. On the acting front, there have also been puzzling choices. Neither Dustin Hoffman nor Jon Voight won best actor for their roles in Midnight Cowboy, although the movie won best film Oscar and best director for John Schlesinger. Instead the prize went to John Wayne for True Grit.

When Spartacus lost out in 1960, the feeling was that it was a victim of the cold war. It was based on a book by a former communist, Howard Fast, and its script was by Dalton Trumbo, who had been jailed for refusing to testify to the House of Representatives committee on un-American activities. Mr Trumbo had already embarrassed the academy by winning an Oscar for The Brave One in 1957 under the pseudonym Robert Rich.

Kirk Douglas lost the best actor prize that year to Burt Lancaster in Elmer Gantry and told Entertainment Weekly in this year's Oscar special that "I thought we were unfairly discriminated against". The other epic of the era, Ben Hur, upset some critics by beating Some Like It Hot to the best film prize.

Whoever does win this year may make briefer thank-you speeches than usual. Conscious of the concerns of programme schedulers and people with low saccharine tolerance, the academy is offering the prize of a new high definition television set to the maker of the shortest speech. In a further bid to cut the endless thank yous, it has also offered to allow entire lists of thank yous to be posted on the internet ,so that winners who want to thank "everyone I have ever met in my life" can do so in full without delaying the actual ceremony. This year's big steal? No-one seems sure, although if, as one New York rumour has it, Chocolat wins against the odds, there will be plenty of candidates.

As for Willie Fulgear, well, he has made it into Vanity Fair's special Oscars issue, but is he happy? "I wish I'd never seen them Oscars," he is quoted as saying. "I'm taking medication! I am stressed!" He put $40,000 of the reward money in a safe at his home but when he came back from a trip last June both the safe and the money had gone. He has put the word out to the academy that he would like tickets to this year's event. So far they have not been forthcoming.

fields.headline: Sunday Times pays out in James Bond libel case
fields.trailText: 1pm: The Sunday Times is facing a legal bill of over £500,000 after a composer sued for libel.
fields.body:
The Sunday Times is facing a legal bill of over half-a-million pounds after an award-winning composer successfully sued for libel over an article that said he had falsely claimed credit for the James Bond theme tune.

Monty Norman was today awarded £30,000 libel damages by a high court jury over a 1997 article in which the Sunday Times claimed he did not write the James Bond theme.

But the total bill is expected to top £500,000 because of legal costs for the two-week trial.

Mr Norman said the Sunday Times article, published under the heading, "Theme tune wrangle has 007 shaken and stirred", "rubbished" his whole career.

The two-week hearing before centred on whether the theme's composer was Mr Norman - who has the work registered with the Performing Rights Society and has always received the royalties - or fellow composer Mr John Barry.

Times Newspapers denied libel and argued that Mr Barry was the composer of the tune, described to the court as "one of the most famous pieces of music in the world".

It first gripped the public imagination in the 1962 movie Dr No.

Sixty-seven-year-old Mr Barry has written the soundtracks to many Bond films, as well as Born Free, Zulu and Midnight Cowboy.

He told the jury that Mr Norman's claim that he, and he alone, wrote the tune was "absolute nonsense".

The case for Times Newspapers was that Mr Barry was brought in to write the theme at a late stage - six months into the project - because Mr Norman had run out of inspiration and there was a crisis.

The jury announced its verdict today after just over four hours deliberation. Mr Norman was present in court.
