The two-week hearing before centred on whether the theme's composer was Mr Norman - who has the work registered with the Performing Rights Society and has always received the royalties - or fellow composer Mr John Barry. Times Newspapers denied libel and argued that Mr Barry was the composer of the tune, described to the court as "one of the most famous pieces of music in the world". It first gripped the public imagination in the 1962 movie Dr No. Sixty-seven-year-old Mr Barry has written the soundtracks to many Bond films, as well as Born Free, Zulu and Midnight Cowboy. He told the jury that Mr Norman's claim that he, and he alone, wrote the tune was "absolute nonsense". The case for Times Newspapers was that Mr Barry was brought in to write the theme at a late stage - six months into the project - because Mr Norman had run out of inspiration and there was a crisis. The jury announced its verdict today after just over four hours deliberation. Mr Norman was present in court.

fields.headline: Kournikova to be new face of Lycos
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Tennis star Anna Kournikova has signed a £7m deal to be the new face of ISP Lycos, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Anna Kournikova has signed a £7m advertising deal to be the new face of internet service provider Lycos.

The 19-year-old tennis star will appear in Lycos TV, print and poster advertising and will feature prominently in promotions for the ISP.

Lycos is planning an online promotion called "Win Anna's Stuff" offering users the chance to win Ms Kournikova's BMW Z3 roadster.

The Russian tennis player has yet to win a major tournament, has nevertheless become one of advertising's most sought-after celebrities.

She has appeared in commercials for Adidas and in a controversial poster campaign for Berlei bras that used the line, "Only the ball should bounce".

And her sexy image has helped her to become the most searched-for sports star on the web, according to a Lycos survey.

The Lycos Sports 50, a ranking of the internet's most searched-for athletes, found Ms Kournikova got twice as many search requests as Tiger Woods and Michael Jordan combined.

It is not yet known whether Lycos will use Ms Kournikova for its European advertising.

Until recently Lycos adapted its US advertising for the European market but last year the company hired London agency Leagas Delaney to create European campaigns.

fields.headline: Interpublic snaps up True North
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Interpublic is to overtake Martin Sorrell's WPP as the world's biggest advertising company after buying True North, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Interpublic, the global advertising company that owns McCann-Erickson and Lowe Lintas, is poised to overtake Martin Sorrell's WPP as the world's biggest advertising company with the acquisition of True North Communications.

The deal, worth £1.39bn, is expected to be announced today. It marks the end of a closely-watched auction that saw True North linked with most of the world's major advertising companies, including France's Havas and WPP.

True North, which owns advertising agencies FCB and Bozell, has been vulnerable to a takeover since it lost Daimler Chrysler, its biggest client, to rival agency BBDO Worldwide last year.

The loss resulted in a large number of redundancies and a drop in True North's share price.

The combined company would have revenues of £4.8bn based on earnings for 2000, making it the world's biggest advertising company by revenues. WPP had revenues of £4.6bn last year.

Chicago-based True North is said to have entered into exclusive negotiations with Interpublic this weekend.

fields.headline: Blair 's bay of pigs (and sheep)
fields.standfirst:
Where JFK had a nuclear stand-off, Blair has an election date crisis

Special report: election countdown
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Where JFK had a nuclear stand-off, Blair has an election date crisis.
fields.body:
In the movie Thirteen Days, which opened yesterday, lookalikes of Jack and Bobby Kennedy avert the third world war during the Cuban missile crisis of 1962. It's a long, slow film - and has been criticised for this - but uses the time and space to illustrate something rarely seen and crucial: the agonising and treacherous process of political decision making. Caught between a war-hungry military and civilian aides wary of reducing their own and other countries to charred rubble, JFK, not yet two years a president, must make choices which will shape the future.

The film sentimentalises Kennedy - ignoring, for example, historical suggestions that his nuclear-powered libido may not have been confined to its silo even as the world faced armageddon - but it serves as a timely corrective to current thinking. We live in a time when it has become standard to regard politicians as venal or idiotic figures, largely ceremonial leaders steered through their displays of fakery by spin doctors. Thirteen Days reminds us of what democracy may come to: a leader alone in a room, knowing that going with Plan A or B may affect the lives of millions or hundreds of millions of people; it manages to depict the process of political thinking.

Watching Bruce Greenwood's imitation of JFK, I thought frequently of Tony Blair. The comparisons were not those for which Alastair Campbell might hope - boyish grin, charisma, rich wife, indelible place in history - but rather the feeling that Blair is fast approaching the decisions on which his career and eventual reputation depend. Where Kennedy had Bay of Pigs and the 1962 nuclear stand-off, Blair faces his Bay of Cows and Sheep and the election date crisis.

Media election coverage frequently makes use of the phrase "decision day". But there is compelling evidence that the decision day that really matters is the one when the leader comes to a verdict which overshadows the rest of his or her administration.

John Major's premiership was effectively over when he spent the national financial reserves on supporting the pound against George Soros and other financial speculators. After that, he was politically a dead man waiting for a grave. Jimmy Carter was sealed as a one-term leader when he agreed to a botched rescue mission for the hostages in Iran. Leadership consists of thousands of decisions and signatures but, finally, a single one of them can topple you.

Sometimes, the dangerous call is the one that looks easy. Margaret Thatcher survived the hardest decision a leader can make - the commitment of your troops to war - but ensured her removal from office by making the wrong choice over a replacement for the rates. Even someone so certain must, when sleepless in the jet speeding between highly paid speeches, replay in her head with a different outcome the moment when she agreed to the poll tax.

Tony Blair's decision day is looming and I don't mean May 3. While still leader of the opposition, Blair gave an intriguing interview to an Easter Sunday newspaper about his religious beliefs. He explained that the historical figure with whom he most identified was Pontius Pilate. Blair saw Christ's reluctant judge as representing the ultimate political dilemma: the leader agonising between the right decision and the popular one. What seems to be a brilliant tactical move (offering the mob Barabbas as an alternative candidate to the maverick preacher) goes wrong. There weren't tabloids in Palestine but the broad outlines of a political crisis remain recognisable.

In the four years since May 1997, Blair must have wondered when his own Pilate night would come. He most feared, we can suppose, a collapse of the pound, a total breakdown of the Irish peace process or a new war in the Gulf. He avoided these and his moment of decision comes down to the lives of sheep and cows and the timing of his plea for another shot of power. Does he risk being seen as a man who put his own political life before the countryside? What might be the political consequences?

William Hague isn't Khrushchev and foot and mouth is no nuclear winter: it's unlikely that, in 39 years' time, Hollywood will make a movie called 28 Days about the British meat crisis, but Blair will come to understand in the next two weeks the truth contained in Thirteen Days: that politics finally comes down to deciding between alternatives which, in the end, determine your journey through history.

The opinion polls (the latest suggesting that Hague has the political bounce of a burned cow) will give Blair hope but he must worry about the possibility of the 1992 effect: when voters were too embarrassed to admit to pollsters that they planned to vote Tory. No recent leader has seemed as dependent on advisers as Blair, but this is a room that the prime minister enters alone.

At the point of decision, polling data and history books and Alastair Campbell will count for nothing. Not even the inevitable sneaky little phone call to Peter in Hartlepool or Notting Hill can help. (Mandelson, we may remember, was codenamed "Bobby", after Robert Kennedy, during a previous spell in exile.) Blair has to close his eyes and jump, trusting his own judgment.

After his own moment of decision, Pontius Pilate called a photo-op in which he wiped his hands of the whole business but that won't wash for Blair. Quite unexpectedly, his premiership has entered its critical period.

comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Eyre quits RTL
fields.trailText: 1pm: Former ITV boss Richard Eyre has quit RTL, the owner of Channel 5 and Pearson TV,, writes Jason Deans
fields.body:
Former ITV boss Richard Eyre has quit RTL Group, the owner of Channel 5 and Pearson TV, the independent company behind ITV hits including The Bill and Neighbours.

Mr Eyre, the former ITV chief executive, is not thought to have another job to go to.

He is believed to have quit RTL because of frustration over his position.

"He thought he was going to have Greg Dyke's job. I am not surprised he is leaving," said one former colleague.

An RTL spokesman said the company was in a closed period in advance of its annual results on Wednesday and could not comment.

Mr Eyre joined Pearson TV in January last year as chief executive - a job vacated by Greg Dyke who had just started as the new director general of the BBC.

However, three months later the company merged with CLT-Ufa to creat RTL and Mr Eyre found his role had changed.

He acquired a new job title and although he was now working for a bigger company he found he was no longer boss.

As RTL Group director of strategy and content, Mr Eyre was only third in the pecking order in the newly merged group.

CLT-Ufa chief executive Didier Bellens and chief operating officer Ewald Walgenbach took the same positions within RTL.

fields.headline: Social work agencies losing 'pariah' status
fields.standfirst: Social work agencies are playing an increasingly important role in shaping the social care workforce, writes Judy Hirst
fields.trailText: Social work agencies are playing an increasingly important role in shaping the social care workforce, writes Judy Hirst.
fields.body:
Social work recruitment agencies were once seen, at best, as a necessary evil - at worst, as get-rich-quick operators supplying an inferior brand of worker. But this pariah-like status is changing. A combination of factors mean that agencies are playing an increasingly important role in shaping the social care workforce.

Chronic staff shortages, particularly in London and the south-east, have created something of a sellers' market for qualified social workers. More are now shopping around, and opting for the higher rates and greater flexibility that agency employment offers. And social services directors are turning in growing numbers to recruitment agencies to meet their increasingly desperate staffing needs. In some inner-London boroughs, up to 50% of social work teams are staffed by agency workers.

Meanwhile, the government's emphasis on outsourcing and the merger of health and social service functions has created a high level of uncertainty about workforce needs. Many employers rely on agencies to meet short term restructuring problems, and some longer term ones too.

The relationship with social services departments has changed significantly, says Mike Biggs, divisional manager for Reed Social Care. "In the old days, they would only use us grudgingly. Now there's a lot of talk about partnership, particularly in areas like training and professional development. Sometimes employers are coming to us to recruit whole teams."

Given the extent to which departments have been pared down, and their need for a fast, flexible recruitment service, Mr Biggs envisages the entire business of social services being outsourced in the future. Reed places around 1,200 qualified and unqualified social workers with employers in any one week. It is also fast developing an "executive register" for more senior staff. The big attraction for most recruits is better pay and bonuses, particularly in areas where market forces put their skills at a premium. But with agencies now offering holiday pay, training access and other benefits, their pulling power can be greater still.

Central Recruitment Services, for example - a relative newcomer to the agency scene - has set up its own training and development programme. It will be offering NVQs and other accreditation to both its own recruits, and staff from the statutory and independent sectors. Director Paul Nulty believes there is a lot of demand for better qualified staff from housing support and extra care services, substance and alcohol abuse units, and other social care fields - and that specialist recruitment agencies have much to offer in this respect.

Central's qualified social workers can earn between £900 and £2,200 extra in annual bonuses. On the other hand, there are no sick pay or pension provisions. However, Mr Nulty believes there are other reasons, beyond monetary ones, why many social workers prefer agency work. "A lot come from dysfunctional organisations, and want the chance to try out a new workplace for three to six months, to see how they fare. We skills match them very carefully and profile prospective employers. We also provide a lot of supervision and support."

Both the major players - such as Reed, Blue Arrow and Reliance Care - and the smaller niche agencies are working overtime to match, and outstrip, the benefits offered by permanent employers. As Unison points out, this is largely for the same competitive reasons that local authorities are vying for each other's staff. But the losers in this scenario are often the service-users, says Ian Johnston, director of the British Association of Social Workers.

"Most social work students are talking about working for agencies, which can't be good for clients who want consistency and continuity from the people caring for them. And it's all too easy for local authorities to pull the plug on agency arrangements. Some agencies do provide a quality service, and go some way towards self-regulation. But at the end of the day they are motivated by profit -which in the long-run won't develop the quality workforce we need."

fields.headline: Lord Onslow of Woking
fields.standfirst: Rightwing Tory backbencher who presided over Mrs Thatcher's demise
fields.trailText: Rightwing Tory backbencher who presided over Mrs Thatcher's demise.
fields.body:
The peak period of influence of Lord Onslow of Woking, who has died aged 74, was between 1984 and 1992, when, as MP Cranley Onslow, he chaired the Tory backbenchers' 1922 Committee - a discreet, uptight loyalist sandwiched between two extroverts, Edward du Cann and Marcus Fox. He presided over the 1990 leadership contest which saw the departure of Margaret Thatcher and the arrival of John Major.

A member of the secret service, MI6, before he became Conservative MP for Woking in 1964, he briefly held two ministerial offices, as under-secretary for aerospace between 1972-74, and minister of state at the Foreign Office from 1982-83. Particularly hostile to Labour's CND left, he once tagged MP Brian Sedgemore as "a boil on the bottom of the Labour party - painful to live with, better not mentioned and best kept out of sight".

As a kinsman of the Earl of Onslow, representing a constituency containing the earl's seat, Onslow was one of the last Tory squires. Three Onslows had served as speakers of the Commons, the first from 1566. His replacement as chairman of the 1922 Committee by Fox, a self-made backstreet Thatcherite, seemed to mark the end of an era.

Born in Bexhill, Onslow was named after the earl, one of whose titles was Baron Cranley, because his ornithologist father wanted to maintain the family link. After Harrow and Sandhurst, he joined up in 1944, becoming a lieutenant in the Queen's Own Hussars. On leaving active service, he joined the Territorials - thus keeping up his marksmanship - and graduated in history from Oriel College, Oxford.

In 1951, he joined M16 and its cover-organisation, the Foreign Office, being posted to Burma in 1953 as third secretary. In 1955, he became consul in Maymyo, north Burma, near the communist Chinese border. Local communist insurgents once attempted to kidnap and ransom him, but by plying him with whisky, Onslow persuaded them to return to the jungle without him. He, in his turn, returned to London to marry Lady Jane Hay, daughter of the 14th Earl of Kinnoull, and to serve in the FO department that controls MI6.

Like other MI6 Tories, Onslow wanted to make his mark in politics. After resigning from the civil service in 1960, he was elected to Dartford rural district council the same year, and to Kent county council in 1961. Two years later, he was selected as Harold Watkinson's successor for Woking. When elected, the Conservatives described him as director of an unnamed Indian-based news agency.

From his maiden speech in December 1964, Onslow proclaimed himself a classic rightwinger. He specialised in aviation, rising to chairman of the Tory MPs' aviation committee, a position he used to defend the British Aircraft Corporation, which had a plant in his constituency. He blamed Harold Wilson's cancellation of the BAC TSR2 warplane on Labour's CND supporters and wore a black and yellow tie, the black mourning the TSR2's demise and the yellow standing for the government's lack of courage in the decision.

Onslow supported hanging, attacked anti-Franco elements among Labour MPs, demanded reductions in third-world aid and tax cuts so the middle classes could send their children to fee-paying schools. He opposed televising the Commons. However, he showed a serious, nonpartisan interest in civil aviation when leading for the Tories in this field in 1968. After his party was returned to power, he held ministerial office under Michael Heseltine from 1972-74.

In the subsequent years of opposition, he introduced a bill to give the vote to servicemen and their wives, and again urged cuts in overseas aid. He became obsessed with the activities of Czechoslovak intelligence agents, seeking to link them with the "disappearing" Labour postmaster-general John Stonehouse.

Mrs Thatcher made him minister of state at the Foreign Office in 1982, replacing Richard Luce, who resigned with Lord Carrington over their failure to prevent the Argentine invasion of the Falklands. A year later, Onslow showed similar loyalty to his boss, Francis Pym, when Thatcher sacked him.

He found a new career in replacing Edward du Cann as chairman of the 1922 Committee in 1984. Here, he used tact in conveying the views of Tory backbenchers - including their 1988 decision that Leon Brittan should resign over his role in the Westland affair. But he did not hesitate to interrupt Thatcher's rants when she went over the top.

His abilities were put to the test in 1990, when Heseltine challenged her for the Tory leadership. As the custodian of backbench votes and views, it fell to Onslow to tell Thatcher, when she failed to win conclusively in the first round, that many MPs wanted a wider choice of candidates; the result was that she stood down and John Major emerged as prime minister. The Thatcherites fury led to Onslow's replacement in 1992 by Fox - though his consolation was a knighthood, and a peerage in 1997, when he stood down from Woking.

He is survived by his wife, three daughters and a son.

 Cranley Gordon Douglas Onslow, Lord Onslow of Woking, politician, born June 8 1926; died March 13 2001

Two years later, he was selected as Harold Watkinson's successor for Woking. When elected, the Conservatives described him as director of an unnamed Indian-based news agency. From his maiden speech in December 1964, Onslow proclaimed himself a classic rightwinger. He specialised in aviation, rising to chairman of the Tory MPs' aviation committee, a position he used to defend the British Aircraft Corporation, which had a plant in his constituency. He blamed Harold Wilson's cancellation of the BAC TSR2 warplane on Labour's CND supporters and wore a black and yellow tie, the black mourning the TSR2's demise and the yellow standing for the government's lack of courage in the decision. Onslow supported hanging, attacked anti-Franco elements among Labour MPs, demanded reductions in third-world aid and tax cuts so the middle classes could send their children to fee-paying schools. He opposed televising the Commons. However, he showed a serious, nonpartisan interest in civil aviation when leading for the Tories in this field in 1968. After his party was returned to power, he held ministerial office under Michael Heseltine from 1972-74. In the subsequent years of opposition, he introduced a bill to give the vote to servicemen and their wives, and again urged cuts in overseas aid. He became obsessed with the activities of Czechoslovak intelligence agents, seeking to link them with the "disappearing" Labour postmaster-general John Stonehouse. Mrs Thatcher made him minister of state at the Foreign Office in 1982, replacing Richard Luce, who resigned with Lord Carrington over their failure to prevent the Argentine invasion of the Falklands. A year later, Onslow showed similar loyalty to his boss, Francis Pym, when Thatcher sacked him. He found a new career in replacing Edward du Cann as chairman of the 1922 Committee in 1984. Here, he used tact in conveying the views of Tory backbenchers - including their 1988 decision that Leon Brittan should resign over his role in the Westland affair. But he did not hesitate to interrupt Thatcher's rants when she went over the top. His abilities were put to the test in 1990, when Heseltine challenged her for the Tory leadership. As the custodian of backbench votes and views, it fell to Onslow to tell Thatcher, when she failed to win conclusively in the first round, that many MPs wanted a wider choice of candidates; the result was that she stood down and John Major emerged as prime minister. The Thatcherites fury led to Onslow's replacement in 1992 by Fox - though his consolation was a knighthood, and a peerage in 1997, when he stood down from Woking. He is survived by his wife, three daughters and a son.  Cranley Gordon Douglas Onslow, Lord Onslow of Woking, politician, born June 8 1926; died March 13 2001

fields.headline: Agency work offers benefits
fields.standfirst: For both an experienced social worker and a linguistics tutor, agency placements offer benefits not found in the statutory sector, writes Judy Hirst
fields.trailText: For both an experienced social worker and a linguistics tutor, agency placements offer benefits not found in the statutory sector, writes Judy Hirst.
fields.body:
Amy Skinner had never really considered working for a social work agency. An experienced, qualified social worker, with a lengthy, successful track record managing mental health services, she had always thought the lack of a career structure would be a major problem with agency work.

However, her views have changed radically since finding a placement as the manager of a mental health day centre in a deprived urban area.

"It's a really good job. Very demanding, with a whole range of service users, but also very fulfilling. I might stay on permanently, but it's been important for me to know I could try the placement out."

Ms Skinner, 37, is paid a higher salary than she would get in the statutory sector, and earns a £2,000 annual bonus on top of that. Under the European working time directive, agencies are obliged to pay holiday pay too.

"The agency, Social Workline, negotiated a good deal for me. And I was impressed with the way they interviewed and vetted me. They've also been really supportive, calling regularly and helping sort problems out. They even offer a subsidised counselling service, and you can access extra training."

Like many social workers, she approached an agency after a period away from the job. "I was really stressed and burnt out. I'd taken voluntary redundancy after some pretty negative experiences with one organisation. After that I travelled, and took a course in drama and movement therapy, something I've always been very interested in. Eventually I contacted an agency for work - mainly because I was broke!"

The experience has been overwhelmingly positive, and the lack of stability and long-term benefits is no longer a major concern. "Yes, sick pay would be good, and so would maternity leave if I decide to start a family. But the psychological reassurance I get from working in this way is more important to me right now."

For very different reasons, agency work also suits Dinah Murray, a highly qualified linguistics tutor, with a special interest in autism. She works shifts in specialist units for adults with autism and severely challenging behaviour. "Unlike a lot of agency staff, I'm not interested in becoming a qualified social worker. I prefer to stay at this level, as a support worker in direct contact with people. And the flexibility suits me because of my other work. But if you want them, the opportunities for further training are there."

Ms Murray has been an agency worker with Central Recruitment for three years, after a spell as a full-time carer in residential care. She is impressed with their seriousness, and willingness to deal with issues like poor practice on placements.

"They treat it as more than just a business. But agencies vary enormously in my experience, and many are not nearly as good. As an agency worker you're very vulnerable to dismissal; most are not in a union and you're not part of the supervision structure. Nor is there anything to stop someone signing up with two agencies, and working longer hours than they should."

She also regrets the impact of the rapid turnover of staff on service users, particularly on extremely vulnerable groups such as people with autism. On the other hand, the recruitment crisis in social care means the problem is not just with agency workers.

"The rate of turnover of local authority staff is nearly as high. It's appalling the speed with which they appear and disappear."

fields.headline: NHS embraces interactive TV
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: Government-backed Living Health will supply viewers with help and advice on health issues, writes Amy Vickers.
Mar 6: Granada sets Wellbeing launch date
Oct 12:Granada and Boots in health venture
fields.body:
Granada's health TV channel Wellbeing could be given a run for its money by a government-backed interactive TV service.

The £3.8m NHS venture, called Living Health, will go live in June to 50,000 Telewest homes.

If the six-month trial is successful, the service will be rolled out nationally.

Living Health is the first of a number of pilot schemes the health service is funding to explore possible health applications on digital interactive services.

The NHS already runs a 24-hour nurse-led helpline called NHS Direct and is pursuing a strategy of connecting all GPs to NHSnet.

Living Health will enable a user to have a TV video conference with a nurse in the NHS Direct call centre.

The main aim of the service, however, is to provide advice and information about local health services.

"This groundbreaking project demonstrates how interactive TV can deliver real benefits for government and reach people who don't necessarily have internet access," said Ronnette Lucraft, general manager of Living Health.

Granada and Boots launched Wellbeing last Wednesday as a TV channel that will eventually become interactive.

Living Health, a joint venture between Telewest Communications and Eden Consulting, has this week signed up Telewest's interactive TV consultancy SmashedAtom to develop the service.

Related stories

webTitle: Cosla review will give new direction

fields.headline: Cosla review will give new direction
fields.standfirst: A review of Cosla will bring stability after the turbulence of the past few months, writes president Norman Murray
fields.trailText: Comment: A review of Cosla will bring stability after the turbulence of the past few months, writes president Norman Murray.
fields.body:
The first months of 2001 have proved to be turbulent for the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) - but now there is much to look forward to and much work to do.

It is regrettable that Scottish local government should be damaged by the decision of a few councils to leave Cosla. A strong national organisation in Scotland is vital to the very future of local government. That strength can only come through unity, and we are committed to continuing to represent our member councils at all levels.

We have provided the platform for Scottish authorities to work together, speak together and act together for more than 25 years. I remain determined that the organisation will carry on this excellent work. Councils trying to operate outside Cosla will be the losers; they will find themselves excluded from all of the progressive work which is going on nationally - for example, work on e-government, the development of community planning and Local Agenda 21. Much of this will come under the microscope at this year's Cosla Annual Conference, held on Wednesday, March 21.

Councils have agreed to fund Cosla at current levels, plus 3%, from April 1, with a "root and branch" review of the organisation to be undertaken, which will be presented to the convention meeting at the end of June.

When council leaders met in February there was clear support - from across the country and from across the political parties - for Cosla's long-term future, but it was also recognised that there are some concerns about the organisation's role, which is why a fundamental review has been agreed to. It will be overseen by a wide-ranging group of councillors, representing all areas of Scotland, who will be examining the organisation and deciding how it should be shaped in the future.

The newly appointed review group will meet for the first time before the end of the month. It is an all-party group and I expect the members to assume the role of overseers of the work, to be undertaken on our behalf by a group of local authority chief executives and officers. There will clearly have to be close cooperation between the group and the Cosla chief executive and her management team.

Most essential for the review group is that their work should have very clearly defined outcomes, and it is on this that their first meeting will focus. I believe it is vital that at the end of the process we have an organisation which is focused on a number of key activities and priorities; an organisation that has clear direction and a structure to achieve those priorities - both politically and in officer terms.

I would also expect the review to produce recommendations on Cosla's budget for this year and the next two years.

It is my hope that the group will not work in isolation. Many people and organisations work closely with Cosla. We work not just with our member authorities but with our partner organisations, central government, the voluntary sector, the private sector, the universities - the list is endless.

All these organisations will have a valuable input to the review and I hope their views will be heard and recognised.

I am very confident that at the end of this process we will have a stronger organisation that will take us forward, and which will bring security for the Cosla staff who have suffered enormous uncertainty over the last few weeks.

fields.headline: Scandal rocks Indian government
fields.standfirst: Will India's coalition government be able to survive the allegations of widespread political corruption? asks Luke Harding
fields.trailText: Will India's coalition government be able to survive the allegations of widespread political corruption? asks Luke Harding.
fields.body:
Can India's coalition government survive? After one of the most tumultuous weeks in modern Indian politics, the answer appears to be - probably.

Since last Tuesday, the government has been rocked by allegations of massive corruption among bureaucrats, military officials and politicians.

India's defence minister, George Fernandes, was forced to resign last week, after a devastating expose by the Indian website, tehelka.com, revealed that he presided over a ministry riddled with corruption. The scandal has also claimed the scalp of Bangaru Laxman, the president of the ruling Bharatiya Janata party (BJP), who was secretly filmed stuffing a £1,500 bribe into his desk.

Seven military officials have been suspended and the president of Mr Fernandes' Samata party, Jaya Jaitly, has also quit after accepting a £3,000 bribe in the defence minister's residence. The question now is: can India's battered prime minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee hang on?

Most analysts believe he can, at least for the time being. His right-wing Hindu nationalist party still commands a majority of 19 in the 545-seat lower house, despite the decision last week by one of his key coalition partners, the Trinamool Congress, to leave the ruling alliance.

The government can comfortably survive a no confidence motion, should the opposition Congress party table one later this week. Parliament was adjourned again in total uproar today as opposition MPs demanded the government's resignation. This they will not get. But its long-term prospects of survival remain uncertain.

With a reduced majority, Mr Vajpayee, who cut a tired and demoralised figure when he addressed the nation on Friday night, is now increasingly at the mercy of his remaining coalition partners. His fate lies largely in the hands of Chandrababu Naidu, the bearded leader of the regional Telegu Desam party.

Mr Naidu, the chief minister of the hi-tech state of Andhra Pradesh, supports the government from outside the ruling coalition. But the votes of his 29 MPs are now crucial to its survival. At the moment Mr Naidu has no incentive to pull the plug on the government, since his main local opponent is the Congress party. But even if Mr Naidu continues to prop up Mr Vajpayee's embattled administration, other smaller parties may decide that they have had enough.

Mr Vajpayee's problems do not end here. The scandal also implicates his private office and some of his most crucial aides. They include India's national security advisor Brajesh Mishra, the PM's personal secretary NK Singh and his own foster son-in-law Ranjan Bhattacharya. All have been accused of personal involvement in defence and power deals.

Intriguingly, the loudest demands for their resignation have been coming not from the opposition, but from the prime minister's own Hindu revivalist allies, including his party's ideological wing, the Rashtriya Swayemsevak Sangh.

Mr Vajpayee has made it clear that if they go, he goes. The crisis leaves the hard-line wing of the BJP strengthened - as well as its heir apparent, India's home minister LK Advani.

The prime minister's party managers are hoping that the government can tough out this week. Parliament then adjourns for a three-week recess. By the time it reassembles the fuss caused by the tehelka expose will have been forgotten, they hope.

The fact that Jaswant Singh, India's foreign minister, has been given temporary charge of the defence minister's portfolio suggests that George Fernandes will get his old job back in four months time, after a judicial inquiry set up in the wake of the scandal has presumably exonerated him.

However, in Indian politics nothing is certain - and something else may finish off the 17-month-old coalition before then. "The government has earned itself some breathing space with George Fernandes' resignation," political analyst Professor Zoya Hassan said yesterday. "But its credibility and authority has been demolished. This is such a major scandal that I think, by the end of the year, we may well see yet another election."

fields.headline: Catchpole quits Mirror for the Express
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: Charlie Catchpole has stunned Fleet Street by announcing he is to leave the Mirror to join the Express, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 19: NUJ calls for action over job cuts
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Charlie Catchpole has stunned Fleet Street by announcing he is to leave the Mirror to join the Express.

The signing of Mr Catchpole, who is regarded by many as the best TV critic in the industry, is a major coup for the Express under new owner Richard Desmond, who last week announced plans to axe 145 journalists.

"I was perfectly happy at the Mirror but this offer came out of the blue and I couldn't refuse it," said Mr Catchpole.

"It is a very good package. The Mirror made a counter offer and Piers has been very nice about it but in the end I decided with a heavy heart to go."

He will join the paper in the same role as star TV critic. He will also continue his once-weekly column about sport on TV.

Mr Catchpole joined the Mirror from the News of the World three years ago - one of editor Piers Morgan's first signings.

His ruminations on television have brought him a well-deserved reputation as one of the nation's favourite critics.

He displays the obligatory sarcasm where necessary, recently describing the axed ITV series Public Property as being so dull it "made watching paint dry seem as exciting as white water rafting".

And last week he castigated Anthea Turner as being "fragile... the way rhinos are thin-skinned".

But his observations can also combine generosity with wit.

He noted of the departure of Chris Eubank from the Celebrity Big Brother house: "Seeing a former championship boxer solemnly telling a member of an Irish boyband that 200 years ago, trousers were invented for the working class, and before then everyone wore dresses, is a moment of televisual history to cherish."

But the signing, following shortly after the announcement of mass job cuts at the Express, is likely to fuel the wrath of journalists on the newspaper, who have been told their jobs are being axed to "radically change the culture of newspapers".

Close friends say Mr Catchpole was unperturbed by the fact the Express had just launched a fierce cost-cutting drive.

"He is part of the rescue team. Newspapers' fortunes go up as well as down," said one.

Mr Desmond's trategy has focused on bringing in named writers on high salaries - including former Sun sports writer Brian Woolnough and Celebrity Big Brother victim Vanessa Feltz - at the expense of a well-staffed newsdesk.

webTitle: BSE risk could restrict blood donors

fields.headline: BSE risk could restrict blood donors
fields.trailText: Nearly one in six blood donors may be banned from giving blood to avoid the theoretical risk that they may pass on the fatal human form of BSE.
fields.body:
Nearly one in six blood donors may be banned from giving blood to avoid the theoretical risk that they may pass on the fatal human form of BSE.

Thousands of volunteers would be rejected simply because they had received transfusions themselves. The move could create huge shortages and leave the blood services struggling to meet demand.

Officials had estimated that between 5% and 10% of donors had received blood themselves but a survey has revealed the figure may be as high as 16%. One in five potential donors could not remember or did not know whether they had received a transfusion, making calculations more difficult.

At least 13 of the 95 British victims of variant CJD have been blood donors and authorities have been struggling over the ethical problem of whether people who have received blood transfusions or vaccinations including donations from these should be informed of the potential risk.

At present, the general guidance is that they should not be informed since there is no test, no cure and no treatment for vCJD. New restrictions could help ease that problem, as well as providing extra safeguards against accidental infection.

White blood cells are already filtered out of blood donations because they are considered most likely to carry the agent responsible for vCJD. webTitle: Canada under fire as haven for terrorists

fields.headline: Canada under fire as haven for terrorists
fields.standfirst: The trial of an alleged bomber has thrown light on serious flaws in Canada's immigration process, writes Anne McIlroy
fields.trailText: The trial of an alleged bomber has thrown light on serious flaws in Canada's immigration process, writes Anne McIlroy.
fields.body:
Canada added to its growing reputation as a haven for terrorists and other criminals last week, amid serious revelations about the ease with which an alleged Y2K bomber got a passport using little more than a forged student card.

Ahmed Ressam is on trial in Los Angeles for conspiracy to commit terrorism and smuggling unlicensed explosives. US officials suspect he was planning to blow up a major target in Seattle on New Year's Eve 2000.

Last week, the jury heard how simple it was for Mr Ressam, an Algerian, to become Canadian Benni Noris. A Montreal student who has already pleaded guilty to two counts of fraud said he had no trouble applying for six passports on behalf on non-existent people.

All it took to give Mr Ressam a squeaky clean new Canadian identity was a fake student card and a forged baptismal certificate. It appears that passport officials did not even do basic checks that would have verified whether his documents were indeed legitimate.

Mr Ressam appears to have used his new passport to travel to Afghanistan in 1998, where US prosecutors allege he learned bomb-making skills at a training camp run by Osama bin Laden. He is the wealthy Saudi militant blamed by the US government for several acts of international terrorism, included the bombings of two US embassies in Africa in 1998.

Mr Ressam came to Canada in 1994, claiming persecution in his native Algeria. Within a few months he had been charged with the first of several criminal theft offences but, when he failed to show up in court, Canadian police and immigration officials were unable to track him down. US prosecutors say he was part of a Montreal-based terrorist cell.

A suspicious US border guard stopped Mr Ressam when he tried to enter the United States at Port Angeles, Washington, from Victoria, British Columbia on December 14 1999. In his trunk were enough explosives and components to make three powerful time bombs.

Government officials are scrambling to show some sceptical US legislators pushing for tighter border controls that Canada is not a haven for criminals and terrorists whose aim is to do damage in the United States.

It didn't help that last week also saw the Royal Canadian mounted police and the immigration department come under fire for taking more than two years to find an alleged Mafia hitman. The Italian government had requested that he be extradited from Canada to face trial at home.

Gaetano Amodeo, who is accused of killings in Italy and Germany, enjoyed life in Montreal until January, even though the Italian government asked that he be arrested in 1999. During that time, his name twice appeared on his wife's application for permanent residency. It appears the immigration department didn't pass this information on to the police.

Embarrassed government ministers will say only that Mr Amodeo could not be found until December of this year. It left them open to attack from opposition politicians, as they were unable to answer some pointed questions. "Who is responsible for Canada being considered as the Club Med for international criminals, as an immigration sieve?" demanded Bloc Québécois house leader Michel Gauthier.

fields.headline: Right, said Fred
fields.standfirst: He is one of Britain's best-loved novelists, with a string of classic spy thrillers to his name. So why is Frederick Forsyth sounding off about politics and hanging out with the shadow cabinet?
fields.trailText: He is one of Britain's best-loved novelists, with a string of classic spy thrillers to his name. So why is Frederick Forsyth sounding off about politics and hanging out with the shadow cabinet?
fields.body:
Frederick Forsyth - conservative, traditionalist, and man of modest tastes - never profers a short answer where a lengthy anecdote will suffice. He is telling me about the previous night's episode of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire. Which he watched alone with a tray supper because his wife can't stand the fug of his Rothmans. About how he thought (for £125,000) that the symbol on the national flag of India was a star. And about how the contestant went 50/50, then phoned a friend, who was actually his ex-wife, and it transpired that the correct answer was a wheel.

My own suggestion (star) some time earlier is glossed over. He doesn't so much talk with as talk at: a pocket orator projecting - with authority - to the centre of his living room. He commands his facts like toy soldiers.

Sixty-two-year-old Forsyth, notably one of Margaret Thatcher's favourite authors, is indeed a man of parts. At 19, he was the youngest pilot in the RAF. As a foreign correspondent for Reuters and then the BBC, he worked throughout Europe and Africa. For more than three decades, he crafted multi-million-selling thrillers, including The Odessa File, The Fourth Protocol and most famously The Day of the Jackal, that exemplary yarn centred on a plot to assassinate De Gaulle. More recently, he has enjoyed bucolic harmony as a gentleman farmer of a 140-acre plot in Hertfordshire (grazing sheep, thus far foot and mouth-free).

But most notably of late, Forsyth has reinvented himself as a sayer of the unsayable. Anti-Euro, pro-hunting, elegant defender of all things rural, constitutional and consistent, he has become as ubiquitous as he is vocal. There has been tough talk in the Mail ("[we have] quietly slid into elective dictatorship in which we are all treated with dismissive contempt"), and robust jottings to the Telegraph letters page. His best work has been reserved for Radio Four's Saturday Essay, on which he alternates with Will Self. The switchboard nearly imploded when he offered, with deliciously voluptuous modulation, the simile "like diarrhoea from a Zulu's bottom". A stately shocker with impeccable manners and a gilded turn of phrase, he has not found himself short on commissions.

He considers himself an activist on only four subjects: our constitution ("one of the best in the world"), parliamentary democracy (which Blair is treating "with contempt"), the countryside (ditto), and Europe (more anon).Inevitably, he applauds the clear vision, radicalism and ground-breaking contribution to the status of working women of Margaret Thatcher.

This increased polemical visibility is in part a response to the Blair government, in part, he says, to the "pandemic sense of helplessness" he sees around him. People yearn for a time when standards were higher, and integrity greater. People don't feel they have a voice. And though he claims only to speak for himself, he suggests that his views do chime with "perhaps 50%" of the population.

"As I said on the Today programme the other day, I think the old left/right definitions don't apply much any more. There's a division, but it's not a vertical one, it's slantwise, and basically it's traditionalists against progressives. I'm a traditionalist, but so is most of left Labour. There's a strong vein of traditionalism within the working class, a strong vein of patriotism. And then of course one has the Blairite tendency, which basically says, 'Let's change it, and move to some utopian upland which we can see and if you buggers can't then screw you.' "

On the upland in question hovers the dark spectre of Europe - which he calls "the European question" because it has yet to be answered to his satisfaction. "I'm a sceptic in the literal sense of the word - one who remains to be convinced. But the lingo becomes very tricky - [Labour thinks that] someone who doesn't believe is a xenophobe, a little Englander, or doesn't understand Europe. I speak five European languages and I've been to every country on the continent bar Liechtenstein. Anyway, you can't disapprove of Europe - it's a continent full of very nice people."

His tendency towards the rabid is eclipsed by a boyish delight in establishing possible conspiracies. "Either a tiny caucus knows exactly where they're going and won't divulge, or they're making it up on the hoof. I find it very difficult to believe that there is no masterplan," he intones with a treacly chuckle.

Although keen to position himself as the anti-establishment irritant, Forsyth joined the Tory party in 1998, because "I thought there ought to be an opposition in this country, and they needed a little help". Now he gives talks to constituency parties in his area - "within a 50-mile radius, I always specify that, or I'd spend my whole life motoring" - and is a member of the Front Bench Club, paying £1,000 a year for the privilege of occasional lunches with members of the shadow cabinet. (There is something corpulent and fleshy about the way he says "lunch". His delivery oozes patrician camp, and when he laughs he presses his lips into a fruity little pout.)

"William Hague is not a man I know well. I've never had a meal with him, never had a drink with him, so we nod and greet and I even get to give Ffion a peck on the cheek. He's not charismatic, but person to person he's highly intelligent, very humorous, self-deprecating, and I think he's got bottle. Blair is exactly the opposite, but boy can he project, like Clinton.

"Hague is always portrayed in the cartoons as somewhere between a baby and a gnome, but he's 5ft 10 1/2 in and rock-solid muscle. It's probably the round bullet head and having lost his hair too young - even though 10% of British males do." But does he have confidence in him as leader of the party? "If there were a Churchill waiting in the wings, I'd say yes, we should have a leadership election. But to be perfectly honest there is nothing like Churchill waiting in the wings."

Forsyth has not written a thriller for several years: "I felt that the challenge and the adrenalin had gone. It was a chore - lucrative, but a chore." Fiction was never a creative compulsion. His regime - two or more years of research, two months of writing - reflects his treasure-hunt fascination with the world of spooks, spies and assassins. His plots - the disintegration of the USSR, black market arms dealing in East Germany, the Gulf war - have always honoured the real. Forsyth knew his stuff.

"Some said that I was a spook, but I just knew a few. I used to know the chiefs of the secret intelligence service in sequence from Maurice Oldfield onwards, but I have got out of touch." Was it exciting to be privy to insider knowledge? "I don't think one gets intoxicated just because one is talking to a controller of the western hemisphere. They are human beings."

Espionage is a British speciality and obsession, he says. "I suspect because we're a bit secretive, matched probably by the Russians but not the Americans. It probably comes from the public school ethos: what is an old school tie but a secret recognition code?"

He has said that one of the reasons why he stopped writing thrillers was the modern absence of grand global themes. "The twin themes that dominated the lives of all of us who are now about 60 were the nuclear threat and the cold war," he explains. "We lived with it on a daily basis. The 'Ban the bomb' marches were far more passionate than [those about] fox hunting. Now we look for mini themes: Saddam Hussein, foxes."

As he talks, his body remains still. His legs are outstretched and the bright brown leather of his shoes squeaks. He talks through the smoke, even when he has just inhaled.

"There was a clarity of loyalty, of interest, and one knew that what was at stake was unspeakable - it was the destruction of the planet. I miss the clarity. The world's now getting to a stage where everything is arguable, but all the issues are basically much smaller than whether the planet survives."

Is he confounded by postmodernity, I joke. He doesn't respond lightly. "Yes, without certain clarities life becomes a howling wilderness, where anyone can make their mind up as to whether Oasis are as good as Shakespeare." He attempts a laugh but it is rather sad.

When I ask him how his politics have evolved over his lifetime he informs me that he has become more mellow and more tolerant. "I was probably rather abrasive as a youngster. I was more simplistic then, thought I could change the world and this is how to do it, and after a while you realise it's not that easy."

Was he a romantic? "The heroes of my young days were the great victors like Marlborough and Wellington. The walls of my boyhood bedroom were decorated with fighter pilots, from the first and second world wars. One did think that ours was a bloody good country with a bloody good history. The self-flagellation hadn't started."

For all the microfiche and macho posturing, wasn't it all rather innocent? "If certainty is innocence and complexity is sophistication, yes it was. One was educated not to have doubts, and that wasn't just the middle class, that was all the country. Is it better to have doubts? Are we smarter? Are we happier?"

But he is contented, he tells me, happily ensconced with his second wife Sandy, besotted with his two grown-up sons. He does not consider himself ambitious: power, fame and wealth have limited appeal to him, he insists. "My tastes are very ordinary - I don't have any foreign houses, I don't have a jet or boat, I don't have masses of male jewellery. I like good plain food, good plain wine, holidays in the sun, and a house of nine rooms."

For all his noble vowels, he is middle class through and through. He has access to the establishment, he tells me, but he is not within it. Beyond the marshmallow pomposity, he is not intellectually arrogant. And of course he name drops, but then wouldn't you?

So who is listening to Frederick Forsyth? Certainly not New Labour. And, given the paucity of Conservative supporters who are famous, articulate and not known crooks, it is telling that Hague appears loath to court him. He is a thorn without a side.

Forsyth's reactions are visceral, simplistic, and sweeping. They are, judged by certain standards, compelling. He's an old naif, a barroom bore, an eccentric in a climate of consensus. Does he care who is listening? There's a fat mailbag from his newspaper offerings. There are ordinary people. There's his unshakeable belief in his right to speak and be heard, even in his quiet living room.

"If iconoclasm goes to the extreme of destroying every single thing that was ever admirable then it doesn't increase the sum human happiness, it increases the sum of human despair," he says gloomily. "And that's why I oppose, and hold to certain old-fashioned ways." He tenderly arranges his ancient Jack Russell in a warm patch on the armchair seat and goes to the loo.

fields.headline: Media Business
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 19
fields.trailText: March 19: GE Life has held an 'online auction' as the final stage of its £7m media review.
fields.body:
GE Life has caused consternation among media agencies by holding what amounted to an online auction as the final stage of its £7m media review.

AOL UK has appointed its first director of general sales, who will double the size of its advertising team in preparation for the launch of a range of spin-off brands.

Posterscope has won the £5m outdoor media account for Cadbury Trebor Bassett from the incumbent Outdoor Connection.

IPC Southbank has poached Attic Futura advertising controller Toby Moore to take up the new role of advertising director for its women's lifestyle portfolio.

Steve Blakeman, managing director of CIA Manchester, has been headhunted by Initiative in France to work as an account director.

fields.headline: O'Brien makes £2m switch to Newcastle
fields.trailText: Newcastle have signed Republic of Ireland under-21 defender Andrew O'Brien from Bradford for £2m.
fields.body:
Newcastle have signed Republic of Ireland under-21 defender Andrew O'Brien from Bradford for £2m.

O'Brien becomes the latest player to leave the Premiership strugglers after Dean Windass and David Hopkin quit the club last week, and will move to St James' Park as a replacement for Alain Goma, who has joined Fulham.

The 21-year-old left the club he joined as a trainee after chairman Geoffrey Richmond allowed him to talk to other Premiership clubs. He will join up with his new team-mates when he returns from international duty next week.

"I shall be for ever grateful to Bradford for giving me the opportunity and would like to thank the chairman for keeping his word and thus giving me the chance to fulfill my International ambitions", O'Brien said.

"I would also like to thank the supporters of the club who have always been fantastic towards me. Bradford City will always be close to my heart."

O'Brien should make his Newcastle debut against Bradford at Valley Parade a week on Saturday.

The 21-year-old left the club he joined as a trainee after chairman Geoffrey Richmond allowed him to talk to other Premiership clubs. He will join up with his new team-mates when he returns from international duty next week. "I shall be for ever grateful to Bradford for giving me the opportunity and would like to thank the chairman for keeping his word and thus giving me the chance to fulfill my International ambitions", O'Brien said. "I would also like to thank the supporters of the club who have always been fantastic towards me. Bradford City will always be close to my heart." O'Brien should make his Newcastle debut against Bradford at Valley Parade a week on Saturday.

fields.headline: Drop everything
fields.standfirst: Could it be that the porn industry and Big Brother hold the key to making the web pay? Amy Vickers explains why drop-dialling is getting everyone excited
fields.trailText: Could the porn industry and Big Brother hold the key to making the web pay? Amy Vickers on why drop-dialling is getting everyone excited.
fields.body:
There's a new buzzword in town and surprise surprise, it's one of those techie ones that only a handful of people will understand. It's drop-dialling and if you've never heard of it, don't worry, for until now the term was only really commonplace in porn circles.

Given its background, it was only a matter of time before the less churlish broadcasters cottoned on to it, especially now that they're all falling over each other to make the web financially robust - and that's the impetus behind drop-dialling. Broadcasters need the web to start to work for them, but there are problems in making web programming pay. Basically, consumers are loath to tediously input credit card details in return for nothing more than a five-minute clip.

But, as the porn industry has found, consumers are quite happy to cover the "broadcast charges" with a premium rate dial-up call if it means they get the clip without having to do anything. The theory is simple: the user clicks on the drop-dialler, it automatically disconnects the user's internet connection and then dials up to the new number, the clip is streamed, ends and the users are connected back to their own internet service. The user is happy; the broadcaster is happy; everyone is happy, especially the telephone company which takes a healthy chunk of the call cost. The benefits are there for all to see. All that broadcasters have to do is get together with one of the growing number of phone operators offering drop-dialling.

Granada Broadband, the digital development division of Granada Media, has declared its interest in drop-dialling, along with the BBC and Channel 5, which have both conducted drop-dialling voting experiments.

The BBC introduced drop-dialling to its Comic Relief Big Brother website (.Comicrelief.com/bigbrother) last week, although the BBC would be the first to admit that, in its current form, drop-dialling leaves something to be desired. The drop-dialler used by Comic Relief to collect revenues from internet voters could not be used by Apple Mac users, nor could it be used by anyone not dialling up to the internet using a modem, given that it has to disconnect the line. Therein lies the flaw in the model. It cannot work with office-leased line connections and it cannot work with broadband. Instead it is limited to the estimated 7.8m home internet users who have narrowband connections.

Even then, it remains debatable whether users will click on the button that says: "When you vote online, your computer will simply stop the modem connection to your usual internet service provider and then reconnect you to the internet via a premium-rate line to register your vote." While it is a relatively painless process, and consumers have gradually accepted the concept of premium-rate phone lines (Who Wants to be a Millionaire? and Big Brother to take two phenomenally profitable examples), it is still easier to pick up a phone than log on to a website and sit and wait for the system to clock your vote. And that's even if you are already online and you are aware of the fixed price of the call - 25p in the case of Celebrity Big Brother.

Audiocall, the BBC Worldwide-owned telephone operator behind the Celebrity Big Brother internet vote, counts Channel 4, Channel 5, BBC Broadcast, BBC Worldwide, ITV, digital and satellite channels and advertising agencies among its clients, but has so far only used drop-dialler voting for Comic Relief and Channel 5's 70s Weekend.

For the 70s Weekend, viewers were given the option to vote for their favourite song from that decade via the broadcaster's website. Because it was the first time a British broadcaster had ever used Audiocall's drop-dialler, the response rates were understandably low and Audiocall is guarded about specific numbers. Likewise, the response rates to the Comic Relief drop-dialler have not yet been revealed.

Justin Judd, controller of content and production for Granada Broadband, is optimistic about the potential of drop-dialling, though: "It may not be the quickest and easiest way to vote in response to a TV programme prompt, but as an internet revenue model that doesn't involve security complications, it has possibilities."

Judd is looking at different opportunities for using drop-diallers to serve broadcast content as a route into internet pay-per-view. "What content we might end up using is still being tested, but it will have to have some scarcity value, not be any old stuff," he says.

Just as broadcasters are assessing the potential of drop-dialling, so is the music industry. With MSN putting time and money into developing a website to stream concerts, it would not be surprising if MSNMusic.com introduced drop-diallers as an alternative to credit card subscriptions.

One possibility for Granada, says Judd, is to stream exclusive clips from its shows such as Cold Feet and Coronation Street, with the cost perhaps set at 25p a minute for a 10-minute clip. At £2.50 a pop per user, split between the operator and the broadcaster, it starts to look like an alternative way of making money from the internet if a few thousand people can be persuaded to download it. This is made even more attractive when the context of the crestfallen internet advertising market is taken into account. No website, it seems, is pulling in satisfactory ad revenues.

"We're all worried about making money from the internet, and making our core business - content - pay online," adds Judd. "The adult industry has demonstrated it does work but it all depends on whether the user wants the content."

Riccardo Donato, general manager of Audiocall, agrees: "The original model was for content and was used for law reports and adult stuff, but now everyone is looking at broadcast quality pay-per-view on the internet, it becomes an easy way for broadcasters to get viewers to pay for quality content." But Donato thinks the most popular application for drop-dialling will be voting, as consumers are increasingly inclined to accept the cost of a phone call if they feel they can have their say. For an indicator of this, one only has to look at the number of people who called in to vote for the Big Brother evictions last year. Some 20m phone calls were made in all, bringing in revenues of around £2m.

No doubt Big Brother 2 will be looking at incorporating a drop-dialler into its website for voting and maybe even for eagerly sought-after clips if the contestants can be coaxed into more outrageous behaviour. In the meantime, expect to see many more websites using drop-diallers over the next 12 months.

Perhaps they could go some way to solving the unsettling revenue crisis the web is currently in, or perhaps they will just be an interim measure until the sensational world of broadband comes along. Whatever it may be, at least it's an alternative revenue model, and that has to be a good thing in the current climate.

fields.headline: MSN beats Yahoo! in web charts
fields.standfirst: Top 10 UK internet sites
fields.trailText:
11.45am: Microsoft has extended its lead over Yahoo! in the latest website charts, writes Amy Vickers.
Table: top 10 UK internet sites
fields.body:
Microsoft has extended its lead over Yahoo! in the latest website charts.

The number of visitors to MSN has increased by 100,000 a month since December.

It now attracts 6.6m people, while Yahoo!'s figures show more modest growth at 5.5m.

According to the latest figures from internet research firm Jupiter MMXI UK, MSN reaches almost 50% of the home internet audience in the UK.

Significant changes during February include BBC Online gaining an additional 150,000 new users and Popstarsonline.net appearing in the rankings with 209,000 unique visitors.

"The UK internet population is maturing, and with over 13m people now online we are seeing how consumers are making more definitive choices of how they spend their time on the web," said Mari Kim Coleman, vice-president of international measurement services for Jupiter MMXI.

Jupiter MMXI estimates the UK home internet population has reached 13.5m people, of which the average person spends six hours, 48 minutes on the web each month.

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Johnny Vegas
fields.trailText: Johnny Vegas talks to Nicola Norton.
fields.body:
Newspapers:

The Guardian, Independent and Sunday Times. I like to spread out everything that comes with it so it looks like I've read it but actually I just read the cartoons. I don't read tabloids. Like most people in Merseyside, I haven't liked the Sun since Hillsborough.

Magazines:

I've just bought a house, so I'm reading Elle Decoration and Homes and Gardens, but when I try to translate something classy, something always seems to get lost in translation.

Books:

Elmore Leonard is fantastic. You can't get his books in St Helens, so I've just spent £70 in London stocking up. I also love Charles Bukowski. He puts me in that mindset of, "Why not hole yourself up somewhere, drink for days and then write something spectacular?" but I always end up drunk and think, "I can't do this, I need some fresh orange juice".

TV:

The Larry Sanders Show is the funniest thing ever and Louis Theroux is a genius. If I find myself watching Hollyoaks, I despise myself for the rest of the evening. I also love Ant & Dec on SM:TV.

Radio:

Terry Wogan is brilliant and possibly the best DJ anywhere. Chris Moyles should be banished - he's the worst example of posse radio.

Film:

Don't get to see a lot because there hasn't been a cinema in St Helens for 10 years, but I love anything by Ken Loach, Mike Leigh and the Coen brothers.

Adverts: Tango turned the corner for ads but I'm not keen on those sketches before programmes, like the ones before Friends. It's like designing the perfect car and then sticking a Garfield toy on the front.

New Media:

I'm still visiting the Lord Of The Rings official website out of pure, seething jealousy. I went for the role of a hobbit, got a final callback and didn't get it. On the home page, I wrote: "Johnny Vegas would have been great in this part. It's a big mistake not to have him in it."

 Comedian Johnny Vegas appears in the new BBC 2 series Happiness, which starts on Tuesday.

fields.headline: Channel 4 goes behind-the-scenes for Prince Naseem's title fight
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Channel 4 has gained access to Prince Naseem's training camp in the run-up to next month's world title fight. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has secured access to Prince Naseem's California training camp in the run-up to his big fight against Marco Antonio Barrera next month for a documentary.

The documentary, which is being shot by UK indie Zig Zag Productions, will follow Naseem as he prepares for his Las Vegas boxing debut and one of the most important fights of his career at his Palm Springs training camp.

Barrera is regarded as the most dangerous opponent in Naseem's featherweight division and the two will be fighting for the IBO world title.

"It's going to be the toughest fight of his career," said Danny Fenton, executive producer and Zig Zag managing director.

The 60-minute documentary, which was commissioned by Channel 4 head of ideas lab Liz Warner, is being produced by Jez Higham.

It is due to go out in the autumn.

webTitle: Wallace and Gromit to make big screen debut

fields.headline: Wallace and Gromit to make big screen debut
fields.trailText: The famous cartoon creations of Aardman Animations are to appear in a feature film following a deal between their creator, Nick Park and Steven Spielberg's DreamWorks
fields.body:
Plasticine pals, Wallace and Gromit, are set to appear on the big screen for their biggest adventure yet after clinching a £25m Hollywood film deal.

Aardman Animations, headed by Oscar-winning Nick Park, will make the first full-length feature about the popular characters who have up to now only appeared in the three short films The Wrong Trousers, A Close Shave and A Grand Day Out.

According to the Daily Express, Park struck the deal with Steven Spielberg's DreamWorks production company after the pair worked together on last year's highly successful Chicken Run, which raked in £187m worldwide.

It is hoped that the new project, as yet untitled, will be released next year and Arthur Sheriff, a spokesman for the Bristol-based Aardman Animations, confirmed that Parks is already working on the script, but added, "Nick will not be influenced by commercial pressures - the script will be ready when it's ready."

Park, who is 42, has already won three Oscars. In 1990 he received the Best Short Animated Film Academy Award for the five-minute Creature Comforts and he collected the same award in 1993 for The Wrong Trousers and in 1995 for A Close Shave.

The company is currently working on an animated version of the Aesop fable, The Tortoise and the Hare, which is due for release late next year.

webTitle: Death of a nameless baby that has shaken a city

fields.headline: Death of a nameless baby that has shaken a city
fields.standfirst: Police still baffled over tiny charred body as deprived Edinburgh estate unites in grief
fields.trailText: Police still baffled over tiny charred body as deprived Edinburgh estate unites in grief.
fields.body:
He was found among the litter in a desolate corner of Edinburgh's Craigmillar estate. Naked and burned and just days old. A small, nameless boy whose death has roused a community and shaken a city to its core.

Billy Franks was walking his dogs at the back of Harewood Crescent last Sunday when he came across the body. It's a bleak landscape of boarded tenement windows and wind-blown rubbish.

The baby had a shock of dark hair and was lying on his side, fists drawn up towards his chest.

Nearby lay a Babygro and a petrol can. Franks, a former soldier who has seen his share of horrors, stumbled to a neighbour's house and called the police.

The story might have ended there. A few paragraphs detailing another local tragedy. But this is Craigmillar, a scheme blighted as much by misconception as by deprivation; and this is Edinburgh, affluent and cultured, glorying in an economic boom.

It's been a week since the discovery, and the police are still baffled.

There is no sign of the mother beyond a sighting of a distressed teenage girl in the area; no hint of what pushed someone to discard the boy on wasteground.

The postmortem examination results have been inconclusive, although police have confirmed that the baby's body was charred. He had drawn breath, however, for at least a couple of days.

The search has widened and 35 officers are now working the case. Craigmillar, meanwhile, has made the boy its own with an outpouring of grief and support. People with little to give have set up a committee to raise money for a funeral and a memorial.

Toys and floral tributes are piling up at the spot where he was left and, if he is never identified, they plan to name him Billy, after Billy Franks. "I think it's the very facts of what happened to the him," said Midge Lamb, the estate's social welfare coordinator. "If he had been abandoned to be found, if he had been stillborn. But the wee soul didn't have a chance and then someone tried to cover the fact that he had ever existed. That's the most horrific thing. That's what's getting to the community.

"But it is not a surprise the way the community has reacted. This is what Craigmillar does and he has struck a chord."

The estate lies on the eastern margin of the city, on the edge of old mining land. Officially, it is being regenerated with some £300m but residents say it is only being prettified by planners keen to erase a blot from Edinburgh's elegant facade. It has a grim reputation. Oxfam's first British project was set up in Craigmillar and the scheme has struggled with economic and social ills. Last year, a commission on social exclusion in the capital identified Craigmillar as one of the key areas of concern.

Richard Holloway, the former Bishop of Edinburgh, who chaired the commission, said he had not been surprised by the overwhelming reaction to the boy's death.

"I think this demonstrates the fact that Craigmillar in spite of its difficulties is filled with warm-hearted people, many of them struggling in quite difficult circumstances," he said. "What strikes me about this response is it has focused on compassion rather than tabloid anger. That is very heartwarming."

Janet McKay, 57, who has lived in the estate all her life, says that it has never lost its heart. "We just feel so strongly about this baby. He belongs to us. He will not be forgotten and he will not go into the ground without a name. We will give him a decent burial with a name and a headstone and there will always be a fresh flower."

At the Richmond Craigmillar Church, minister Liz Henderson has given over her hall to the committee coordinating the community response.

"We have had more than our fair share of tragedies here, " she said. "But I have never seen such an amazing depth of concern for those in need. At the end of the day it doesn't matter how someone dies; if it was an accident or an overdose or a murder. The whole community pulls together.

"There is no sense of judgment. Just deep sadness and a willingness to do whatever they can to help."

There is no sign of the mother beyond a sighting of a distressed teenage girl in the area; no hint of what pushed someone to discard the boy on wasteground. webTitle: Parliament appeals for outside military aid

fields.headline: Parliament appeals for outside military aid
fields.standfirst:
Unity against rebels

Special report: Crisis in the Balkans
fields.trailText: In a show of unity between politicians from both major ethnic communities, the Macedonian parliament ended three days of debate yesterday with a condemnation of the gunmen who have been attacking the town of Tetovo.
fields.body:
In a show of unity between politicians from both major ethnic communities, the Macedonian parliament ended three days of debate yesterday with a condemnation of the gunmen who have been attacking the town of Tetovo.

They called for outside military help to deal with the rebels, but said this should not include troops from neighbouring countries.

The resolution, supported by the major Albanian and ethnic Macedonian parties, was a compromise. Bulgaria and Greece have offered aid but Albanian politicians are determined not to let the crisis slide into a conflict pitting Muslims against Orthodox Christians.

The motion called for a "wider dialogue" among the "relevant forces" in Macedonia to deal with the country's problems.

The government is also stepping up its military efforts at the gunmen lodged in the hills above Tetovo. The prime minister Ljubco Georgievski announced new measures to crack down on the rebels' fight for greater rights and recognition, including a curfew and restrictions on movement in the Tetovo region.

He accused the US and Germany, whose troops patrol neighbouring Kosovo as part of Nato's contingent, of not doing enough to stop the rebels. Meanwhile, he said, "Macedonia is rapidly arming itself."

"You cannot convince us that the chieftains of these gangs are unknown to your governments, nor can you persuade us that they cannot be stopped," he said. "Macedonia will win this battle without giving up a single foot of our territory. And after the victory, Macedonians and Albanians will continue to live together - as they must."
