fields.headline: Crisis in the Balkans
fields.standfirst:
Ethnic Albanian guerrillas based in Kosovo are fighting Serb and Macedonian forces along the western border. Nato troops in the notionally Yugoslav province are apparently unwilling or unable to intervene in the latest Balkan crisis
Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Ethnic Albanian guerrillas in Kosovo are fighting Serbs and Macedonians along the western border. Nato troops in the notionally Yugoslav province seem unwilling or unable to intervene in the latest Balkan crisis. Derek Brown and Simon Jeffery explain.
fields.body:
What is the crisis?
Ethnic Albanian guerillas are battling for control of the western part of Macedonia, the breakaway Yugoslav republic. The area, along the Kosovo border, is steadily falling to the rebels as the Macedonian police and army units fail to hold them back. Some fear it may be the start of a new civil war in the Balkans.

Who are the rebels?
They call themselves the National Liberation Army (NLA), but are also known as the Liberation Army of Presevo, Medvedja and Bujanovac. These are all towns in the southern part of Serbia with an Albanian ethnic majority.

What do they want?
The guerrillas say they want to protect their kinsfolk both in Serbia, which makes up most of the rump state of Yugoslavia, and Macedonia, which has a 30% Albanian minority. Some of the rebels claim that they are fighting for a greater Kosovo, taking in the ethnic Albanian parts of both Serbia and Macedonia. Some even want a greater Albania.

Is there another motive?
Control of the porous border is extremely lucrative. The lawless frontiers have become an international crossroads for drugs and arms smugglers, and for the trade in illegal migration.

How many guerrillas are there?
Estimates vary, but most observers believe that at best the rebels have only a few hundred fighters. However, the group has close links to the much bigger Kosovo Liberation Army, which was supposed to have disbanded after Nato troops took control of the province in 1999. The rebels are also urging ethnic Albanians in Macedonia to join their struggle; they claim 2,000 have volunteered.

Why have the Serbian or Yugoslav forces not cracked down on the group?
They were not allowed to. The guerrillas are operating in a buffer zone on the Serbian side of the Kosovo border, from which Belgrade's troops were excluded at the end of the Kosovo war. But, as Serbia is now under democratic leadership, Yugoslav troops are set to take over the entire zone.

What will that mean?
It is a high-risk strategy which puts Yugoslav troops in an area where the predominately ethnic Albanian population remembers them as their oppressors. It may ignite wider Albanian guerilla insurgency in the southern Balkans.

Could Nato have stepped in?
It is not in their remit to cross the Macedonian border, and to control the Kosovo side would take thousands of troops. However, politicians from both ethnic Albanian and Macedonian communities have called for outside military help to protect their country from the guerillas and a possible civil war.

What is happening inside Kosovo?
Technically, the province remains part of Yugoslavia. In reality, it is a Nato protectorate, with K-For troops maintaining an uneasy peace between the Albanian majority and the rump population of Serbs, who live in ghetto-like conditions.

Is the present flare-up a passing phenomenon?
Alas, no. Spring is coming to the mountainous borders of Kosovo, and in the Balkans that means the fighting season is only just beginning.

webTitle: Leader: red faces over red noses

fields.headline: Leader: red faces over red noses
fields.trailText: British Telecom is not quite as black- hearted as it has been made out. Its critics have been condemning the company for the profits it has made from calls generated by last week's Comic Relief. Some estimates put it at £250,000, but others have placed it much higher.
fields.body:
British Telecom is not quite as black- hearted as it has been made out. Its critics have been condemning the company for the profits it has made from calls generated by last week's Comic Relief. Some estimates put it at £250,000, but others have placed it much higher.

Why, when actors and many other people involved in last week's charity efforts have given their time for free, is the telephone company pocketing the extra profits from the millions of extra calls? BT blames the regulator. Under the terms of the company's licence with Oftel, it has to charge a minimum amount for every call. Oftel confirmed this defence, explaining that because of BT's monopoly position, it was required to treat all users the same and not make exceptions for certain good causes.

Comic relief went even further in alleviating the red faces at BT. It recognised the disruption which the biennial appeal made on the network and the significant resources and expenses incurred in ensuring regular customer services were not interrupted. This year BT donated £65,000 directly to Comic Relief and it had also bought 36,000 vehicle red noses at a cost of £25,0000. Then there were donations in kind, including helping employees to give their time free in taking calls on the big day. Good for them.

But if the company was genuine about wanting to give more to the charity, there is a simple way round the Oftel rule which would achieve its wish: increasing the donation to Comic Relief so that it equals the profit made. True this is a difficult time for the company. Its share price has fallen to its lowest level for two years and it has accumulated debts of £30bn. This week it meets its shareholders. But there could be no better way of demonstrating that it is not just profit-driven - nor just shareholder-driven. A company making almost £3bn profit a year can afford to be more community minded. In PR terms alone, it would be worth every penny.

webTitle: Seth versus Syal in EMMA awards

fields.headline: Seth versus Syal in EMMA awards
fields.trailText: The Best Book/Novel shortlist for the annual BT Ethnic Multicultural Media Awards (EMMA), set up to recognise ethnically diverse talent in the media, has been revealed.
fields.body:
The Best Book/Novel shortlist for the annual BT Ethnic Multicultural Media Awards (EMMA), set up to recognise ethnically diverse talent in the media, has been revealed.

In the eclectic list, veteran author Vikram Seth, nominated for An Equal Music, is joined by comedian and broadcaster Meera Syal for her second novel Life Isn't All Ha Ha Hee Hee, crime writer Mike Phillips for A Shadow of Myself and Ben Arogundade for his controversial look at the black aesthetic, Black Beauty.

The shortlist now goes to the public vote, either by phone (0870 333 6133) or online.

As well as the Best Book category, there are awards in music, film, television and the print and broadcast media industries. There is also a Lifetime Achievement Award, which last year was won by Nelson Mandela.

The awards ceremony will take place on April 26 at the Grosvenor Park Hotel, to be screened by BBC2 on Saturday April 28. For a full list of awards visit the BT EMMA Awards website.

The shortlist

An Equal Music by Vikram Seth
Seth's third novel, set in Venice, Vienna and London, tells the story of a classical musician's consuming vocation and the rediscovery of his lost love.

Life Isn't All Ha Ha Hee Hee by Meera Syal
This follow-up to the award-winning Anita and Me focuses on a trio of women from London's East End. Friends since school and tied by their Punjabi roots, they navigate the emotional rollercoaster of oncoming middle youth.

A Shadow of Myself by Mike Phillips
Crime writer Phillips returns with this tightly plotted thriller about a black documentary film-maker who meets a stranger claiming to be his brother and is propelled into a nightmare world of intrigue and murder.

Black Beauty by Ben Arogundade
British journalist and model Arogundade's lavishly illustrated book chronicles the ever-changing definition of black beauty within popular culture, from Muhammad Ali to Lil' Kim.

webTitle: Know your way around the courts

fields.headline: Know your way around the courts
fields.standfirst: Courting disaster
fields.trailText: A judge has ruled that newspaper articles causing "alarm or distress" can amount to harassment, writes Clare Dyer.
fields.body:
The media face a new and unforeseen legal threat with the disclosure last week of a judge's ruling that newspaper articles causing "alarm or distress" can amount to harassment.

Esther Thomas, a former clerk with the City of London police, won the ruling against the Sun under the 1997 Protection from Harassment Act, the law designed to deter stalkers. She received race-related hate mail after two articles blamed her for disciplinary action that led to the demotion of two police sergeants and a £700 fine for another over an incident involving an asylum seeker.

Andrew Neil belittled the judgment on Radio 4's The World Tonight, noting that it was delivered by a "little county court judge", and predicting that it would be overturned by the Court of Appeal. But the Guardian has now discovered that an injunction under the same act was nearly granted last March by a High Court judge and was averted only when the paper, the Daily Mail, offered an undertaking instead.

Birmingham law firm Tyndallwoods and counsel Stephanie Harrison, representing an Algerian asylum seeker, went to court for an emergency injunction to try to stop the Mail from publishing an article suggesting he was a terrorist. Mr Justice Hooper said that he was "minded" to grant the order and asked the Mail to send a lawyer to put its case.

The lawyer gave an undertaking that the paper would take legal advice on whether it would be "reasonable" to publish the article - a defence under the act. The threatened story never appeared.

The Mail had earlier run a front page story accusing the man, who has two wives and 13 children, of being a benefits scrounger. Pictures of him and his wives were published and the streets where the family live in two houses were identified. A reporter and photographer went into the mosque where he was praying and tried to interview him.

Apart from the fear of racist attacks, the judge was told that the man's life would be in danger if the article was published. It could also affect the outcome of his asylum application, which was eventually successful.

Will the new legal weapon threaten investigative journalism? Stephen Grosz, a media and human rights lawyer at Bindman and Partners, thinks not. "When you're considering what the defence of reasonableness means, you're going to have to look at the right to freedom of expression and the whole line the court has always run about the press being a public watchdog. I don't see it as a fetter or limitation on press freedom, save in cases where there is an overriding need to protect privacy."

 Media Guardian has received several calls from readers wishing to contribute to Esther Thomas's legal fund. For those who would like to, cheques made payable to North Lambeth Law Centre can be sent to: Lawrence Davies, North Lambeth Law Centre, 14 Bowden Street, London SE11 4DS. Please write "Esther Thomas Fund" on the back of the cheque.

fields.headline: Courting disaster
fields.standfirst:
A supermodel and a former police clerk are just two people bringing court cases which may ultimately threaten press freedom. But why do these, and a slew of other actions, pose such a menace to the future of British newspapers? Alan Rusbridger explains

Know your way around the courts
fields.trailText: A supermodel and a former police clerk are just two people bringing court cases that may threaten press freedom. But why do these actions pose such a menace to the future of British newspapers? Alan Rusbridger explains.
fields.body:
In the labyrinth of buildings squatting along Wapping Highway in east London, there live two fabled lawyers, Brett & Crone. Between them, Brett & Crone cater for all Rupert Murdoch's legal needs. Mess with any of his British newspapers and Brett & Crone swing into resolute action. They are clever, resourceful and experienced. And just now they are very busy.

Brett is in the high court today defending the Times against a libel charge brought by a Russian businessmen. A block away from Brett's office in Wapping, Crone is urgently drafting a defence for the Times's sister paper, the Sun, over a claim that its journalism infringed the Protection From Harassment Act 1997.

Brett - Alastair Brett, to give him his full due - is asking judges to reward "responsible" newspapers by giving them more protection for journalism deemed to be in the public interest.

Meanwhile Crone - Tom Crone , the legal manager of News International - is asking judges to give the Sun the licence to publish articles that even its lawyer admits were "strident, aggressive and inflammatory."

Brett and the Times are fighting a libel action against one Dr Grigori Loutchansky, who is suing the paper for linking him and his Nordex group of companies to organised crime - a link which he has consistently denied.

Crone and the Sun are fighting Esther Thomas, a black 29-year-old former civilian clerk with the City of London Police, who recently won a landmark ruling in Lambeth county court. She can now pursue her claim that a series of articles about her - and about the complaints of racism she had made against three police colleagues - constituted harassment.

Brett & Crone will naturally adopt different arguments and tactics in each case. But in the deeper recesses of their erudite minds - the fathomless cranial cavities marked "Without Prejudice" - each doubtless recognises that the two cases are linked.

They are not only linked to each other, they are linked to a whole barrage of other cases at various stages of assorted legal and regulatory slipways around London.

 There is the case of Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones, in which the Hollywood celebrities have won the backing of a court of appeal judge for their argument that they have a right to privacy under the Human Rights Act.

 There is the supermodel Naomi Campbell who is also threatening to use the Human Rights Act against the Mirror for taking long-lens pictures of her leaving a Narcotics Anonymous meeting in Fulham in February.

 There is the newscaster Anna Ford, who is discussing with lawyers the possibility of going for judicial review of a press complaints com mission ruling that she had no right to privacy while on a Spanish beach with her partner and children.

Not all these cases will come to court. Some clearly have more merit than others. But they all concern fundamental issues about the extent to which freedom of expression has to be balanced with other rights - the right to a reputation, the right to privacy, the right to be free from racial harassment, and so on.

It is only fair to point out that worries about privacy are not the exclusive preserve of celebrities. Richard Desmond, the new owner of the Express, is very particular about his own press. And his battle with the Mail has demonstrated that Associated's chairman, Jonathan Rothermere, dislikes his own privacy being invaded. He is also currently in discussions with the Mail's official historian, Sally Taylor, over references to his late father's life in a forthcoming book.

The reality is dawning on newspaper lawyers and editors that the courts are - with some degree of relish - about to embark on a process of establishing and developing a right to privacy, as enshrined within Article Eight of the European Convention on Human Rights.

At the same time lawyers and editors are waking up to the realisation that - despite recent advances - the English libel laws still remain an unpredictable and awesome weapon in the hands of determined claimants.

Paul Dacre at the Mail had an unpleasant shock last month when he was ordered to pay Alan Sugar £100,000 (plus costs estimated at well over £500,000) for the paper accusing him of being a miserly boss while in charge at Tottenham.

Many lawyers had imagined that the days of enormous damages against newspapers were past. But the jury in the Sugar trial awarded the same sum for hurt feelings that the Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme recommends for the loss of both arms or the loss of both eyes. (They later reached an out of court compromise on £60,000 - itself equivalent to both the loss of a tongue and an injury causing "permanent disabling mental disorder.")

David Yelland at the Sun was naturally pleased to win his recent appeal against Bruce Grobbelaar, the goalkeeper accused of throwing matches. He will have been less pleased at the judges' scathing rejection of the paper's appeal to have some form of qualified privilege for its reporting.

The issue of qualified privilege (see below) - a measure of protection for journalism in the public interest - was also at the heart of a powerful editorial written last week by the Times editor, Peter Stothard, in relation to his case beginning today in the high court. In pre-trial argument in the court of appeal last week the Times was prevented from using certain material as part of its defence.

Add to this melange of cases a number of other controversial issues - the right to report courts, the right to report local councils, the threat of being sued in distant countries for material posted on the internet, the right to receive information from the police - and you currently have a lot of editors and lawyers extremely concerned about the gradual erosion of press freedom in this country.

The challenge facing the press is whether it is prepared to see these issues as in any way connected and whether editors can see a way of forming a common cause to fight these threats together.

Take our friends Brett & Crone. Broadsheet Brett wants to get more concessions for the press so that responsible Mr Stothard can write about people in public life in an unencumbered way. But Mr Brett, being a sophisticated sort, will know that no politician or judge is going to make a single concession to the press without cast-iron guarantees that it wouldn't be used to help tabloid editors kick down bedroom doors.

Mr Stothard himself would probably not be unduly worried by giving guarantees on privacy (with appropriate public interest safeguards) if he could get a decent libel law on the statute books. The Times does not often invade people's privacy without good reason.

Over the road at Wapping, Mr Crone currently approaches the problem from precisely the other end of the telescope. Mr Crone will fight tooth and nail to prevent any concessions on privacy. His papers - rather more profitable to Mr Murdoch than the Times - thrive on invading privacy. Libel, to him, is a secondary issue.

So the reality is that unless Brett & Crone - and their counterparts on other titles - can work out some kind of common path, the press will never present a united front on many of these issues. And without a united front from the press it is inevitable that other people will sort it out for them.

Those "other people" are likely to be judges. Politicians may run scared at the first whiff of grapeshot from Lord Wakeham or the executive chairman of News International, Les Hinton. Judges are another matter altogether.

Recent judgments in a variety of courts since the introduction of the Human Rights Act have tended to show a keen appreciation of the importance of Article 10, which protects freedom of expression.

But - as the Grobbelaar, Zeta-Jones, Lambeth and Albert Reynolds cases show - judges are also determined to carve out a concept of responsible reporting which shows due recognition of other, sometimes conflicting, rights.

The press's traditional answer is to plead that everything should be left to self-regulation. The Anna Ford judicial review, if it goes ahead, will be a stern test of that.

Firstly, the case would establish whether or not PCC judgments are capable of judicial review (answer: probably yes). It would then establish whether the PCC's assorted judgments on long-lens photography amount to a coherent policy (answer: probably not). In the longer term the PCC may have to demonstrate that it offers sufficient remedies - as required by the Human Rights Act.

There may or may not be limited sympathy for celebrities who take to the courts. The case of Esther Thomas is a different kettle of fish, involving as it does an ordinary young black woman - in no conventional sense a public figure.

On any account she suffered an extremely unpleasant experience as a result of the attacks on her by Sun journalists and readers. Whether this is enough to justify any form of legal protection is another issue: it would be easy to see any number of Vazes, Hindujas and Ashcrofts rushing in on her coat tails.

Because there are so many current cases involving vital issues of freedom of expression, the Guardian is launching a regular media law page. In this section every week we will examine these issues in some depth. I very much hope that the players in these issues will take part in this important debate. Including, or even especially, Messrs Brett & Crone.

Qualified Privilege (QP)

QP is the concept that papers ought to receive extra protection from being sued for libel if they are writing about matters in the public interest and which the public has an interest in receiving.

In America the so-called Sullivan doctrine means that public figures find it virtually impossible to sue newspapers unless they can prove that they were reckless or motivated by malice. Newspapers are protected, even if they make honest mistakes.

In British law the judgment in the libel action brought by Albert Reynolds against the Sunday Times provides certain protection for newspapers. But they have to satisfy certain conditions before they can claim QP.

Judges will consider, among other things, the seriousness of the charges, the source of the information, the steps taken to verify the information, the urgency of the matter and whether comment was sought from the claimant before publication.

fields.headline: VAT 'error' may mean entry charges
fields.trailText: The tradition of free admission to some of the oldest museums in England is under threat, because the university museums have been left out, apparently inadvertently, from the concession allowing non-charging museums to reclaim VAT announced in the Budget.
fields.body:
The tradition of free admission to some of the oldest museums in England is under threat, because the university museums have been left out, apparently inadvertently, from the concession allowing non-charging museums to reclaim VAT announced in the Budget.

Chancellor Gordon Brown's move was intended to introduce universal free admission to major collections, ending an anomaly that penalised free museums and dissuaded others from ending charges. Only the charging museums were regarded by customs and excise as operating a business, and therefore allowed to reclaim VAT. This cost the free museums millions - the British Museum faced a VAT bill of £5m for its Great Court development.

The vice chancellor of Manchester University has privately informed the government that he would consider introducing charges at Manchester Museum, which has one of the world's finest Egyptology collections, if the university museums were not given the same concession.

Other universities would be certain to follow. The list caught by the anomaly includes the world's oldest public museum, the Ashmolean in Oxford, the Fitzwilliam in Cambridge, and 15 others with collections designated as of national importance.

The director of the Manchester Museum, Tristram Besterman, who is leading the campaign to persuade the government to extend the provision, said: "If my vice chancellor introduces charges it would be a personal tragedy. I have spent my whole career in museums campaigning for free admission. But it would be intolerable if we alone were left unable to reclaim VAT."

At the Ashmolean, director Christopher Brown pointed out that since local authority museums could reclaim VAT through their councils, the university museums would be left as the only free museums in the country unable to reclaim VAT.

webTitle: Fear for museums as lottery 'golden age' ends

fields.headline: Fear for museums as lottery 'golden age' ends
fields.trailText: Museums will close and have their collections warehoused or scattered as the "golden age" of lottery-backed expansion comes to a halt, according to a report published today.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Museums will close and have their collections warehoused or scattered as the "golden age" of lottery-backed expansion comes to a halt, according to a report published today.

The huge expansion, bringing science, environment and art-based attractions and extensions to museums, left the sector with an extra £29m a year bill for increased costs in a static or declining market, the author, Adrian Babbidge, suggested.

The most spectacular casualties so far are the Faith Centre in Bradford, the Centre for Popular Music in Sheffield and the Centre for the Visual Arts in Cardiff, but more closures are predicted for the next few years among the traditional museums.

Museums also face increased competition, from rival attractions and from innovations such as Sunday trading. Mr Babbidge, director of the East Midlands Museums Service, said that in his area the opening of Ikea, the furnishings store, has had a perceptible impact on museum visiting on Sunday, formerly the busiest day.

Mr Babbidge, who has also worked at museums in Essex and Wales, has published his grim forecast in Cultural Trends, the journal of the Policy Studies Institute.

He suggested that the museum sector had been expanding unsustainably since the 1960s. The lottery had provided a unique opportunity for funding to catch up.

However, his analysis shows that the bulk of the lottery money spent on museums since 1995, 55% of more than £500m, has gone on new museums, extensions or renewal of existing buildings.

Just under half the money went to national museums, but cash for the regionals, more than £300m, could have solved the problems of decades of underfunding, particularly the backlog of collections' care and documentation. Instead he calculated that the new spaces created would cost an extra £29m a year to maintain, making the problem worse.

The report shows a startling division in the government's regional spending on museums, from 6p per head of the population in the east midlands and 15p per head in the west midlands to £9.59 per head in the south-east, where most of the national museums, directly supported by the government, are concentrated. The north-west is in second place, at £2.63 per head.

The gap should be filled by local authority spending, but Mr Babbidge's figures show that after a slow rise until 1995 overall spending on revenue and capital support has been falling. The fall is steepest in the south-west: 6% down between 1994 and 1999.

His study suggests that part of the regions' problem is the rapid growth in the 1960s, when dozens of branch museums opened in libraries and other public spaces. Thirty-nine of these have closed, and he predicted more to come.

Wages in the sector were not only well below other public sector wages (in turn considerably lower than the private sector), said Mr Babbidge, but the gap was widening. In 1973 an average museum professional, with a degree and usually a post-graduate qualification, earned £2,178, compared with £2,464 for a graduate school teacher. The comparative salaries were now £16,771 and £23,193.

"Financial prospects for entrants are limited, at a time when most will have to begin to pay off overdrafts and student loans.For many, and especially for those from poorer families, a museum career is highly unattractive."

Mr Babbidge challenged the government to formulate a genuine national policy for all English museums, in which coherent decisions could be taken.

"Instead we get interventions in the market, like the recent announcement on VAT, which could make it cheaper for people to get on a train and go to the Science Museum in London, if it becomes free, than to visit their local museum if it charges.

"If museums are going to close, and I believe they will, there has to be a policy in place in which sensible decisions can be taken about the fate of their collections."

A Department of Culture spokesman dismissed the findings as unduly alarmist. "The problems of regional museums are precisely the remit of the task force recently announced by the government, and it would be wrong to prejudge their findings.

"Resource [the museums, galleries and archives council] is considering long term policy for museums and will also be deciding the best allocation of the £20m extra announced last year for regional museums."

Concepts that took the cash and failed

 The Life Force Centre, beside Bradford Cathedral, which cost £5m including a £2.2m millennium grant, closed last month after seven months. It was projected to attract 40,000 people a year, but in its first week had 62 paying visitors.

 The National Centre for Popular Music, in Sheffield, closed last August after 16 months. It cost £15m, with £11m in lottery grants. The spectacular building was projected to attract 400,000 people a year, but drew fewer than a quarter of that.

 The Centre for Visual Arts in Cardiff closed in November, after attracting 47,500 instead of 220,000 visitors in its first year. The transformation of a listed former library building cost £9m, including a £3m lottery grant.

fields.headline: Freemasons shake hands with the media
fields.trailText: 10.45am: The Freemasons have hired their first-ever PR agency, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
After decades as Britain's most secret society, the Freemasons have hired their first-ever PR agency to improve the organisation's image.

MDA, the PR agency run by former army officer Mike Dewar, has been appointed to bring the masons into the open.

The agency will concentrate on getting more positive media coverage for the organisation, including promoting its charitable donations.

"The intention is very much to go onto the front foot and seek media coverage," said Mr Dewar.

"They've had a very bad press in the past, which was partly their own doing.

"In the 1920s and 30s they were persecuted in Europe and they withdrew into themselves as a result of that, so there are a lot of prejudices to overcome."

Although not a direct recruitment exercise, the PR push is aimed in part at boosting membership, which has fallen in recent years.

The organisation is particularly keen to change the commonly held perception that it is only for middle-aged men.

The move is part of an ongoing effort to change the public's perception of the Freemasons.

The organisation recently hired its first internal PR manager and it has relaunched its magazine Freemasonry Today to attract younger readers.

But even in the new spirit of openness, there are some subjects that will remain off bounds.

"The ceremony to initiate people into the Freemasons will remain a secret," said Mr Dewar.

fields.headline: Biss Lancaster chairman joins PRCA
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Biss Lancaster Euro RSCG chief Graham Lancaster is to become chairman of PR body the PRCA, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Biss Lancaster Euro RSCG chairman Graham Lancaster is to become chairman of PR trade body, the Public Relations Consultants Association.

Mr Lancaster will become PRCA vice-chairman this May, taking over from GCI's Adrian Wheeler.

In May, Mr Lancaster will take over as chairman as Tom Watson leaves office.

He is planning to shake up public, business and media attitudes to PR.

Mr Lancaster said the PR industry had been hijacked by the notion of spin-doctors and will use his two years at the helm of the PRCA to push for PR to be taken seriously.

"We have been hijacked by the spin side. But the major issues - communicating production, profitability, expanding the image and profile of a company - the practical, tangible parts of business and life, are not understood," he said.

He added that the PR industry must publicly discuss what it does to help people understand and recognise its value.

fields.headline: NUJ calls for Express action
fields.trailText:
10.15am: The union has warned Express staff industrial action is 'the only way' to prevent large-scale redundancies, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 16: Express journalists consider work-to-rule
Mar 15: Sports writers under threat
Mar 15: Dot.gone from Express
Mar 15: NUJ fears for future of Express
Mar 15: Union warns of cuts
fields.body:
Jeremy Dear, the NUJ's national newspaper organiser, has issued a warning to staff on the Express that industrial action is "the only way" to prevent large-scale redundancies.

The warning follows a meeting last Friday of the Express Newspapers NUJ chapel.

An overwhelming vote to prepare a ballot for industrial action was passed, with four votes against and 11 abstentions.

Mr Dear said he wanted to make it clear the only way to prevent redundancies was to opt for industrial action.

He spoke following speculation over the weekend that an overwhelming number of journalists may push for voluntary redundancy.

The NUJ is keen to prevent as many journalists as possible from leaving the paper in the short term.

The union believes resistance across the board to Richard Desmond's plans could prevent the Express Newspapers chief from making the cutbacks.

But insiders say the NUJ's ambitions may be optimistic.

Sources claim a number of senior staff are already negotiating to leave the paper.

Last week it was confirmed Express Newspapers would shed 145 journalists.

fields.headline: Bell backs Beijing bid for Olympics
fields.trailText: 10.15am: PR supremo Lord Bell is set to win the contract to promote Beijing's bid for the 2008 Olympics, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
PR supremo Lord Bell is poised to win a multimillion pound contract to promote Beijing's bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games.

The bizarre pairing of Beijing's communist regime with the man who helped propel Margaret Thatcher to power is expected to be announced later this week.

Bell Pottinger, the PR agency set up by Lord Bell, is in the final stages of negotiations with the Chinese authorities about the deal.

Beijing is competing against Toronto, Paris, Istanbul and Osaka to host the games.

The Chinese city is the favourite to win the vote because International Olympic Committee president Juan Antonio Sanchez has lobbied over the years for a Chinese Olympics.

China lost out to Sydney in the race for the 2000 games.

But Bell Pottinger faces an uphill task in convincing people of Beijing's suitability. Many believe China's human rights record should discount it from the prestigious task of hosting the games.

fields.headline: Future slides into the red
fields.trailText:
10am: Beleaguered publisher Future Network has plunged into the red after a 'bruising' year took its toll, writes Dan Milmo.
Mar 19: Future's finance chief goes
fields.body:
Beleaguered magazine group Future Network has plunged into the red after a "bruising" year took its toll on the company.

The publisher, which specialises in computer and new technology titles, said the weak computer games market and a downturn in new media advertising had contributed to a slump in last year's figures, which came in below analysts' expectations.

There appears to be no sign of a quick turnaround in the group's fortunes, as it forecast a "substantial loss" for the first half of 2001.

It reported an operating loss of £2.5m last year, against an operating profit of £20.2m for 1999.

Future Network, whose flagship title is Business 2.0, has been hit by the change in fortunes in the internet sector.

The company has issued two profit warnings in the last eight months, and made drastic cutbacks including the loss of 350 jobs and closure of 20 magazines.

"For all the revenue growth and momentum, 2000 ultimately became a bruising year for Future," said Greg Ingham, chief executive of the group.

Mr Ingham added that despite a 28% growth in revenues to £254m, the company was buffeted by a number of "external and internal factors" in the last four months of the year.

"The much weaker games market, the dot.com collapse, a general tech downturn and softer advertising markets all contributed to a performance that was some way below expectations," he said.

Future Network also announced the resignation of finance director Ian Linkins, with former Emap executive Colin Morrison stepping up to chief operating officer.

The boardroom changes are a response to investors' demands for management change at the company, which has issued two profit warnings over the past four months.

"Future's clear goal for 2001 and 2002 is to restore the company to positive cashflow by the resolute focus on our core business," said Chris Anderson, chairman of Future Network.

The group is leaving no stone unturned in the quest to reverse its slump in fortunes. Last month Future announced the loss of 350 jobs and the closure of 20 magazine titles.

A core part of the recovery strategy is the sale of the Business 2.0 e-economy title and there has been strong interest in a publication whose fortunes are closely tied to the strength of the technology market.

But Future Network is still exposed to weakness in the computer games market, which is the source of 35% of its revenue and is in virtual recession following the delay in launching the PlayStation 2 console.

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: There were mixed reactions all round for Revolution's annual awards last week, Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
 Mixed reactions all round for Revolution's annual awards last week. Host Mark "just shut up and let me get this over with" Lamarr clearly hated every minute of it, revellers can't remember if they had a good time, and sponsors were slightly peeved because no one paid any attention to the awards or to their carefully crafted branding - for which they had paid thousands. The problem was the venue - the Commonwealth Institute: all well and good for sober world leaders, but not the ideal location for pissed new media types forced to sit through a power cut. Crap joke of the night was: how many leading lights of new media does it take to drain the power? Thankfully, I don't think there was an answer to that rather droll witticism.

 It was merely a matter of time before some enterprising new media soul tried to get in on the foot and mouth act. Prescient individual Dan Willmot, who registered Footandmouth.co.uk last August, has suddenly realised that all his Christmases have come at once. He says the name was going to be a web design agency until the current crisis (likely story), but now he's going to sell it to the highest bidder, and make a culling (no pun intended). Offers are flooding in but it's still on the market. Must mean that he's gunning for quite a coffer.

 More bad news at Revolution Towers: Haymarket has pulled the plug on the proposed Australian version of the mag. Market conditions are not good, but then we always knew that, didn't we. Poor Mairi Clarke has not had much luck with start-ups, although Diary wouldn't dare go so far as to suggest the lovely Mairi is the kiss of death. It is merely a coincidence that Mairi has been on the receiving end of strategy changes, and sadly, this time around, it means the end of a dream job in Australia. Ah well, life is tough.

 Here's one trick BT has so far missed, courtesy of Merrill Lynch analyst Neil Blackley, quoted in Television magazine. Alarmed that upstart UPC France had achieved 45% initial penetration, dethroned monopoly France Telecom found a deliciously effective solution: "They put one 60-year-old in charge of number portability, who got in at 10am, left at 4pm and had a two-hour lunch-break, and gave him one fax machine which only took 40 sheets of paper, and one telephone. UPC ended up buying FT a new 250-page fax machine."

 Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst: Matthew Bannister
fields.trailText: Matthew Bannister talks to Nicola Norton.
fields.body:
Favourite website?

Being a bit of a radio fan, I like flashradio.com and grooveradio.com, a hip hop station out of the US. My son and I enjoy neopets.com, where you can acquire a virtual pet, which you have to look after and feed. But first you have to earn the money so you can feed it. I'm not that good at the feeding and the pet has started to protest.

Last online purchase?

A Dorothy L Sayers first edition from bookfinder.com. I use this site to search through a wonderful collection of secondhand bookshops from all over the world.

Most recent technological faux pas?

I'm a fairly mainstream web user so I don't think I've made any, but I haven't really tested the limits of my technical knowledge.

Ever been in a chat room?

To be honest, I've got better things to do with my life, like talk to people.

Main news source?

BBC online gets better and better. Its depth and authority are the best in the world. It also has the best video and audio archive. I also like peoplenews.com for a bit of gossip.

Which site is least likely to succeed?

One with no business model. People often have a traffic model, ie, an idea to get people to a site, but without knowing if they will buy anything when they get there. The revenue model is what people need to look at. You need to employ traditional skills of marketing, customer care, delivery, cost controls and original ideas. A bright idea on its own is not good enough.

Time spent on web?

It varies day to day; about an hour a night and a few hours at the weekend. It's dangerous to get lost in it to the exclusion of everything else.

Least useful site on the web?

My bugbear is banking sites. They offer attractive interest rates if you bank online, but take hours to download and are deeply complicated.

Screensaver?

The Radio 1 screensaver. It got put there and it stayed.

Most irritating thing about the web?

When it fails to deliver, sites which are designed for designers and not users, sites that show off and sites that crash leaving you the message: "Your computer has performed an illegal operation". What does that mean? Am I about to go to prison?

Do you still bother with old media?

Each development should add to the others. People thought TV would abolish radio and the web would take over from newspapers, but they can coexist. We now have a much richer choice of ways in which we can get information and entertainment. The web adds new potential and if the medium is clever, and someone gets it right, it will work.

 Former Radio 1 controller and BBC marketing director Matthew Bannister was recently appointed chairman and chief executive of trustthedj.com

To be honest, I've got better things to do with my life, like talk to people. Main news source? BBC online gets better and better. Its depth and authority are the best in the world. It also has the best video and audio archive. I also like peoplenews.com for a bit of gossip. Which site is least likely to succeed? One with no business model. People often have a traffic model, ie, an idea to get people to a site, but without knowing if they will buy anything when they get there. The revenue model is what people need to look at. You need to employ traditional skills of marketing, customer care, delivery, cost controls and original ideas. A bright idea on its own is not good enough. Time spent on web? It varies day to day; about an hour a night and a few hours at the weekend. It's dangerous to get lost in it to the exclusion of everything else. Least useful site on the web? My bugbear is banking sites. They offer attractive interest rates if you bank online, but take hours to download and are deeply complicated. Screensaver? The Radio 1 screensaver. It got put there and it stayed. Most irritating thing about the web? When it fails to deliver, sites which are designed for designers and not users, sites that show off and sites that crash leaving you the message: "Your computer has performed an illegal operation". What does that mean? Am I about to go to prison? Do you still bother with old media? Each development should add to the others. fields.headline: Mirror image
fields.standfirst: Philip Graf is still popular after 16 months as Trinity Mirror boss but he's had a hard baptism.  Bill Hagerty asks him about the Slickers, the DTI and Piers Morgan
fields.trailText: Philip Graf is still popular after 16 months as Trinity Mirror boss but he's had a hard baptism, writes Bill Hagerty.
fields.body:
Like his predecessor as chief executive of what is now Trinity Mirror newspapers, Philip Graf is an Ulsterman. But this particular Northern Irishman is not only ready to laugh at the slightest provocation, but is affable and self-effacing. Nationality apart, there is no resemblance between Philip Graf and David Montgomery, whom Graf succeeded in the Canary Wharf hot seat.

When the skeletal, domineering Montgomery smiles, you can almost hear ice splintering. But jollity and the lack of it is just one of the many differences. It is a fair bet that the name of Montgomery would produce venom from some who have had dealings with him, but it is rare to find anyone with a bad word to say about Graf.

Painstakingly careful over his replies, Graf never shirks answering a question but the minefield through which he appears to think he is tiptoeing during this interview gets even more dangerous when Piers Morgan and the City Slickers are discussed. Asked if he was concerned about the DTI investigation into the shares affair, Graf told me: "I don't believe they will find anything untoward. If they do, we'll have to review the situation, but I really don't think they will find anything as far as Piers is concerned. I think the PCC was very clear about what he did, which was ill-judged [the PCC found that Morgan had "fallen short of the high professional standards" demanded by its code]. The matter was actually dealt with very quickly, before that report came out.

"The Slickers [Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell] went through a proper, careful disciplinary procedure in which I was not involved and were fired. As far as I am concerned, the issue has been dealt with, unless something remarkable, unexpected and new emerges."

But what of the internal emails published by the Sunday Times, which the paper suggested indicated that the editor should have been aware the Slickers would be recommending Viglen shares the morning after he bought them? These emails had not, apparently, been disclosed to the PCC. Surely this was damaging for Morgan and the company?

"No, the email was not shown to the PCC. The PCC was not investigating the company. It was Piers Morgan who gave evidence to the PCC, not the company, so we didn't show them any documents." And the email in which Morgan referred to a discussion he had with Bhoyrul on "Viglen day" about the merits of the editor selling other shares in order to buy Viglen - was it conceivable that such a conversation could have taken place without the following morning's pro-Viglen story being mentioned? "We've never denied that they had spoken about Viglen, but that email does not show that they talked about Viglen that day. It had appeared in the City Slickers column on several occasions, remember."

Another email revealed, as the Sunday Times put it, Morgan's appetite for investment and the occasional free gift: does not this not indicate embarrassing greed on the part of the editor of the group's flagship title? "If you are saying, was it a desire to exploit his position to make lots of money, well, I stand by the fact that the pattern of behaviour was a foolish pattern, not a greedy pattern."

The only child of a Belfast bakery foreman of German extraction, Philip Graf was educated at Methodist College, Belfast, and then Cambridge, where he read law. The Belfast Telegraph came into the family home every day. After university, he got his opportunity in the newspaper industry with Thomson Regional Newspapers, before returning to Belfast and the Thomson-owned Telegraph, where he became group circulation and marketing controller (he was "pretty cross" when, two decades later, the Monopolies Commission forced Trinity-Mirror to sell it after the merger). He next joined Trinity in Liverpool, rising to chief executive in 1993.

The acquisition of the Thomson group in 1995 moved Trinity into the big league. Graf recalls: "It was clear company policy that we would go beyond regional newspapers, but where we would go was a question we constantly worked at. [Then] It became clear the Mirror was a possibility." In what, to some City observers, seemed an audacious move - MGN was much the bigger of the two companies - Trinity edged out Regional Independent Media and captured Mirror Group for £1.24bn.

Among the early casualties of the Trinity regime was L!ve TV. But, typically, Graf refuses to be horrid about Janet, Kelvin and topless darts. "As a brand it had become damaged beyond repair, but I wouldn't criticise people for having a go at doing what they tried to do. It was unfortunate the way it turned out."

Since the 1999 deal, he says, "From a financial perspective, we've delivered the numbers we said we would deliver. In terms of taking the business forward, we are looking to step up our pace. Trinity Mirror is the leading regional publisher, which is very nice. Now we want to continue to develop our existing newspapers, but also look at how we can move the business by acquisition." (And by recently acquiring the Southnews papers for £284.6m, Trinity Mirror boosted the titles under Graf's control to 260).

Was Trinity not tempted to enter the bidding for the Express, especially as the Daily Star and Sunday People would have made comfy bedfellows? "No. We felt that to make a success of it in its particular competitive environment is always going to take a lot of money and effort." Does this mean Richard Desmond may have bitten off more than he possibly can chew? "I am sure he has thought about that very carefully," says Graf, very carefully. "He has certainly taken on a very formidable competitor in the DMGT [Daily Mail and General Trust]. They haven't messed about, have they?"

Desmond has talked of launching a Sunday version of the Daily Star. David Sullivan, proprietor of the Sport, has made similar noises about a new Sunday tabloid. The last thing Trinity Mirror needs, I suggested, were further challengers in a fiercely competitive national Sunday market, where the Sunday People and, to a lesser extent, the Sunday Mirror, trail further and further behind in the wake of the News of the World.

"If and when that situation arises we shall have to react appropriately," says Graf. "The Sunday market is tough and I am not going to sit here and pretend I've got a solution for it. Social changes have transformed the British Sunday and made life tougher for, in particular, the Sunday red-tops. I think the Sunday Mirror has done well for us over the last couple of years. The Sunday People is a tougher challenge. Its rate of decline has slowed, but we've got to keep working at it."

At the time of the first of my two long interviews with Graf, the ABC circulation figures for all three titles were disappointing and there was an even gloomier report from the National Readership Survey, showing a sharp drop for the Mirror and only a minor one for The Sun. "It's the fundamental ABC performance of the paper over a certain amount of time that concerns me," he said, "and I am very happy with what the Mirror has done in that respect." (The latest figures make unhappy reading for him, though: in February it was showing a 3.25% year-on-year decline).

Nevertheless, 16 months down the road, the CEO is not dissatisfied. It has, however, been a bumpy journey, with Morgan coming perilously close to tumbling down a pothole and both Daily Record editor Martin Clarke ("I'm afraid I'm unwilling to discuss the departure of Martin Clarke") and Trinity Mirror's managing director of national titles Roger Eastoe falling by the wayside somewhat abruptly. He is, he agrees, more likely to wake in the middle of the night thinking of the Trinity Mirror share price than the Piers Morgan shares affair - "Although I think about the share price as a reflection of the long-term health, future and prospects of the company, not today's share price compared to yesterday's."

His ambitions for the company include the growth of its internet operations, although he cautions: "I don't believe any of us involved believe all the hype [about the web], much of which is clearly unsustainable. We see the internet as helping us protect and develop our existing franchises and as another way of supplying information to people and services to commercial customers. Whether it is a way of making money is certainly less clear than 12 months ago. It won't replace the profit stream from newspapers, absolutely not, but it is a way of exploiting our strengths. There is a lot of merit in working with television and radio companies to deliver the content of our papers, for example, and to work [with them] on internet projects."

There are those who will consider Graf's faith in his journalists' essential decency the height of naivety, but he is nothing but realistic about the future of the national press in an increasingly difficult market. "If you ask me whether in 10 years' time there will be the same number of titles, I [would say] I would be surprised. In their present form, I think it will be difficult for them all to survive. But, then, I don't think there will be the same number of companies in the TV industry. Or in the radio industry. Life will change." But will Trinity Mirror still be publishing the same number of national titles? "I see no reason why we won't be."

 Bill Hagerty is a former deputy editor of the Daily Mirror and, subsequently, editor of the People. He is now a freelance writer and broadcaster. fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.trailText: The chatterati argue in their columns the election should be put back only if the national mood dictates it. And who dictates the national mood? Those same columnists, writes John Kampfner.
fields.body:
To postpone, or not to postpone? Last week's events were a classic case of political shadow boxing. As the foot and mouth crisis worsened, the political correspondents weighed in. The calls grew to cancel May 3. It was, in the view of Downing Street, a circular argument, in which they found themselves on the outside. The chatterati argued in their columns that the election should be put back only if the national mood dictated it. And who dictates the national mood? Those same columnists.

Some around the government saw the new bout of election-timing fever as politically motivated - friendly editors helping the Tories in their time of need. But columnists such as Don MacIntyre in the Independent and the Guardian's Hugo Young are hardly paid-up members of the William Hague fan club. Bizarrely, the Sun was the most vehement in taking the contrary view, that the election should take place as soon as possible. This led No 10 and Millbank Tower to see a different conspiracy - old-fashioned trouble-making by hacks.

The journalists couldn't lose. If the election were postponed, the next few months would be great fun, with a government buffeted by external events such as foot and mouth and stock-market jitters. If it went ahead, it would be much more unpredictable than had seemed the case a month ago.

Convinced that the issue of postponement had been "got up" by the hacks, the government spin machine swung into action. They had put out a "business as usual" message every day, but speculation was continuing. Monday was quiet; by Tuesday the noises were getting louder; by Wednesday, they decided to act. During the swotting for PM's questions that morning, a stronger line on May 3 was agreed. They didn't think Hague would ask the question - that would expose him. But, after being forced to talk about "crisis", Tony Blair would be asked by a Tory backbencher what his responsibilities were to the electorate. When no one stood up on the subject, it was left to Alastair Campbell to brief the lobby. This had mixed results. By Friday, the Independent and the FT's Philip Stephens were urging ministers to go ahead as planned; the Guardian was more circumspect.

The government calculation is that, if it can ride out the next week or so, it should be safe to call a poll. After all, few stories last for more than a week, and this one has lasted longer than others. The broadsheets continue to devote an average of two inside pages to it. Even so, news editors have already tried hard to lead with a different story on TV and radio bulletins, or on the front page. So, once the election campaign begins, foot and mouth will be pushed downpage.

In any case, do the media really want the election postponed? Meticulous election plans would have to be put on hold or redrawn. Hacks preparing to forego Easter and May Day holidays in deference to May 3 were planning to disappear for Whitsun and for the summer. Correspondents recalled from foreign climes to reinforce coverage would find themselves at a loose end for weeks, or possibly months.

The prospect for broadcasters is more alarming. Outside broadcast locations and satellite trucks have been booked, interviews with the party leaders had been pencilled in and, worst of all for the BBC, its Westminster newsroom is due for a computer overhaul in the summer. Those logistics meetings have been more frantic than ever.

webTitle: BT says it has to cash in on Comic Relief

fields.headline: BT says it has to cash in on Comic Relief
fields.trailText: BT has admitted it was making a fortune by taking a cut from the Comic Relief telephone lines, but the company claimed that regulations meant it could not provide the service for free - even for charity.
fields.body:
BT has admitted it was making a fortune by taking a cut from the Comic Relief telephone lines, but the company claimed that regulations meant it could not provide the service for free - even for charity.

The BBC, which broadcast Friday's eight-hour comedy marathon, was inundated with calls from outraged viewers demanding to know why the phone company was taking such a large slice of the revenue from premium rate calls.

The television and radio spectacular included a number of premium rate phone-ins to raise money for Comic Relief, from the phenomenally successful Celebrity Big Brother eviction telephone lines to Radio 4's The Funniest Thing I Ever Heard poll. Every vote to evict a celebrity from the Big Brother compound cost 25p - of that money 15.5p went directly to Comic Relief, with the other 9.5p going to BT and the tax man.

It is estimated that the Big Brother project will have generated around £720,000, of which £280,000 will go to BT before VAT is deducted.

An astonishing 742,885 calls were made the night Chris Eubank was evicted, raising £115,147 for Comic Relief and £70,574 for BT. The eviction of Vanessa Feltz raised £108,857 for the charity and £66,719 for BT while Anthea Turner's goodbye contributed £112,651 to the charity and £69,044 to BT.

A similar number of calls were expected for last night's final vote which decided who won out of comedian Jack Dee, Keith Duffy from the band Boyzone and Claire Sweeney from Brookside.

A spokeswoman for BT said that under the terms of the company's licence with Oftel, the telephone regulator, they have to charge a minimum amount for every call.

"We are just not allowed to give anything away free at all," she said. "I suspect the amount we are charging comic relief is the minimum."

An Oftel spokeswoman said that because of BT's monopoly it must treat all users the same and exceptions could not be made for good causes.

In a statement Comic Relief defended BT, saying the company had a duty to all its customers to continue to carry normal traffic without disruption. "Comic Relief recognises the disruption that such an appeal can have on the network and that significant resource and expense is incurred by BT."

According to the charity, this year BT has donated £65,000 directly to Comic Relief as well as making other donations in kind and helping employees to give their time in taking calls on the day. The statement added that the company had bought 36,000 vehicle red noses - at a cost of £25,000 - proceeds of which go directly to the charity.

fields.headline: Hard sell in your hand
fields.standfirst: If you have a mobile phone - beware, you are about to become a target in a huge personalised advertising push.  Julia Day  on the junk mail from which there is no escape
fields.trailText: If you have a mobile phone - beware, you are about to become a target in a huge personalised advertising push. Julia Day on the junk mail from which there is no escape
fields.body:
It's a disturbing thought: the cute, designer-clad constant companion that spends hours of every day clamped to your hand suddenly turns out to be a KitKat salesman.

Welcome to the dawning of a new advertising era, where mobile phone marketing is about to make the "brand-in-the-hand" dreams of marketers the world over come true.

Nestlé is launching KitKat-sponsored games on mobiles. McDonald's, American Express, lastminute.com and even the Labour party have all started to target consumers through mobiles.

Mobiles offer marketers the ultimate direct, personalised, time- and location-sensitive method of advertising. But this method of marketing also carries the risk of brands becoming unwelcome intruders in people's lives and presents a dilemma over direct and unmonitored advertising to children.

Any consumer backlash could damage the advertiser and ricochet on to the mobile network operator. And if consumers are unhappy about the content of branded text messages, or don't want to receive ads, who do they complain to? The medium does not fall under the remit of any established regulator.

But the bandwagon is rolling. Mobile phone network operators - anxious to recoup the £22bn spent on 3G network licences - handset manufacturers, internet service providers, website owners, the ad industry, the nascent mobile marketing industry and advertisers all have a vested interest in making mobile marketing work.

The European m-commerce market is set to soar in value from £201m in 1998 to £14.3bn by 2003, with advertising accounting for almost a quarter of that revenue, according to internet investor Durlacher. Even conservative ad revenue forecasts are not to be scoffed at. Forrester Research estimates Europe's mobile ad market will be worth £1.8bn by 2005.

A new advertising model is needed to establish how to create, evaluate and charge for wireless campaigns, alongside discovering what consumers are willing to accept and pay for.

The opportunity to send personalised messages direct to consumers - ones they are almost guaranteed to look at - could not have come at a better time for brand owners.

In a fragmenting media marketplace companies are desperately seeking new ways of getting their message across, particularly to the youth market, the most avid users of text messaging.

Companies, including Coca-Cola, are pulling back from TV advertising and ploughing resources in to marketing which "adds value" to consumers' lives: music, sport and entertainment sponsorships, viral marketing and initiatives which allow the consumer to interact with the brand.

A recent two-month trial by US mobile marketing network WindWire, involving seven wireless websites, 14 advertisers and six ad agencies with 22 campaigns and 105 ads, gives a taste of the allure of wireless for advertisers.

The campaigns inspired click-through and call-through rates up to 15%, a 46% ad recall rate and a 24%-86% likelihood to purchase after seeing the ads. It also showed 86% of consumers want free or ad-subsidised content and that 64% are concerned about privacy issues.

The figures are driving commitment from the ad industry. Carat, one of the world's biggest media buying networks, was involved in the WindWire trials.

Doug Flynn, chief executive of Carat's parent company Aegis, says: "Mobile marketing is still embryonic. But it does have applications. Developments such as Vodafone's Vizzavi, which offers one internet portal across all devices, will start to cause a shift of dollars."

Charles Vallance, managing director of Vizzavi's ad agency WCRS, says mobile marketing will be commonplace by the end of this year: "It will be huge as a medium. It is the most personalised medium that has ever existed. But a new media protocol needs to be set up to decide who sells, who are the contractors, who are the regulators."

People are targeted by their personal preferences - such as leisure activities, shopping patterns and location - by segmenting information-rich databases.

Ad agencies, just getting to grips with internet and interactive TV advertising, now have to learn to create concise mobile ad campaigns with only 160 characters to play with. As the mobile technology develops, so will the complexity of campaigns. Dedicated mobile ad creative teams will begin to appear in agencies.

WCRS clients are interested in using mobiles in their campaigns, but are wary: "The main issue is not letting it backfire by inundating people with messages. Do you get people to say yes to messages or do you pump them out regardless?" says Vallance. He is convinced interesting and relevant ads which offer discounts or entertainment value will succeed.

Ex-DJ Peter Powell's multimedia company Worldpop is staking its success on offering entertaining, revenue-generating digital marketing. "This medium is not just about whacking out text messages, it's interactive. Its about getting a response with consumers ringing a phone line or looking at a website," says Geoff Smith, Worldpop joint managing director.

Worldpop is testing sponsored mobile phone pop quiz games, will send ads and special offers with event news to ravers at this year's Ericsson@homelands dance music festival and will run a similar service to Ibiza clubbers in the summer, as it did last year.

It knows the music preferences of its 4.5m-strong database, down to who likes which drum and bass maestro. British Airways, BT, Woolworth's, Durex and Kodak have tapped in to that information so far.

"We're not making any extravagant claims of mobile marketing taking over from TV or print, but increasingly we are producing campaigns linking traditional media with mobiles," says Smith.

One of the main benefits for marketers is that mobile campaigns are measurable, they can be tracked and the cost of customer acquisition can be calculated.

According to mobile marketing company 12snap, text messaging campaigns result in a response rate 15% higher than traditional direct marketing campaigns.

McDonald's is launching a year-long text messaging campaign in a joint venture with 12snap.

The burger chain's German marketing chief Jeffrey T Wahl says: "We want to reach our customers through the most direct means - namely their mobile phones. We are convinced that the mobile will become an inte grated component of the marketing mix in the future."

But targeting young people with ads for burgers or anything else courts controversy. Sweden and Greece already have restraints on advertising to children, and ads that go direct to children's mobiles unmonitored by parents will cause concern.

"There is so much room for abuse," says 12snap managing director Anne de Kerckhove. "We are not comfortable targeting under-16s and payment methods stop under-18s taking part. But we have to discuss what the ethical dilemmas are and how much we can push a direct relationship without parental consent."

A set of self-regulatory rules to govern use, and potential abuse, of marketing by mobile companies have been drawn up by new industry body the Wireless Marketing Association, supported by Orange, BTCellnet and Vodafone. But the WMA's voluntary code of practice is unenforceable, non-members cannot be controlled and there is no external regulatory body.

Steve Wunker, WMA chairman and chief executive of location-based mobile phone company Saverfone, says clients and the ad industry need to be educated: "Marketers always ask if there will be a backlash so we have agreed standards that they can apply."

The text message phenomenon - 929m were sent in the UK during January - has been driven by consumers who realised it was a quick and cheap way of communicating. Now the advertisers and mobile phone companies are set to cash in.

If your letter box is groaning under the weight of junk mail and you email inbox is full of messages from virtual doorstep salesmen, you may well feel inclined to switch off your mobile now.

fields.headline: Forget the quality, feel the cuts
fields.standfirst: If Richard Desmond thinks that all Express readers care about is Posh and Becks' latest exploits, he's wrong, warns  Roy Greenslade, and axing 145 staff will not only ensure the demise of serious reporting, but of the papers themselves
fields.trailText: If Richard Desmond thinks that all Express readers care about is Posh and Becks' latest exploits, he's wrong, warns Roy Greenslade, and axing 145 staff will not only ensure the demise of serious reporting, but of the papers themselves
fields.body:
To use a phrase far too polite for the lips of Richard Desmond, let's cut the crap here. The guy has lost it. Instead of investing in his newspapers, he is divesting them of any hope for the future. His job cuts may save money, but they won't save the Daily and Sunday Express. The only possible result of culling 130 journalists and eliminating 15 library staff will be to hasten the demise of his papers.

Despite having the supposed backing of his editors, they know what I know and what the rest of Fleet Street knows: the three titles are already understaffed and, after the cuts, they will not be able to compete at any level with their rivals.

In order to justify what the Press Gazette properly calls a "bloodbath", Desmond's spinners have also been circulating a totally false tale about staffing on other papers. So let me put the record straight once and for all, to end the mischievous rumours which suggest that the redundancies will somehow bring the Express into line with the Mirror, and won't compare too unfavourably with the Mail.

The Daily Mail has 330 journalists; the Mail on Sunday has 145 and the Evening Standard has 225. A further 100 journalists across the country work for Associated's free title, Metro. The Mirror has 344 journalists; the Sunday Mirror has 99; and the People has 97. That's a total of 540.

To put that in perspective, the Daily Star has 106 journalists, and the Daily and Sunday Express between them have 404, a total across the three titles of 510. After the cuts, that total will come down to 380, which clearly doesn't come close to either the Mail or Mirror papers. My understanding is that the Star, which suffered savage cuts about four years ago under the previous ownership when it had 180 journalists, will not drop below 100.

Assuming, therefore, that few (perhaps five) jobs go at the Star, it follows that 125 will be axed from the two Express titles, giving them a final complement of 279. It will mean a wholesale change of culture, leading to the merging of the sports, pictures, news and subs desks. The Scottish office will be devastated, leaving at best a third of the current staff, and there will be the merest tokenism, if that, in the regions.

No wonder the National Union of Journalists' official, Jeremy Dear, says with masterly understatement: "We don't believe these cuts are necessary or desirable if Mr Desmond is truly interested in restoring his papers to their rightful position."

For the first time in many years, even non-union journalists will agree with that NUJ assessment. One irony of this episode is that Desmond may well bring a largely quiescent union, which has 250 members at Express Newspapers, back to life. Old-style militant talk was being muttered at a chapel meeting on Friday attended by more than 150 people which resolved to organise a ballot for industrial action with just four votes against and 11 abstentions. But this is the beginning of a lengthy process which will not be concluded until July 15. First, there will be a 90-day statutory consultation period, which doesn't get under way until the beginning of next month. Then comes a month-long consultation between management and those who have opted, or been selected, for redundancy.

One fascinating aspect, as always, will be to see who and how many decide to go under the initial voluntary redundancy offer. Express editor Chris Williams - who must surely be downcast, having expected cuts but not of this order - will not allow anyone he thinks crucial to his team to take the money and run. This will prevent the more talented people, who would most easily find jobs elsewhere, from leaving. It also means, inevitably, that in the end management will have to demand mandatory redundancies. At that point, the NUJ will find itself in direct confrontation with Desmond.

Doubtless, there will be many twists and turns as negotiations continue. Whatever the eventual outcome of that industrial trial of strength, it is easier to predict the future for the Expresses. Their sales have been falling for years, and there has been a noticeable acceleration since Desmond took over in November, with the daily title losing 84,000 copies a day in four months. The Sunday Express has lost 76,000 in the same period. Desmond has, let it be said, invested by upping the pagination on all his titles at a time when newsprint costs have risen. He has also spent large sums on television promotion for the Sunday title and the Daily Star, which has added 25,000 sales since November.

Unlike Clive Hollick before him, who cut costs without investing in the product, Desmond has probably spent £15m on the Star alone and several million on the Sunday title with its extra section. That's why the editors and senior journalists have not rebelled in spite of their upset at the need to cut jobs. They might think Desmond inexperienced, and they are less than happy at his nightly editorial interventions, but they do think their new owner is well motivated.

That's fine, of course, as far as it goes. But it doesn't come anywhere near to convincing me that Desmond's strategy of reducing his journalistic staff will work in the end. I think he has learned the wrong lessons from the remarkable effort at the Star, where a tiny staff manages to produce a paper that has stopped the circulation rot despite competing with two giant rivals.

If Desmond is using that as a guide to staffing the Express then it is a mistake. The Daily Star, right from its launch in 1978, has always been a rough-and-ready red-top tabloid, biting away at the northern heels of the Sun, particularly on Merseyside, and picking up a fraction of the old-style Daily Mirror audience.

It is brash, brazen and a bit bloody-minded, but it can never truly hope to be anything other than an annoyance to its competitors, which still have the kind of newspaper credibility (I kid you not!) that the Star cannot match. The Expresses are different. In the new post-Rosie Boycott format, they are lively, shameless, showbusiness packages, well-designed, with bags of pace. But the slight erosion of heavyweight material is putting in jeopardy the papers' claim to being taken seriously. The entertainment-based content may well attract new readers in the short term, but it will alienate much of the traditional audience and, over time, will irritate the newcomers too.

There is nothing to worry about yet. Comparing Friday's Express and Mail, both 96 pages, the Mail carried slightly more serious stories in the first half and certainly gave greater weight to non-celebrity-based news reports. But a swingeing staff cut, regardless of how adept the senior editors might be at covering all the bases, will reduce the Express's chance to deal with serious stories in sufficient depth. If it is also forced to rely on the news agencies for all its stories and background material, then it will be beaten regularly by other papers.

Newsgathering is not about reaction. There is no substitute for having a person out on the road, knocking on the doors, following up tips, digging away. A paper that sacrifices its reporting capability in order to spend more on pictures of a super-model is not worth paying for.

I suspect that Richard Desmond knows nothing of this and cares even less. Journalism for him is accomplished within an office, with a small, badly paid staff scurrying around to illustrate the latest philosophical gem gleaned from Posh and Becks. It may be OK! for him. For journalists, and the Express, it is a wretched fate.
