webTitle: Spurs name their new manager (but it's not Hoddle - yet)

fields.headline: Spurs name their new manager (but it's not Hoddle - yet)
fields.trailText: David Pleat will be confirmed this week as Tottenham's manager until the end of the season while Enic seeks a replacement for George Graham.
fields.body:
David Pleat will be confirmed this week as Tottenham's manager until the end of the season while Enic seeks a replacement for George Graham.

Pleat, who was in the Netherlands yesterday running the rule over possible signings, was asked to take charge of the team until May after leading Spurs to a 3-0 victory at home to Coventry City on Saturday.

The 56-year-old steps up from his post as director of football and his next two matches will be against Arsenal, first in the Premiership at Highbury and then in the FA Cup semi-final at Old Trafford.

The former Luton and Sheffield Wednesday manager, who was in charge of Spurs from 1986-87, will hold further talks with the new owner early this week and will hold the fort while Enic intensifies its search for a long-term successor to Graham, who was sacked on Friday.

The Southampton manager Glenn Hoddle is thought to be the No1 target.

No official approach has been made yet but Hoddle's agent Dennis Roach has said his client "would have to talk" to Spurs if he were offered the chance to return to the club where he started his career and played for more than 10 years.

Face-to-face talks are not expected in the next few days because David Buchler, the Tottenham executive vice-chairman who is in charge of the day-to-day running of the club, is in the US on business and Hoddle is on holiday abroad this week because Southampton do not play for a fortnight.

Hoddle is known to be enjoying life at the Dell and, although the lure of Spurs would be huge, his decision could not be taken for granted. The 43-year-old's willingness to take the job may hinge on finances, the issue that precipitated Graham's dismissal.

With Southampton hopeful of qualifying for the Uefa Cup and due to move to a 32,000-seat stadium next season, he may seek assurances that there is significant money available for signings.

Graham said there was only a "limited budget", though Buchler denies that, saying the eight-figure sum available could not be described as limited. Southampton's Dean Richards and the Paris St-Germain defender Sylvain Distin have been identified as possible signings and an official offer of about £500,000 has been made for Southampton's Moroccan midfielder Hassan Kachloul, whose contract expires at the end of the season.

A clause in Hoddle's contract allows him to leave for about £800,000, and the feeling among some of the players at the Dell is that he will go.

Graham, meanwhile, has enlisted the help of the League Managers' Association in an attempt to have the remaining 15 months of his contract paid out.

Tottenham have promised to defend any legal action. They have suggested that Graham contrived his own dismissal and it emerged last night that he would have had to pay the club about £1.5m, the sum he received as a "golden hello" when he arrived from Leeds in October 1998, had he left of his own volition.

Southampton's Dean Richards and the Paris St-Germain defender Sylvain Distin have been identified as possible signings and an official offer of about £500,000 has been made for Southampton's Moroccan midfielder Hassan Kachloul, whose contract expires at the end of the season. A clause in Hoddle's contract allows him to leave for about £800,000, and the feeling among some of the players at the Dell is that he will go. Graham, meanwhile, has enlisted the help of the League Managers' Association in an attempt to have the remaining 15 months of his contract paid out. Tottenham have promised to defend any legal action. They have suggested that Graham contrived his own dismissal and it emerged last night that he would have had to pay the club about £1.5m, the sum he received as a "golden hello" when he arrived from Leeds in October 1998, had he left of his own volition.

webTitle: Can politics spin its own web in time?

fields.headline: Can politics spin its own web in time?
fields.trailText: Earlier this year a senior Labour MP and election strategist was asked what impact he thought the internet would have on the coming general election. "None," he replied. "And I hope things stay that way."
fields.body:
Earlier this year a senior Labour MP and election strategist was asked what impact he thought the internet would have on the coming general election. "None," he replied. "And I hope things stay that way."

A stark message from a party that, in public, parades its support for the electronic economy. Politicians see the internet as something they can't control and in most cases, can't even use. Every party has its site, but it is a safe bet the leader has never logged on. There are no established tactics for spinning over the net: users have too much power and politicians fear it will corrupt their message.

Yet politicians also know that they cannot ignore the web. Just as every business and every government service is now judged partly on the standard of its website, so parties realise they must use the internet. The question is how. For the election - whenever it comes - will be an important test. Will anything that happens on the internet change the way people vote?

Intangible, fast-changing and heavily-promoted, politics might seem a perfect product for the new economy. Until now, though, e-politics has been led by evangelical obsessives, uncomfortable at the thought that their specialism might be opened up to others. Britain's handful of political websites focus on users who are already experts. There is little which might appeal to the mainstream.

This must change if the net is to matter at the election. Newspapers learned the lesson much earlier, dropping gallery reports from the Commons but letting parliamentary sketchwriters thrive. On television, too, politics can appeal to a big audience. Now it is the web's turn.

The main parties talk bravely of their plans for electronic campaigning in 2001 and disruption in rural Britain might make the internet one of the few practical ways of contacting voters. Yet the portents, from America, are mixed. For all the glossy websites set up ahead of last year's presidential election, the net did not come into its own until after the polls had closed. Only then did it grab the agenda. Live results from the Florida count carried on the web are said to have stayed Al Gore's hand when he prepared to concede defeat early on the morning of November 12.

And although both candidates ran massive web operations during the campaign, research suggests that most people who viewed the sites already knew who they were going to vote for. Gore and George Bush learned the trick of using the net as a massive free advertising space to reassure and encourage core supporters.

There is more to the internet than this. The question is how its strengths can be best applied to politics and whether that can be done in time for the general election. One route, using a basic technology, is already clear - 360,000 email messages are sent every second in Britain. If users follow the pattern set in the US last year, they will include jokes about politicians or requests to help on a campaign, or contribute money, or lobby a cause. Pressure groups will mail out lists of sympathetic candidates, whether cat lovers or anti-abortionists. Labour's weekly email briefing is already a fixture.

So, wise activists will pay attention to their email strategies, and perhaps even the way they use mobile text messages - a technology which fascinates Alastair Campbell. Messaging has replaced pagers as the way spin doctors keep in touch. But for the internet to count in the way that print journalism and television already does, political sensations will have to be played out on the web in their full interactive glory.

This requires sites to cut through the cocoon of spin which protects politicians, offering voters information which other, older, media cannot. With its limitless capacity the web is ideal for storing data - on how MPs voted in parliament, or how much they have earned. Whitehall now has a remarkable internal database, the Knowledge Network. Freedom of information means the public ought to plug in to it too.

T actical voting is one thing the internet might just make work. So-called Nader-trading in America did not prevent George Bush winning, but a similar effort here could oust Michael Howard from his seat of Folkestone and Hyde.

And because of its flexibility and immediacy the web can catch and control political sparks - whether the price of petrol, resentment of global capitalism or even the impact of foot and mouth. The likelihood is that this election will be safe, predictable and massively ignored by voters. But there is a chance that some person, event or issue might set things on a different course.

It's too early to say what the issue might be. But if this election is to catch fire, it will be the internet that provides the match. And after that no politician will risk overlooking it again.

 Julian Glover is editor of Guardian Unlimited Politics which launches at the end of March. A Guardian Unlimited event, The Net Election: are you ready?, takes place on March 27 at the LSE. For more information go to: www.theguardian.com/eventsandoffers

fields.headline: Brand Aid
fields.standfirst: Wedgwood
fields.trailText: Wedgwood
fields.body:
What is it?
That frightfully nice blue and white china Mum brings out on a Sunday. The Wedgwood dinner service has been an obligatory entry on every Home Counties wedding list for centuries and Peter Jones still sells them by the truck-load.

So what's the problem?
The five-course dinner party is a thing of the past. Foreigners still love Wedgwood but today's well-heeled young Brits are more likely to wheel out their great-aunt than their Wedgwood.

And what are they doing about it?
Wedgwood is aiming for what's become known as "doing a Burberry". The company has signed fashion designers Vivienne Westwood, John Rocha and Jasper Conran to shake off its stuffy image and reinvent itself as a designer brand.

Anything else?
A new ad campaign shows some sleek and very un-Wedgwood chinaware alongside the line, "Wedgwouldn't? Wedgwood". A website at www.wedgwouldnt.com showcases the new range, which includes designer dog bowls at £65. Apparently they're set to overtake the Burberry dog coat as the dernier cri in canine accessories.

So what's next?
Wedgwood-branded gourmet food, jewellery and linen.

History:
Founded by Josiah Wedgwood in 1759, Wedgwood was the first pottery company to mass- produce chinaware, bringing the matching dinner set to Britain's middle classes for the first time.

What about the competition?
Not too much to trouble them. Arch-rival Royal Doulton is still in the fashion doldrums, so the time may be right.

Isn't Fergie a fan?
Wedgwood chief Tony O'Reilly was so impressed by what Sarah, Duchess of York had done for Weightwatchers in the US that he hired her as Wedgwood spokeswoman in the US. Sales have soared by over a third and Wedgwood's sales and marketing chief Carey Cuddeback describes Fergie as "the perfect brand metaphor - beautiful, classic but resilient".

webTitle: 'When the Sun demands six spreads in a week, I fear for my soul'

fields.headline: 'When the Sun demands six spreads in a week, I fear for my soul'
fields.standfirst: Ian Johnson, press officer for ITV's Popstars, shares his memories of four months at the centre of a TV sensation
fields.trailText: Ian Johnson, press officer for ITV's Popstars, shares his memories of four months at the centre of a TV sensation
fields.body:
Friday December 1

Cold Feet series three is almost at an end, Christmas is coming and I'm looking forward to my first holiday in six months. Stumbling into the regular Granada publicity meeting expecting the usual perfunctory round-up of Barrymore specials, Audience Withs and Richard and Judy crises, I sit down to buff my nails. But I am wrenched from my end-of-year torpor by a new programme on the agenda - and amazingly, it's up for grabs. A long-repressed desire to be Phil Oakey's love-child resurfaces as the head of press describes this new series as the bastard offspring of Big Brother and The Monkees. Before you can say Hit Me Baby One More Time, Popstars is mine.

Monday December 4

LWT's entertainment chief, Nigel Lythgoe, has spent the summer searching the country for wannabe pop talent with former Spice Girls PR Nicki Chapman and Polydor A&R director Paul Adam. The results of their search is known only to a few production staff and the aspirant pop stars' immediate families. In a procedure of which MI5 would be proud, I'm made to sign a confidentiality agreement before I'm even allowed to see photos of the chosen five. All we have to do now is keep them under wraps for a couple of months until they are revealed midway through the series. A hard task, but one that LWT's stringent security plan should cover.

Not for long. Freelance journalist Paul Scott is on the phone just moments later. He knows the names, ages, home towns, current whereabouts and gym membership details of the band members. It is no longer a case of whether the press will find out who's in the band, but how long before they do.

We need to keep the publicity pot boiling without giving too much away, and with billboards across the country proclaiming "Nigel Pick Me", what better distraction for the press than a 50-something TV executive with a cartoon on-screen identity and a bad haircut. Nasty Nigel is born.

Monday January 15

The show is on air and causing a media sensation, DJs, TV presenters and columnists all have an opinion on Nigel's audition techniques and "Nasty Nigel" is a household name. Nigel achieves a lifetime's ambition when he appears on the cover of Media Guardian, but as the tabloid hysteria increases, I begin to worry about the nature of the pact we have signed. The extent of Nigel's celebrity status becomes apparent when Top of the Pops magazine demands that he reviews the month's singles.

Tuesday January 16

The world is going completely mad. I am woken at 7.30am by Kiss FM which gives me 10 seconds' notice before putting me live on air. Either I take them to meet the band or they reveal the band's address. My offer to sleep with DJ Bam Bam as an alternative gets a lukewarm response.

Wednesday January 17

Such is the show's zeitgeist appeal that even the losers are cover stories. Heat magazine wants Big Claire from Glasgow and Darius "the pain in the Arias". (Copyright, Daily Star.) But there's a problem: Claire's bosses at Kwik-Fit won't allow her to take an extended lunchbreak - her moment of fame is slipping through my fingers. We even offer to pay Kwik-Fit for lost income, but they don't bite. But a last-ditch compromise is agreed and we do the shoot in her works canteen as her colleagues look on. Fame costs and here's where you start paying.

Friday January 19

Amid the publicity whirlwind, a crisis emerges. It's increasingly clear that we have a leak in the camp. Someone is spilling the beans - too many tabloids seem to know intimate details of where the band are living, where they are from and who they've slept with. Most alarmingly, they know about the Kym Situation [that she has two children]. A steady stream of "exclusive" stories are offered to keep the five's names out of the papers until the band is revealed onscreen. The tabloids agree readily: a revealed band does not sell papers, a real-life soap opera does.

Saturday January 20

Things appear to be under control and after a hugely successful webcast with Nasty Nigel, we retire to a West End bar for a celebratory drink. But I'm only two sips into a pina colada when the phone goes - the Sunday People is planning to break ranks. My increasingly desperate attempts to persuade the paper's editor to keep the Popstars secret fall on deaf ears. Under a banner headline on page 11, Noel, Danny, Kym, Suzanne and Myleene are revealed to the nation. Arse.

Sunday January 21

The band are gutted. Kym threatens to nut Paul Scott. I sympathise with the response but professional integrity prevents me from endorsing this course of action. Instead, we stick to the line that 10 hopefuls are still under consideration and the final five have not been chosen. It would be an unmitigated disaster if the line-up was to change but it is still a remote possibility, and there are five replacements at the ready in the highly unlikely event that one of the chosen band should walk out.

Monday January 22

A large number of journalists now know the final line-up and are using this as ammunition. My sidekick, Joe Stroud, and I must provide a steady stream of tabloid fodder to keep the hounds at bay. It is a pact with the devil - when the Sun demands six double-page spreads in a week, I fear for my soul. Nigel, Darius, Claire and a host of other wannabes step forward to fill the void.

Tuesday January 23

Meanwhile, Kiss FM are still on my case. They want an interview with the band and are prepared to go to any lengths to get one. Their powers of investigative journalism did not stop with finding out the band line-up. They know my home address, my parents' home address, where I went to university - and have dredged up details of a particularly embarrassing medical complaint from my teens of which my mother is, even now, unaware. Martyr-like I decide that if the world is to find out why I was christened Buster Gonad at college, then it is a price I am prepared to pay. I don't answer the phone before 8am ever again.

Thursday January 25

Taking a break from the maelstrom, Nigel decides to hobnob with the glitterati at the South Bank Show awards. Amongst the great and good of the artistic community, the man who brought Ice Warriors to ITV is mobbed by journalists asking how he is coping with his new-found fame. While Nigel is besieged, Dame Antoinette Sibley looks on bemused.

Friday January 26

Things are getting out of hand when a meeting with ITV network bosses is interrupted by Sunday Mirror hacks, who have brought the woman who beat Nigel in a childhood tap-dancing contest 40 years ago down from Liverpool to London for a Tearful Reunion. That'll teach him to tell family anecdotes to Media Guardian.

Saturday March 3

The show is going stellar and the Popstars also-rans want a slice of the action. Joe, who has taken on the roles of bag-carrier and nursemaid as well as Popstars' publicity assistant, gets them on to the guest list at the newest celeb hang-out, Red Cube. Life enters the twilight zone when Jordan and her celebrity breasts contact the office and demand to be fixed up with Darius. Dane Bowers, her erstwhile beau, has been critical of Mr Danesh in the press, and she can smell the heady perfume of revenge mixed with tabloid headlines. Popstars failures now rank above D-list footballers and Big Brother contestants.

Monday March 5

Finally, we have made it to the point in the show when the five are officially revealed and it's time to show them off at a press conference at Heathrow. They sing, they charm, they head off to shoot their first five magazine covers and I breathe a sigh of relief.

Monday March 19

For the first time in weeks, the LWT phone lines are not in a state of meltdown. Polydor has taken on the lion's share of the band's publicity in the lead-up to the release of the debut single, and I move on to my next project, a politically sensitive film of the events of Bloody Sunday. I cancel my subscription to Smash Hits and pick up a copy of Don Mullan's definitive account of the events of 30 years ago, Eyewitness Bloody Sunday. That weekend I attend the first day of filming in Derry in which Granada Film will recreate the civil rights march that led to the tragedy.

Painfully aware of the political sensitivities of the project, I keep my English head down as 6,000 Derry residents turn out to take part in the film. Suddenly a group of teenage extras rush over to ask a question. Worried that I might reveal flaws in my knowledge of the civil rights movement, I steel myself for an interrogation. "You're that bloke off Popstars, aren't you - what's Myleene really like?"

You couldn't make it up.

 Ian Johnson is a press officer for LWT. He takes up the post of head of publicity for drama and entertainment at the BBC next month.

webTitle: HIV man jailed for knowingly infecting lover

fields.headline: HIV man jailed for knowingly infecting lover
fields.trailText: A man found guilty of infecting his girlfriend with the HIV virus was jailed for five years yesterday in a case that has made British legal history and caused an outcry by HIV and human rights campaigners.
fields.body:
A man found guilty of infecting his girlfriend with the HIV virus was jailed for five years yesterday in a case that has made British legal history and caused an outcry by HIV and human rights campaigners.

Stephen Kelly, 33, of Provanmill in Glasgow, was found guilty last month of endangering Anne Craig, a mother of three, by repeatedly having sex with her despite knowing he carried the virus. At the high court in Edinburgh yesterday he was jailed for five years for culpable and reckless conduct.

It is the first time in the UK that anyone has been convicted of deliberately infecting another person with the virus, and the sentence has been condemned by campaigners who say it will only criminalise the disease and further stigmatise and alienate sufferers.

There are also concerns that police investigating the case were able to seize evidence of blood samples from a confidential clinical trial to use in the prosecution.

fields.headline: Reckless limits
fields.trailText: Aids charities are not helping their cause in attacking the prosecution - and sentencing - of Stephen Kelly, the first case in Britain of a person being convicted of knowingly infecting a lover with HIV.
fields.body:
Aids charities are not helping their cause in attacking the prosecution - and sentencing - of Stephen Kelly, the first case in Britain of a person being convicted of knowingly infecting a lover with HIV. Although their opposition is not prompted by a wish to condone Mr Kelly's behaviour - it springs from a hope of ending the stigma attached to the disease - the charities have come close to condoning his irresponsible act.

Stephen Kelly, who was informed while in prison in 1992 that he was HIV positive, began an affair with Anne Craig, a mother of three young children, in 1994 without telling her about his condition. Asked by Ms Craig whether there was any reason why they should not have unprotected sex, other than the risk of pregnancy, he said there was not. He had been advised in prison about the importance of safe sex, but had unprotected sex with Ms Craig for four months until, after the first signs of her infection developed, owning up. He was sentenced to five years in prison in Glasgow last Friday for culpable and reckless conduct.

The Terence Higgins Trust Lighthouse, the country's largest HIV/Aids organisation, said it "did not believe that criminalising the virus is going to make things any better". But the case does not criminalise the virus. What it does is criminalise reckless sexual behaviour by people who knowingly have the virus. The trust's second ground for opposing the prosecution is equally illogical: the wish for people to be more open about their condition. Certainly there are better ways than deterrence, but the case does show people thinking about being reckless that they face sanctions if they do. Ms Craig, who is now confined to a wheelchair, provided the most pertinent comment: "If the verdict saves one life from the misery I have been through then it will all have been worthwhile."

Where critics are right in criticising the case is in its breach of the confidentiality code governing research studies. Kelly had agreed while in prison to give a sample to a confidential clinical trial into HIV outbreaks. He was assured that the findings would be held in strictest confidence, but the sample was later used as evidence in the trial. Scientists are right to be concerned by the blatant breach of the confidentiality guarantee and the medical research council is being too complacent in rejecting their criticisms. Undermining confidentiality guarantees strikes at the heart of serious research.

webTitle: Transplant patient in coma after overdose blunder

fields.headline: Transplant patient in coma after overdose blunder
fields.trailText: A former nurse was in a coma yesterday after being given an insulin overdose following a liver transplant operation.
fields.body:
A former nurse was in a coma yesterday after being given an insulin overdose following a liver transplant operation.

Teresita Cruz, 56, was recovering after surgery at the Queen Elizabeth hospital in Birmingham when the accident happened.

Family members said an insulin pump regulating her blood sugar level was not monitored for eight hours. They added that the overdose would leave Ms Cruz, who lives in Leicester, brain damaged if she emerged from her coma.

Yesterday the hospital issued a "full and unreserved apology" to her family and said an investigation was in progress.

The incident follows other hospital blunders this year. In February a senior consultant at the Royal Sussex county hospital in Brighton was suspended after injecting a local anaesthetic into a vein of a patient rather than his spine. That mistake came a week after the death of Wayne Jowett, aged 18, who had an anti-cancer drug accidentally injected into his spine instead of a vein at the Queen's Medical Centre in Nottingham. Two junior doctors were suspended.

Speaking from the hospital, Ms Cruz's sister Lota Hopewell described the accident as "awful, just awful".

"It is killing me to see her this way," she said. "It is killing all of us. Just a few days ago she looked well, she was getting better from her operation and looking forward to a new life. She gave 30 years of her life to the NHS as a nurse and this is how she is repaid.

"I don't know what will happen. The doctors are saying she might die, but I can't give up on her. I will keep fighting for her."

Mrs Hopewell's husband Derrol said the family could not understand how the overdose was given while Ms Cruz was in intensive care. "We just can't believe what has happened," he said. "Teresita was looking forward to a new life after the transplant.

"She had the operation and was recovering well. She had regained consciousness and was getting better all the time. Now they don't know if she will wake up, or if she does, how bad the damage will be."

Mr Hopewell said he was first aware there had been complications when he received a phone call from a relative. "My brother-in-law Rico had been called into the office by the consultant.

"They said the insulin pump had not been monitored for eight hours and she had received an overdose. At the moment they are saying a large part of her brain is dead, but we don't know what the outcome will be."

He said no one could understand how the overdose could have been given to a patient on an intensive care ward. "The whole system was a failure."

A spokeswoman for the hospital said: "We have offered a full and unreserved apology to Teresita and her family for what has happened. We have got an investigation ongoing and the results of that will be out some time next week.

"Teresita was on insulin, and it looks as if she received more than she should have done. We don't know at the moment whether that was due to human error or machine error.

"We are talking to the family about the best way forward for her."

webTitle: Ian Linkins to step down as chief of Future Network

fields.headline: Future's finance chief goes
fields.trailText: Future Network is expected to announce its finance director, Ian Linkins, is stepping down as part of a management shake-up, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
Future Network, the troubled publishing group, is expected to announce today that its finance director, Ian Linkins, is stepping down as part of a management shake up to appease the company's shareholders.

The business, which has suffered a sharp fall in value following a succession of profit warnings, will also announce measures to beef up its board with the appointment of a deputy chairman to take some responsibilities from founder and chairman Chris Anderson.

Former Emap executive Colin Morrison will be appointed as chief operating officer giving him control of much of the day-to-day running of the business.

Mr Linkins will stay with the company in a reduced role; the search has begun for a full-time replacement. In the interim, his job will be performed by one of the magazine group's other directors.

Investors have been pressing for management change at Future. The company, which makes around 35% of its revenue from computer games magazines, has been battered by delays in the launch of new consoles such as PlayStation 2 as well as the softening advertising market in the US and overstated earnings in its French business.

Insiders said the company had been aware of feelings in the investor community that the business had been over-hyped during the dot.com-fuelled mania. Shares in Future peaked at 973p in March last year but are now worth just 97.5p.

The company last month began a process of rehabilitation when it embarked on a cost-cutting exercise involving the loss of 350 jobs and the closure of 20 magazine titles.

Future is also expected to update shareholders today on the progress of the sale of Business 2.0, its magazine for the e-economy.

Investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter was last month mandated to assess the alternatives for Business 2.0 and there is understood to have been no shortage of companies willing to take the title off Future's hands. Time, Condé Nast, Ziff Davis Media and Gruner & Jahr have all been named as potential bidders.

The magazine is understood to have made revenues of £40m in 2000 in the US, although advertising volume is likely to be far lower this year.

Future had been hoping to use the US edition as the platform for launching the magazine in other markets including the UK where it first appeared in May last year. But the company has conceded that it does not have the necessary infrastructure to support the title and that it would likely be more prosperous in a larger company. Of the jobs being cut, around 90 are in Britain, where six magazines are to close. The group employs 2,000 people in Britain, the United States, Germany and France.

Future announced in October that it had discovered £4.2m black hole in the accounts of its French subsidiary. The accounting irregularity dated back to 1998 and had been caused by inaccurate recording of sales.

Probably the most damaging problem has not been of Future's making - the protracted downturn in the computer games market. With PlayStation2 now in the shops and the upcoming launch of Microsoft's X-box, the company is hoping the market will begin to look more positive.

webTitle: Holiday camp plays host to asylum seekers

fields.headline: Holiday camp plays host to asylum seekers
fields.standfirst: A private beach, 300 acres of countryside and a warm welcome for hundreds of refugees seeking a safe haven in Ireland.
fields.trailText: A private beach, 300 acres of countryside and a warm welcome for hundreds of refugees seeking a safe haven in Ireland. Rosie Cowan reports
fields.body:
The Saturday night karaoke was fun, there is a magic show this evening, and the staff are trying to round up volunteers for the choir. In the restaurant, the children cannot wait to get down from their chairs and race about outside.

Thirty miles north of Dublin, set in 300 acres of lush Co Meath countryside with a private beach, Mosney holiday camp has given a warm welcome to hundreds of thousands of Irish families since 1948. But none of the 300 residents on this bracing day is Irish, nor has any a home to go back to.

There are 26 nationalities, in this limbo of brightly coloured chalets and dance halls, more used to glamorous granny and lovely legs contests than the competition to see who will win the right to stay in the Republic of Ireland.

An average of 1,000 asylum seekers from more than 140 countries enter each month, pushing Ireland to near top of the European Union refugee league. The combined outlay of the departments of justice, welfare, health and education on the crisis topped IR£100m last year.

"There are far more direct flights from Africa to Dublin than there were. And there are no controls between Great Britain and here, so if you come into Dover or wherever, you can simply carry on to Ireland," said Colette Morey, from the justice department. Permanent residency is granted to less than 18%, who have to prove persecution in their country of origin; the process can take more than a year. In the meantime, the government is housing 3,500 people in 75 locations; Mosney, which will eventually take 500, is the biggest.

"Up until 1999, most stayed in central Dublin," said Ms Morey. "Christmas 1998, there were children sleeping rough on the streets. The dispersal programme, which started in November 1999, has been a big change for rural Ireland, and a massive learning curve for us."

There have been racist incidents, but Ms Morey said that most communities came to accept the newcomers. "The foreigners also tended to try and get back to the city, even though they'd be leaving for nothing short of hovels." The asylum seekers cannot work unless they are granted refugee status.

The booming economy means there is no shortage of jobs, although many well-educated incomers do menial tasks. But Ms Morey said the real problem was housing. "There is a big shortfall, even for our own population," she said. "We are coping but if the numbers go up, it's hard to know where we could find roofs to put over their heads." As the traditional seaside holiday fights for survival against overseas packages, Mosney, which in its 1950s and 1960s heydays had more than 50,000 visitors and 160,000 day trippers in a 14-week season, seems a good way to cope. The land could have raised tens of millions on the property development market, but managing director Phelim McCloskey is glad his five-year deal with the government gives job security to the 60 staff.

Heating has been installed in the chalets, there is a regular train service to Dublin and free buses to nearby Drogheda, and satellite dishes and internet services so the residents watch their home stations and email relatives.

There is a rulebook, no drugs, no soliciting, no begging, and residents must sign a daily register. But Mr McCloskey said some restrictions were necessary in any community, and by and large, the visitors were free to come and go. "It's not a prison," hesaid. "People go shopping and the children go to school in nearby towns, which has helped ease local worries." While quite a number of residents are graduates with excellent English, Mr McCloskey said English classes had helped bring people together.

Many families have sad and extraordinary stories about how they came to be there, and their futures are far from certain. Mariam and Bayo Adinyi, engineers from Nigeria, have been at Mosney two weeks, with their daughters, Nana, eight, and 18-month-old Wuraola. Bayo's tribe wanted to elect him religious chief but they practised human sacrifice, and the family, who are Christian, ran away in terror.

Mariam, who had to leave her 10-year-old daughter with her elderly mother, met an Irish missionary who helped her get out. In the panic, she got separated from Bayo, but the couple were reunited by chance in Dublin. "Our lives were at risk and we had to flee," she said. "But I miss my daughter so much. I never left her before and I'm so worried about her.

"I don't mind living with other people, it broadens your views and makes you realise you're not the only one with problems - but it is boring here. We just eat, sleep and watch TV. In Nigeria, we had our own house and good jobs in the city. We'd just like to get work and send our children to school."

Elana, 24, a Romanian, gave birth to seven-week-old Kevin at Mosney. In Romania she had been halfway through a degree but gave up due to lack of money; her husband, Nicolae, could not get a job because he lacked correct papers.

She was already pregnant when she found out that a baby born in Ireland would get Irish citizenship, and the couple found a lorry driver willing to take them. "I was eight months pregnant and so anxious to get here in time," she said. "It was a very long, uncomfortable journey. He left us off outside Dublin. We just had a change of clothes and a few pounds but we would have been penniless at home. This is my mother's first grandchild and I cried every time I spoke to her on the phone."

The couple have been allocated a house in Waterford, so their child will be brought up in the country where he was born.

"I am a little bit scared about starting somewhere new, but thank God we are here and we will be able to make a life for ourselves," she said.

I never left her before and I'm so worried about her. "I don't mind living with other people, it broadens your views and makes you realise you're not the only one with problems - but it is boring here. We just eat, sleep and watch TV. In Nigeria, we had our own house and good jobs in the city. We'd just like to get work and send our children to school." Elana, 24, a Romanian, gave birth to seven-week-old Kevin at Mosney. In Romania she had been halfway through a degree but gave up due to lack of money; her husband, Nicolae, could not get a job because he lacked correct papers. She was already pregnant when she found out that a baby born in Ireland would get Irish citizenship, and the couple found a lorry driver willing to take them. "I was eight months pregnant and so anxious to get here in time," she said. "It was a very long, uncomfortable journey. He left us off outside Dublin. We just had a change of clothes and a few pounds but we would have been penniless at home. This is my mother's first grandchild and I cried every time I spoke to her on the phone." The couple have been allocated a house in Waterford, so their child will be brought up in the country where he was born. "I am a little bit scared about starting somewhere new, but thank God we are here and we will be able to make a life for ourselves," she said.

fields.headline: Vodafone promises end to junk mail
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Vodafone is developing new technology it claims will put an end to unwanted junk mail, writes Julia Day.

Mar 15: Vodafone gets wrong number

Mar 1: Vodafone sponsors F1 team

Feb 28: WCRS to raise profile of Vizzavi
fields.body:
Vodafone is developing global customer database technology it claims will put an end to unwanted junk mail.

As part of a global rebranding exercise, the telecoms giant is working on a technology capable of analysing data on all its customers across the 30 different Vodafone-owned networks worldwide.

The initiative means Vodafone will be able to target customers according to their personal preferences. It will also lead to cost-savings for the group.

"The software platform will analyse data in a uniform way across the group," said Jon Earl, investor relations manager at Vodafone.

"Customer data is our raw material, particularly with data services on the horizon. It will give a much higher level of personalisation and will mean our marketing won't spam customers with junk mail."

The group's chief executive Chris Gent has stated his intention to make Vodafone one of the most valuable global brands by 2004.

The telecoms giant, still digesting its takeovers of Airtouch and Mannesman, has a stake in 30 mobile networks around the world.

fields.headline: New York correspondent quits Sunday Times
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Sunday Times' New York correspondent Tom Rhodes is leaving the paper, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Tom Rhodes, the Sunday Times's New York correspondent, is leaving the paper.

He will be replaced by Sarah Baxter, the editor of the paper's News Review, who joins the New York office of the Sunday Times on July 1. He will leave the paper in June.

Mr Rhodes could not be reached for comment but is believed to be quitting journalism for a career in business.

He has worked for the Sunday Times since 1998, when he joined from the Times where he was Washington correspondent.

Ms Baxter has edited the News Review section for four years. Before that she was the senior assistant editor at the Observer, following a stint as political editor at the New Statesman.

Ms Baxter's successor has not been appointed. Insiders say her deputy, Tiffanie Darke, has not been in the job for long enough for her to be considered as a replacement for the position.

fields.headline: Debut single sets a record
fields.trailText: Hear'Say, the band created by the Popstars TV series, soared to the top of the charts last night, writes Thomas Penny.
fields.body:
Hear'Say, the band created by the Popstars TV series, soared to the top of the charts last night with the best selling debut single of all time.

Pure & Simple sold 549,823 copies in its first week, beating the previous best for a debut artist - Britney Spears's Baby, One More Time' - by 85,000.

The band only lost out on the accolade of fastest selling single of all time to Elton John's Candle in the Wind for Princess Diana's funeral and the Band Aid charity record Do They Know It's Christmas?.

The band, created after thousands of hopefuls were auditioned on television, heard the news in the final programme of the series, broadcast live from the north London house shared by members Noel Sullivan, 20, Myleene Klass, 22, Kym Marsh, 24, Danny Foster, 21 and Suzanne Shaw, 19.

"It's absolutely amazing, we can't believe it," Sullivan said. "We want to thank everyone who bought it, all the people who supported us through Popstars and the judges for making the right decision."

The were continuing their relentless promotional schedule straight after the announcement with a web chat before they were able to return and enjoy the night with their families.

Klass warned other bands to watch out for the newly created force in pop music. "The lid has been lifted on the music business," she said. "It gives everyone hope that they can be part of it - we were unknowns six months ago.

"And everyone who doesn't deserve to be part of it: We're coming to get you!"

Judge "Nasty" Nigel Lythgoe was not at the celebration as he was filming in Borneo, but Popstars judges Nicki Chapman and Paul Adam turned up to give moral support.

An ITV spokesman said they were delighted that the single was the best-selling debut single ever.

"We're over the moon. The judges definitely picked the right band."

The five-piece band's single was well ahead of Westlife's Comic Relief offering Uptown Girl, which fell to number two.

Bookmakers have already offered odds of 6-1 that Hear'Say will have this year's Christmas number one.

fields.headline: C4 faces £500,000 bill for Tour de France
fields.trailText: 8.30amChannel 4 is facing a £500,000 bill after cancelling its coverage of the Tour de France, writes Jason Deans
fields.body:
Channel 4 is facing a bill of £500,000 after cancelling its coverage of the Tour de France to concentrate on cricket.

The station decided to axe the cycling race after 15 years because its efforts to show both the Tour and the cricket last summer proved a scheduling nightmare, with overrunning Test cricket coverage on Channel 4 clashing with the Tour de France's traditional early evening slot.

But the European Broadcasting Union, which handles the TV rights to the Tour, is demanding full payment for Channel 4's contract to transmit a daily highlights show from the event.

The UK broadcaster's contract, which has two years to run, is worth about £250,000 a year.

A Channel 4 spokesman justified the decision saying the broadcaster would save money because it would not now have to pay production costs for the cancelled output.

But the decision provoked a furious reaction from British fans. A cycling magazine has launched a campaign to persuade Channel 4 to change its mind, and 2,000 people have responded so far.

The move came in spite of a raft of British cycling medals in the Sydney Olympics and last year's British success in the Tour, where David Millar held the leader's yellow jersey for three days.

Channel 4 had approached the BBC about selling on the rights, but the corporation has said it cannot find room in its schedules at such short notice.

"Around the time of the Tour in July we have things like the US Masters golf and Wimbledon," a BBC Sport spokeswoman said.

fields.headline: Media Monkey's diary
fields.trailText: • A pat on the back to the Telegraph's Stephen Pile for a bit of hoax busting. Today's ITC programme complaints bulletin raps our old friends Carlton for yet again falling into the trap. A Carlton Weekend Live show last summer about soap addiction wheeled out two guests supposedly from a soap clinic. Except, after Pile's alert, Carlton has now admitted they were no such thing. Nor is it good enough relying on a disclaimer form signed by guests for protection. There must be a "respect for truth" in all factual programmes, says the ITC. Will they never learn?
fields.body:
 A pat on the back to the Telegraph's Stephen Pile for a bit of hoax busting. Today's ITC programme complaints bulletin raps our old friends Carlton for yet again falling into the trap. A Carlton Weekend Live show last summer about soap addiction wheeled out two guests supposedly from a soap clinic. Except, after Pile's alert, Carlton has now admitted they were no such thing. Nor is it good enough relying on a disclaimer form signed by guests for protection. There must be a "respect for truth" in all factual programmes, says the ITC. Will they never learn?

 It's a small, small world. The buzz from the secret Survivor! location in Borneo, where ITV's version is being filmed under the eagle eye of Nigel (Popstars) Lythgoe, is that the production team has made one small miscalculation. It is costing far more than expected to ensure that the increasingly media-savvy locals don't leak details to the tabloids. Local currency (Monkey believes it is the rupiah) in an envelope please to Nasty Nigel, Borneo.

 Monkey hopes that Jeremy Mills is paying attention to the Survivor! team's problems. The man behind BBC1's Castaway 2000 says that plans are well advanced for the sequel, with 35,000 volunteers now whittled down to 200, which suggests more helicopters and tantrums kicking off in the early summer. After Taransay, the BBC is understood to feel there will be fewer problems with a hot and sunny location. Better stock up on the rupiahs now.

 As The Archers develops its full-blown foot and mouth storyline, spare a thought for Lorraine Heggessey and her (sole?) returning drama series, Down to Earth. One of the very rare breed of BBC1 autumn Sunday night dramas that attracted enough viewers to be recommissioned, its rural locations have ensured that filming on the second series has had to be suspended.

 Still in the countryside, Nat Mags glossy Country Living launched its "farmer needs a wife campaign" in the March issue, with pics of 30 lonely rural males, some with gun dogs, looking for friendship and more. Readers have until March 31 to write in before a "get to know you" barn dance planned in London for May 17. "We're in constant touch with the men, none have become directly involved in foot and mouth, not all are livestock farmers," says editor Susy Smith. "You could take a view that with rural life becoming absolute hell our service is more needed than ever". Or you could take the view that a barn dance with added disinfectant is not all that conducive to romance.

 Back to Monkey's favourite read, Ariel's letters page, and a post-bomb question from NUJ executive member Trevor Goodchild recalling long negotiations with BBC management over the creation of the great, glass folly that is the White City news centre. "Who, we argued, would locate a glass-fronted high-profile newsroom next to a public highway that any terrorist could target?" Who indeed? Maybe the man who moved all the journalists there only to realise there wasn't enough room for them - Tony Hall.

 Down at the Express's Blackfriars HQ, staff at Dickie Desmond's "empire" are well used to budget cuts by now. The latest cheese-paring innovation introduced at the start of this month is to have beleaguered Express business staff submit their copy for the Daily Star's business page. Patrick Hosking sent a memo around the City desk explaining. "It is not necessary to file the full version of your Express story. Two hundred words is probably the max, and most stories will be shorter. If you have time and it is needed, please try to come up with a suitable Star-ish intro," he told his staff. "I know this is extra responsibility when we are already very heavily loaded."

 Meanwhile, times are also hard at that monument to capitalism, the FT. Following last week's suggestion that Pearson is slashing spending on FT.com by half after a whopping £200m online outlay, budget clampdowns are being felt in other areas. A staff hiring freeze and a cut in the travel budget is under way on the FT newspaper itself, but huge savings will undoubtedly be made by a new measure of having security staff patrol the FT's Southwark Bridge offices on weekends, to turn off lights.

 You can catch up with Monkey every day at www.mediatheguardian.com

fields.headline: Billiton plans £20bn merger with BHP
fields.trailText: Britain's Billiton and BHP, the Australian mining and oil group, are to announce a £20bn merger that would create the world's second largest minerals and metals company, according to reports yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's Billiton and BHP, the Australian mining and oil group, are to announce a £20bn merger that would create the world's second largest minerals and metals company, according to reports yesterday.

The deal would mean the merged group became a leading global player, beaten in size only by Alcoa, the American metals group.

Billiton declined to comment on the report, and BHP spokesman Michael Spencer said: "We don't comment on market speculation."

BHP, with a market capitalisation of £12.9bn, is almost twice the size of Billiton. It is one of the world's biggest coal exporters and iron ore miners and also has oil and gas interests. Billiton, the world's biggest producer of chrome and manganese ores and alloys, also has major interests in aluminium. Its value on Friday was about £6.7bn.

The equity in the new group is likely to be split 60:40 in favour of the Australians.

Billiton began life in South Africa, where it still operates, and also has interests in Australasia and South America.

A combined BHP-Billiton would overtake Billiton's old South African rival, Anglo American. But Anglo, which owns about 7% of Billiton, is viewed as a possible counter-bidder for the company.

The group is likely to be named BHP Billiton but would retain separate listings in Sydney and London to keep some measure of independence.

webTitle: Holiday camp plays host to asylum seekers

fields.headline: Holiday camp plays host to asylum seekers
fields.standfirst:
A private beach, 300 acres of countryside and a warm welcome for hundreds of refugees seeking a safe haven in Ireland

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A private beach, 300 acres of countryside and a warm welcome for hundreds of refugees seeking a safe haven in Ireland.
fields.body:
The Saturday night karaoke was fun, there is a magic show this evening, and the staff are trying to round up volunteers for the choir. In the restaurant, the children cannot wait to get down from their chairs and race about outside.

Thirty miles north of Dublin, set in 300 acres of lush Co Meath countryside with a private beach, Mosney holiday camp has given a warm welcome to hundreds of thousands of Irish families since 1948. But none of the 300 residents on this bracing day is Irish, nor has any a home to go back to.

There are 26 nationalities, in this limbo of brightly coloured chalets and dance halls, more used to glamorous granny and lovely legs contests than the competition to see who will win the right to stay in the Republic of Ireland.

An average of 1,000 asylum seekers from more than 140 countries enter each month, pushing Ireland to near top of the European Union refugee league. The combined outlay of the departments of justice, welfare, health and education on the crisis topped IR£100m last year.

"There are far more direct flights from Africa to Dublin than there were. And there are no controls between Great Britain and here, so if you come into Dover or wherever, you can simply carry on to Ireland," said Colette Morey, from the justice department. Permanent residency is granted to less than 18%, who have to prove persecution in their country of origin; the process can take more than a year. In the meantime, the government is housing 3,500 people in 75 locations; Mosney, which will eventually take 500, is the biggest.

"Up until 1999, most stayed in central Dublin," said Ms Morey. "Christmas 1998, there were children sleeping rough on the streets. The dispersal programme, which started in November 1999, has been a big change for rural Ireland, and a massive learning curve for us."

There have been racist incidents, but Ms Morey said that most communities came to accept the newcomers. "The foreigners also tended to try and get back to the city, even though they'd be leaving for nothing short of hovels." The asylum seekers cannot work unless they are granted refugee status.

The booming economy means there is no shortage of jobs, although many well-educated incomers do menial tasks. But Ms Morey said the real problem was housing. "There is a big shortfall, even for our own population," she said. "We are coping but if the numbers go up, it's hard to know where we could find roofs to put over their heads." As the traditional seaside holiday fights for survival against overseas packages, Mosney, which in its 1950s and 1960s heydays had more than 50,000 visitors and 160,000 day trippers in a 14-week season, seems a good way to cope. The land could have raised tens of millions on the property development market, but managing director Phelim McCloskey is glad his five-year deal with the government gives job security to the 60 staff.

Heating has been installed in the chalets, there is a regular train service to Dublin and free buses to nearby Drogheda, and satellite dishes and internet services so the residents watch their home stations and email relatives.

There is a rulebook, no drugs, no soliciting, no begging, and residents must sign a daily register. But Mr McCloskey said some restrictions were necessary in any community, and by and large, the visitors were free to come and go. "It's not a prison," hesaid. "People go shopping and the children go to school in nearby towns, which has helped ease local worries." While quite a number of residents are graduates with excellent English, Mr McCloskey said English classes had helped bring people together.

Many families have sad and extraordinary stories about how they came to be there, and their futures are far from certain. Mariam and Bayo Adinyi, engineers from Nigeria, have been at Mosney two weeks, with their daughters, Nana, eight, and 18-month-old Wuraola. Bayo's tribe wanted to elect him religious chief but they practised human sacrifice, and the family, who are Christian, ran away in terror.

Mariam, who had to leave her 10-year-old daughter with her elderly mother, met an Irish missionary who helped her get out. In the panic, she got separated from Bayo, but the couple were reunited by chance in Dublin. "Our lives were at risk and we had to flee," she said. "But I miss my daughter so much. I never left her before and I'm so worried about her.

"I don't mind living with other people, it broadens your views and makes you realise you're not the only one with problems - but it is boring here. We just eat, sleep and watch TV. In Nigeria, we had our own house and good jobs in the city. We'd just like to get work and send our children to school."

Elana, 24, a Romanian, gave birth to seven-week-old Kevin at Mosney. In Romania she had been halfway through a degree but gave up due to lack of money; her husband, Nicolae, could not get a job because he lacked correct papers.

She was already pregnant when she found out that a baby born in Ireland would get Irish citizenship, and the couple found a lorry driver willing to take them. "I was eight months pregnant and so anxious to get here in time," she said. "It was a very long, uncomfortable journey. He left us off outside Dublin. We just had a change of clothes and a few pounds but we would have been penniless at home. This is my mother's first grandchild and I cried every time I spoke to her on the phone."

The couple have been allocated a house in Waterford, so their child will be brought up in the country where he was born.

"I am a little bit scared about starting somewhere new, but thank God we are here and we will be able to make a life for ourselves," she said.

As the traditional seaside holiday fights for survival against overseas packages, Mosney, which in its 1950s and 1960s heydays had more than 50,000 visitors and 160,000 day trippers in a 14-week season, seems a good way to cope. The land could have raised tens of millions on the property development market, but managing director Phelim McCloskey is glad his five-year deal with the government gives job security to the 60 staff. Heating has been installed in the chalets, there is a regular train service to Dublin and free buses to nearby Drogheda, and satellite dishes and internet services so the residents watch their home stations and email relatives. There is a rulebook, no drugs, no soliciting, no begging, and residents must sign a daily register. But Mr McCloskey said some restrictions were necessary in any community, and by and large, the visitors were free to come and go. "It's not a prison," hesaid. "People go shopping and the children go to school in nearby towns, which has helped ease local worries." While quite a number of residents are graduates with excellent English, Mr McCloskey said English classes had helped bring people together. Many families have sad and extraordinary stories about how they came to be there, and their futures are far from certain. Mariam and Bayo Adinyi, engineers from Nigeria, have been at Mosney two weeks, with their daughters, Nana, eight, and 18-month-old Wuraola. Bayo's tribe wanted to elect him religious chief but they practised human sacrifice, and the family, who are Christian, ran away in terror. Mariam, who had to leave her 10-year-old daughter with her elderly mother, met an Irish missionary who helped her get out. In the panic, she got separated from Bayo, but the couple were reunited by chance in Dublin. "Our lives were at risk and we had to flee," she said. "But I miss my daughter so much. I never left her before and I'm so worried about her. "I don't mind living with other people, it broadens your views and makes you realise you're not the only one with problems - but it is boring here. We just eat, sleep and watch TV. In Nigeria, we had our own house and good jobs in the city. We'd just like to get work and send our children to school." Elana, 24, a Romanian, gave birth to seven-week-old Kevin at Mosney. In Romania she had been halfway through a degree but gave up due to lack of money; her husband, Nicolae, could not get a job because he lacked correct papers. She was already pregnant when she found out that a baby born in Ireland would get Irish citizenship, and the couple found a lorry driver willing to take them. "I was eight months pregnant and so anxious to get here in time," she said. "It was a very long, uncomfortable journey. He left us off outside Dublin. We just had a change of clothes and a few pounds but we would have been penniless at home. This is my mother's first grandchild and I cried every time I spoke to her on the phone." The couple have been allocated a house in Waterford, so their child will be brought up in the country where he was born. "I am a little bit scared about starting somewhere new, but thank God we are here and we will be able to make a life for ourselves," she said.

fields.headline: Theophilus Beckford
fields.trailText: Pianist and vocalist, credited as the originator of ska.
fields.body:
Many people credited the pianist and vocalist Theophilus Beckford, who has died aged 65, as the originator of ska. He was stabbed to death in Kingston, Jamaica, following an altercation with an unidentified man.

Born in Trench Town, west Kingston, Beckford's access to the family piano enabled him to develop his talent. He cited the Memphis jump-blues piano playing of Rosco Gordon as particularly influential on his style, with Fats Domino another major inspiration; he was also fond of singers Lloyd Price and Patti Page.

In the mid-1950s, he was the featured pianist backing calypso artists such as Count Lasher and Lord Flea, whose songs, aimed primarily at tourists, were cut for Jewish-Jamaican entrepreneur Stanley Motta, proprietor of a downtown photographic supply shop. The dominant music in Jamaica then was American rhythm and blues, and most local artists copied the sounds of New Orleans.

In late 1956, Beckford started to develop a style that drew from r&b, but had a markedly different rhythmic structure; instead of the fore-beat emphasis of boogie woogie, he used piano chords to emphasise the after-beat, the second and fourth beats of every measure rather than the first and third.

The first song to surface with this rhythm was Beckford's Easy Snapping, backed by session band Clue J and the Blues Blasters for sound system operator Clement "Sir Coxsone" Dodd, founder of the Studio One labels. Dodd initially retained Easy Snapping on acetate as a dub-plate for his Downbeat sound system, and it was highly popular among the dancing public.

Beckford cut further vocal tunes for Dodd, including Jack And Jill Shuffle and That's Me, and became one of his most valued session keyboardists in the ska years, though he also played for rival producers. He voiced Seven Long Years (1962) for King Edwards, Burnette (1963) for Duke Reid, and featured on some of Justin Hinds and the Dominoes' biggest hits. For Prince Buster, he voiced a handful of forlorn love songs in 1964-5.

Seeking greater creative and financial autonomy, Beckford formed the King Pioneer label by 1963 as a vehicle for his own mento and folk-based material. Although his adaptation of the folksong Boller Man A Come was popular, most King Pioneer material failed to become hits.

From the late 1960s, Beckford was one of the featured pianists in Beverley's All Stars, the house band of producer Leslie Kong. In the early reggae period, he backed Eric "Monty" Morris, Toots and the Maytals, and Desmond Dekker. Later, he worked for Lee "Scratch" Perry and Bunny Lee, backing many artists and tutoring younger talent.

Once the digital revolution curtailed the use of live musicians in Jamaica from 1985, Beckford was less active in the studio, though he continued to perform live.

 Theophilus Beckford, music- ian, born 1935; died February 19 2001

fields.headline: Peter Bielenberg
fields.standfirst: German resistance activist who plotted against Hitler and survived the labour camps to settle in Ireland as a farmer
fields.trailText: German resistance activist who plotted against Hitler and survived the labour camps to settle in Ireland as a farmer.
fields.body:
Peter Bielenberg, who has died aged 89, was a member of the internal German resistance to Nazism and was sent to a forced-labour camp after the abortive July 1944 coup against Hitler. This story provided the climax of The Past Is Myself (1968), the bestselling autobiography of his British wife Christabel, who lived through the war in Germany.

Bielenberg was active in the Kreisau circle, which became the focus of German upper-class and intellectual opposition to the Nazi movement. It was his close association with Adam von Trott zu Solz, one of its heroes, that led to Bielenberg's arrest and imprisonment without trial. Despite the moral and physical courage of such individuals, the opposition to Hitler - once the left had been suppressed and the Wehrmacht seduced with prospects of expansion and conquest - was not only modest but had much to be modest about.

The objections of the upper-class opposition to Hitler were initially more moral and aesthetic than practical, though they were seen as no less dangerous. The dissidents despised the petty-bourgeois respectability in which the Nazis clothed their excesses. Initially, the Kreisau circle's principal aim, fatuous in retrospect, was to persuade likeminded Wehrmacht officers and influential foreign, especially British, sympathisers to warn Hitler off.

Only in 1943, when it became obvious that Germany could not win the second world war, did the resisters accept that they might as well be hanged for a sheep as for a lamb, and turned their minds to armed revolt. But, in July 1944, Claus von Stauffenberg's bomb failed to kill Hitler.

Bielenberg was born in Hamburg, the son of the head of a prosperous law firm, in whose footsteps he was meant to follow. He was only 20 when he met the well-connected, Anglo-Irish Christabel Burton, nearly three years his senior, who had given up an Oxford scholarship to study singing in Hamburg. Ironically, Bielenberg, who had been awarded a scholarship to the United States, lost it in 1933, when the Americans expressed a preference for a representative of the "new Germany" - a Nazi.

Both tall and elegant, Bielenberg and Christabel danced exceptionally well together, and married in September 1934, despite misgivings in both their families. The new Frau Bielenberg thereupon chose to become a German citizen by naturalisation.

In an early example of their blithe, upper-class assumption that it was not what you knew but who you knew that mattered - an instinct often proved right, even under Nazism - Bielenberg wangled an attachment to the German embassy in London as part of his work experience as a trainee lawyer. He and his wife then moved to Hamburg, until he got his law doctorate in 1937 and joined the family firm.

The following year, he secured the acquittal of a socialist on a charge of distributing illegal pamphlets - but was shocked when his client was arrested and taken away immediately afterwards. At that point, the couple wanted to emigrate to neutral Eire, but Trott dissuaded them.

Instead, early in 1939, they moved to Berlin, where Bielenberg, with extreme distaste, joined the Nazi party in order to take up a civil-service post. During a holiday in England that August, he visited his wife's highly-placed contacts - she was related to the Harmsworths, making her a niece of the press Lords Northcliffe and Rothermere. Like Trott, who undertook similar missions, Bielenberg looked, in vain, for prominent, non-political Britons to warn Hitler against invading Poland. They got back to Germany just in time for the outbreak of war in September.

The dissidents, organised into a communist-style cell system, continued to meet in the Bielenbergs' huge apartment, where there were no neighbours to overhear their agonising about how to stop Hitler. They still placed their hope in German generals and foreign - particularly American - intervention in the war, rather than in the possibility of direct action of their own.

Through contacts, Bielenberg wangled his way out of his ministry - and military - service into war-work in industry. When he was posted to eastern Germany, Christabel took their children to the Black Forest, and the couple saw little of each other until the last days of the war.

The Gestapo closed in on the dissidents even before July 1944; afterwards, hundreds were arrested, and the ringleaders hanged by piano-wire after macabre show trials. Bielenberg, whom Trott had tried hard to reach just before the bomb plot, was held on suspicion of treason, just as he was preparing to raid the armoury at his Prussian factory for weapons with which to snatch his friend from prison.

Christabel, accustomed to pulling strings and getting her own way, used her contacts to get Peter transferred from the east to Berlin. But after six weeks he was sent to Ravensbruck, a forced-labour camp for women, 50 miles north of Berlin, and was confined in the SS punishment block.

A furious Christabel now decided to tackle the Gestapo officer responsible for Peter's interrogation, giving him such a dressing-down that he promised to get her husband out of the camp before he left for the eastern front. Bielenberg was released to a punishment company, but escaped to join his family in the Black Forest, where he hid until the fighting ended in May 1945.

After the war, Christabel's indefatigable string-pulling ensured that her husband was the first German civilian to get a permit to go to Britain. Once he had recovered from a serious motor- cycle accident, they and their three sons emigrated to Ireland in 1948 and took up farming in County Carlow.

Bielenberg approached this new challenge with a thoroughness worthy of the Prussian general staff, reading up on agriculture and finance while commissioning locally unheard-of soil tests. The resulting well-chosen fertilisers transformed a dilapidated and exhausted farm into a commercial success.

As they settled amid Christabel's vast extended family, to which their own children and grandchildren added in due course, Peter seemed content to fade into the background, even when his wife's wartime memoir became a runaway bestseller. She survives him, as do their children.

 Peter Bielenberg, lawyer, farmer and wartime dissident, born December 13 1911; died March 13 2001

fields.headline: Bangladesh kidnappers 'treated hostages well'
fields.trailText: The freed British hostage Tim Selby was exceptionally well treated by his kidnappers and survived for more than a month in the Bangladesh jungle by playing chess and recounting as many pop artists as he could, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The freed British hostage Tim Selby was exceptionally well treated by his kidnappers and survived for more than a month in the Bangladesh jungle by playing chess and recounting as many pop artists as he could, it emerged yesterday.

Mr Selby, 28, who was released by his kidnappers in the remote Chittagong hills on Saturday morning, lived in the forests on a diet of rice, dhal and scrambled eggs.

The kidnappers also gave him and his two Danish colleagues "a little bit of fruit" and the occasional lump of meat, officials said.

"They were treated very well. The guys were really good to them. The kidnappers sometimes went without, so their captives could have food," Jon Geddes, spokesman for the British high commission in Dhaka said.

"They prepared lodgings for them where they could and prepared the ground for them so that they could sleep. They gave them rudimentary bedding. They were extremely well treated."

Mr Selby, whose family lives in Oldham, Greater Manchester, was yesterday recovering at a military hospital in Dhaka. He was said to have been unscathed by his ordeal but was being detained by Bangladesh officials who wanted to interrogate him about the kidnapping.

They have so far refused to let him fly home. British officials are hopeful that he will be released later today.

Over the weekend the Bangladesh military claimed that Mr Selby had been "rescued" by army commandos who stormed the jungle hideout where he was being held, firing dozens of shots during the assault.

However it emerged that in fact, the three European hostages were released as part of a secret pre-arranged deal between the authorities and the kidnappers, reliable sources confirmed last night. A ransom may have been paid, they added.

"The hostages were told late on Friday evening around midnight by their captors that they were going to be released. They were then taken on a six-hour march through the jungle, being handed from one group to another as they went,' one source said.

"Ultimately at 6am they were put into a hut and the latter group melted away. The Bangladesh military promptly arrived on the scene."

Mr Selby, who works for the Danish construction firm Kampsax, was seized at gunpoint on February 16 while on a road-surveying project near the hill station of Rangamati in south-easternBangladesh. He and his two colleagues were led away up a twisting dirt track, by tribal bandits who had stopped their car. Yesterday it emerged the kidnappers shifted the hostages every couple of days.

"Some of the faces changed throughout the month. But there was a leader who stayed with them the entire time," Mr Geddes said.

"The hostages played a little chess. Tim also thought of some amusing games, by thinking of as many pop artists as he could. They sat around and tried to sleep as much as they could," he added.

In Britain Mr Selby's parents, brother and girlfriend toasted his release with champagne. "We think he will be home this week sometime. I didn't have much time to speak to him on the phone and we still don't know exactly what happened," his father Alf, 61, a retired deputy head teacher said yesterday.

His mother Margaret, 61, said: "It has been very stressful and of course our imaginations were running wild. Now I know Tim is in safe hands my worries and fears have gone and we can just get back to a normal life."

Mr Selby's 25-year-old girlfriend, Brigid Thorns, added: "The past months have been nightmarish. It's just been hell."

The rebels who seized Mr Selby are believed to belong to a dissident tribal faction opposed to a peace accord signed in 1998 which ended a long and bloody insurgency in the Chittagong region. The 13 tribes there are Buddhists, rather than Muslim, and have never come to terms with the fledgling Islamic state in which they live.

webTitle: BSE risk could restrict blood donors

fields.headline: BSE risk could restrict blood donors
fields.standfirst: BSE
fields.trailText: Nearly one in six blood donors may be banned from giving blood to avoid the theoretical risk that they may pass on the fatal human form of BSE.
fields.body:
Nearly one in six blood donors may be banned from giving blood to avoid the theoretical risk that they may pass on the fatal human form of BSE.

Thousands of volunteers would be rejected simply because they had received transfusions themselves. The move could create huge shortages and leave the blood services struggling to meet demand.

Officials had estimated that between 5% and 10% of donors had received blood themselves but a survey has revealed the figure may be as high as 16%. One in five potential donors could not remember or did not know whether they had received a transfusion, making calculations more difficult.

At least 13 of the 95 British victims of variant CJD have been blood donors and authorities have been struggling over the ethical problem of whether people who have received blood transfusions or vaccinations including donations from these should be informed of the potential risk.

At present, the general guidance is that they should not be informed since there is no test, no cure and no treatment for vCJD. New restrictions could help ease that problem, as well as providing extra safeguards against accidental infection.

White blood cells are already filtered out of blood donations because they are considered most likely to carry the agent responsible for vCJD. But tests which have indicated that sheep can transmit BSE through blood transfusion have strengthened fears that people too could unwittingly infect each other.

The advisory committee on the microbiological safety of blood and tissues for transplantation will consider the measures on blood donation next month, the department of health confirmed last night.

webTitle: Trucker in Malawi death crash accused of murder

fields.headline: Trucker in Malawi death crash accused of murder
fields.trailText: The driver of a truck which crashed in Malawi, killing five people including three British teenagers on a gap year trip, is due in court today charged with murder.
fields.body:
The driver of a truck which crashed in Malawi, killing five people including three British teenagers on a gap year trip, is due in court today charged with murder.

Mphenzeni Keni, 34, who was last night under guard in hospital where he is recovering from the crash, will appear at the chief resident magistrate's court in the capital Lilongwe.

Amber Montgomery, 18, Arabella McDonald, 19, and Kate Morgan, 18, died when the pick-up truck in which they were travelling overturned after skidding into a ditch on Thursday. Their friend Lizzi Ryan, 18, of Somerset, is recovering in a clinic at the British high commission in Lilongwe. Two Malawians also died in the crash.

Superintendent Oliver Soko, of the Malawi police service, said Keni also faced charges of causing death by neglect, careless or dangerous driving.

The families of the dead were yesterday trying to come to terms with the tragedy. Brigadier David Montgomery, said he had received a letter from his daugther, Amber, on Saturday morning.

He plans to fly out to Malawi to retrieve her body and see where the group died.

Amber, eldest of three girls, had planned to go to Newcastle University this year to study sociology.

Mr Montgomery, speaking from his home near Sandwich, Kent, yesterday said: "She loved working with children and we received a letter from her and in it she said, 'I love them all so much and I would like to bring them all home'.

"It was heartbreaking to see her words. We were very similar in character in many ways and I shall always remember her as my best friend."
