webTitle: Radio review: Video saved the radio star

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: Video saved the radio star
fields.trailText: Video saved the radio star.
fields.body:
In the first issue of Glamour magazine, Simon, 27, from Buxton, admits to being besotted with Radio 4 newsreader Charlotte Green. Her voice, he says, sounds like "she might want to lick warm honey off your naked body". He wrote in a for a picture of her, but they sent him James Naughtie instead.

Writing to a radio station for a picture - do people still do that? With presenter profiles on station websites and all the spying potential of studio webcams, the act of writing in feels posi tively Victorian. Simon from Buxton should log on to the Today programme's website for an image of his belusted.

Should Simon want moving pictures, it all gets more complicated, with webcam provision patchy across different stations and heartbreakingly rubbish in the main. The Today programme has a very chichi website, all Soviet propaganda-poster chic, aglow with revolutionary red. There's even a sweet 30s-style television to watch the live studio visuals on during the show, but so hi-tech is the operation (you need the latest Real Player, version 8 Basic) that my laptop couldn't cope. I could watch Madonna at Brixton online but can't get to see Sue McGregor in action.

PM is better, but still bad. It is filmed in jerky, shaky NYPD Blue style. Two people read their scripts. That's it.

Other stations feature fixed image webcams, with the picture updating at regular intervals - every 10 minutes on Radio 1, every 30 at Capital FM. The ones that do this best (Sara Cox and Chris Moyles at Radio 1, and Xfm) tend to be those with a younger audience, with the notable exception of Terry Wogan on Radio 2, who plays up to the studiocam like billyo. Woman's Hour gamely enters into the spirit; the clutter-free studio, all pretty in pink, looks like it has been feng-shuied.

Other stations forgo webcam pleasures. Radio 3 clearly deems them vulgar and ignores them, as does Classic FM, while TalkSPORT has a "candid camera" with photographs of luscious babes and, um, Dirty Den.

Quite what studiocams are really for remains something of a mystery, though. If you want to catch presenters mid-nose-pick, for example, maybe it's time to get out more. And if you're a honey monster looking for gratification, the technology will let you down horribly. That Naughtie photograph will have to do for now.

Charlotte Green

Sara Cox and Chris Moyles

Xfm
Women's Hour

Capital FM

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Comic Relief draws 12.6m | Move to digital TV 'flawed' | Baby boy abandoned | Art for art's sake |  Two share lottery £7.4m
fields.body:
Comic Relief draws 12.6m

Comic Relief had raised £25m for charity by last night, £12m more than at the same stage of the last event in 1999, which eventually raised £35m. Friday's seven-hour televised extravaganza attracted record viewing figures, with a peak of 12.6m viewers, and an average of 9.1m.

Move to digital TV 'flawed'

Plans to switch off the analogue television signal within 10 years were criticised as "fatally flawed" by the Consumers' Association yesterday. It said many people rejected digital TV for the same reason others chose it - more channels.

Baby boy abandoned

Police were last night trying to trace the mother of a newborn boy found abandoned in Sawtry, Cambridgeshire. The boy is being cared for in hospital.

Art for art's sake

A Birmingham arts centre is hoping to pull in visitors with a free conceptual exhibition of 60 imaginary exhibits with written descriptions. Organiser Stuart Tait said: "It's a questioning of what art is all about. It has been suggested we are chancers but a lot of thought has gone into it."

Two share lottery £7.4m

Two ticket holders shared Saturday's £7.4m lottery jackpot - numbers 1, 3, 15, 26, 45, 46, bonus 48. There were no £5.5m lottery extra winners - 17, 23, 26, 35, 42, 46, and no Thunderball winner - numbers 8, 14, 16, 19, 32, Thunderball 4.

webTitle: Arts: How does a woman who escaped the Holocaust by the skin of her teeth end up in a play about Nazis?

fields.headline: 'My best acting was in the war'
fields.standfirst: How does a woman who escaped the Holocaust by the skin of her teeth end up in a play about Nazis?  Lyn Gardner reports
fields.trailText: How does a woman who escaped the Holocaust by the skin of her teeth end up in a play about Nazis? Lyn Gardner talks to Ruth Posner.
fields.body:
Between September and November 1940, the Nazis herded almost half a million Polish Jews into a 3.5-square-mile area that became known as the Warsaw Ghetto. One of them was Ruth Posner. Over the next four years, thousands were to perish within the ghetto walls, dying of typhus, starvation, and at the hands of bored German soldiers who would take pot shots at them for fun. Many more hundreds of thousands were deported to the gas chambers at Treblinka. A few, like Posner, escaped.

She was the only child of a man who had been a local government official before the war. He knew his family's only hope of survival was to escape the ghetto - which, by mid-November 1940, was surrounded by a 10ft wall - and he still had the connections to do it. The Nazis hated the Jews but they also needed their forced labour, and in 1942 Posner's father arranged for his 12-year-old daughter and her aunt, whose two small children had already perished, to go to work at a Jewish-owned leather factory beyond the ghetto walls. Once a week, the factory workers were taken to a bathhouse close to the Aryan sector. One week Posner and her aunt made a run for it. "We knew that if we were noticed, we would be shot. But if we stayed, we knew we would die anyway," she recalls.

Posner spent the rest of the war pretending to be a young Polish Catholic girl called Irena Slabowska. It helped that, unlike so many Polish Jews, the family had not spoken Yiddish at home, so her Polish was pure and unaccented. It also helped that she was a natural actress. More than 30 years later, when Posner had had a career as a dancer and founder member of London Contemporary Dance, she told her aunt she intended to become an actress. Her aunt replied: "Don't be silly - you did your best acting when you were 12. During the war you acted better than Sarah Bernhardt."

Those less good at dissembling paid with their lives. Posner never found out what happened to her parents, although she believes they probably perished in Treblinka, unable to put into action their own escape plans, which she knows they had prepared, before one of the many mass deportations from the ghetto. She has never tried to find out for certain. "Some people want to know exactly what happened to their families, but I don't because I feel part of them is still with me. I have enough imagination to know what happened to them, and I just hope it happened quickly."

But she does know what happened to an eight-year-old cousin and another aunt who, like Posner, succeeded in escaping the ghetto and passed themselves off as Aryans. At eight it is hard to live a lie, and the little girl let slip her Jewish origins to their landlady, who denounced them to the Gestapo. Posner made no such slips. So ingrained was her new Polish Catholic identity that when, more than 40 years later, she was appearing in Theresa, a play about the Holocaust, she initially found it difficult to utter the line: "I am a Jew."

But Posner is a Jew and proud of it. Since appearing in Theresa she has starred in a number of other plays about the Holocaust, all written by the Jewish writer and director Julia Pascal. The latest, Woman in the Moon, which opened at the Arcola Theatre last week, considers the career of Wernher Von Braun, the Nazi scientist who engineered the building of the V1 and V2 rockets that devastated wartime London. Unlike many of his high-ranking Nazi colleagues, Von Braun was not tried at Nuremberg. Instead he was welcomed in the US, where he became the brains behind the 1969 moon landing. Yet during the war many slave workers died while working in the V2 factory.

In Woman in the Moon, Posner plays Dora, a journalist interviewing Von Braun in the US after the war. Dora's own childhood escape from the concentration camps is no less incredible than Posner's. Reliving her experience every night must be traumatic. "I think it is a kind of exorcism," replies Posner, who says that when she first came to Britain after the war she never discussed her past and, in fact, made strong efforts to leave it behind and wipe away all traces of her accent. She certainly has no desire to become known as "that woman who always plays Holocaust survivors" and says she sometimes longs for a role in a light comedy, "although I know that with my accent nobody is going to cast me as Lady Bracknell. When Julia first talked to me about the play I thought, 'No, not another Holocaust play.' But then I remember there are people like David Irving around and that in 20 years there will be no witnesses left. We will all be dead. I think maybe that is why I became an actress - to tell these stories, not just to perform."

Later, after escaping to the Polish countryside, she and her aunt returned to Warsaw. After the Warsaw uprising they were evacuated to a prisoner of war camp in Germany with other Poles. Even so, they were unable to let their disguises slip lest they be denounced as Jews. But, as the war drew to an end, the Germans wanted rid of these Polish prisoners. They were herded onto a train. Rumours spread that they were being sent to a concentration camp. As the train went through Essen it was caught in an American bombing raid. The German guards panicked and opened the train doors. Posner and her aunt slipped away.

They were taken in by the owners of a farm, where they spent the rest of the war as labourers, still pretending to be Catholics. In the final days of the war two young German soldiers took refuge in the farm's attic. Allied forces came looking for German soldiers. "They asked us if anyone was hiding there. I saw the German farmer's wife looking at us. I thought of everything we had been through, the pretending and the hiding. They were only boys - we couldn't betray them. My aunt and I said nothing."

 Woman in the Moon is at the Arcola Theatre, London E8 (020-7503 1646), until April 7.

webTitle: Michell Hanson: A recipe for disaster.

fields.headline: Michele Hanson
fields.standfirst: A recipe for disaster
fields.trailText: A recipe for disaster.
fields.body:
Last week I found my mother lying in bed blubbing in the middle of the day. "I'm depressed," she cried poignantly. "All my friends are dead!" So I ordered her to get up and make a steamed jam pudding, which she did in a trice and it snapped her out of the doldrums.

Cooking is a life-saver to my mother. When she was nearly dead with pneumonia, she spotted Ken Hom cooking prawns on telly, sat up at once and demanded a Chinese take-away. So even I have dredged up a bit of enthusiasm. I have this new fad of various warm bits on salad. I tried to tell Rosemary about it on our dog walk but she was horrified. "No!" she shouted. "Not recipes! It's almost as bad as routes!"

Her daughter, who has moved to the East End, likes to chat forever about routes from there to here. Usually it is men who like to discuss routes, because they tend to know a better route than you do and will even argue with signposts. "No, I wouldn't go that way. Always avoid the M11 and that Stanstead turn-off. You should take the A10 to Ipswich and blah blah."

I often have vicious rows with Gardener about routes. He likes to go twirling about the back streets, avoiding this, that and the other, whereas I like to zoom straight down the high street and get home in a flash. But a twirler cannot take a direct route, even at 1am when the roads are completely deserted. He must widdle all around the houses and back streets, via the Hebrides, until the passenger, who knows a much better, quicker way, is bursting with silent rage or screaming and nutting the passenger window, and could have walked home in half the time.

I bet scores of relationships have foundered on a long, twirly journey. Or on a recipe. I notice that a twirler cannot even go straight through a recipe, but must add his own extras. Yesterday I was slaving away in the kitchen, sticking to the blessed Delia's every instruction, when Gardener drifted in suggesting alternatives and hurled extra bits of his own into my stew, without permission.

Luckily he has, so far, never redirected one of my mother's recipes. That would be a direct route to the end of the road.

webTitle: Women: As one woman is convicted of the rape of another, Mary Kenny asks what happened to sisternhood.

fields.headline: Women beware women
fields.standfirst: As one woman is convicted of the rape of another,  Mary Kenny asks what has changed since those halcyon days of 70s feminism when sisterhood was a given
fields.trailText: As one woman is convicted of the rape of another,  Mary Kenny asks what has changed since those halcyon days of 70s feminism when sisterhood was a given.
fields.body:
Can one woman rape another? Technically, no, since the legal definition of rape is penile penetration. But women have been accused of participating in the crime of rape and at Blackfriars Crown Court in London on Friday, 18-year-old Claire Marsh was convicted of the rape of a 37-year-old woman. The teenager, who pinned the woman to the ground during a "vile and horrifying" sex attack, is thought to be the youngest of the few females ever to be convicted of such an offence in this country.

Rape has been so strongly characterised as the definitive male crime against women that it is shocking to think another woman could side with the enemy in it. It is always assumed that women will identify with the female victim of rape and judge an accused man harshly. This is not necessarily so. Anecdotally, it has been observed that female jurors are more likely to listen sympathetically to the man and wonder whether the woman "asked for it" by wearing provocative clothes or "leading him on".

The notion of "sisterhood" - that 1970s feminist theory of solidarity between all females - was based on the assumption that all women will identify with one another to the exclusion of all men. This idea came from America, where Marxism had never really got a foothold: for Marxism had taught that notions of solidarity were based on class, not sex. Simone de Beauvoir believed that feminism could never unite all women because of her understanding of Marxist thinking: the woman bourgeois does not have the same class interests as the female proletariat.

But American-led feminism proclaimed that all women were sisters and that remains the philosophical basis of thinking about feminism to this day. Thus it is assumed that women in general will welcome the "feminisation of the workplace" and will identify with and support other women in a range of personal, and even political, circumstances. We are supposed to be horrified that the next parliament will very likely have fewer women MPs , though many females were probably secretly delighted when Germaine Greer trashed "Blair's Babes" as a useless yes-sir backing group for a narcissistic Tony Blair.

Wanting more women in parliament is very 1970s, based on the notion that every woman in the country wants a female MP. They don't. They want an MP who best represents their interests, whether individual or community, and that could be either a man or a woman.

I don't disparage, entirely, the notion of "sisterhood" advanced by 1970s feminism: like Christianity - and Marxism - there is a basic idealism and even a basic kindness to it. Women should be nice to one another and help one another along. Women shouldn't fall into the bitchy "scratch-your-eyes-out" stereotype that had been advanced in the past (and that is sometimes caricatured by male gays when camping up a quarrel).

Women shouldn't be prejudiced against one another, as sometimes our mothers were, "Loved him, hated her" being a common judgment on encountering a couple. My mother had been friends with the German ambassador to Ireland in the 1940s and as a young feminist I remonstrated with her for this. "How could you? He was a Nazi!" Mother was indignant. "He was a perfect gentleman! She might have been a Nazi" - referring to the attractive wife in question - "but he certainly wasn't."

"Oh, blame the woman!" I yelled. We believed our generation would never take this hostile woman-against-woman approach: we would show solidarity with other females.

All ideals eventually involve hypocrisy, because virtue is essentially against human nature. And looking back now, with as much honesty as I can bear to muster, this "sisterly solidarity" contained vast dollops of hypocrisy. Beneath the surface of feminist sisterly decorum, the usual spite and hatreds seethed. We thought nothing of stealing another woman's husband if it suited us, as the recent revelations in Esther Rantzen's autobiography have so disingenuously demonstrated. I now believe women positively like seducing other women's husbands, because the thrill of taking possession of the man is added to the usual frisson of a sexual adventure.

Indeed, I think many young women actually prefer married men to single men because of the competitive excitement of trumping another woman - along with a Darwinian attraction to proven successful mates. fields.headline: No 1841
fields.standfirst: Ursula Andress
fields.trailText: Ursula Andress
fields.body:
Appearance: Dripping. Sashaying. Pert.

Easy, tiger. Occupation: Icon.

What kind of job is that? She's an actor. But not just any old actor. She's an Icon Actor.

And the difference is? Actors work terribly hard and appear in lots of different films and plays, using their thespian brilliance to transform themselves, chameleon-like, into any character you care to mention.

And icons? Icons work terribly hard and appear in lots of different films and plays, using their thespian brilliance blah, blah . . . but nobody remembers anything other than a bikini they once wore in a Bond film.

That's where I know the name from! She was Honey Ryder, emerging tantalisingly from the sea to utter the immortal line: "Is that a knife attached to your undergarments or are you just pleased to see me?" Um, something like that.

So why's she in Pass notes? She's 65 today - Andress is an OAP.

She can come and collect her pension off me any time she likes. Yes, yes, preferably carrying a conch, I know. Anyway, I think we should move on from this bikini thing. Andress has had many memorable roles since.

Remind me: Louise de Valliere in The Fifth Musketeer (1979); the Queen in Cremaster 5, an arthouse flick in which she sings in Hungarian and her memorable role as Karen in the top 80s cross-species TV show Manimal . . . maybe we should go back to the bikini after all.

What happened to the bikini anyway? I hoped you'd ask. It is soon to be appearing, slightly food-stained no doubt, on the wall of the Planet Hollywood restaurant in Piccadilly, after restaurateur Robert Hall paid £41,000 for it at an auction last month.

Do say: "Ursula Andress" in a Sean Connery accent. It's relatively amusing, depending on how drunk you are.

Don't say: Goldfingaaaaaaaah!

Why not? Because it was Dr No, idiot.

fields.headline: State of the markets
fields.trailText: Is the iron discipline of market forces which made life a misery for those working in further education and other public services the same as that which merrily dispatched billions into cyberspace by creating a vast financial bubble in dot.com shares based on nothing (Fear stalks the markets, March 17)?
fields.body:
Is the iron discipline of market forces which made life a misery for those working in further education and other public services the same as that which merrily dispatched billions into cyberspace by creating a vast financial bubble in dot.com shares based on nothing (Fear stalks the markets, March 17)?
DBC Reed
Northampton

 The (class 1) academics who produced this pecking order tripe for a census (Teachers demoted in class structure, March 16) are presumably funded by a government that wants a "classless society"?
Tony Bayliss
Wolverhampton

 Fig trees at only £15.99 (Reader offer, G2, March 16)? Couldn't someone have told the interior designers at Portcullis House (Diary, March 16)?
Geoff Booth
Knebworth, Herts

 David Girling's speculation (Letters, March 17) that Swift may have invented the name Vanessa in his 1713 poem Cadenus and Vanessa, is well-founded. According to Chambers Cambridge English Dictionary, he derived it from those of Esther Vanhomrigh, whose place in Dean Swift's life I leave it to the experts to determine.
Richard Tagart
Antwerp, Belgium

 Nice bit of glib generalisation on the cross-Pennine divide (Leader, March 17). In fact, the most modern-sounding pop records of 20 years ago, and the ones whose "modernity" stands up best today, came from Sheffield (The Human League's early albums and ABC's The Lexicon of Love).
Robin Carmody
Portland, Dorset

 With all the animal carcasses around, is there not a danger of a slump in the market for modern art?
F Knox
London

webTitle: Letters: Facing up to the moguls

fields.headline: Facing up to the moguls
fields.trailText: Thank you for giving William Dalrymple the freedom and space to write on the situation in Israel and Palestine and the media responses to it (Comment, March 16).
fields.body:
Thank you for giving William Dalrymple the freedom and space to write on the situation in Israel and Palestine and the media responses to it (Comment, March 16). Crossing a media mogul is a very dangerous thing to do when your vocation (and livelihood) depend on being published. I hope that William Dalrymple and the other writers who have also stood up against Conrad Black know they have the gratitude of many people.

I returned from the West Bank two weeks ago, having found the Palestinians I met determined to endure through this most terrible siege they are under, and the Jewish peacemakers in despair at the stranglehold on the media that makes it so difficult for their criticism of their own government to be heard. I stood with the (Jewish) Women in Black on their weekly demonstration against the occupation while passers by called them Nazis and traitors. The international community has a part to play in achieving peace and to do that we need fair media coverage.
Sue Plater
Tollesbury, Essex
ssplater@gn.apc.org

 It is ridiculous to accuse Conrad Black of attempting to silence criticism against Israel. The Telegraph and Spectator regularly publish critical material on Israeli policies. In contrast, neither the Guardian nor Independent ever try to present a balanced picture. Conrad Black deserves praise for his courageous decision to engage in open discussion instead of trying to sack or censure his journalists. By doing this he has demonstrated integrity and respect for the freedom of speech.
Efraim Podoksik
Cambridge
ep225@cam.ac.uk

 I wish I were "Edward Luttwack [sic], a former Israeli tank commander and friend of [Conrad] Black", as William Dalrymple wrote. He may or may not be an anti-semite (someone who dislikes the Jews more than they deserve), but he is evidently poorly read. The Oxfordshire Light Infantry had no tanks in my day. As for Conrad Black, alas, I met him only once, a decade ago for perhaps 10 minutes. It was an Aryan who asked me to write for the Sunday Telegraph years later. But one cannot be sure, of course. For all I know, the Japanese newspaper Yomuiri Shimbun and the German Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, which also run my pieces, could also be controlled by the underground headquarters where Black communes with the other 66 "secret rabbis". Black is not Jewish, of course, but, as the Gestapo explained, judeophile Aryans are even worse than Jews.
Edward Luttwak
Sunday Telegraph

webTitle: 200 hurt as 'people of Seattle' converge on Naples

fields.headline: 200 hurt as 'people of Seattle' converge on Naples
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: The city of Naples was yesterday counting the cost of a day of urban warfare during which 20,000 anti-globalisation demonstrators were involved in furious clashes with the police.
fields.body:
The city of Naples was yesterday counting the cost of a day of urban warfare during which 20,000 anti-globalisation demonstrators were involved in furious clashes with the police.

More then 200 people were injured - half of them police officers - as the vast crowd tried to carry the protest against the globalisation of the economy to an international conference on information technology and government which concluded on Saturday in the Palazzo Reale. Tear gas wafted over the squares of central Naples as 6,000 police fought to stop the demonstators penetrating a security cordon ringing the conference area.

A small group among the "people of Seattle" - who started a season of international anti-globalisation protests at the WTO's millennium round conference in the US three years ago - replied by hurling stones and molotov cocktails.

Two men, an Italian and a Spaniard, were arrested and a further 21 denounced to the authorities for alleged involvement in the mayhem, during which banks were pelted with missiles and an employment agency ransacked in the worst urban violence Italy has seen for years.

Organisers of the protest, politicians and parents' groups have accused the police of overreacting to the demonstration. TV tape shot by the organisers shows isolated demonstrators being kicked and beaten by police, who were also said to be responsible for beating journalists and TV cameramen and, mistakenly, two of their own plainclothes officers.

"It was easier for sub-comandante Marcos to reach Mexico City than for these kids to reach Piazza Plebiscito," said Fr Vitaliano Della Sala, a left-wing priest who participated in the march of Mexico's zapatistas and in Saturday's Naples protest.

Representatives of a Naples parents' group said they had seen 14-year-olds beaten as they tried to leave with their hands held in the air. Police spokesmen said the security services had only reacted when they came under attack.

The subject matter of the e-government conference was largely obscured. Enzo Bianco, the interior minister, presented a Neapolitan with Italy's first electronic ID card - and judging by Saturday's scenes, the hi-tech police of the future are likely to have an interest in the scheme's success.

webTitle: Short joins push for new WTO talks

fields.headline: Short joins push for new WTO talks
fields.standfirst:
It is not enough to cut poor nations' debt, says development minister. They must be drawn into the global economy


Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
Special report: World Trade Organisation
fields.trailText: It is not enough to cut poor nations' debt, says development minister. They must be drawn into the global economy
fields.body:
Marginalisation rather than globalisation poses the greatest threat to the economies of impoverished countries - or so the international development secretary, Clare Short, and the head of the WTO, Mike Moore, will argue today.

In an attempt to pave the way for a fresh round of trade liberalisation talks this autumn, they will tell a gathering of EU development ministers that opening new markets is crucial to hitting targets set by the UN for reducing poverty by 2015.

Ms Short will stress that debt relief alone will be insufficient to put the poorest countries on the road to sustained prosperity and that further trade liberalisation will help boost export growth and overall economic performance.

Despite the strength of anti-globalisation protests since the Seattle conference in December 1999, she believes there is a growing commitment in international capitals to launch a new round.

This weekend thousands of anti-globalisation protesters clashed with riot police in Naples over a meeting of the Global Forum - a conference of government and technology leaders being held in the city.

While accepting that the gap between rich and poor countries has widened, Ms Short will say the key to faster development is closer integration, with rich countries abandoning protectionist policies and developing countries liberalising their service sectors.

"In order to make progress in reducing extreme poverty, the poorest countries need to be drawn into the global economy and increase their access to modern knowledge and technology. Clearly debt relief for the heavily indebted poor countries [HIPC] is important to remove the overhang of unpayable debt that blocks their development, but it is not enough to put these very poor countries on the path to development. It is very important that once a country has received its debt relief, it avoids running up huge debts again," Ms Short will say.

"In reality no amount of HIPC debt reduction of official development assistance can guarantee that we will reach the international development targets and poverty reduction goals. It is clear that we can not achieve systematic and sustained poverty reduction without economic growth."

Ms Short is emerging as a crucial ally for Mr Moore in his attempts to complete preparations by July for the launch of a new round in Qatar in November. She is urging her EU colleagues to press for a "development round" at the UN conference on least developed countries in Brussels in May.

Mr Moore, the WTO's director general, will tell today's meeting that the multilateral trading system has probably done more to boost living standards over the past 50 years than any other intervention, and that the countries that have done spectacularly well since the second world war have all been trade oriented.

The WTO has found that a main stumbling block to the launch of a new round is the sense in some developing countries that they have yet to see any benefits from the last round - the Uruguay round - concluded in December 1993.

However, Mr Moore hopes the support of developing countries such as South Africa will help convince the WTO's poorer members that they have much to gain from a new round. He said: "Dwelling on the perceived injustices of the past does nothing to prevent even greater injustices in the future. Many developing country governments are coming round to that view. They increasingly understand that the greatest threat to their economies is not globalisation but marginalisation.

"A new round is the surest way to prevent the further marginalisation of least developed countries from the world economy and to deal with the problems that they may have with existing WTO agreements and the way the WTO is run." Mr Moore is hopeful that the threat of a global economic downturn will boost support for trade liberalisation, particularly from the EU and the US.

He will say the further liberalisation of trade will make a "huge contribution" to alleviating poverty and achieving by 2015 the UN targets of halving the number of people below the poverty line, giving every child a primary education and and reducing infant mortality by two thirds.

But both he and Ms Short believe developing countries will only have their fears assuaged if richer nations are prepared to make the poor a focus of new talks. "To be genuine in our policy stance that liberalisation brings broad-based benefits we in the north must lead by example. We must address northern protectionism, and we can easily afford to do so."

Trade Balance

 According to the Department for International Development, the share of the poorest countries in world trade has declined from 0.8% in 1980 to 0.4% today.

 The estimated benefit of a 50% cut in tariffs in developed and developing countries: $150bn (£105bn) - about three times the value of total overseas aid.

 The World Trade Organisation says that world trade has increased 17-fold since 1950, world output has risen sixfold.

 Exports from developing countries grew at 4.3% in the 1980s and 6.4% in the 1990s.

 Growth in GDP per head increased from 0.4% to 1.5% a year. For the least developed countries, export growth rose from 2.9% to 3.2%. GDP per head fell by 0.6% in the 1980s, and climbed 0.8% in the 1990s.

But both he and Ms Short believe developing countries will only have their fears assuaged if richer nations are prepared to make the poor a focus of new talks. "To be genuine in our policy stance that liberalisation brings broad-based benefits we in the north must lead by example. We must address northern protectionism, and we can easily afford to do so." For the least developed countries, export growth rose from 2.9% to 3.2%. GDP per head fell by 0.6% in the 1980s, and climbed 0.8% in the 1990s.

webTitle: Letters: Science does not back cull

fields.headline: Science does not back cull
fields.trailText: As the president of the Primate Society of Great Britain, I watched the slaughter of hundreds of monkeys last year with dismay. The current response to foot and mouth (Leader, March 17) is even more catastrophic and has even less justification, at least based on "science".
fields.body:
As the president of the Primate Society of Great Britain, I watched the slaughter of hundreds of monkeys last year with dismay. This strategy to control a poorly understood simian virus has implications for zoos worldwide and consequences for critically endangered species and captive breeding programmes. The current response to foot and mouth (Leader, March 17) is even more catastrophic and has even less justification, at least based on "science".

Ministers and Maff spokespersons maintain that immunisation is not possible as one can no longer distinguish between animals which have acquired their immunity from exposure to the disease or via vaccination. This defies rational interpretation. Does this imply that children should no longer get measles jabs, since we can't distinguish between immunity acquired due to disease or injection? Or that since measles has a moderate fatality rate, we should shoot all measles victims and produce a 100% fatality? Where is the science here?

Other science tells us that foot and mouth causes a 40% reduction in production. For how long do these declines persist? How would we know? No animal since 1927 has survived in the UK after infection. We have no information on the response of modern UK breeds to this illness. Nor are there data from the US, since the last outbreak there was in 1929. Where does this information come from, and how relevant is it to the UK?

Without eradication, our tourist industry would suffer. Really? I see little impact on tourism in Greece or Turkey, where the disease is still endemic. The impact on tourism with the current controls is, however, catastrophic.

As a scientist concerned with issues of conservation and animal welfare, I find the government's response hard to interpret as science; rather it appears to be historical, political and economic. Let the debate focus more clearly on the origins of the policy of culling rather than on poorly presented scientific justifications. The "science" itself has not been subject to scrutiny or debate - it is simply the misapplication of science at the speed of a bullet.
PC Lee
Reader in behavioural biology
University of Cambridge
pcl1@cus.cam.ac.uk

 You rightly suggest we should be tough with this outbreak of foot and mouth but the other method of producing a firebreak to stop disease spreading, vaccination, appears not to have been considered by Maff. The sheep in the areas surrounding the Cumbrian, Welsh, Scottish and south-west outbreaks could all be vaccinated for the relevant strain of FMD. This method has been used in European outbreaks and was endorsed in a 1999 EU report by the scientific committee on animals health and welfare. This would mean a mass vaccination of sheep in the areas affected and the continuation of restrictions for 30 days after vaccination. Animals could then be blood-tested to see if they had suffered from foot and mouth before being safely moved for slaughter in the normal way.
Graham Hines
Kemsing, Kent
grayvet@totalise.co.uk

 Emma Nicholson's livestock e-mart proposal (An online lifeline, March 17) is not a new concept, having operated for a number of years from a mart in Inverurie, north-east Scotland. Although it goes some way to reducing disease transfer risks by addressing the issue of mass contamination at marts, it does not address the huge distances livestock will continue to travel. Only comprehensive plans to re-establish local links from farm gate to consumers' plates will reinvigorate our local food economies and reduce the impact of diseases such as foot and mouth.
Mark Ruskell
Edinburgh

webTitle: Leader: Even Aids victims can be culpable

fields.headline: Reckless limits
fields.standfirst:
Even Aids victims can be culpable

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Aids charities are not helping their cause in attacking the prosecution - and sentencing - of Stephen Kelly, the first case in Britain of a person being convicted of knowingly infecting a lover with HIV.
fields.body:
Aids charities are not helping their cause in attacking the prosecution - and sentencing - of Stephen Kelly, the first case in Britain of a person being convicted of knowingly infecting a lover with HIV. Although their opposition is not prompted by a wish to condone Mr Kelly's behaviour - it springs from a hope of ending the stigma attached to the disease - the charities have come close to condoning his irresponsible act.

Stephen Kelly, who was informed while in prison in 1992 that he was HIV positive, began an affair with Anne Craig, a mother of three young children, in 1994 without telling her about his condition. Asked by Ms Craig whether there was any reason why they should not have unprotected sex, other than the risk of pregnancy, he said there was not. He had been advised in prison about the importance of safe sex, but had unprotected sex with Ms Craig for four months until, after the first signs of her infection developed, owning up. He was sentenced to five years in prison in Glasgow last Friday for culpable and reckless conduct.

The Terence Higgins Trust Lighthouse, the country's largest HIV/Aids organisation, said it "did not believe that criminalising the virus is going to make things any better". But the case does not criminalise the virus. What it does is criminalise reckless sexual behaviour by people who knowingly have the virus. The trust's second ground for opposing the prosecution is equally illogical: the wish for people to be more open about their condition. Certainly there are better ways than deterrence, but the case does show people thinking about being reckless that they face sanctions if they do. Ms Craig, who is now confined to a wheelchair, provided the most pertinent comment: "If the verdict saves one life from the misery I have been through then it will all have been worthwhile."

Where critics are right in criticising the case is in its breach of the confidentiality code governing research studies. Kelly had agreed while in prison to give a sample to a confidential clinical trial into HIV outbreaks. He was assured that the findings would be held in strictest confidence, but the sample was later used as evidence in the trial. Scientists are right to be concerned by the blatant breach of the confidentiality guarantee and the medical research council is being too complacent in rejecting their criticisms. Undermining confidentiality guarantees strikes at the heart of serious research.

webTitle: Leader: BT should ensure donations equal profits

fields.headline: Red faces over red noses
fields.standfirst: BT should ensure donations equal profits
fields.trailText: British Telecom is not quite as black- hearted as it has been made out. Its critics have been condemning the company for the profits it has made from calls generated by last week's Comic Relief. Some estimates put it at £250,000, but others have placed it much higher.
fields.body:
British Telecom is not quite as black- hearted as it has been made out. Its critics have been condemning the company for the profits it has made from calls generated by last week's Comic Relief. Some estimates put it at £250,000, but others have placed it much higher.

Why, when actors and many other people involved in last week's charity efforts have given their time for free, is the telephone company pocketing the extra profits from the millions of extra calls? BT blames the regulator. Under the terms of the company's licence with Oftel, it has to charge a minimum amount for every call. Oftel confirmed this defence, explaining that because of BT's monopoly position, it was required to treat all users the same and not make exceptions for certain good causes.

Comic relief went even further in alleviating the red faces at BT. It recognised the disruption which the biennial appeal made on the network and the significant resources and expenses incurred in ensuring regular customer services were not interrupted. This year BT donated £65,000 directly to Comic Relief and it had also bought 36,000 vehicle red noses at a cost of £25,0000. Then there were donations in kind, including helping employees to give their time free in taking calls on the big day. Good for them.

But if the company was genuine about wanting to give more to the charity, there is a simple way round the Oftel rule which would achieve its wish: increasing the donation to Comic Relief so that it equals the profit made. True this is a difficult time for the company. Its share price has fallen to its lowest level for two years and it has accumulated debts of £30bn. This week it meets its shareholders. But there could be no better way of demonstrating that it is not just profit-driven - nor just shareholder-driven. A company making almost £3bn profit a year can afford to be more community minded. In PR terms alone, it would be worth every penny.

webTitle: Letters: Global warming a hotly debated issue

fields.headline: Global warming a hotly debated issue
fields.trailText: I am no supporter of Mr Bush nor of "smokestack utilities" (Leader, March 16), but I am passionate about truth and honesty in science.
fields.body:
I am no supporter of Mr Bush nor of "smokestack utilities" (Leader, March 16), but I am passionate about truth and honesty in science. In the last three months, a series of heavyweight scientific papers have appeared in journals such as Nature and Climate Research, showing incontrovertibly the "incomplete state of scientific knowledge" about climate change.

The critical focus has been on the role of water vapour, which is unquestionably the most important "greenhouse" gas, not carbon dioxide; the geological relationships between carbon dioxide and temperature; the many missing, or little-known variables, in the main climate models, including soot and "Pacific" vents; and the need to correct many temperature measurements, especially those over the oceans. One paper from the prestigious Harvard-Smithsonian center for astrophysics, concludes that: "Our review of the literature has shown that GCMs [climate models] are not sufficiently robust to provide an understanding of the potential effects of CO2 on climate necessary for public discussion."

It is surely time in the UK for a more adult scientific openness about the limitations of our current knowledge. Emissions may be politically important, but their precise scientific role has been seriously questioned.
Prof Philip Stott
University of London
stott2@compuserve.com

 WWF believes that President Bush's decision to seek to exclude CO2 from new emissions reductions for electricity plants (Bush drops pledge on cutting CO2, March 15) is a disaster for the world's climate. Mr Bush is being disingenuous in using the claim that we have incomplete scientific knowledge on the causes of climate change as an excuse for inaction. Recent reports have confirmed climate change is a reality and that humans are primarily to blame.

The US is responsible for 25% of global emissions of CO2. It has a clear responsibility to cut the emissions that cause global warming. Mr Blair has recognised that Britain has a "special responsibility" in ensuring the implementation of the Kyoto Protocol. He must use the UK's special relationship to get an immediate reversal of the US position.
Robert Napier
Chief executive, WWF-UK

fields.headline: Starting up
fields.standfirst:
Substance is more important than style

More net news
fields.trailText: Substance is more important than style.
fields.body:
One of the areas we have been a little frustrated with for some time now is our website. For a dot.com, this is obviously a critical component.

Over the past year we have followed a site development that matched our needs. The first version of the site was primarily intended to tell visitors about Rools. At this early stage it was functional rather than flash. The target audience was people within the new media, e-commerce and financial services industries, so it was quite consciously not "teen cool".

The site did its job, but we were pleased to move to a second version at the end of last year which made concessions to the younger consumer.

It was clear that functionality was more important than appearance. We were lacking skills and experience in web design, and ended up making more compromises than we would have liked.

We do most of our developments online, rather than off line. Again, this means the present site does its job but is not the finished article. We needed an experienced designer and finally found what we wanted. His focus for the last seven weeks has been on the next version of the site.

The new look has involved the whole team. Four redesigns of the site were whittled down to one by vote. This went through enhancements before we agreed on the template. Work is continuing and it should be launched in the coming weeks.

It looks great, and will certainly appeal more to our target teens. Rather than the white background of our present pages favoured by industry leaders such as Yahoo! and Amazon we have chosen an eye-catching yellow. And we have been able to introduce some animated characters to liven things up.

A lot of thought has gone into the "user experience", and visitors will find it much easier to navigate their way through the site. Feedback suggests many pages were too busy, so we have reduced the volume of text and restricted each of the main pages to a maximum of two or three main messages. We are preparing a more polished product. When we have finished, we will have reached a milestone.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are founders of Rools, an e-payment service for teenagers

fields.headline: No vendetta against Vaz
fields.trailText: From the transcripts of the committee on standards and privileges, I have discovered the extraordinary lengths to which Keith Vaz went, when speaking to the committee, to try to undermine my credibility as a witness.
fields.body:
From the transcripts of the committee on standards and privileges, I have discovered the extraordinary lengths to which Keith Vaz went, when speaking to the committee, to try to undermine my credibility as a witness. Significantly misrepresenting a number of the facts and ignoring the deep concerns we in Leicester have expressed about his past conduct, Keith tried to persuade the commissioner and the committee that, motivated by envy, I was personally orchestrating a vendetta against him (pages 18-20).

I am pleased to read that the commissioner dealt with these allegations very directly. In her published report she says, "he (Sir Peter) has gone out of his way to ensure that I was not in any doubt about the difficulties in his relationship with Mr Vaz over many years. This, in my view, is not the action of someone who is actuated by malice or revenge and I have seen no sign of such motivation in any of Sir Peter's dealings with me during this inquiry" (para 351).

In their report, the committee members said: "We have considered carefully whether the antipathy between them may have coloured Sir Peter's evidence to the commissioner and to us, as Mr Vaz suggested to us. In our view it did not" (para 38).

It is, of course, regrettable that the committee members were not given sufficient cooperation to come to clear conclusions about the more substantial issues in front of them. But at least we in Leicester have the satisfaction of knowing that the rest of the country now understands Keith nearly as well as we do.
Peter Soulsby
Leicester
peter.soulsby@leicester.gov.uk

webTitle: Past notes: Baa, Baa, Black Sheep

fields.headline: Past notes
fields.trailText: Baa, Baa, Black Sheep
fields.body:
Anniversary of the week: Baa, Baa, Black Sheep published. Children's publishing took a seven-league-boot leap forward on March 22 1744 when Mrs Mary Cooper brought out the first book of English nursery rhymes: Tommy Thumb's Song Book. Included in this slim volume was the classic Baa, Baa, Black Sheep, which, according to spoilsports in the wool trade, is far from being a ditty about a master, a dame and a little boy happily walking off with a bag each.

Instead, it is a kind of musical financial statement about a tax imposed in 1275. "The little boy who lives down the lane" is a coded reference to the tax inspector, over whose eyes wool is presumably to be pulled to prevent him from extracting 33.3% of the sheep farm's produce.

By contrast, Ring A Ring O' Roses, the verses of which were first printed in 1881, was said to be about the great plague of 1665, on the grounds that sufferers had a red rash, carried posies as an attempted disinfectant and sneezed shortly before death. But the plague theory falls down; the rhyme also came in many other versions, none of them remotely medical.

Similarly, Little Jack Horner was thought to be a satire on one 15th-century Horner, who appropriated a manor from Glastonbury Abbey. But he was Thomas not Jack, there was no sitting in corners - and no thumb no plum either. Otherwise, the parallels are obvious.

fields.headline: Charge sheet
fields.trailText: We protest at the continued harassment of Delroy Lindo by the Metropolitan police (Lindo furious at fresh arrest, March 17).
fields.body:
We protest at the continued harassment of Delroy Lindo by the Metropolitan police (Lindo furious at fresh arrest, March 17). Last Friday Delroy was dragged off the street and detained in Hornsey police station for six hours before being released without charge. He has now been detained 38 times since 1992, charged 18 times, his wife Sonia twice and both have been cleared on all occasions.

This latest outrage comes just weeks after the Met admitted in an internal report the Lindos were being harassed "because of negative stereotyping" by officers. Delroy had the right to expect that the police's admission of their own culpability would be an end to his troubles. This is the same force involved in the violent death of Roger Sylvester. We have no confidence in the Met to sort out the situation. Top officers must be made accountable. The chief superintendent of Haringey police, Stephen James, should be sacked and officers involved disciplined.

We also call for the scrapping of stop and search. Home Office figures show that although the number of stops is down, black people are still five times more likely to be stopped than whites and four times more likely to be arrested. It is time that Jack Straw, instead of giving police ever more powers, started taking some away. How else can black citizens believe government claims that it takes combating racism seriously? Victor Sylvester (Haringey Trades Council), Louise Christian, Deborah Coles (Inquest), Paddy Hill (Miscarriages of Justice Organisation), Raphael Rowe, and seven others
hassm80@hotmail.com

The chief superintendent of Haringey police, Stephen James, should be sacked and officers involved disciplined. We also call for the scrapping of stop and search. Home Office figures show that although the number of stops is down, black people are still five times more likely to be stopped than whites and four times more likely to be arrested. It is time that Jack Straw, instead of giving police ever more powers, started taking some away. How else can black citizens believe government claims that it takes combating racism seriously? webTitle: DoCoMo to start 4G four years early

fields.headline: DoCoMo to start 4G four years early
fields.trailText: Japanese mobile phone company NTT DoCoMo is planning to bring forward the launch of its fourth-generation transmission networks by as much as four years.
fields.body:
Japanese mobile phone company NTT DoCoMo is planning to bring forward the launch of its fourth-generation transmission networks by as much as four years.

The company, already ahead of the pack in the race to launch 3G mobile phones, is reported to be aiming to start rolling out the 4G service in 2006 instead of 2010.

3G mobile phones, which promise fast data transmission, CD-quality sound and video services, are due to be launched in May by DoCoMo and are under development by a number of other global telecoms carriers.

The 4G phones will be able to receive high-resolution films and TV programmes and feature ID applications that would effectively turn them into proof of identification.

DoCoMo said in December it would tie up with Hewlett-Packard Co to develop multimedia delivery and network applications over 4G wireless broadband networks.

The phones will be able to transmit data at a rate of more than 20 megabits per second - or 2,000 times faster than existing mobile phones and 10 times the rates of 3G phones.

Meanwhile, Japan looks set to be the world's first testing ground for high-speed 3G services.

DoCoMo, whose name means "anywhere" in Japanese, is betting that its gamble to be the world's first to begin 3G services on May 31 will pay off.

webTitle: Japan and US expected to cut rates

fields.headline: Japan and US expected to cut rates
fields.standfirst:
Bankers planning concerted action in response to market decline

Special report: Japan
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Bankers planning concerted action in response to market decline.
fields.body:
The world's two biggest economies are expected to cut interest rates this week in an effort to prevent the turmoil in financial markets triggering a global recession.

The Bank of Japan is likely to lead the way today by returning to its zero-interest-rate policy followed tomorrow by a cut by the US Federal Reserve.

City analysts believe that the Fed is poised to slash its benchmark lending rate, currently 5.5%, by at least a half a percentage point. Since the beginning of the year the Fed has cut rates by a full percentage point.

Rate cuts should help calm jittery markets. In the US the Dow Jones and the Nasdaq lost 8% last week. In the same period, The FTSE 100 lost 355 points to 5,562.8, wiping more than £80bn off the value of the market. Traders fear it could be pushed as low as 5,250 before the situation improves.

The economics team at HSBC in London said that while the Fed did not target the stock market directly, it would want to prevent crashing share prices feeding through to further declines in consumer and business confidence.

Today's expected easing of Japanese monetary policy will coincide with a meeting between the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, and George Bush in Washington, which will be dominated the deteriorating outlook for global growth. Last week secretary of state Colin Powell gave a frank assessment of the situation to Congress, warning that Japan's fragile economy could pose a security threat to the United States.

Even though recent economic data from America have been mixed, share dealers have been panicked by wave after wave of profit warnings from global hi-tech outfits such as Dell, Intel, Yahoo!, Cisco Systems and Motorola.

While policymakers are not unhappy about the pricking of the hi-tech stock bubble, they are concerned that it is threatening the real economy.

There is particular concern about Japan, the world's second largest economy, where many banks still carry bad loans on their books and their financial difficulties are being compounded by falling share prices which further erode their already shaky asset bases.

In Tokyo yesterday, politicians piled pressure on the Bank of Japan.

The BOJ, to the fury of politicians, abandoned its 18-month experiment with free money last August when it raised the overnight rate to 0.25%.

Fearing that the US slowdown could damage confidence in the UK, the Bank of England trimmed its key lending rate by a quarter point to 5.75% in February.

webTitle: 3G costs too high, firms tell minister

fields.headline: 3G costs too high, firms tell minister
fields.standfirst: Vodafone and One2One press for concessions to ease roll-out and licence debt
fields.trailText: Vodafone and One2One press for concessions to ease roll-out and licence debt.
fields.body:
Vodafone and One2One have complained to ministers about the crippling costs of acquiring third-generation mobile phone licences and are appealing for help.

In separate meetings, the companies - which together paid in total £10bn to the Treasury - are said to have asked for changes to their licence agreements to ease their debt burdens. One change could see the life of licences - at present 20 years - extended.

They are also thought to have asked for assurances from the government that planning regulations will not delay the erection of some 50,000 3G masts.

Vodafone's chief executive, Chris Gent, is said to have met Patricia Hewitt, the e-commerce minister, two weeks ago to discuss the issue. Meanwhile Harris Jones, managing director of One2One, is understood to have held talks with the telecoms regulator Dave Edmonds and the DTI, Ms Hewitt's department.

Rival firms have already admitted they are considering joining forces to build the next generation of mobile networks in an attempt to reduce some of the huge costs involved.

Many influential players have also warned telecoms firms about the burden that 3G licences placed them under. Last autumn Mario Monti, the EC's anti-monopoly chief, warned operators that he would not allow firms to pass on the "astronomical" costs of buying licences for so-called 3G services to the public.

Analysts point out that only last week many smaller firms such as Viatel were close to being rated "junk" stock. Many fear that bigger operators could also be dragged down by the cost of the licences and building new networks.

Five 3G licences were auc tioned by the government last spring at the height of the technology boom. The auction, conceived by Professor Ken Binmore of University College London, raised £22.5bn, more than four times as much as expected.

It was aimed at making the firms pay what it was thought licences were worth rather than risk short-changing the taxpayer by giving them away too cheaply. Prof Binmore said the firms rather than civil servants were in the best position to decide their value.

Since the auction the 3G euphoria has evaporated and the successful bidders are thought to be concerned about their ability to recoup the costs of rolling out the service.

Vodafone paid £5.96bn for the largest licence open to an existing operator and One2One paid £4bn.

While refusing to comment on the talks with the government, Mr Jones said: "Yes, I would have liked to have paid less for the licence. We are now totally focused on how to get the revenues back."

He predicted it would take 10 years to recoup the costs.

The new services, offering everything from fast internet access and mobile e-commerce to video clips, games and entertainment, are due to start rolling out in 2002.

A DTI spokesman said Ms Hewitt frequently met people from the telecoms market but added: "We are not aware of any discussions on this subject." Vodafone declined to comment saying: "There is a lot of rumour and speculation at the moment."

In December last year One2One failed in a high court claim to delay payment to the Exchequer, saying that some of its competitors had not been forced to hand over the cost of licence immediately.

One2One claimed it could have saved £80m in interest payments if it could have delayed payment to the Treasury.

webTitle: Big investors call BT to account

fields.headline: Big investors call BT to account
fields.trailText: BT will come under pressure this week to explain how it intends to cut its £30bn debt mountain by a third.
fields.body:
BT will come under pressure this week to explain how it intends to cut its £30bn debt mountain by a third.

The former state-owned phone company is to meet its biggest shareholders to try to restore confidence after seeing its share price drop to its lowest for over two years. BT is reviewing options ranging from a possible £5bn rights issue to a full demerger of BT Wireless, its mobile business.

City analysts believe that if BT decides to go to its shareholders for a deeply discounted rights issue the process will be so "humiliating" that investors could ask for the early retirement of Sir Iain Vallance, BT's chairman, in return for supporting the issue. He and chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield have been under pressure to resign to appease larger shareholders.

The company is weighed down by £30bn of debt - equal to three quarters of its stock market valuation - because of its investment in third-generation mobile licences and in overseas acquisitions.

BT wants to keep its credit rating; any downgrade would cost it an extra £200m a year in interest payments.

Philip Hampton, the recently appointed finance director, has publicly stated that BT must reduce its debt by £10bn by the end of this year.

Mr Hampton is reported to be against spinning off BT Wireless after the recent poor performance of Orange shares. Under his plan, BT Wireless shares would be distributed to the company's shareholders.

The group had hoped to pay back some of its loans by selling off its non-core assets and demerging others as separate listed firms but the collapse in technology and telecoms stocks means it would struggle to raise significant sums.

Market conditions are also likely to scupper plans to float Yell, BT's Yellow Pages unit.

The company's share price has tumbled from £15 to just above £5 in the past year.

BT yesterday refused to comment on what it called the "speculation and rumour" surrounding the future of its senior executives, but a spokesperson said: "We can't tell you when a decision will be made, but all the options are being considered."

A decision will have to be taken soon if the company is to meet its end of year deadline.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer | Sunday Business | Sunday Telegraph | Mail on Sunday
fields.body:
Observer

Steel maker Corus discarded a union plan, designed to safeguard jobs at its UK plants, three weeks before its own deadlines for an alternative rescue option. Michael Leahy, general secretary of the ISTC, announced plans for industrial action, saying the company would be forced to "listen to the arguments of force".

Sir Richard Branson has hired Peter Norris, former chief executive of Barings, as an adviser to his Virgin business empire.

Sunday Business

British water and electricity company United Utilities is considering a £4bn break-up of the group that could return £1bn to shareholders.

Royal Bank of Scotland is being linked to a friendly merger with Ireland's largest financial group, Allied Irish Banks. A tie-up would create a financial services group worth more than £46bn.

Sunday Telegraph

Clear Channel Communications, the world's biggest outdoor media group, is preparing a bid through its SFX entertainment division for Wembley Arena and its accompanying exhibition centres. The company is keen to link up with a property group to launch the bid, which would value the arena at around £100m.

The Phone People, a privately owned group of mobile phone retailers, has gone into administration following months of boardroom disputes. The chain, which owns 125 stores across the UK, has appointed Kidson Impey as administrators.

Homebase, which was acquired by Schroder Ventures for £750m in December, is expected to announce the appointment of Rob Templeman as chief executive. Mr Templeman is a former chief executive of Harveys Furnishing.

New Star Asset Management, the company founded last year by John Duffield, the former chief executive of Jupiter, has announced its interest in Aberdeen Asset Management. AXA and ABN Amro are also believed to be considering a bid for the group, which is the largest independent manager in Scotland.

Trinity Mirror has rejected an approach from an investment bank tied to Kelvin Mackenzie, chairman and chief executive of Wireless Group, which wanted to broker a merger. The deal would have valued Wireless at about £200m.

Donald Daft, chief executive of Coca-Cola, has announced that the company has completed trials of a scheme allowing the drink to be piped into its customers' homes. The innovation mixes Coke's secret syrup with carbonated water before pumping it out through a regular tap.

IoS

Domenico de Sole, head of the Gucci fashion empire, is expected to announce the $1bn (£700m) takeover of the designer label Valentino. HdP, the luxury goods group which owns Valentino, has not announced its intention of selling the clothing label, but analysts say it wanted to concentrate on its Fila sports clothing brand.

Institutional investors in the retail group Kingfisher have increased pressure on chief executive Sir Geoff Mulcahy to announce a date for his retirement and to name a successor.

Mail on Sunday

The competition commission is to launch a fresh attack on the four major high street banks over their dominance of the small business market.

The move may force Barclays, HSBC, Lloyds TSB and Natwest to sell off branches.

An influential report by Ernst & Young's Item Club has claimed that Britain's weakening ties with the US could help protect it from any big fall on Wall Street.

webTitle: Gats is no service to anyone

fields.headline: Gats is no service to anyone
fields.standfirst: Special report: World Trade Organisation
fields.trailText: Don't sign any contract until you've read the small print. This is especially true for international trade agreements that affect the lives of millions.
fields.body:
Don't sign any contract until you've read the small print. This is especially true for international trade agreements that affect the lives of millions. Their core provisions are hidden behind a welter of acronyms and legal phrases. In the Guardian debate on February 26, Mike Moore, director general of the World Trade Organisation, said that concerns about Gats, or the general agreement on trade in services, were "lies and distortions". Let's look at the fine print.

Gats aims for "progressive liberalisation". What does this mean? Governments agree to remove more and more regulations or restrictions on foreign service firms. Although there are temporary exceptions allowed, the whole thrust of Gats is to remove them. And it is a one-way process. WTO officials have described Gats as a means to lock in liberalisation and make it irreversible.

At a time when governments are questioning the impact of gung-ho liberalisation, this is a dangerous provision. Gats would lock them into these policies, denying the opportunity for democratic debate on alternative policies.

Even countries that have considerable experience in regulating service sectors are seeing the dangers of ill-conceived privatisation. Gats would mean that even public opinion or a change in government would not be able to reverse failed policies. It is a denial of democratic rights.

Gats does not, as Mr Moore claims, allow countries to choose only the sectors they want to open up. Present negotiations aim to change the structure of Gats so that rules on one sector apply to related sectors. Gats also has provisions that apply to all service sectors. The rules on domestic regulation aim to remove "unnecessary restrictions" on trade and investment in services. Who decides what is unnecessary? The WTO.

Mr Moore claims there is adequate protection under Gats for health and the environment. Yet WTO rules have already been used to overturn restrictions on trade to protect dolphins and turtles, block tobacco and hormone-injected beef imports and support Caribbean banana farmers.

What are the criteria applied by the WTO? This is the subject of talks that recommence this month. Negotiators have rejected a broad definition of "necessary to protect the public interest". The criterion already included is that any measure must be "no more burdensome than necessary" on foreign service providers. That could be used to challenge national and local government rules.

At its core, Gats gives foreign firms rights that are elevated above other aims. As the European commission has said: "Gats is not just something that exists between governments. It is first and foremost an instrument for the benefit of business."

Mr Moore is right to say Gats excludes services supplied by governments. But Gats does include those services supplied commercially or in competition with the private sector. This describes an increasingly large proportion of "public" service sectors.

More broadly, he suggests that WTO members are eager to negotiate on Gats. But few poor countries have the capacity to get a good deal. And they are likely to make commitments under Gats that are not in their long-term interest as a price for reform of the EU's common agricultural policy. The priority for the WTO must be to fix existing unfair agreements and negotiating processes.

Mr Moore's claims of the vast benefits of liberalisation are a based on trickle-down economics. More evidence would be helpful. Developing nations have been calling for a full assessment of the experience from services liberalisation in the past. It hasn't been done.

Unfair rules that prioritise the interests of firms are a recipe for exploitation. A strong campaign on Gats is building around the world. A motion on it in the Scottish parliament is supported by most MSPs, and 150 Westminster MPs have signed a motion. Last week, the international development committee called for an independent commission on Gats. If Mr Moore can't read the fine print, it is fortunate for democracy there are others who can.

webTitle: Monarch casts doubt on sport of kings

fields.headline: Queen questions racing resumption
fields.standfirst:
Monarch casts doubt on sport of kings

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Monarch casts doubt on sport of kings.
fields.body:
The Queen has written to racing industry authorities to ask whether racing should continue in light of the foot and mouth crisis.

The Queen, patron of the Jockey Club, wrote to the British Horseracing Board a week ago asking them to consider carefully whether racing should continue. Her intervention follows the donation of £500,000 by the Prince of Wales last week to help farmers stricken by the crisis.

Racing was suspended for seven days at the beginning of the crisis, but resumed, with a slightly truncated programme, after government scientists gave it the all clear.

Yesterday a Buckingham Palace spokeswoman said "any view she has on the matter would be expressed privately".

However Tristram Ricketts, secretary general of the British Horseracing Board, confirmed the Queen had become involved. "Last week Her Majesty The Queen expressed her concern that racing should consider its response to the foot and mouth outbreak very carefully, but has not asked for horse racing to stop," he said.

"In view of the Queen's personal involvement in racing, the BHB has kept Her Majesty fully informed of racing's response to the outbreak."

It appeared yesterday that she had not consulted any of her trainers before writing to the board. The Queen's 18 horses are spread between Sir Michael Stoute at Newmarket and Richard Hannon and Roger Charlton in Wiltshire, and it is business as usual this week, according to Mr Hannon.

"Her Majesty's three-year-old Princes Street is due to run at Doncaster on Saturday and I will be declaring him for the race tomorrow. No one has instructed me otherwise," he said.

Veterinary advice has won over a number of racing professionals who felt it was wrong to continue racing in the current climate.

Ferdy Murphy, who trains over 100 horses at Middleham in North Yorkshire, shut up shop fearing his horses might bring the disease to the neighbouring farming community.

However, he had five runners at the Huntingdon meeting last Thursday and said: "I have talked to everyone I can about it and Peter Webbon, the Jockey Club's chief vet, has convinced me that we won't be doing any harm."

fields.headline: Policeman killed by Eta bomb
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: A car bomb planted by the Basque separatist group Eta killed a Spanish police officer in the north-eastern holiday resort of Roses, near Girona in Catalonia, yesterday as the separatists began a pre-Easter campaign in tourist areas.
fields.body:
A car bomb planted by the Basque separatist group Eta killed a Spanish police officer in the north-eastern holiday resort of Roses, near Girona in Catalonia, yesterday as the separatists began a pre-Easter campaign in tourist areas.

Santos Santamaria was killed by flying shrapnel while trying to clear people from the area where Eta had planted a car bomb. Three other officers were slightly injured.

The car had been placed in front of the Montecarlo Hotel near the seafront at Roses.

A few hours later bomb disposal experts exploded a car 250 miles south at the Gandia resort, near Valencia, which contained a 50kg bomb.

The second car bomb was parked in front of the Hotel Riviera in Gandia, which was not due to open until Easter. Police evacuated residents from a nearby block of flats and diners at four restaurants.

In both cases a caller claiming to be from Eta had warned that the bombs were set to explode. Police said the Roses bomb had exploded seven minutes before the time given by the caller and that the Eta unit responsible for both bombs was probably based in France.

The bombs sparked anger from separatists in Catalonia, who said violence by Eta had become an obstacle in their own fight for independence.

"Eta has now declared itself to be an enemy of the Catalan people and of our own right to decide how and when we solve Catalonia's own problems," said Josep Lluis Carod-Rivera of the Catalan Republican Left party.

fields.headline: Macedonian rebels recruit and advance
fields.standfirst:
Security forces trapped in their bunkers

Special report: Crisis in the Balkans
fields.trailText: Macedonian security forces made further artillery and mortar strikes around the country's second city Tetovo yesterday, but there were signs that the rebels were taking control of more of the high ground above the city and erecting road blocks.
fields.byline: Nicholas Wood  in Selce and agencies in Tetovo
fields.body:
Macedonian security forces made further artillery and mortar strikes around the country's second city Tetovo yesterday, but there were signs that the rebels were taking control of more of the high ground above the city and erecting road blocks.

Government forces fired 120mm mortar rounds over a mountain ridge in an attempt to reach the insurgent positions further back.

The National Liberation Army (NLA) rebel force said it was recruiting thousands of men throughout the country. At rebel headquarters in the village of Selce, three and half miles from Tetovo, a commander said dozens of young men were lining up to join his group.

"Our number have increased since the fighting began. In four days we have had two hundred volunteers, but there have been two thousand new soldiers joining the NLA throughout Macedonia.

"Our organisation is in all the Albanian towns, all over Macedonia. The Albanian people have their army now. If we mobilise, all the youth will be ready to join."

Evidence of the NLA's growing numbers could be seen on the outskirts of Tetovo, where armed men in civilian clothes stopped traffic from entering the town and cut down trees to block the roads to nearby Albanian villages.

Two days ago Macedonian police took up positions in the area, between the villages of Licets and Sipkovica, but yesterday it slipped out of their control.

The police have now withdrawn a mile and half down the road, well within the city area.

"Not only will we try and protect our positions but we are going to expand them, and take more territory," the NLA commander said.

But he admitted that his forces had suffered casualties in the main area of fighting, near the village of Larce.

"We have had many soldiers slightly wounded. One soldier has been killed by a sniper. He was shot in the leg. He was a little bit far away and nobody could help him. He bled to death."

The rebels have urged Albanian citizens of Macedonia to take up arms and join their struggle, but many remain suspicious of the NLA and its motives.

"I don't know what to say about them. I do not know even if we can trust them or not," said Shefik Azizi, 25, after guiding a group of fellow ethnic Albanians fleeing the threat of violence into neighbouring Albania.

In some areas of Tetovo yesterday no more than 50 metres separated the government troops, huddled in fortified positions on the outskirts, and rebel units hidden on the scrub-covered slopes.

Near the old bazaar district residents hid behind walls and cowered in doorways during sporadic gun battles.

A little girl cradled a pink stuffed rabbit, covering its ears during the gunfire.

The security forces were unable to leave their fortified bunkers. Rebels control the few roads into the steep mountains around the Popova Shapka ski centre, near the Kosovan border, and were on the watch behind roadblocks of branches.

A bit further into the city, in the Slav neighbourhood of Koltuk, about 30 people gathered for a Christian Orthodox service at Saint Nicholas church.

They held bunches of dried sage during the chanting of the lenten liturgy, drowned out by the sounds of battle half a mile away.

"Pray for the Christians of Macedonia and especially here in Tetovo," the priest intoned.

The sharp smell of the burning woodland carried by on a north wind drifted into the church and mixed with the odour of incense.

"I don't often go to church," said Dimitri Kolovski, who winced at each blast from the Macedonian gunners.

"But how can you not pray at a time like this?"

Outside, people packed their cars with essential belongings and headed away from the main Slav enclave in Tetovo.

Hundreds were reported to have fled from Tetovo and Skopje, the capital, among them about 350 ethnic Macedonians who escaped to southern area of Serbia.
