webTitle: Exit polls give left the edge in Paris election

fields.headline: Exit polls give left the edge in Paris election
fields.trailText: A page in the history of Paris looked set to turn last night as exit polls put the left ahead in an agonisingly tight race for the French capital, under conservative control for 130 years.
fields.body:
A page in the history of Paris looked set to turn last night as exit polls put the left ahead in an agonisingly tight race for the French capital, under conservative control for 130 years.

Projections by the pollsters Sofres and Ipsos gave a socialist-led coalition between 79 and 90 seats on the 163-seat Paris city council, against 73 to 84 for the right, while a rival organisation, CSA, predicted the left-wing alliance would capture 88 seats.

On a night when many of France's provincial towns swung to the right, the vote in the country's second-biggest city, Lyon, looked even closer than in Paris, with the Socialists again forecast to emerge victorious by just two or three seats.

Although the results were unlikely to be confirmed until this morning, several thousand champagne-swilling Socialist supporters began gathering outside Paris city hall by late evening to celebrate.

The French capital has not been run by a leftwing council since the uprising of the 1871 Paris Commune, and throughout the 1980s was so dominated by President Jacques Chirac's Gaullist RPR party that all 20 of its arrondissements were under conservative control.

Ahead of presidential and parliamentary elections in 2002, its capture by the left would deal a blow to the French president, who is struggling to defend himself against an array of corruption scandals dating from his 18 years as the city's mayor.

If his victory is confirmed, the unassuming Socialist candidate for mayor, Bertrand Delanoe, will become the first publicly-declared homosexual politician to hold a post of national importance in France.

Last Sunday's first round of voting to elect some 36,000 mayors around France saw all eyes focused on the conservative Paris, Lyon and Toulouse.

In the capital, a feud between the rightist candidate, Philippe Séguin, and the outgoing mayor, Jean Tiberi, threatened to hand victory to the Socialists.

In Toulouse, the Socialists and Greens appeared to have narrowly lost in their bid to upset the rightist candidate, Philippe Douste-Blazy.

The run-off was not exclusively good news for the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin: The high-profile Socialist labour minister Elisabeth Guigou in Avignon, the European affairs minister Pierre Moscovici in Montbeliard and the education minister Jack Lang in Blois all seemed headed for defeat.

The vote also looked bleak for the Communists. Sofres projected that one party incumbent, Alain Clary, would fall to the RPR in Nimes .

webTitle: Four pop fans die in Jakarta crush

fields.headline: Four pop fans die in Jakarta crush
fields.trailText: Four teenage girls died yesterday after collapsing in a crush of 2,000 fans who had swamped a shopping centre in Jakarta to get the autographs of the British boy band a1.
fields.body:
Four teenage girls died yesterday after collapsing in a crush of 2,000 fans who had swamped a shopping centre in Jakarta to get the autographs of the British boy band a1.

Four other girls who fainted were taken to hospital. They were discharged after receiving treatment.

A spokeswoman for Ben, Paul, Christian and Mark, who were voted Best Newcomer band at the 2001 Brit awards, said the boys were "in severe shock" last night.

Lala Hamid, the promotions director for Sony Music Entertainment Indonesia, said: "The deaths were a tragic accident, beyond our control. The fans were so excited, they hadn't eaten or drunk anything for hours. When the pushing started they just were not able to cope."

She insisted that Sony, the band's promoters during the Asian tour, had taken sufficient precautions. "We deployed 50 of our own security guards at the record shop in addition to the mall's staff. That had been enough for other bands."

However a similar signing session for a1 in Manila on an earlier leg of the tour was cancelled after 20,000 screaming fans turned up. The organisers had expected only 1,000.

The fans started gathering at the Taman Anggrek mall in west Jakarta at 6am yesterday, three hours before the shopping centre opened and eight hours before a1 was due to appear.

Ten minutes after the group arrived, just before 2pm, the pushing had got so bad Ms Hamid decided to halt the event. Only about 30 fans had got autographs.

"I said that if we did not stop many others would have fainted," she said. "So we left the venue having called a doctor [to tend to the eight girls who had fainted]."

The band then sang three songs in a nightclub before performing at a TV station. "We only heard that the girls had died during the live TV performance," Ms Hamid said.

webTitle: Home Office may monitor use of 'date rape' drug

fields.headline: Home Office may monitor use of 'date rape' drug
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Britain may introduce monitoring of the use of a recreational "club drug" that has been linked to date rape and four deaths following mounting concern over its safety and the role of organised crime in its production.
fields.body:
Britain may introduce monitoring of the use of a recreational "club drug" that has been linked to date rape and four deaths following mounting concern over its safety and the role of organised crime in its production.

The Home Office has so far decided not to add GHB to the list of controlled drugs such as ecstasy, cocaine and cannabis but European drug authorities are increasingly worried by its potential to dope people via spiked drinks so they do not resist sexual assaults.

They also believe its recreational use in liquid form or powder poses significant risks to health because of the fine line between the relaxation and euphoria the drug can induce and loss of consciousness or irreversible coma. Britain accounts for more than a third of the 11 deaths associated with the drug since 1995 and has among the highest number of overdose cases reported.

GHB is legally used in much of Europe as an anaesthetic or for treatment of alcoholics but its street names such as "liquid ecstasy" and "easy lay" illustrate its darker side, warns the Lisbon-based EU drugs agency.

European ministers have agreed new checks on its use before they consider whether EU-wide controls are necessary. The Home Office said its advisers on the misuse of drugs did not think there was enough evidence of widespread misuse to merit controls on GHB. It has however agreed to increased monitoring and drug education programmes aimed at young people.

But the Roofie Foundation , which runs a telephone helpline for date rape victims, estimates that as many as 40% of the 500 date rape victims a year who call for help have been secretly given GHB because it is colourless, odourless and difficult to taste making it easier to disguise than some alternatives.

Founder Graham Rhodes welcomed the EU moves although he admitted it was difficult to know the exact extent of the use of GHB, because "Our victims are the last people to know what their have been spiked with, but from talking to them, my gut feeling is it is on the increase. I think this is the tip of the iceberg."

Many callers rang months after an incident. They did not remember what had happened and might wake up in someone else's bed, a back street or in the countryside. "Some are quite calm and collected. Some are angry. Some are traumatised. All are seeking a solution as to what happened."

Six EU states , Belgium, Denmark, France, Ireland , Italy and Sweden , already control GHB, which can easily be made in the home, through misuse of drugs legislation.

The agency is worried both by the "kitchen sink" industry and by promotion of GHB through internet sites for helping people get to sleep, mood enhancement, bodybuilding, anti-aging and improving sexual enjoyment. Its head Georges Estievenart said: "There's a strong feeling among member states that GHB should be tightly monitored to provide more insight into the spread of its abuse."

webTitle: Transplant patient in coma after overdose blunder

fields.headline: Transplant patient in coma after overdose blunder
fields.standfirst: Former nurse given too much insulin while on intensive care ward
fields.trailText: A former nurse was in a coma yesterday after being given an insulin overdose following a liver transplant operation.
fields.body:
A former nurse was in a coma yesterday after being given an insulin overdose following a liver transplant operation.

Teresita Cruz, 56, was recovering after surgery at the Queen Elizabeth hospital in Birmingham when the accident happened.

Family members said an insulin pump regulating her blood sugar level was not monitored for eight hours. They added that the overdose would leave Ms Cruz, who lives in Leicester, brain damaged if she emerged from her coma.

Yesterday the hospital issued a "full and unreserved apology" to her family and said an investigation was in progress.

The incident follows other hospital blunders this year. In February a senior consultant at the Royal Sussex county hospital in Brighton was suspended after injecting a local anaesthetic into a vein of a patient rather than his spine. That mistake came a week after the death of Wayne Jowett, aged 18, who had an anti-cancer drug accidentally injected into his spine instead of a vein at the Queen's Medical Centre in Nottingham. Two junior doctors were suspended.

Speaking from the hospital, Ms Cruz's sister Lota Hopewell described the accident as "awful, just awful".

"It is killing me to see her this way," she said. "It is killing all of us. Just a few days ago she looked well, she was getting better from her operation and looking forward to a new life. She gave 30 years of her life to the NHS as a nurse and this is how she is repaid.

"I don't know what will happen. The doctors are saying she might die, but I can't give up on her. I will keep fighting for her."

Mrs Hopewell's husband Derrol said the family could not understand how the overdose was given while Ms Cruz was in intensive care. "We just can't believe what has happened," he said. "Teresita was looking forward to a new life after the transplant.

"She had the operation and was recovering well. She had regained consciousness and was getting better all the time. Now they don't know if she will wake up, or if she does, how bad the damage will be."

Mr Hopewell said he was first aware there had been complications when he received a phone call from a relative. "My brother-in-law Rico had been called into the office by the consultant.

"They said the insulin pump had not been monitored for eight hours and she had received an overdose. At the moment they are saying a large part of her brain is dead, but we don't know what the outcome will be."

He said no one could understand how the overdose could have been given to a patient on an intensive care ward. "The whole system was a failure."

A spokeswoman for the hospital said: "We have offered a full and unreserved apology to Teresita and her family for what has happened. We have got an investigation ongoing and the results of that will be out some time next week.

"Teresita was on insulin, and it looks as if she received more than she should have done. We don't know at the moment whether that was due to human error or machine error.

"We are talking to the family about the best way forward for her."

webTitle: Analysis: tourist industry faces devastating losses

fields.headline: Green, unpleasant land
fields.standfirst:
Reports of the costs of the foot and mouth outbreak have concentrated on agriculture, but the tourist industry faces devastating losses

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Reports of the costs of the foot and mouth outbreak have concentrated on agriculture, but the tourist industry faces devastating losses.
fields.body:
Tourists, accustomed to a Gainsborough vision of the English countryside in which all is pastoral peace, have had their view shattered. The order turns out to have been an illusion; with the arrival of foot and mouth, a hellish scene of fire and slaughter has erupted instead, more Hieronymus Bosch than 18th-century landscape portrait. They have cancelled their holidays in droves.

Americans have decided it is safer to spend the £20m a week they usually bring to the UK elsewhere. British day trippers who bring £9m a year to country businesses have melted away too. The English Tourist Council estimates that the tourist trade is losing £250m a week.

Farmers meanwhile are losing perhaps £60m a week, and people are beginning to question whether the smoke from the funeral pyres has blinded us to the economic realities. With draconian restrictions on movement, and policies which have effectively closed down the countryside, has the government been concentrating its efforts on the wrong people?

Tourism generates about 4% of GDP, while agriculture (arable included) makes about 1.5% of GDP. Take out poultry, which is not affected by the disease, and the total value of livestock from British farms was about £4bn in 1999.

Takings from tourism in March are usually worth more than £700m, rising to about £1.2bn in April, but advanced bookings are down by about a third. In Cumbria alone, pubs, shops, hotels, restaurants and other businesses that cater to the tourist trade are losing £8m and 350 jobs a week.

In fact if you start to look at jobs, the response to the crisis can look even more distorted. Agriculture accounts for just 2% of employment in rural districts. As the chart shows most people in the country work not on the land but in leisure and distribution (21%), public services (28%), banking and finance (11%) or manufacturing (17%).

Yet the government has focused on minimising the impact on agriculture. It has negotiated with Brussels to bring forward £154m of European Union agricultural support payments, 80% of which will be paid by UK taxpayers. And farmers will have the lifeline of compensation. By the middle of last week 69 claims worth £6.7m had been authorised by the Ministry of Agriculture (Maff). The potential claims from those who have either suffered confirmed outbreaks of foot and mouth or whose herds have been in dangerous contact with the disease were standing at about 365 at the end of last week. Compensation for these could be £36m or more. Now that the government has decided to cull all animals within a 3km radius of infected flocks, these payments could quadruple.

So far the talk of support to other rural businesses devastated by the epidemic extends as far as a holiday from rates, which might cost £25m.

But somehow all these figures miss the point. The paradox of British farming is that although it earns a tiny fraction of national income, it occupies 75% of the national space. Urbanites who argue that farmers these days are little more than custodians (and none too environmentally friendly ones at that) of theme park Britain fail to understand the extent to which our sense of identity is invested in the pastoral landscape.

The grazing of animals has acquired symbolic meaning. The English landscape is a tamed and cultivated one, shaped over centuries by men and animals, medieval drove roads, by generations of ploughing and hill farming and the enclosures. It is all that which attracts the tourists. Despite being one of the most industrialised and urbanised countries in the world, we cling to agricultural rituals because they give us our sense of place and season.

The gap between bucolic idyll and reality has always existed. Gainsborough's Mr and Mrs Andrews may have sat in prosperous harmony atop their Capability Brown style parkland, but even in the 18th century writers knew the truth to be that the country was a harsh and dirty place. (Tobias Smollett's Humphry Clinker hated his journeys through the countryside; in real life the coaches of the rich had window blinds decorated with elegant urban scenes to shield their occupants from sight of the mire.)

Modern rural reality may be hell, with warehouses selling discount electrical goods on ring roads and farms with cattle sheds the size of factories. But we maintain the illusion and fight to preserve it because our social history has been bound up with it since earliest times. That is why an agricultural crisis, with farmers traumatised by the loss of their flocks, has so much more power to move than the closure of black coal pits or ugly car factories.

The sentiment is not just stubborn habit. Tourism, leisure and farming are inextricably linked. As the Country Land and Business Association put it so graphically, "people don't go for a picnic looking over a field of sugar beet". They like to see meadows where sheep may safely graze. That is one reason why those representing the tourist industry have been so reluctant to criticise Maff's priorities.

With the new policy of mass slaughter, up to 500,000 animals may have to be killed. That would still be only a fraction of the 35m or so pigs, sheep and cattle sent to the abattoirs in the UK each year for food, but the prospect of shooting swaths of the national herd touches many more than the farmers who mourn them directly.

 Felicity Lawrence is the Guardian's consumer affairs correspondent.

fields.headline: Speed traps and goldmines
fields.standfirst: This week's number: nine
fields.trailText: This week's number: nine
fields.body:
L ast week I was told I was not eligible to hire a car. I had pariah status, the man behind the counter sneered. There were nine points on my licence and the rental company deemed me an impossible insurance risk. All nine points were imposed after I was caught by speeding cameras, snapped doing a combined total of 20mph above the limit on three separate occasions. They are stricter than Anne Robinson, the cameras round our way, particularly the one that lurks up behind a tree on a fast stretch of road leading out of town. It has done me twice and last week caught my wife out. She has now joined me as a member of the criminal classes, picking up a fine and three points for driving past the lynx-eyed grey box at 37mph at 10.30pm on a Saturday night. Kerching! Another £40 for the speed police. And we're not alone. From Princess Anne to Geri Halliwell via virtually everyone I know, we are all being flashed and fined the moment our foot gets a little heavy on the pedal.

Not that mine does anymore. I have noticed that my driving habits have changed entirely as a result of being caught. Just one more indiscretion away from a ban, I have now turned into the slowest man on the road, pootling along as if on a Sunday outing, carefully adhering to limits at all times, hitting the break at the approach of any turn in the road, just in case a camera lurks round the corner. Which is surely the point of the beasts, isn't it? To stop us tearing through residential areas, to make us think, to reduce accidents.

Well, apparently not. A new and sophisticated camera in stalled in Nottingham has just been deemed a failure by the local authority which had great hopes for it. A super-sensitive machine, it promised, according to the manufacturer, to pick up every law-breaker the moment they strayed above the limit. Expensive to buy and maintain it might have been, but traffic administrators in the city swooned at the thought of the profits to be trousered as it trained its all-prying lens on passing motors. Except that drivers quickly learned to slow down in its vicinity.

This was a good thing, you might think. Serious accidents on the road near it dropped 52% in six months as average speeds were cut by 5mph. However, that wasn't really what the council wanted. It was after fines. It was income they craved - the £700,000 a year they had been led to believe they would bank. And when only nine drivers a day were caught when the council was anticipating 60, the expensive cameras were removed, giving the motorists of Nottingham licence to speed once more. Which entirely confirms what some of us always suspected was the purpose of these mechanical tax collectors: it is money, not lives, that counts.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Snakes alive!
fields.trailText: Snakes alive!
fields.body:
Thorpe Hamlet, Norfolk

It was extraordinary to reflect, as I lifted the lid on my favourite jumble of old scrap metal, that the snowman in our garden had only melted five days earlier. Yet there they were, the first snakes of spring, newly emerged from hibernation.

Where the metal sheet had lain all winter the vegetation was a sickly rectangle of insipid yellow. Against such a lifeless colour the brown and blackish zigzag patterns of the adders appeared all the more startling. Arranged in perfect coils, the snakes looked like some weird perennial bloom that had just pushed up in the hothouse conditions beneath their metal cloche. Although they seem to have nothing whatsoever in common with the virginal innocence of snowdrops, the snakes share with the flowers a symbolic status as our earliest sign of spring.

The adder is one of the world's most cold-tolerant snakes. It has been recorded at altitudes of up to 3000m in the Swiss Alps and occurs in the Russian and Scandinavian taiga beyond the Arctic Circle to 68 N, which must be the northerly limit for any reptile.

It can emerge from the hibernaculum as soon as the average midday temperature rises to 8 C, and in southern Europe the period of dormancy can be as little as three months. At the extreme northern edge of its range, however, there may be as many as 275 days of inactivity. It means that this relatively long-lived creature can spend three-quarters of its life sleeping.

One cannot help wondering, as these creatures lie coiled together in their mysterious subterranean chamber, what dreams disturb those long months of slumber once March comes round again?

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Lamacq Live | Evening Concert | Wild Europe
fields.body:
A new documentary strand in Lamacq Live (8.0pm, Radio 1) examines key influences on the music business. Given the recent wedding and all that, Madonna was always likely to be among the first. She clinched it by laying on an exclusive interview. If the singer has changed the pop business, it has certainly returned the favour. Her 50-odd singles in the British charts have brought in a fair chunk of her $650m.

Natalie Wheen is also preoccupied with musical influences. In the Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM) she recalls some of the splendid work encouraged by the Venetian Republic's 17th century rulers. After a cloth-eared Duke of Mantua sacked Monteverdi, the Venetians snapped him up to spend his remaining 30 years at St Mark's cathedral. And, when the city fathers charitably enrolled orphan girls as music students at the Ospedalle della Pieta's conservertoire, they also had the nous to make Vivaldiz the music master. The result was hundreds of works specially written for the girls.

The dazzling range of fungi displayed by supermarkets may not be there much longer. In Wild Europe (9.0pm, Radio 4) Lionel Kelleway questions whether this exploding international trade can possibly be sustained. where mushroom gathering in eastern Europe was once a family enterprise, it is now a vast agribusiness, and there is little hope that the fungi can replace themselves at the required pace.

webTitle: Office hours: Secs in the City

fields.headline: Secs in the City
fields.trailText: There are certain qualities that the average PA should possess. A good typing speed, friendly phone manner and total discretion are probably pretty much essential - and I can claim almost one of these. There are times, however, when one's colleagues expect so much more.
fields.body:
There are certain qualities that the average PA should possess. A good typing speed, friendly phone manner and total discretion are probably pretty much essential - and I can claim almost one of these. There are times, however, when one's colleagues expect so much more.

The other day, the file server unexpectedly quit. Or so the alert on my computer screen told me. What it actually means - apart from "broken" - is anyone's guess. But from the way my anxious co-workers clustered around my desk expecting me to rectify the situation as a matter of urgency, you might have been forgiven for believing that I'm Bill Gates's chief technical adviser. Fought hard to resist the urge to point out that if, in fact, I had an advanced degree in computer science, I would not be working as an underpaid lackey for the likes of them.

At moments like this I phone IT Ian. IT Ian is my favourite person in the whole world. He works for a company of computer consultants, in an office that I can only imagine is a haven of happily humming hard drives and zippy ISDN lines. And he is an all too frequent visitor to our office, which isn't. He is endlessly good-humoured, tirelessly patient and can make the bloody computers work. For this alone, I have pledged IT Ian my eternal devotion.

IT Ian, on the other hand, hates me with a passion. He cannot stand our office. It's hardly surprising - our server is so aged that it runs on steam, we treat our valuable computer equipment with a disregard bordering on contempt (and get pretty much the same treatment in return) and we clog up our hard drives with useless internet downloads, files that we don't know how to get rid of and personal emails about EastEnders.

The nail in the coffin of our relationship came when I had to phone him to ask him how to turn on my computer. Then call him again, eight hours later, so I could turn it off.

And, yes, this problem is also ludicrously simple to rectify. IT Ian now regards me as a medical experiment gone wrong. Unfortunately, however, the sight of me apparently sorting it only serves to strengthen my colleagues' conviction that I am a technical whizz kid, and everything from crashed computers to hard drives with fatal errors are now left to me to rectify. I'm getting a bit sick of it. One of these days, like the file server, I might unexpectedly quit.

webTitle: Satellite, cable and digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Satellite, cable and digital pick of the day
fields.trailText: Absence Of Malice | Blaze | Fanny and Alexander, Parts 1 and 2 | Key Largo | Payback | The Black Sox Scandal
fields.body:
Films

Absence Of Malice (Sydney Pollack, 1981) 6pm, FilmFour
Pollack's exploration of press freedom and responsibility has Sally Field as an unscrupulous Miami reporter all but ruining mobster's son Paul Newman when she wrongly implicates him in the disappearance of a union man. An absorbing drama that provides an interesting counterpoint to the scrupulous journalism of Pakula's All The President's Men - though the issues get a little clouded by the stars' emotional wrestling match.

Blaze (Ron Shelton, 1989) 8pm, Sky Cinema
Colourful portrait of Louisiana governor Earl K Long, brother of dodgy Huey, at the time of his infamous affair with New Orleans stripper Blaze Starr, in 1959. Paul Newman and Lolita Davidovich create a fine romance against a vibrant political backdrop: Long, who espoused black civil rights, was branded as drunk and mad by his many opponents.

Fanny And Alexander, Parts 1 and 2 (Ingmar Bergman, 1981/1982) 8pm, FilmFour
Not your miserly three-hour big screen version: this is the whole smorgasbord, the five-hour-plus TV version of Bergman's magisterial family saga set in early 20th century Sweden. At its centre are 10-year-old Alexander (Bertil Guve) and eight-year-old Fanny (Pernilla Alwin), children of the well-off Ekdahl family. It's a world that turns from dream to nightmare, cosy to scary, particularly in the presence of the stern father. This is Bergman's warmest, most enjoyable work, superbly photographed by Sven Nykvist.

Key Largo (John Huston, 1948) 9pm, TCM
Gangsters and goodies holed up in a Florida Keys hotel with a hurricane blowing up: highly charged atmospherics in Huston's version of the Maxwell Anderson play. The cast helps crank up the electricity: Edward G Robinson as rotten Rocco, Claire Trevor his drunken moll; Humphrey Bogart the ex-army officer mulling over whether to take on the baddies or stay out of trouble (now which will it be ...), and Lauren Bacall, so brilliant at looking on, coolly.

Payback (Brian Helgeland,1998) 10pm, Sky Premier
Mel Gibson had a serious falling out with director Helgeland, replacing him to reshoot and add new scenes to a thriller that isn't as hardboiled as it would like to be. It's a rerun of Point Blank, John Boorman's version of Richard Stark's novel The Hunter, with Gibson trying to fill the considerable Lee Marvin role as Porter, a-hard-as-coffin-nails hood double- crossed and left for dead, and now returning to get even with the Outfit. Punchy.
Paul Howlett

Sports

The Black Sox Scandal 9pm, History Channel
There have always been cheats in sport, from footballers who dive to win a penalty to cricketers who claim to have caught a bouncing ball, but rarely does a single event have such an impact. When eight Chicago White Sox baseball players deliberately threw the 1919 World Series, it took two years for them to be punished - but the story is still remembered 80 years on.
Simon Burnton

webTitle: TV review: We should be so lucky

fields.headline: We should be so lucky
fields.trailText: The Hit Factor: The Pete Waterman Story | Walk On By | Omnibus
fields.body:
In The Hit Factory: The Pete Waterman Story (C5, Sunday), pop producer Pete Waterman was keen to persuade us how difficult it is to keep pumping out pop songs. People think it's easy but it's not, he steamed. A pop song is no good if you don't believe in it, because you won't convince the public. As he grows longer in the tooth and sits back to take stock (or indeed Aitken) of his glittering career, Waterman has obviously adopted this as his mantra, since he had already given us a variation on it in BBC2's new history-of-pop series Walk On By on Saturday night. That time, he insisted that writing pop songs is "the hardest thing in the world".

Myself, I suspect that writing pop songs probably isn't harder than finding a cure for Alzheimer's disease or making the trains run on time, but one of the great things about being in pop is that you know if you can survive 15 years after your first (or only) hit, you're guaranteed uncritical retrospective deification. Which isn't to say that Stock, Aitken & Waterman didn't have an extraordinary knack for pumping out high-energy pop-disco potboilers, nor that there isn't a distinct skill in concocting a song to suit a particular performer, especially if it's Rick Astley. There was also a lip-smacking irony in the fact that Waterman's records regularly topped the independent charts, driving followers of Morrissey or the Sisters Of Mercy to self-righteous apoplexy. But to start claiming that SAW's battery-farmed knock-offs were "great pop music" which "defined a decade" is rather like hailing the modesty and wisdom of Lord Irvine, or putting Vanessa Feltz's head on the stamps.

Walk On By took a look at pop history through the opposite end of the telescope. While we are now assured that there is no qualitative difference between Mozart and Eminem, as long as you're tone deaf and have never owned a CD player, that's still no excuse for the deployment of politically correct anthropology as an infallible guide to the history of pop.

Some of this opening programme was quite "interesting" - a lethal adjective, but show me a better one - particularly some rare home movies of such titans of tunesmithery as George Gershwin and Irving Berlin. But its determination to trawl through the history of emigration from Russia in the 19th century to explain how Popular Music was eventually born in New York made for vexatious viewing. There was lots of professorial stuff about ethnic rivalries in the Big Apple and the way black performers had to caricature themselves to get ahead in vaudeville, but you never got much sense of the dynamism and irresponsibility of popular music. Pop makes you kick your shoes off and start leaping around the room, and one of the things that has always made it popular is that you don't have to study academic tracts from people like the critic Stanley Crouch or "writer and musician" Ian Whitcomb in order to enjoy it. Maybe forthcoming episodes will feature more pop and fewer po-faces.

Connoisseurs of fine art probably don't regard television as their primary source of information on the subject - they've learned the hard way that all TV viewers want to know is "why we're all obsessed with Big Brother!" - so it seems reasonable to hail Omnibus 's effort to put Botticelli on the small screen (BBC2, Saturday). The film traced the way Botticelli's drawings enhanced Dante's Divine Comedy, and a gallery of critics, clerics and academics had been teed up to eulogise the great Florentine's mastery of line, his wicked gift for caricature, and his profound understanding of the horror and anguish in Dante's depictions of Hell and Purgatory.

My preview tape didn't have any captions on it, so I was left to puzzle over the identities of the various talking heads. Who was the rather louche gentleman sitting in a book-lined study? Who was the nervous lady reluctant to discuss Botticelli's fondness for obscene innuendo? It seemed like a flashback to a more innocent age of broadcasting. However, in reality it was a plug for the Botticelli exhibition at the Royal Academy.

fields.headline: Safety problems stall tube deal
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: A new batch of 204 safety problems, including cracked escalators that could lead to "multi-passenger fatalities", have been identified on the London underground by the health and safety executive - problems that could seriously delay the government's partial privatisation of the tube.
fields.body:
A new batch of 204 safety problems, including cracked escalators that could lead to "multi-passenger fatalities", have been identified on the London underground by the health and safety executive - problems that could seriously delay the government's partial privatisation of the tube.

The new batch, which takes the combined total of unresolved safety issues to 273, could hold up the proposed public-private partnership for at least three months, even if the government and London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, can settle their differences on how the tube should be managed under the PPP scheme.

The joint system would see the public sector operating the trains and stations, while upkeep and improvements to track and signalling fell to three private construction and engineering groups, but under the direction of Bob Kiley, the transport commissioner appointed by Mr Livingstone.

The new HSE checklist, sent to London Underground and the rail unions, shows that the safety agency is not happy with measures for escalators. It says there could be bad accidents.

It also criticises the lack of information for trapped passengers trying to get out of the underground in an emergency.

Bob Crow, deputy general secretary of the Rail Maritime and Transport Union, said last night: "This report should be the death knell for the PPP." Ideology was being put before safety, he said. "It is time that Tony Blair intervened to prevent a Hatfield on the tube."

HSE sources said yesterday that the 273 problems had to be resolved before the PPP could go ahead.

Mr Kiley and his negotiating team yesterday played down suggestions from the government that a deal had been reached. Talks are still going on, with Mr Kiley insisting that any deal must give him the authority to order emergency work without seeking permission from any of the three operating companies.

This would avoid a repetition of what happened in the lead-up to the Hatfield rail crash in October when Rail track and its subcontractors failed to agree on emergency work to repair cracked rails.

The Treasury is prepared to guarantee an average subsidy of £600m a year for seven and a half years. The money would be paid to London Underground as part of a £15bn overhaul of the capital's transport network. The remainder will come from private contractors and ticket revenues.

 The Labour party yesterday admitted that a lobbyist who works for a company bidding for the PPP contracts will work as a public relations man for John Prescott in the coming election, writes Nicholas Watt.

Mike Craven runs Lexington Communications, which acts for Metronet, a bidder for two of the three tube contracts.

webTitle: Sydney's drugs suburb 'treated like a colony'

fields.headline: Sydney's drugs suburb 'treated like a colony'
fields.trailText: The western Sydney suburb of Cabramatta is a bustling community whose shops sell cheap clothes, mobile phones and Vietnamese snacks. But the district's main trade is in heroin and visiting addicts bring gang warfare, teenage prostitution and disease.
fields.body:
The western Sydney suburb of Cabramatta is a bustling community whose shops sell cheap clothes, mobile phones and Vietnamese snacks. But the district's main trade is in heroin and visiting addicts bring gang warfare, teenage prostitution and disease.

Now residents of the most multicultural district in Australia are fighting back - against the police and the government.

Last week a group of Cabramatta businesspeople launched an extraordinary legal action against the New South Wales government for failing to combat the drug trade.

An parliamentary inquiry has exposed a catalogue of policy blunders in Cabramatta, including the launch of a $A176m (£60m) drug prevention initiative that failed to make an impact partly because its newsletters were printed only in English, which is not the first language for 70% of the suburb's residents.

While police chiefs insist that their campaign to boost beat policing has been a success, there have been more than 500 overdoses in Cabramatta in the last two years and the number of arrests for drug dealing has fallen by 52%.

The government plans to increase police numbers by 100 in the area and Bob Carr, the New South Wales premier, has called for fresh policing ideas.

According to Thang Ngo, the only Vietnamese-speaking local councillor, the police must build better relations with his community if they are to combat the drugs problem. None of the 140 officers in Cabramatta speak Vietnamese or Chinese.

"You can't police a community you don't understand and Cabramatta is like no other community in Australia," said Mr Ngo. "More than 130 different languages are spoken in the area. Until there is some understanding between police and the community we won't make progress."

Police said yesterday that some officers would be enrolled in crash courses in Vietnamese and Cambodian, but there has so far been no drive to recruit officers from ethnic minorities.

As confidence in the police has fallen, so drug-related crime has risen. Residents of one street claim the street was burgled 85 times in six months, but just nine incidents were reported to the authorities.

Two constables patrolling the streets on mountain bikes shrug their shoulders when asked about the drug problem. They can arrest dealers, send them to court and even prison, but they always return.

"Part of the problem is we have an almost colonial relationship with places like Cabramatta," said Dr Richard Basham, an Asian crime analyst. "The police don't have community roots. They are there for six months and then they are gone. They are almost seen as an occupying force. No one is going to provide them with any useful intelligence."

According to Mr Ngo, the failure of the authorities to combat Cabramatta's heroin problem has been an indirect way of preventing the spread of the heroin trade.

"We believe that the government and police have conspired - whether intentionally or not - to contain the heroin problem in Cabramatta," he said.

"When you crack down in Cabramatta you spread the problem elsewhere. There are a lot of migrants here who can't speak English and are afraid of authority. How better to keep a situation under control than confine it in an area where people can't communicate?"

The government admits that it could take 10 years to clean up Cabramatta. But Mr Ngo says it will take longer to rid the suburb of its dirty name.

"Kids tell me when they go for a job interview they give a relative's address elsewhere. They can't say they're from Cabramatta. Even if they have the talent to make it, the fact that they come from Cabramatta stops them."

webTitle: San Quentin prison may be sold as real estate

fields.headline: Californians could soon feel like prisoners in their own homes
fields.trailText: New real estate in the Bay Area - which could be on the market as early as the summer - appears to have everything going for it. There is a small problem with the address, however. Death Row, San Quentin has a slightly gloomy ring to it.
fields.body:
Magnificent views, historic location, excellent security and convenient access to San Francisco's silicon valley. The new real estate in the Bay Area that could be on the market as early as the summer appears to have everything going for it.

There is a small problem with the address, however. Death Row, San Quentin has a slightly gloomy ring to it.

Faced with the ever-increasing costs of maintaining the crumbling building, the authorities responsible for one of the world's most famous prisons are considering closing it down and putting it on the market for development.

A feasibility study ordered by the California state legislature is due in the summer and a stabilising prison population means that the inmates could be shipped elsewhere.

"It would be a very desirable property," said Joy Luck of Pacific Union realtors in San Francisco yesterday. "It has water views, access to the freeway and would be very good for a commute into the city."

Johnny Cash sang of San Quentin prison "I hate every stone of you", but developers would be singing to a different tune. The jail occupies 432 acres of prime land in Marin County, long the home of the Bay Area's health-conscious and liberal free-thinkers. Even with the dot.com boom slowing, homes in the area are among the most expensive in the US and land is always in demand.

Built in 1852 by inmates housed on a prison ship, San Quentin is the oldest jail in the state and has been home to some of the country's best-known prisoners, including Charles Manson, Sirhan Sirhan who assassinated Robert Kennedy, and the Black Panther leader and prison writer George Jackson who was shot dead during an alleged escape attempt in 1971.

But the ancient design of San Quentin has meant steep maintenance bills and it now costs 50% more - an estimated $120m (£75m) this year - to run than a prison housing the same number of inmates elsewhere in the state.

"We've been wanting to close San Quentin for a long time, but we had no place to put the inmates," said Robert Presley, secretary of California's correctional agency.

California already jails more people per capita than any other state and currently locks up about 160,000 people across the state. But under a change in the criminal justice system offenders found guilty of non-violent drug possession will in future not be jailed and this could reduce the prison population.

San Quentin houses 6,100 inmates and has a staff of 1,500 who could be relocated by as early as next year. Another reason for closing the jail is that authorities say its outdated design presents security risks.

The jail houses all the state's 560 prisoners awaiting execution on Death Row and it is their presence that has raised objections to the closure. Many have lawyers in San Francisco and relocating them might hamper discussions on appeals and pleas for clemency.

But there are already various ideas for the development. The local district council would like to see a waterfront village with access for boats and ferry transport to relieve heavy traffic heading across the Golden Gate bridge into the city.

fields.headline: Sharon seeks Bush's blessing
fields.standfirst:
As the Israeli prime minister tries to erase the stain of his involvement in Beirut, a United Nations envoy urges a revival of the border zone

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: As the Israeli prime minister tries to erase the stain of his involvement in Beirut, a United Nations envoy urges a revival of the border zone
fields.body:
Ariel Sharon left Israel yesterday on the ritual pilgrimage to Washington, hoping it will put the stamp of credibility on his new government and rub out the taint of his notorious past.

He hopes to use the traditional US distrust of Yasser Arafat to persuade President George Bush that the Palestinian authority has lost its legitimacy.

Leaving Tel Aviv airport, he spoke of the "common interests" of Israel and the US, "including the drive towards regional stability and preventing terrorism and violence".

Israeli officials were confident the visit would go smoothly.

"I would say Israel has a good starting point ... because we are meeting with a government that ... agrees with many of our assessments," Zalman Shoval, a former ambassador to the US and an adviser to Mr Sharon, told Israel Radio. Mr Sharon is to meet President Bush tomorrow.

The Israeli press said he was travelling with two aims: to explore common ground with Washington in its desire to contain Saddam Hussein, and to assure Mr Bush that Israel will not try to drag Washington into an active mediating role with the Palestinians.

Mr Sharon's advisers are preaching "containment": using Israel's siege of Palestinian cities to force an end to the intifada.

Yesterday Palestinian officials accused Israeli soldiers of tightening the siege by installing an electric gate on a road north from Jericho to Nablus, sealing both towns off from their agricultural hinterland.

The area has been the most peaceful part of the West Bank during the uprising.

The government has stepped up its rhetoric against Mr Arafat's administration, directly accusing his elite Force 17 bodyguard of attacking Israeli soldiers and civilians.

Mr Sharon hopes this will persuade Mr Bush that the Palestinian Authority is a terrorist body. Nevertheless, he confirmed yesterday that he had ordered renewed talks between his security chiefs and their Palestinain counterparts.

He is also expected to stress Israel's concern about Russian and Iranian nuclear cooperation and the prospect of Syria winning a seat on the UN security council.

The government is nervous about protests in Washington drawing attention to Mr Sharon's past and his indirect responsibility for the massacre of hundreds of Palestinian refugees by Christian militias in Beirut in 1982.

"This may be a small step for President Bush, who is currently gathering a string of the world's leaders at his court, but it is a very big step for Sharon," the commentator Hemi Shalev wrote in Yediot Ahronoth, Israel's biggest-selling daily, yesterday.

"The person who was once pushed to the margins of politics is finding himself alive and kicking in the centre of things, and he does not care if everyone else turns green with envy.

"Mr Sharon may have been sworn in as prime minister but in many respects he will only be inaugurated this week, in the Oval Room, in front of the world and its leaders."

The transformation is especially sweet since it was President George Bush Sr who forbade senior US officials to meet him when he visited Washington as housing minister 10 years ago.

Other commentators said Mr Sharon could lose support if the West Bank siege stands in the way of Washington's efforts to create an Arab coalition against Saddam Hussein.

webTitle: Lebanon peace lies in development, UN says

fields.headline: Lebanon peace lies in development, UN says
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Amid heightened tension on Lebanon's southern border, a senior UN official yesterday called for the area to be developed and repopulated to prevent further conflict.
fields.body:
Amid heightened tension on Lebanon's southern border, a senior UN official yesterday called for the area to be developed and repopulated to prevent further conflict.

Ten months after Israeli forces withdrew from southern Lebanon, only 70,000-80,000 people are living there, compared with 200,000 before the Israelis arrived. Meanwhile, the Lebanese government refuses to deploy its army, leaving the area mainly in the hands of Hizbullah and 5,300 UN peacekeepers (Unifil).

"The territory evacuated by the Israeli troops has not yet been filled with people, economic activities or social infrastructure and this needs to be addressed," said Staffan de Mistura, the UN secretary general's representative in Lebanon.

"The argument that the area is still insecure is not sufficient to justify this vacuum. There are incidents, but they are limited," he added.

Last week a furore blew up over water from the small Hasbani river which flows through Lebanon, crosses the border and ultimately drains into the Sea of Galilee.

During the occupation, the Israelis installed two pumps on the Lebanese side, which continue to supply water to settlements across the border. Recently Lebanon decided to install a pump to supply Wazzani, a village of 100 residents. Because the village is close to the border, the UN notified the Israelis, who did not object.

Last week, this erupted in the Israeli media as a plan to "divert" the river. The head of Israel's national water company and Avigdor Lieberman, the new minister for infrastructure, even suggested it was grounds for war.

Timur Goksel, Unifil's chief troubleshooter, said it was nothing of the kind: "It's simply an Israeli communication problem."

A few days earlier, Unifil bulldozers had quelled another potential flashpoint - perhaps temporarily - by filling in an Israeli-dug trench at neighbouring Ghajar.

Ghajar (population 1,300) is an oddity. It is inhabited by Syrian Alawites with Israeli identity; two-thirds of it lies in Lebanon and the remainder on the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights. This is where cannabis grown in Lebanon's Beka'a Valley passes on its way to consumers in Israel.

After the Israelis withdrew last May, Mr Goksel said there was "an undeclared consensus" not to partition the village. "We just let it be," he said. As a result, the new high-security border fence stops when it reaches Ghajar. This, UN officials admit, has left Ghajar as the soft underbelly of the border, though no one is sure what to do about it.

Recently the Israelis tried to extend the security fence around the northern side of the village. They had dug a foundation trench 400 metres into Lebanese territory before Lebanon denounced it as annexation and the UN ordered the Israelis to stop.

For Mr Goksel, these are everyday problems. "We constantly hold hands," he said. "There is an essential role for the UN to provide communication where there is none."

Even Hizbullah and the Israelis use the UN as a conduit for messages to each other - probably a reason why the ongoing conflict in the disputed Sheba'a Farms area has not escalated. But Mr Goksel warned: "One miscalculation would be a big problem. There are just too many guns."

He said that attracting people to the south would be the best long-term protection. "An empty village is a trouble [spot]" he said. "Having people there stops military operations, but they need services such as water and electricity."

Unifil not only helps to maintain peace but sustains the local economy. It has become the region's biggest employer and many livelihoods depend on it.

Hanna Anbar, editor of Beirut's Daily Star, said: "The south had always been a neglected area, but the Israeli withdrawal left a vacuum; 2,000 Lebanese used to cross the border to work in Israel every day."

Even after the Israeli withdrawal, southern Lebanon is still occupied in one sense. There are about 130,000 land mines left behind by the Israelis and others. On average, these "unseen soldiers" kill or injure one person a week.

The latest victim, Ali Aqiqa, 34, a father of five, was blown up last Monday when his tractor hit a mine on a side road near Shaqra.

Mr De Mistura said: "The first, best, thing we can all do to make the south what it should be is to liberate it from these mines."

webTitle: Tracing source of outbreak from pigswill

fields.headline: Tracing source of outbreak from pigswill
fields.standfirst:
Virus travelled thousands of miles before hitting Britain

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Virus travelled thousands of miles before hitting Britain.
fields.body:
In more than 200 outbreaks of foot and mouth disease, one case stands out: Burnside farm, Heddon-on-the-Wall, and its probable cause, pigswill.

Behind this case lies a complex investigation of how the virus managed to jump several thousand miles to an obscure piggery in Northumberland.

A virus, imported in meat from an unknown country, found its way into pigswill and began to cut a swath through British farming which has so far led to the deaths of nearly 200,000 animals.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, and the chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, have repeatedly said this virus could not arrive in Britain legally, let alone get into pigswill.

Somewhere along the line, and probably more than once, there must have been illegal action.

The fear of spreading the disease further immediately led to the banning of British live exports and animals products.

It was the ban on live animals and meat from countries with foot and mouth that had protected the UK from the disease for 20 years, but somewhere the system failed.

To protect Europe, all airline foods and foods from ships are destroyed, and there are detailed regulations on what can be fed to farm animals. Only pigs are allowed to eat meat in the form of treated swill.

With hindsight, despite the long gap between outbreaks and, at least on paper, the tight regulations, the return of foot and mouth was predictable. Two connected factors have made its arrival more likely. One is the spread of the disease across the world, and the second is the liberalisation of trade, which means cheap frozen meat is traded across continents.

The type O virus now rampant in Britain was originally found in India in 1990 and spread west to Saudi Arabia and the Middle East, reaching Greece before being snuffed out in 1998.

It also moved eastward, reaching China, Tibet, Russia, Taiwan, Burma, Vietnam, Cambodia, Thailand, Malaysia, Laos, South Korea and Japan by 2000. Last year it moved to South Africa.

South America already has foot and mouth but not the same strain.

Under international rules, an immediate ban is placed on movements of meat and dairy products to the EU from infected countries. All meat must in any event be certified foot and mouth free before it can be imported.

But there is no inspection system in Britain for the disease. Certificates and forms showing country of origin rely on the honesty of the shipper; inspection has not been seen as a priority because there is no danger to human health from infected meat.

So assuming meat from one of these countries with outbreaks, and carcasses from Botswana in southern Africa, can be bought at Smithfield market in London, how did infected meat find its way into pigswill in Northumberland?

Bobby Waugh, the farmer concerned in the Heddon-on-the-Wall outbreak, said food from schools in Sunderland and Gateshead went into his pigswill - containing scraps of meat from an unknown source.

So if cash-strapped local authorities had been buying cheap foreign meat for their pupils, which turned out to have come from a country with a foot and mouth problem, this could have caused the infection.

But the rules on cooking up pigswill are strict and designed to prevent this. The swill has to be at 100C (212F) for an hour to kill all viruses including foot and mouth. This should have saved Mr Waugh's pig herd, even if he was unfortunate enough to have had infected meat in his swill.

The Ministry of Agriculture is still solving the puzzle of what caused Mr Waugh's outbreak.

Fear of prejudicing any prosecution has brought an end to official comment on the precise route of the infection, but Mr Brown has ordered a review of the whole issue of feeding swill to pigs.

He said the practice was now confined to less than 2% of the pig industry. A complete ban is one of the most likely outcomes of the current crisis.

webTitle: Cull begins with 1,800 sheep in Scotland

fields.headline: Cull begins with 1,800 sheep in Scotland
fields.standfirst:
Slaughter of healthy animals agreed as necessary by Scots farmers' leader, as chief vet prepares to talk to English rebels

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Slaughter of healthy animals agreed as necessary by Scots farmers' leader, as chief vet prepares to talk to English rebels.
fields.body:
More than 1,800 healthy sheep were slaughtered on two farms in the north of Scotland at the weekend, as farmers north of the border appeared to accept the foot and mouth cull as a necessary evil.

The farms, in Morayshire and Aberdeenshire, had not shown any sign of the disease but had links to an infected market, Longtown in Cumbria. A spokesman for the Scottish executive would not identify the farms but said more than 1,800 animals had been slaughtered.

Culls are expected at four farms in the Highlands early this week, and may also start in the south-west, so far the only area of Scotland to be hit by the outbreak. Two further cases have brought the Scottish total to 42, all in Dumfries and Galloway.

The stated aim is to destroy 200,000 healthy sheep in Scotland in a pre-emptive strike to try to halt the outbreak. Animals within 3km of infected farms will be culled, along with thousands of healthy sheep at 30 farms outside the 3km radius but which had links to the Longtown market. Of the 30 farms involved, 17 are in Dumfries and Galloway, one in Ayrshire, one in Aberdeenshire, six in the Highlands, four in the Borders and one in Renfrewshire.

The cull in Dumfries and Galloway is planned to accompany one in adjacent Cumbria. But some farmers in Cumbria are promising "all-out war" over the mass cull, and therefore it will not begin in Cumbria and in Dumfries and Galloway until after Jim Scudamore, the chief veterinary officer, meets farmers' leaders today. Yesterday, however, farmers in Scotland described the measure as heartbreaking but a necessary evil.

"They realise and understand the need, and know it must be done as quickly as possible," said John Kinnaird, vice president of the National Farmers Union in Scotland. "It is a very virulent disease and can be masked in sheep, that's why they need to be taken out in the cull. We have to rely on veterinary and scientific advice, and that's their best advice. At the moment they see it as the only means of trying to contain the disease and ultimately eradicate it."

Mr Kinnaird did warn that many farmers were facing total loss. "Many people will not restart. You are looking at a lifetime's work being destroyed. People talk about compensation, but money will not replace a lifetime's work."

Vets have confirmed more than 120 cases in the area of Cumbria and Dumfries and Galloway, and agriculture department officials believe culls are the only way they can eradicate the disease. But some farmers are angry at the proposals to slaughter all sheep and pigs, and cattle that vets believe could be infected, within 3kms of an outbreak.

In England, a lobby group, Farmers For Action, has warned that it will launch "all-out war" to stop healthy animals being destroyed and is seeking a judicial review of the government's handling of the crisis.

"Any war being fought should be against the disease, not against the authorities trying to contain it," countered Nick Brown, the minister for agriculture, at a departmental briefing in London yesterday.

"The whole country has got to be on the same side. It is not helpful to try to obstruct the government's disease control measures. They will work best if people cooperate.

"I know it is incredibly hard and how worried farmers must be, which is why I have asked Jim [Scudamore] to go up to explain to fair-minded farmers, who I think will understand it is necessary."

Joyce Quin, the deputy agriculture minister, visited Cumbria for talks yesterday and Mr Brown hopes to meet farmers there by the end of the week.

Ms Quin said farmers she had spoken to were very concerned about government policy, but that there was "huge support" for the overall strategy.

Mr Brown also warned that Devon, which had seen 43 cases by last night, might face a similar cull. "We are trying very hard not to do this in Devon, but I cannot promise that we won't," he said.

Meanwhile, some parts of the Scottish countryside have reopened to the public. Mountaineers can roam on the northern side of Ben Nevis and its sister mountains - but will have to be disinfected before they are allowed to climb. The Queen has also opened up parts of her Balmoral estate, including access to Lochnagar.

webTitle: Socialist victory makes history in Paris

fields.headline: Socialist victory makes history in Paris
fields.trailText: A giant party erupted outside Paris's town hall last night at the news that a socialist mayor is to take over for the first time in more than 130 years after the capital swung to the left in elections yesterday.
fields.body:
A giant party erupted outside Paris's town hall last night at the news that a socialist mayor is to take over for the first time in more than 130 years after the capital swung to the left in elections yesterday.

An alliance dominated by the Socialist party and the Greens headed by the unassuming Bertrand Delanoë - until last year an unknown senator and local councillor - was proclaimed the winner of a majority of seats after an agonisingly tight race.

The official result, due to be confirmed by the interior ministry this morning, is expected to give the coalition 88 seats on the 163-seat council. A committee of councillors formally elects the mayor on Friday.

The Paris result came in the second round of local elections across France, but the news in many other centres was far from bright for the governing Socialists.

In the capital, however, a delirious crowd of tens of thousands of champagne-drinking supporters converged on the town hall - for nearly a quarter of a century the fiefdom of Jacques Chirac, now France's conservative president.

Mr Delanoë promised to be a mayor for all Parisians. He called the election outcome a "victory for audacity and reason".

In the square at the town hall, the Hotel de Ville, members of the Delanoë coalition - which also includes Communists and leftwing radicals - were swinging from lamp-posts and waving their house keys as they jokingly demanded entry: "Give us the keys! Give us the keys!"

The French capital has not been run by a leftwing administration since the bloody popular uprising of the 1871 Paris Commune, and throughout the 1980s was so dominated by Mr Chirac's Gaullist RPR party that all 20 of its arrondissements were under conservative control.

Ahead of presidential and parliamentary elections in 2002, the capture of Paris by the left is bound to deal a blow to the president, who is struggling to defend himself against an array of corruption scandals dating from his 18 years as the city's mayor.

An incoming Socialist administration is likely to cooperate fully with magistrates investigating the scandals - inquiries which until now have dragged along.

Last night Mr Delanoë told cheering supporters it was "time for a democratic party from which no Parisians should feel excluded".

The people of the city had made a choice for "profound change" in electing him as mayor. Their decision would bring "a change of culture and of democratic practices".

Mr Delanoë will also become the first publicly declared homosexual politician to hold a post of national importance in France.

On a night when many of France's provincial towns swung to the right, the vote in the country's second-biggest city, Lyon, looked even closer than in Paris, with the Socialists forecast to emerge victorious by just two or three seats.

Last Sunday's first round of voting to elect some 36,000 mayors across France had focused eyes on the conservative Paris, Lyon and Toulouse.

In the capital, a feud between the rightist candidate, Philippe Séguin, and the outgoing mayor, Jean Tiberi, helped to hand victory to the Socialists. Last night, Mr Séguin said that he would have won if not for the "iniquitous" voting system. He said the right got 50.3% of the votes cast, ahead of the left's 48.5%.

"There is no doubt that under a system of universal suffrage I would today have been elected mayor of Paris," he told reporters and activists.

But Mr Tiberi, who was re-elected as mayor of his Left Bank stronghold of the fifth arrondissement, was quick to blame Mr Séguin for the right's defeat.

"I wanted unity, to merge our lists," he said. "Our political leaders, Mr Séguin and the heads of lists refused... a grave and a historic mistake."

In Toulouse, the Socialists and Greens appeared to have narrowly lost in their attempt to upset the conservative candidate, Philippe Douste-Blazy.

Other Socialists who seemed to be headed for defeat were the education minister, Jack Lang, in Blois; the high-profile labour minister, Elisabeth Guigou, in Avignon; and the European affairs minister, Pierre Moscovici, in Montbeliard.

webTitle: Office hours: The workplace could become a safe haven for the abused.

fields.headline: A problem shared
fields.standfirst: A victim of domestic violence may not see her boss as the obvious person to confide in, but if the GMB has its way, the workplace could become a safe haven for the abused. Dolly Dhingra reports
fields.trailText: A victim of domestic violence may not see her boss as the obvious person to confide in, but if the GMB has its way, the workplace could become a safe haven for the abused. Dolly Dhingra reports.
fields.body:
Britain's general union, the GMB, is campaigning to give the taboo subject of domestic violence a voice in the workplace. The Daphne Project was recently launched nationwide in an attempt to offer support and understanding to victims of domestic violence within the world of work.

"Workers can't be expected to hang their emotions up in the cloakroom when they get to work. Good employers are concerned about their employees," says Karen Constantine, head of equal rights at the GMB. "It's an issue that's been on the agenda for more than 10 years and it's evolved into a clear workplace issue for us."

Whether or not employers choose to acknowledge domestic violence, many are fully aware that it exists, stresses Constantine. Workers invariably take time off as a result of domestic violence - poor attendance and punctuality are telltale signs. A recent study carried out by the American Federation for State County and Municipal Employees revealed that 56% of battered women were late for work five times a month, 28% of them left early five times a month and 54% missed at least three days work a month. More alarmingly, 74% of victims interviewed were even harassed while at work.

Essentially a training system and workplace policy, The Daphne Project is targeting employers and trade union shop stewards to explain in detail the structures needed to support victims of abuse. It hopes to educate employers to detect signs of domestic violence and understand the myths surrounding the offence. Employers are asked to publicise the project at work and a commitment is sought to ensure the workplace is a secure environment from which victims can contact police and solicitors, and can even get help to find accommodation. When necessary, employers should also allow victims appropriate time off.

Some may consider this a tall order, and certainly Amanda White, occupational psychologist and director of CGR Business Psychologists, has reservations. "I think that it is generally a good thing that employers have their employees' interests at heart but there are major obstacles that need to be overcome in terms of implementing policies such as these. Some individuals may not want their problems aired at work. And even if they do, I'm not sure that managers have the necessary skills to deal with them," she says.

Constantine dismisses this argument. "We are not asking employers to take on the burden of dealing with an employee's domestic violence situation," she says, "but to give them the space to deal with it in a safe environment. Quite often it's Human Resources (HR) people who deal with it and you have to bear in mind that HR people are often dealing with pretty nitty-gritty issues anyway. A lot of the responses from HR have welcomed the project because they've finally been given something very practical, some real guidance."

Victims are overwhelmingly women - Constantine has never come across a male victim, but support under The Daphne Project would be offered to all, regardless of gender.

White is aware that it is women who suffer and believes that in some work cultures acknowledging such personal problems would be perceived as a sign of weakness. Women are therefore often in a Catch 22 situation. "In some macho cultures, women might not want to disclose that they are not managing their personal life too well because colleagues might think that they can't manage their professional life either. They may also feel that it damages their promotion prospects," she says.

"In these very cultures, I've run stress management courses and have been asked to change the name of the course to 'managing pressure' or 'managing pressure in others', because if it was called 'stress' no one would attend," says White. "They wouldn't admit that they were suffering from stress."

Exactly who victims should approach with domestic violence issues, and how they should do so, is not entirely clear-cut, but Constantine proposes line managers and supervisors as well as personnel departments.

White, however, claims that managers in the industrial and commercial world are unprepared for such disclosures. "Managers are OK when dealing with professional issues, but when it comes to the Kleenex issue it's not that they don't care, but they are very uncomfortable with that kind of closeness. It comes up time and again in my dealings with managers."

But like it or not, managers may have to deal with it, or suffer the consequences. "Domestic violence has an impact on an employee's self-esteem and confidence, which severely affects their ability to develop at work," says Constantine. It is a message that managers would be foolish to ignore.

fields.headline: The inside track
fields.standfirst: Ethical business
fields.trailText: Buying a bar of fairtrade chocolate may seem a small gesture in a big bad world, but the trend for applying ethical principles to business practice is gaining ground where it matters.
fields.body:
Buying a bar of fairtrade chocolate may seem a small gesture in a big bad world, but the trend for applying ethical principles to business practice is gaining ground where it matters.

Investors are increasingly asking what kind of enterprises their money is backing and, in response, financial houses are developing ethical investment trusts that not only guarantee clients' money does not prop up anything nasty, but may actively seek to fund schemes to make things better. Merrill Lynch, for example, is launching a fund dedicated to research into alternative energy.

Although ethical investment is still a very small sector of the market, ethical funds manage £3.3bn of investors' money. And the amount of money placed with ethical investment is doubling every two years. This money is an investment not a donation and, overall, ethical funds do just as well in the market as any other kind. It is the skill of the fund managers that counts, not the nature of the businesses they track.

Ethical investment began in the "greed is good" 80s, when a group of churches and charities founded the Ethical Investment Research Service. The first ethical investment trust was set up in 1984. At the time, the main issue was withdrawing investment from South Africa. Since then, other concerns have included avoiding the arms trade and promoting environmentally friendly business. The working conditions in overseas factories used by British companies is the most recent issue to attract attention.

Apart from apartheid, perhaps another catalyst for the emergence of ethical investment in the past two decades has been the rise of women in the City. There is no hard statistical evidence, but there seems to be agreement that women play a larger role in ethical investment than they do elsewhere. It is easy to be cynical about the gesture politics of the 80s, but if you were a feminist who shunned Barclays, the last laugh may yet be at the expense of those who called you humourless. This calls for a bar of chocolate.

webTitle: Working for a fair trade chocolate company

fields.headline: Sweet success
fields.standfirst: When Malcolm Clark was looking for work, he wasn't motivated by money, but fair trade. A chocolate company proved just the job, he tells Sarah Richardson
fields.trailText: When Malcolm Clark was looking for work, he wasn't motivated by money, but fair trade. A chocolate company proved just the job, he tells Sarah Richardson.
fields.body:
Warwick graduate Malcolm Clark knows that he could earn more elsewhere. But he decided against a lucrative milk-round job in favour of a PA role with the Day Chocolate Company, a small but growing business that produces the chocolate bars Divine and Dubble. The company represents an important step for fair trade, because the farmers that grow the cocoa for these products are also shareholders. And as well as sharing in the profits, they have a say in how the chocolate is produced and sold.

Motivated by a desire to put his knowledge of third world and fair-trade issues into practice, Clark works for the managing director, Sophi Tranchell. "My role is 50% traditional administration and computer literacy," he says. "But I also handle information requests, send out information packs, help organise fair-trade events and generally enthuse and support activists. We aim to ensure that our products are available in all the major supermarkets."

Fair trade means that the farmers are paid a price that covers the cost of producing, say, the cocoa, coffee beans or tea that western society consumes, and have the security of a long-term trading contract," explains Clark. "This year The Fair Trade Foundation launched Fair Trade Fortnight with a big media event at the Royal Commonwealth Society. All the companies licensed to carry the Fair Trade mark were involved, and we also organised some supermarket tastings and a series of business breakfasts for academics, journalists and politicians."

Clark's interest in third world and fair-trade issues was kindled during his pre-university gap year, when he taught English and geography in a secondary school in Tanzania. Then, on his arrival to study history and politics at Warwick, he joined the People and Planet Society, a national organisation that campaigns on social justice and environmental issues.

"Through them I became involved with the Jubilee 2000 'Drop the debt' campaign and with promoting fair trade as well as campus-based environmental projects," he recalls. "Our main aim was to raise awareness. We wanted to let people know there is an alternative [to western corporations] so they can be in a position to make an educated choice. I also ran a stand in the student union selling fair-trade tea, coffee, chocolate and tradecraft."

Clark's commitment was such that he secured funding to return to Tanzania with three other students to write a report on farming conditions. "In my final year, we gave a number of talks to youth groups and societies about what we'd learned," he says. "I was particularly involved in the student union, heading up the campaigns committee and liaising between students taking a stand and getting involved in issues. My role was listening and supporting what was going on."

Malcolm, now 23, first contacted the Day Chocolate Company a year ago. "They were looking for volunteers to man promotional stalls in the Morrisons supermarket chain," he says. "I chatted to the team and they sent me through a pack of posters, chocolate and promotional literature so I could promote Divine on my student union stand. People loved it."

By the time he graduated, Clark knew he wasn't going to join a safe blue-chip firm, and wrote to Day offering to volunteer in its office. The company recognised his name, and mentioned there was a full-time job going as PA to Tranchell. "I sent in my CV, had an interview and they took me on," he says. "It may be deeply unfashionable, but my involvement with my student union and my voluntary work definitely helped me get this job. You need to show commitment, to read up about the issues and to know the products available. You can get a foot in the door through initially offering your services for free."

Surrounded by chocolate, pamphlets and promotional materials, Clark is in his element. "We launched Dubble in association with Comic Relief last October and sold 1m bars before Christmas," he enthuses.

"I have a twin brother who works for McKinsey [management consultancy] and his starting salary is exactly double mine," he adds. "Yes, I could be earning more elsewhere but I wouldn't be doing a job I enjoyed and wouldn't be working for a company whose values and objectives I admire and appreciate."
