fields.headline: An advanced guide to shirking
fields.standfirst: Work, work, work - don't you just hate it. Well, now you can avoid it, while appearing so busy that your boss will probably think you need a pay rise
fields.trailText: Work, work, work - don't you just hate it. Well, now you can avoid it, while appearing so busy that your boss will probably think you need a pay rise.
fields.body:
Before I begin, I'd like to point out to all my employers, past, future and most especially present, that the activities, tactics and gambits described below are not ones that I myself have ever engaged in. Honest. But I know that I'm somewhat unusual. From time to time even the most dedicated employee finds herself at a loose end, is a little bit tired, or just can't be bothered, quite frankly. Of course, it's not part of any sane person's career plan to let on to one's colleagues - they might give you some work to do for a start - which is where our advanced array of highly effective, albeit covert, time-wasting techniques comes into play.

 Of course, there are times when time-wasting is all but expected. It's 4.30 on a Friday afternoon. Your colleagues have conspired to leave early, skive off for the day, or be otherwise occupied out of the office. You've been left holding the fort with a full packet of chocolate digestives and this month's issue of Marie Claire. And they really expect you to occupy your time with that bit of filing that's been hanging around since October? I don't think so. This is the time for personal phone calls, leafing through the Ikea catalogue and leaving half an hour early. Go on: how often do you have this much fun in the office?

 Most of the time it's not that easy. Think of it as a battle of wills between them - intent on you finishing that report on next quarter's projected sales figures - and you - determined to see off your hangover in peace. Visit the toilet so frequently that your line manager suspects that you've developed a persistent bladder infection. While there, take the time to reapply a full face of make-up, imagine what you'd look like with any of 47 different hairstyles, and read the next chapter of the latest Jilly Cooper. You will find that senior management is remarkably reluctant to question what you've been up to in the WC. Who wants to find themselves embroiled in a discussion with their PA about cystitis treatments? Otherwise, wandering round the office, staring vacantly out of the window or hovering expectantly by the photocopier (no one need know you're not actually copying anything) will help pass those idle minutes.

 Those with more hawk-eyed employers will have to use advanced techniques of shirking and slackness. The perfect technique for avoiding the work you should be doing is by doing work that is neither important, difficult nor your responsibility. For example, offer to run minor errands for other overworked colleagues. You will be surprised at how easily a brisk walk to the Post Office can encompass a detour via Top Shop or Kentucky Fried Chicken. Be taken by a sudden attack of generosity and make tea for the entire building. Yes, all 10 floors. Or proofread someone else's presentation - then sit staring intently at the same page for 45 minutes, chewing on your pen. Remember: if your sudden interest in helping out your workmates is mistaken for laziness, look wounded and confused.

 As all office workers eventually realise, our working hours, although allowing for a decent social life and normal sleep patterns, are nevertheless totally unreasonable. How are we supposed to deal with the minutiae of our lives - banks, phone companies, pedicures - when we're meant to be working? It's not possible, of course, and if your employers will insist on having you in the office at such unreasonable times, it's only to be expected that from time to time you'll have to spend an hour on hold while trying to get through to the water board. In fact, why not just sit staring vacantly into space, phone clamped to your ear, making occasional irritated remarks about the terrible standards of customer service in this country? There's actually no need to phone anyone.

 Email is the defining invention of the late 20th century. It will revolutionise the way we communicate, the way we work, the way we live. It's also, like, dead useful for sorting out what you're doing at the weekend. So it's a vital business tool - who cares as long as you've got a steady flow of gossip coming in from your friends? No doubt your boss fondly imagines that your email account is chock-full of work-related messages, or - if you're really being indulged - you confine any personal mailing to the five minutes before hometime. Sucker. As if you're really going to wait five hours before you spread the joyous news about your housemate, her boss, the living-room sofa and the tub of Häagen-Dazs.

 The internet has all the benefits of email - instant, discreet, available at the click of a mouse - with the added incentive of online shopping. Let's just pause for a moment to appreciate the beauty of this invention. You don't have to move, you don't have to battle with malevolent pre-teens to get to the sale CDs in HMV, you don't have to think. It's shopping, only better. And your boss expects you not to use this? Is she mad? Even if your credit card has wilted, there's still a world of useless information to be explored. A vague notion about possibly going to the cinema flits across your mind and before you know it you're trawling though the Internet Movie Database and searching for recipes for homemade popcorn. And then you're back at georgeclooney.com. Again.

 Sometimes, though, there is no alternative other than simply pretending to be working when you're not. Audio typists get a good deal here - put on your headphones, but plug them into the radio concealed under your desk, or just use them to block out unwanted sounds - the sound of your boss asking you to do something, for example. Otherwise, simply stare intently at your computer screen. Try to appear utterly absorbed in some highly complex task. Who's to know that you're only putting together that evening's shopping list? Or grab a willing colleague and head off to a quiet corner of the office for a vital meeting. Vital because you both really, really need to check out what Victoria Beckham is wearing in this month's OK!

 If by now the guilt is beginning to prickle - but not so much that you actually want to attempt to get to grips with typing those letters - then move on to the fine art of procrastination. This is advanced level time-wasting - not so much work avoidance, as work juggling. You really should be putting together the itinerary for the Manchester trip, but don't you think it would be so much easier once you've completely tidied your desk? Or deleted all the old files from your computer? Or downloaded yourself a new screen-saver? Or invented a new filing system? You can easily spend hours, even days, avoiding odious tasks in this way and - shockingly - you might get some useful things done at the same time.

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: So how the devil are you? You don't have to answer that; it's a rhetorical question. WPM is merely employing "the rhetorical devices of Aristotle, Christ, Cicero and Lincoln", as you do, on a Monday morning, when things are a bit slow around the office and you've no new messages in your inbox...
fields.body:
So how the devil are you? You don't have to answer that; it's a rhetorical question. WPM is merely employing "the rhetorical devices of Aristotle, Christ, Cicero and Lincoln", as you do, on a Monday morning, when things are a bit slow around the office and you've no new messages in your inbox (and believe you me, this morning WPM has tried every single way to occupy her mind, and keep her from filing. Indeed it was while trawling through the internet, in search, quite inexplicably, of the lyrics to Warren G's Regulate, that WPM chanced upon an illuminating feature at business365.co.uk, which informs bosses everywhere about the complex role of the secretary. There's even a handy cut-out-'n'-keep section entitled Managing Your PA, as though a PA is little more than a slightly unruly poodle, who will insist on yapping a lot when the MD's on the telephone, and tugging at the tablecloth when you've got guests round for tea.)

Admittedly, it's a little early in the day to be indulging in these kinds of rhetorical shenanigans, but WPM is simply sneaking in a spot of presentation practice - a bit like doing your pelvic floor exercises while answering the telephone. WPM, you see, has heard about a new book by management training guru John Matlock called Powerful Presentations. Matlock's principal argument appears to be one of "Did Aristotle have flip-charts? Did he buggery." Which is fair enough, and factually correct. But then again, WPM would wager that Aristotle didn't have an ergonomically correct chair or an i-Mac, either - and she ain't gonna give those up in a hurry.

One of John's choicest pieces of advice is for us to spurn the overhead projectors and instead wonder "What goes into the listener's head?" WPM doesn't like to imagine what goes into her head. Probably a whole lot of feathers and soot and obscure facts about minor celebrities. And she isn't really sure she wants to replace any of it with last month's sales statistics - unless, of course, they come in a Glamour-shaped, handbag-sized pamphlet, with lots of pictures of Vanessa Feltz.

 This week, WPM has very kindly been sent a nice little stook of information about Talking CV! TM, a sparkling new service which can post your CV live onto the internet. Like magic. The theory goes that you show up at one of its Satellite Assessment Centres (Lord only knows what happens if you don't have a satellite to be assessed. Perhaps they'll lend you one, like bowling shoes or ice skates?) and a webcam records you blathering on about your Sunday-morning orienteering club, and how you have an Advanced GNVQ in putting toner in photocopiers. WPM is a little dubious about this new invention. Surely employers can only stomach so many wobbly home videos of pasty-faced youths reeling off their GCSE results while sweating frantically in their slightly shiny, double-breasted interview suits?

Enclosed with the press release was the inspirational photograph displayed here on these pages, for your delectation and delight, which purports to show a candidate being welcomed to a Talking CV! TM Satellite Assessment Centre. In truth what it actually shows is a young lady with hair like scrunched pasta, wafting some blue-shirted chap in the general direction of a beige computer. The bloke (let's call him Simon) rather worryingly appears to be leering at the computer screen, like some latter-day Robert Kilroy-Silk. Look at his chinos. He has selected his outfit with the sort of dedication rarely seen outside the menswear department of C&A (RIP). Simon knows that when his prospective employers see his Talking CV! TM, they'll recognise that he, Simon Sloecombe, is the sort of high-buttoned salesperson they want to employ. Such is WPM's infatuation with this unassuming snapshot of futuristic office life, that she has taped it to the edge of her computer screen. It is surely only a matter of time until she starts to sleep with it tucked under her pillow, along with her picture of Zammo from Grange Hill, and a load of scrappy, half-used tissues.

Got the uncontrollable desire to tell WPM how you are? Email officehours@theguardian.com. Pleeease.

fields.headline: Guerra contra la coca
fields.standfirst: American cash is backing a campaign in Colombia to destroy the plantations producing coca, which is used to make the drug, cocaine. But this will, in turn, have a big effect on the population and environment, so is this the only way forward? Eulalia Furriol asks young people for their views
fields.trailText: American cash is backing a campaign in Colombia to destroy the plantations producing coca, which is used to make the drug, cocaine. But this will, in turn, have a big effect on the population and environment, so is this the only way forward? Eulalia Furriol asks young people for their views
fields.body:
Colombiaes el primer productor mundial de hojas de coca. Y Estados Unidos es el primer consumidor mundial de cocaína. Por ello Washington ha propuesto al gobierno colombiano el Plan Colombia: una ayuda de1.300 millones de dólares para acabar con las plantaciones de hojas de coca y el narcotrífico. Se trata bísicamente de un plan militar que incluye la compra de sesenta helicópteros de combate Black Hawk y Huey, y la compra de material para el espionaje móvil. También incluye la fumigació n de plantaciones ilegales de coca con productos químicos o biológicos.

Colombia sufre, además, la guerra más antigua del continente americano. Un conflicto cada día más violento que enfrenta a ejército, guerrilla, narcotraficantes y paramilitares. Cuatro jóvenes colombianos nos explican la situación y nos dan su opinión sobre el Plan Colombia.

¿Crees que Estados Unidos debe financiar la lucha contra la droga en Colombia? ¿Qué piensas del Plan Colombia?

Carlos Andrés (16 años): La ayuda de Estados Unidos no beneficia para nada. Sólo aporta más muertes y más violencia. Y la ayuda no es para la gente pobre sino para comprar armas a Estados Unidos.

Federico (18 años): Estados Unidos no deber?a financiar nuestra guerra sino nuestra paz. El Plan Colombia es una campaña de imagen de Estados Unidos. Sólo el diez por ciento del Plan Colombia es para evitar que la gente participe en el negocio de la droga. Y la gente necesita subsistir.

Gina (19 años): Estados Unidos tiene un problema con el consumo de drogas y debería solucionarlo en su propio país. Nosotros tenemos el problema de las plantaciones de coca y es un problema interno de nuestro país. Estados Unidos no debería intervenir. El Plan Colombia es en realidad una excusa para controlar el gobierno colombiano. Es un atentado contra nuestra soberanía.

Luis (17 años): El paquete de ayuda de Estados Unidos es indispensable. Nosotros solos no podemos destruir las plantaciones de coca. Si tenemos que usar la fuerza contra paramilitares y guerrillas necesitamos la ayuda militar de Estados Unidos. Y también la colaboración de los países vecinos.

¿ Qué influencia tiene la droga en la guerra en Colombia?

Carlos Andrés: Toda. La gente planta coca para sobrevivir y la guerrilla los protege.

Federico: Es el principal problema del país. Todos los grupos armados intentan controlar las plantaciones ilegales. Entonces pelean entre ellos y matan a campesinos inocentes.

Luis: Lo único positivo del narcotrófico en Colombia son dos equipos de fútbol: Nacional y América.

¿Crees que el Plan Colombia pone en peligro el medio ambiente en el Amazonas?

Carlos Andrés: S?. Fumigan las zonas más inaccesibles, precisamente donde menos contaminación hay.

Federico: Muchos colombianos mueren cada año por culpa de estas plantaciones. Sus vidas son para mí más importantes que el medio ambiente.

Gina: Sí, porque con las fumigaciones miles de hectáreas quedan estériles. Y las personas que respiran estos productos también sufren, y pueden crear deformaciones en sus hijos.

Luis: Las fumigaciones son la única posibilidad de acceder a la zona.

¿Qué se debería hacer con las plantaciones ilegales?

Carlos Andrés: Legalizar las drogas. Así sería más barata y no habr?a tantos intereses económicos y tantas muertes.

Federico: Reemplazar las plantaciones ilegales por otros productos. Y garantizar a los campesinos que podrán venderlos. Para ello hay que construir carreteras y puentes, para poder acceder al resto del país.

Gina: Acabar con las plantaciones de coca sobre el terreno y no desde el aire.

¿Crees que es posible un futuro sin guerra en Colombia?

Carlos Andrés: Sólo si acabamos con la droga.

Federico: Creo que en un futuro no muy lejano habrá una Colombia sin guerra, pero los colombianos debemos trabajar por la paz.

Gina: En Colombia existe una doble moral. Todos dicen que quieren paz, pero prefieren defender sus intereses. La gente necesita creer y confiar, y ahora no puede.

Luis: Espero que sí.

confiar to trust
la contaminació n pollution
fumigar to spray, to dust
la guerrilla guerrilla forces, guerrilla warfare
intentar to try
no muy lejano not too far off
el medio ambiente environment
pelear to fight
por culpa de because of, through the fault of
la soberanía sovereignty
sobre el terreno on the spot

Por ello Washington ha propuesto al gobierno colombiano el Plan Colombia: una ayuda de1.300 millones de dólares para acabar con las plantaciones de hojas de coca y el narcotrífico. Se trata bísicamente de un plan militar que incluye la compra de sesenta helicópteros de combate Black Hawk y Huey, y la compra de material para el espionaje móvil. También incluye la fumigació n de plantaciones ilegales de coca con productos químicos o biológicos. Colombia sufre, además, la guerra más antigua del continente americano. Un conflicto cada día más violento que enfrenta a ejército, guerrilla, narcotraficantes y paramilitares. Cuatro jóvenes colombianos nos explican la situación y nos dan su opinión sobre el Plan Colombia. ¿Crees que Estados Unidos debe financiar la lucha contra la droga en Colombia? ¿Qué piensas del Plan Colombia? Carlos Andrés (16 años): La ayuda de Estados Unidos no beneficia para nada. Sólo aporta más muertes y más violencia. Y la ayuda no es para la gente pobre sino para comprar armas a Estados Unidos. Federico (18 años): Estados Unidos no deber?a financiar nuestra guerra sino nuestra paz. El Plan Colombia es una campaña de imagen de Estados Unidos. Sólo el diez por ciento del Plan Colombia es para evitar que la gente participe en el negocio de la droga. Y la gente necesita subsistir. Gina (19 años): Estados Unidos tiene un problema con el consumo de drogas y debería solucionarlo en su propio país. Nosotros tenemos el problema de las plantaciones de coca y es un problema interno de nuestro país. Estados Unidos no debería intervenir. El Plan Colombia es en realidad una excusa para controlar el gobierno colombiano. Es un atentado contra nuestra soberanía. Luis (17 años): El paquete de ayuda de Estados Unidos es indispensable. Nosotros solos no podemos destruir las plantaciones de coca. Si tenemos que usar la fuerza contra paramilitares y guerrillas necesitamos la ayuda militar de Estados Unidos. Y también la colaboración de los países vecinos. ¿ Qué influencia tiene la droga en la guerra en Colombia? Carlos Andrés: Toda. La gente planta coca para sobrevivir y la guerrilla los protege. Federico: Es el principal problema del país. Todos los grupos armados intentan controlar las plantaciones ilegales. Entonces pelean entre ellos y matan a campesinos inocentes. Luis: Lo único positivo del narcotrófico en Colombia son dos equipos de fútbol: Nacional y América. ¿Crees que el Plan Colombia pone en peligro el medio ambiente en el Amazonas? Carlos Andrés: S?. Fumigan las zonas más inaccesibles, precisamente donde menos contaminación hay. Federico: Muchos colombianos mueren cada año por culpa de estas plantaciones. Sus vidas son para mí más importantes que el medio ambiente. Gina: Sí, porque con las fumigaciones miles de hectáreas quedan estériles. Y las personas que respiran estos productos también sufren, y pueden crear deformaciones en sus hijos. Luis: Las fumigaciones son la única posibilidad de acceder a la zona. ¿Qué se debería hacer con las plantaciones ilegales? Carlos Andrés: Legalizar las drogas. Así sería más barata y no habr?a tantos intereses económicos y tantas muertes. Federico: Reemplazar las plantaciones ilegales por otros productos. Y garantizar a los campesinos que podrán venderlos. Para ello hay que construir carreteras y puentes, para poder acceder al resto del país. Gina: Acabar con las plantaciones de coca sobre el terreno y no desde el aire. ¿Crees que es posible un futuro sin guerra en Colombia? Carlos Andrés: Sólo si acabamos con la droga. Federico: Creo que en un futuro no muy lejano habrá una Colombia sin guerra, pero los colombianos debemos trabajar por la paz. Gina: En Colombia existe una doble moral. Todos dicen que quieren paz, pero prefieren defender sus intereses. La gente necesita creer y confiar, y ahora no puede. Luis: Espero que sí. webTitle: Architecture: Jonathan Glancey on London's skyline.

fields.headline: The sky's the limit
fields.standfirst: With the right kind of skyscraper, London could once again be as beautiful as it was in the days of Wren, says  Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: With the right kind of skyscraper, London could once again be as beautiful as it was in the days of Wren, says Jonathan Glancey.
fields.body:
Whatever happened to St Benet Sherehog, St Mildred Poultry and All Hallows Honey Lane? They have given way over the years to the likes of Heron Tower, London Bridge Tower and the so-called Erotic Gherkin (of which more later). The first three are former City of London churches either destroyed in the Great Fire of London in 1666, or demolished, in the case of St Mildred's, for road widening in the 1870s. The second three are the latest skyscrapers about to vault from architects' computer screens into the London cloudscape.

In between these demolished and up-and-coming towers, the skyline of central London has been punctuated by gimcrack, second-rate office towers, none of which is a patch on, say, the Empire State or Chrysler buildings in Manhattan. They were built after Conservative governments of the 1950s loosened laws that kept the height of London buildings below that of St Paul's Cathedral (365ft).

Most are lone sentinels rising above stock brick and stucco squares or acres of Victorian dross. Here's Euston Tower lumbering above the grim urban freeway below. There's Centre Point, a pop era concrete beehive buzzing above busy Oxford Street. A mile or so west from Centre Point is the Park Lane Hilton, waving the flag for late 1950s kitsch high above Hyde Park. Looking south, there's Vicker's Tower, all stainless steel and genteel curves sprouting above Tate Britain.

Looming in the distance, out in Docklands, is Britain's tallest building, Canary Wharf Tower (One Canada Square: 800ft) and its latest offspring, the twin 700ft HSBC and Citigroup towers built to separate designs by Foster and Partners and Cesar Pelli, and both nearing completion.

None, to date, inspires. And now we are about to see London overlooked by a fresh sprouting of towers. Business is keen. Ken Livingstone, mayor of London, is on their side. So, too, with critical reservations, are Cabe (the government's Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment), and even English Heritage. The latter's London advisory group supports the development of Heron Tower even while its main body, under Neil Cousins, wants the skyscraper proposal called in for discussion by the Department of the Environment.

Heron Tower is meant to be part of a cluster of office towers orbiting Tower 42, formerly the NatWest Tower. The idea is that the City of London will have the look of a central business district (CBD) along the lines of, say, Sydney, Hong Kong, Shanghai or Los Angeles. Other European cities are creating just such towering CBDs; the City of London doesn't want to fall behind either Frankfurt or Canary Wharf in its own backyard.

Clusters of city office blocks are in vogue. Not only do they form a powerful economic hub, but they also help keep dense property development contained within specific areas of cities rather than spread through them, as happened in the heyday of Euston and Centre Point towers. They also form picturesque cityscapes, most famously in Manhattan. Grouped, the skyscrapers of New York, Chicago and Sydney fascinate from a distance. They are urban mountain ranges, and the lesser buildings - there are plenty of duds in New York and Sydney - are hidden.

However, one cluster of skyscrapers may not be enough for London. A second is expected to sprout around the proposed London Bridge Tower, "a glass shard" no less than 1,016ft tall designed by Renzo Piano, one of the world's finest architects. That's US-league height. A third cluster might yet grow up from the replanned Elephant and Castle in south-east London, and a fourth around Paddington station in the west.

Paris, a quintessentially low-rise capital, saved itself from major upheaval by (a) not being bombed by the Luftwaffe, and (b) planting its monolithic modern office blocks in one place: La Défense. La Défense may have saved central Paris from invasion by office towers, and it looked great by night in Godard's movie Alphaville, yet it suffered, and continues to suffer, from the fact that a Z-list of architects was chosen to design the individual blocks.

And yet there is precedent for clusters of city towers displaying subtle, individual characteristics. Look at an engraving of the City of London in its Baroque and classical heydays. After the Great Fire, Wren and his team replaced 51 churches. Nearly every one, even if following a fairly routine plan or corsetted awkwardly into an existing site, was graced with a tower drawn from a well of rich imagination. Together they must have looked quite magical, spires intersecting with domes and towers. This was architecture as urban jewellery. It was also a lesson in how to design tight clusters of towers that might otherwise be repetitive, mere slabs of stone rising from a labyrinth of dark and narrow streets.

One sad thing about the clusters proposed for London is that the individual buildings are on the bland side, with the exception of Foster's intriguing Erotic Gherkin and perhaps (it's too early to say) Piano's London Bridge Tower. Unless architects tweak these essentially conventional buildings - steel frames, dating back in matter and spirit to 1870s Chicago - we will end up with skylines reminiscent of Sydney or post-1950s Manhattan, which are picturesque only at a distance, and at their best lit up after sunset.

Each of the new-wave buildings, whether at London Bridge, Paddington or the City, could be re-thought somewhere along the line of Wren's intricate church towers. Where are the contemporary versions of wedding-cake spires and coronets, upper-storey arcades? Where is the filigree quality of the superstructure of St Mary-le-Bow or St Brides, Fleet Street? Both at street level and high in the sky, tall city buildings do need to be artistically reconsidered. New York and Chicago architects got this aspect of design so right for several decades, from the 1870s to the 1940s; they have since forgotten, as have most architects elsewhere working for big developers.

It's tempting to blame today's developers for wanting to build too big, too high and too fast for too great a return on capital. New York's Woolworth, Chrysler and Empire State buildings were all designed as rent-slabs, yet each is handsome and an adornment to the city's skyline. In London, of the new towers, Foster and Partners' is by far the most imaginative. This 590ft, 40-storey tower has been designed for a specific, enlightened client. It is not a rent-slab - unlike London Bridge Tower or Heron Tower, which has been designed by the London office of the US practice Kohn Pedersen Fox.

Heron Tower is being developed by Gerald Ronson's Heron property group. It will stand behind St Paul's and intrude on the view of the cathedral from the South Bank. It has planning permission; if only it were more imaginative, more graceful. London Bridge Tower is the brainchild of Irvine Sellar, the 1960s Carnaby Street clothes-magnate-turned-developer. His proposed tower is already in good company. Down below, London Bridge station is to be roofed over with a massive new hi-tech office designed by Chris Wilkinson, architect of the superb train depot outside Stratford tube station.

Expect to see these dramatic and soaring changes soon. But insist that London's skyline be informed as much by the spirit of All Hallows Honey Lane, St Mildred Poultry and St Benet Sherehog - in a contemporary way, sure - as it is by Mammon, the need to beat Frankfurt and other rivals, and sheer, skyscraping urban bragadoccio.

fields.headline: Work shy or work sick?
fields.standfirst: While the media suggests social workers are out shopping, the real cause behind absenteeism is work-related stress, writes Ruth Stark
fields.trailText: Ruth Stark: While the media suggests social workers are out shopping, the real cause behind absenteeism is work-related stress.
fields.body:
Last week, the Scotsman appeared to be accounting for Glasgow social work absenteeism rates in terms of a lack of commitment and competitiveness to the job. The newspaper implied that some people were skiving rather than genuinely ill. One article was accompanied by a photograph showing shoppers, suggesting that some people perhaps went shopping when they should have been at work. It indicated that such high absenteeism rates would not be accepted by the private sector.

This attitude reflects nothing of the complexity of the job of social workers or the part played by under-investment over many years. It ignores the role of employers in making sure staff have the resources available to do the work.

Research during the past few years has drawn attention to the difficulties in the profession. The reality of knocking on the door of a family that does not want a social worker interfering, but where child abuse is suspected, is challenging, worrying and stressful. When the door is slammed in your face you have to think of other strategies.

When you are traced to your home by an aggrieved parent or partner of a parent, you react as any other person would who is the victim of stalking. When your phone rings at 3am, your sleep is disturbed and you cannot get back to sleep with the thoughts of what horrors the next day will bring.

These are some of the issues behind the high number of social workers that were victims of violence at work reflected in the National Institute for Social Work research in 1999, and Brian Littlechild's research last year into coping with violence as a social worker.

We have seen workers in health and education recognised as providing essential services through substantial increases in their wage settlements and training for their work. That same recognition has not been awarded to social care staff by this Labour government.

As we head for another general election, we need to take stock of what has been achieved in the provision of social work services and to ask questions of our political paymasters about their visions of social work as it strives to work towards social inclusion.

Legislation is heading for royal assent in most parts of the UK and Northern Ireland that will set up commissions to regulate services and councils to oversee staff.

We have some additional resources for community care and children's services but these are often diverted through health and education budgets and not always ring-fenced at local government level.

We have seen reluctance to implement the Sutherland report on long-term care for the elderly by the UK parliament - although Scotland has backed it with a promise of free personal care.

There has been a failure to see the importance of the social work in mental health services in England, or the social work contribution in criminal justice interventions. We need to ask questions about what the vision is for the next government programme.

A key part of the survival of social work is the role of the codes of conduct for employers and staff. In Australia and the US a sabbatical period during employment is considered a necessary part of an individual's "professional maintenance". Here, health professionals need continuing professional development points to continue to practice - and it's likely social workers will need them once the supervisory register is up and running. But this can only happen if employers and politicians place investment in continuing training backed up by time off for staff to renew their skills.

Supportive management or cooperative structures enable people to develop their professional potential. The roles of the commissions and councils in all countries are essential for the positive development of social work services and a healthy, productive workforce.

To achieve their goals, the commissions and councils in England, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales have to be properly funded. Each has to recognise and respect the needs of its social care registrants in providing the services demanded by society. Each has to recognise that to meet those needs there has to be value and investment in the people providing the services.

Unjustified, negative interpretations of the reasons behind workforce absences, which in reality are often caused by stress-related illnesses, contribute nothing to the future provision of those social care services that are necessary for an inclusive society.

Ruth Stark is a proffessional officer at the British Association of Social Workers Scotland.

webTitle: Kangaroo leaps on to Europe's menus

fields.headline: Kangaroo leaps on to Europe's menus
fields.standfirst: Following the BSE and foot and mouth scares, demand for the flesh of Australia's national icon has jumped by 20% this year, says Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: Following the BSE and foot and mouth scares, demand for the flesh of Australia's national icon has increased by 20% in Europe this year, says Patrick Barkham in Sydney.
fields.body:
The faces of the customs officers at Australia's international airports are creased with worry.

Sniffer dogs in hand, they are working overtime during the foot and mouth crisis in an attempt to keep the country free from the disease. There are draconian restrictions on what you can bring into Australia and even after a 24-hour flight, every tourist from Britain is searched and their shoes scrubbed with disinfectant.

If the disease breaks out in Australia it will be a calamity for the country, whose economy - now dipping into recession - depends on its multibillion dollar farming industry far more than in the UK.

But there is one group of Australians who are profiting from the foot and mouth crisis across the world. Demand for the flesh of Australia's national icon, the kangaroo, has jumped by 20% in Europe this year as the BSE scare and the foot and mouth outbreak dent consumer confidence.

The kangaroo industry is racing to supply new markets in eastern Europe, who would normally buy cheap cuts of beef from the European Union. Bargain-basement kangaroo meat is now being used instead to make salami and sausages in countries such as Russia, Romania and Serbia.

The Kangaroo Industry Association of Australia (KIAA) says that most of the 20% increase comes from sales to Germany, France, Holland and Belgium, which with their strong tradition of eating wild meat have naturally taken to kangaroo. Demand in Britain remains relatively low because it doesn't have much of an appetite for game cuisine, says John Kelly of KIAA.

Animal rights groups continue to strongly object to the consumption of kangaroo, which takes pride of place on Australia's coat of arms. But, traditionally used in pet food and for leather football boots, human consumption of the versatile marsupial in Australia has increased 50-fold in the last decade. Many of the country's top restaurants now offer high quality kangaroo steaks along with other innovative "bush tucker" dishes.

"It's cheap, it's safe, it's clean and green. High quality kangaroo meat tastes a little bit like deer and folk say it's good for you," says Don Cairns, a senior Australian trade commissioner based in Bucharest.

Chefs extol kangaroo's flavour and leanness. The marsupial only eats grass and has an active "free range" lifestyle, which means it contains less than 2% fat, of which 48% is healthy polyunsaturated fat. The meat is also high in iron.

There are 35 million kangaroos hopping around Australia. None are farmed yet, but each year national parks officers assess how many can be culled sustainably, usually ruling that up to 10% of the kangaroo population can be killed. Still in its infancy, the kangaroo industry has yet to fill any of its quotas.

Mr Kelly says: "It is environmentally wise for us in Australia to produce our food from animals that belong here, rather than use introduced exotics like sheep and cattle which cause considerable environmental damage."

Unlike hard-hoofed animals, such as sheep, native kangaroos have soft pads, which cause less damage to Australia's fragile plains. "Harvesting" wild kangaroos has far less of an impact on the land than the high-intensity farming of beef cattle, for which forests are often cleared.

Red and grey kangaroos are not threatened species. But the Australian Conservation Foundation says that although some culling operations could be justified, it opposes the commercial hunting of wild kangaroos, while any proposals for kangaroo farming should be subject to stringent environmental controls.

"We're pretty cautious about kangaroo farming because local circumstances can dictate the sustainability of farming practices," says Charlie Sherwin, an ACF spokesperson. "Producers should be required to prove that their operations won't adversely affect the ecology, genetics or sustainability of wild or captive kangaroo populations."

The Kangaroo Industry Association of Australia (KIAA) says that most of the 20% increase comes from sales to Germany, France, Holland and Belgium, which with their strong tradition of eating wild meat have naturally taken to kangaroo. Demand in Britain remains relatively low because it doesn't have much of an appetite for game cuisine, says John Kelly of KIAA. Animal rights groups continue to strongly object to the consumption of kangaroo, which takes pride of place on Australia's coat of arms. But, traditionally used in pet food and for leather football boots, human consumption of the versatile marsupial in Australia has increased 50-fold in the last decade. Many of the country's top restaurants now offer high quality kangaroo steaks along with other innovative "bush tucker" dishes. "It's cheap, it's safe, it's clean and green. High quality kangaroo meat tastes a little bit like deer and folk say it's good for you," says Don Cairns, a senior Australian trade commissioner based in Bucharest. Chefs extol kangaroo's flavour and leanness. The marsupial only eats grass and has an active "free range" lifestyle, which means it contains less than 2% fat, of which 48% is healthy polyunsaturated fat. The meat is also high in iron. There are 35 million kangaroos hopping around Australia. None are farmed yet, but each year national parks officers assess how many can be culled sustainably, usually ruling that up to 10% of the kangaroo population can be killed. Still in its infancy, the kangaroo industry has yet to fill any of its quotas. Mr Kelly says: "It is environmentally wise for us in Australia to produce our food from animals that belong here, rather than use introduced exotics like sheep and cattle which cause considerable environmental damage." Unlike hard-hoofed animals, such as sheep, native kangaroos have soft pads, which cause less damage to Australia's fragile plains. "Harvesting" wild kangaroos has far less of an impact on the land than the high-intensity farming of beef cattle, for which forests are often cleared. Red and grey kangaroos are not threatened species. But the Australian Conservation Foundation says that although some culling operations could be justified, it opposes the commercial hunting of wild kangaroos, while any proposals for kangaroo farming should be subject to stringent environmental controls. "We're pretty cautious about kangaroo farming because local circumstances can dictate the sustainability of farming practices," says Charlie Sherwin, an ACF spokesperson. "Producers should be required to prove that their operations won't adversely affect the ecology, genetics or sustainability of wild or captive kangaroo populations." webTitle: It's a man's world: Emma Brockes on sexual discrimination in the Square Mile.

fields.headline: It's a man's world
fields.standfirst: Last week an investment bank trader accepted £70,000 for unfair dismissal. She had been asked to wear short skirts and give massages, and was made redundant while on maternity leave. Is this a rare incident or is the Square Mile still a haven for unreconstructed men? By  Emma Brockes
fields.trailText: Last week an investment bank trader accepted £70,000 for unfair dismissal. She had been asked to wear short skirts and give massages, and was made redundant while on maternity leave. Is this a rare incident or is the Square Mile still a haven for unreconstructed men? By Emma Brockes
fields.body:
There was a game they used to play, at the bank where Sue Temple worked. Every morning when she walked in, her male colleagues would try to guess what underwear she had on. "Camisole!" they would yell. Or, "French knickers!" One of 25 women brokers among 300 men, she would pass the bank of desks while its occupants crouched and craned to verify their guesses. It was like a building site, she says, only all the blokes were wearing suits.

The gap between modern standards of behaviour and those practised in the City widened again last week, when the Japanese finance house, Nomura, paid out £70,000 to Isabelle Terrillon, one of its former brokers. Terrillon, 35, returned from maternity leave three years ago to find that her job no longer existed. At a tribunal in Stratford, east London, she described Nomura as the kind of place in which a male colleague would declare, loudly enough for her to hear, that "of all the women on the dealing floor, the one he really wanted to fuck was [Isabelle]".

During a client meeting, Terrillon said she was asked to strip down and administer a massage to one of her colleagues. If she showed displeasure, she was asked whether or not she was "going to start crying". Last Monday, she dropped the sexual discrimination claim and accepted a £70,000 out-of-court settlement for unfair dismissal.

Behaviour in the City is traditionally graded between the extremes of yobbish brokerage and genteel corporate finance. Brokerage, it is imagined, is a gladiatorial arena in which everyone is mean to everyone else, while corporate finance is a euphemism for "gentlemanly". According to women who have worked in both, however, it is not the degree of sexism that differs so much as its expression, which by subtle means is as alive now as it was during the 1980s. Over the past five years, the Equal Opportunities Commission has taken on 35 cases of sex discrimination from workers in the City, six of which have been successful. "Many of them settle before they get to court," says a spokeswoman, who believes that these figures are a drop in the ocean.

"Most City males think the world is divided into three types of women," says one former analyst. "The sweet, virginal, Julia Roberts look-a-like who responds with delighted giggles to any sort of "perfectly normal workplace banter", yet is desperate to don crotchless knickers and give the boss a blow-job. Then there are the mothers - unreliable because not only did they go and get pregnant, but they have the nerve to clock off early if a child breaks an arm. And then there is the largest group of women - the humourless bitches."

For 10 years, Helen Cartwright was a money broker for an international Swiss bank, one of six women among 250 men. She earned £80,000 a year. "It was like a cartoon," she says. "The men in the office would say: 'When are you going to go home, get married and have babies?' The more they put me down, the better they were regarded by the others."

On the off chance that they would "get lucky", Cartwright's male colleagues would book rooms by the hour at London hotels such as the Strand Palace or the Great Eastern Hotel and try to persuade her to return there with them. On one occasion, a male colleague approached Cartwright's desk, undid his flies, and exposed the stitches of his recent circumcision to her. She told him to put it away or she would hit it with the phone.

"The nastiest thing they ever did was when I split up with my ex-husband. They talked very loudly about the new girl he was seeing. It was devastating. I lost a stone and a half in two weeks." Cartwright eventually left the bank and received an out-of-court settlement on the condition that she never disclosed its value.

These were not the sort of circumstances into which Laura Browning imagined she was entering. After leaving a relatively civilised US company, she joined a more traditional British merchant bank as a middle-ranking executive.

"If I'd had a tape recorder, I could have taken them to the cleaners," she says. "I had a very swashbuckling client, who required long meetings late into the night and at weekends. During one meeting, this man cleared a boardroom of 30 people by saying: 'Could all of you please leave while I speak to Linda.' Once they had left, he actually chased me round the boardroom. It was unbelievable. Part of me wanted to laugh, the other to slap him."

When the client persisted in commenting on Davies's clothes and tried to grab her again, she took the matter to a senior director. "My dear," he said, "did no one ever tell you the customer is always right?" The subtext, says Davies, was that if the client wanted to sleep with her, then she should let him. "I went straight to a headhunter and said get me out of here".

This kind of overt grappling has been replaced, recently, by more covert forms of intimidation, much favoured by litigation-weary bankers. "It is about the subtle discounting of ability," says Helena Dennison, chair of the City Women's Network, which represents 200 senior female executives working in the Square Mile. "Covert discrimination means rubbishing a woman's contribution during meetings, either with snide remarks or remarks about her appearance. Covert discrimination undermines confidence."

The language of sexism grows more respectable the further up a company you go, becomes more subtle and harder to censure. When she worked on the trading floor, Cartwright says women were referred to as "tarts, slappers and dogs".

"In a funny way, I think overt sexism is easier to deal with," says a former analyst who worked in a US firm for five years. "What I experienced was a constant undercurrent which, without anyone saying it, ensured that women knew their place. It was clear that only attractive females were being hired. There was an atmosphere of testosterone which meant clients were taken to lap-dancing clubs, places where women would be uncomfortable."

Every morning, her boss would walk past his secretary and say: "Show me your tits." One morning after months of this, she did. (He never asked again.) "There was an under-lying feeling that you would never get on. You only had to look at the number of female executives to know that you had no future."

While the average intake in a City firm is divided equally between the sexes, only 3% of executives at the highest level are women. According to the Equal Opportunities Commission, women working full-time in banking and finance currently earn 55% of their male counterparts' earnings. "Sexism is more dangerous now," says Justine Burgess, who used to work in international equity. When her boss pulled her on to his knee or massaged her shoulders when she was on the phone to a client, she found it relatively easy to diffuse. "I could laugh it off," she says.

"The men used to get their willies out, but you'd just learn to put up with it," says Sue Temple. "You deal with it because everyone is in the same boat. There was no point complaining. Women had to take it on the chin."

"What is more difficult," says Burgess, "is an environment in which you get fewer daily comments, but a lot of subtle discrimination over promotions and pay." One of her friends has just filed suit against a merchant bank after being passed over for promotion because, she suspects, she couldn't play golf. "She was out of that whole guy thing and although she brought in as much revenue as the rest of them, they froze her out."

Dennison believes many woman don't take their grievances to court for fear of gaining reputations as troublemakers. "If you were making £300,000 a year, would you jeopardise your career by speaking out against the firm?" Deutsche Bank, which last year paid an estimated £500,000 in damages to a female banker after her manager publicly accused her of sleeping with a male client, could not, despite numerous requests, rustle up anyone to discuss its harassment policy. One analyst said: "The problem with these places is that they don't take their human resources departments seriously. They see them as a service rather than a critical part of the company." Most of her female colleagues, she says, look straight past toothless personnel sections to the courts for redress.

Against the odds, Isabelle Terrillon has found another job in the City. Laura Browning, after a "dehumanising" spell on the trading floor, left to write financial thrillers. Temple gave as good as she got for seven years and now practises as a healer in Brighton. Justine Burgess had a child and moved from equity into the more civilised field of financial headhunting. Cartwright is an estate agent in Tunbridge Wells. She has a favourite exchange from her time in the City, which she tells with a vigorous but bitter irony. "I don't like women", a male colleague once volunteered. Cartwright allowed a short pause before replying: "So leave."

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: Headgear Girl struggles with the woes of wearing a brace and a haunted hotel where the bedbugs and the bellboys make life a misery for a courting couple.
fields.trailText: Headgear Girl struggles with the woes of wearing a brace and a haunted hotel where the bedbugs and the bellboys make life a misery for a courting couple.
fields.body:
Headgear Girl
(www.undergroundfilm.com)

Streaming video, by and large, isn't kind to indie film. When you're struggling to distinguish objects from people on a two-inch video window, the finer points of character-driven studies tend to pass you by. Emily Weissman's keen-eyed portrait of pre-teen angst is remarkable then, in its ability to put across girlish pain in just a handful of everyday suburban scenes. Her secret weapon is actress Megan Casey, the Headgear Girl of the title, whose elaborate toothbrace looks like a cross between a fondue set and a radio mast, condemning her to life as the class scapegoat. Casey's spare performance, alternately stoical and coltishly optimistic, shines out of the smallest of screens. (KS)
 View the film

Ghost of Stephen Foster
(www.ifilm.com)

This cheerfully retro black and white cartoon started life as the music video accompanying an equally cheerful ditty by off-beat band, the Squirrel Nut Zippers. Their oompah kletzmer sound makes a neat fit with the giddy and skilful Max Fleischer-style animation adopted by director Raymond Persi. Goggle as a Betty Boop-alike and her beau are chased around the haunted Hotel Paradise by everybody from the bellboy to the bedbugs. All underpinned by the catchy pastiche title tune - "The Camptown Ladies NEVER sang all the doo-dah day" apparently. (KS)
 View the film

fields.headline: Falstaff
fields.standfirst:
Royal Northern College of Music
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Royal Northern College of Music
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.body:
One of the privileges of living near Manchester is the Royal Northern College of Music opera, which is never seen elsewhere (although perhaps it should be). There are plenty of singers here who are ready to step onto the professional stage, operas are routinely sung in their original language with surtitles, and in Stefan Janski's hands the productions are always imaginative.

Verdi's last opera is in many ways his hardest to present. It bristles with action and jokes, it has an enormous number of characters, and it has almost cinematographic changes of mood, with glorious moments of stillness amid the bustle. Janski's approach is to avoid any funny business: he keeps the stage relatively clear and he blocks the characters in a fairly traditional manner. In short, he concentrates on telling the story and clarifying the characters. Judith Croft's designs are splendid but economical, retaining the same basic set except for the last scene. The many upper-storey windows with faces poking out give the sense of everything happening in a world where gossip and intrigue prevail. Nick Richings provides lighting of an unusual sensitivity. It is rare to see a production of Falstaff in which all the details and gags are so easy to understand, contributing deftly to the work's impact.

Stephen Barlow conducts with considerable flair. The student orchestra is over-enthusiastic at the start, rather drowning the young voices with Verdi's heavy scoring. But that soon sorts itself out, and the bright colours and the often cruelly exposed virtuoso orchestration meld perfectly with the stage. Darren Jeffery seems ideally suited to the enormous title-role: never overacting, never tiring, he is excellent, and produces in the last act some of the loveliest sounds of the evening. An extremely strong supporting cast includes Rebecca von Lipinski's authoritative Alice, Anne-Marie Gibbons, solid in the difficult role of Quickly, a neatly acted Ford from Roland Davitt, and delightful young lovers from Claire Ormshaw and Nicholas Sharratt. In a beautifully conceived innovation members of the RNCM Junior Strings Project sang as the fairies in the last scene.

 In rep until March 31. Box office: 0161-907 5278.

fields.headline: Marc Almond parties like it's 1981
fields.standfirst:
Soft Cell
Ocean
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Soft Cell
Ocean
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
"What was so fucking great about the 80s?" asks Marc Almond, Soft Cell's impish frontman. "I had some good times," he shrugs, "shagged a few people. Took a few drugs. But if that's what you want I'm not going to spoil it for you."

Not that he'd be able to. Everyone here is ready to party like it's 1981 - at least, they've come prepared with lashings of eyeliner. Almond wears a peroxide blond quiff, a black top that sparkles and wide trousers that swish; as he struts around the stage, throwing robotic dance moves and entreating the crowd to sing Memorabilia, it's like the past 20 years never happened.

The outpouring of affection is surprising considering Soft Cell's short - though glittering - career. Almond and colleague Dave Ball split in 1984 after just four years of pop stardom, ending the stream of seedy glamour and unrestrained sexuality they brought to the charts and an unlikely but successful relationship. Ball maintains the prerequisite glum visage, but he's clearly happy standing behind his bank of electronic equipment. Almond, meanwhile, is a nonstop ball of enthusiasm, excitement and emotion. His dramatics are almost as impressive as his rich voice, with faux displays of tragedy and a bouncing, arm-waving joy.

But then drama was always Soft Cell's defining characteristic. Ball's electronic scribblings consist largely of a repetitive beat that creates a feeling of unease; while that worms its way under your skin, delicate trumpet and piano add colour to the urban sound. Almond stands at the front of the stage, leading the audience in a rendition of Youth, joining them for another soaring vocal, his flourishes filling in the blank spaces between the beats.

Nostalgia has sold the tickets (and the venue is packed), but the duo also choose to play a couple of new, unreleased songs. "Apparently we sound too much like Soft Cell," Almond remarks. "People we've played them to say: 'Can't you make it sound like the Chemical Brothers?'" It's fair to say that Divided Souls - inspired by Marvin Gaye - isn't big beat, but it is the kind of detail-laden, down-at-heel song that Soft Cell do best, a poppy tale of introspection and isolation.

The songs go on for a bit too long, but when they include the squalid but beautiful Bedsitter, it's forgivable. Tainted Love is fantastic, the magic made greater by its slow-burning fusion into the Supremes' Where Did Our Love Go? Almond shakes his hips as he whacks the drum machine, but on Say Hello Wave Goodbye he is almost redundant, his attempt to sing the song a little bit faster than usual shot down in flames by the crowd who know exactly how it should be done. You don't mess with a classic, after all.

The songs go on for a bit too long, but when they include the squalid but beautiful Bedsitter, it's forgivable. Tainted Love is fantastic, the magic made greater by its slow-burning fusion into the Supremes' Where Did Our Love Go? Almond shakes his hips as he whacks the drum machine, but on Say Hello Wave Goodbye he is almost redundant, his attempt to sing the song a little bit faster than usual shot down in flames by the crowd who know exactly how it should be done. You don't mess with a classic, after all.

fields.headline: OAE/ McGegan
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Paris in the 1770s was a place of musical upheaval and intellectual ferment. Battles raged over the merits of Italian versus German opera, and concerts were fiercely promoted by rival impresarios. Mozart, Haydn and Gluck were the most famous foreign musicians to be sucked into this musical maelstrom. But the composers who lived and worked in Paris, such as Philidor, Grétry and Gossec, are much less familiar. Nicholas McGegan's concert with the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment presented a rare chance to hear music by these Parisian composers, alongside masterpieces by Mozart and Haydn.

The reputation of François-André Danican Philidor's music has sunk so low that few will have heard of his 1767 opera Ernelinde, Princesse de Norvège, from which soprano Joan Rodgers sang a recitative and aria with passion and precision. And yet there was real compositional interest in Philidor's music. He depicts the pain of Ernelinde's lover in a searing crescendo for two horns, and creates a swirl of string figuration to describe a thickening mist.

Rodgers was also a superb advocate of an aria from André-Ernest-Modeste Grétry's Zémire et Azor, a retelling of the Beauty and the Beast story. Grétry creates a picturesque dialogue between Zémire, singing in praise of a sparrow, and a flute. Rodgers relished the acrobatic music, soaring from the depths of her range to the heights of her coloratura.

Next to these attractive showpieces, François-Joseph Gossec's G major Symphony was crude and workmanlike, even though McGegan and the OAE did their best to characterise Gossec's sometimes surprising harmonic twists. But Gossec's symphony was always going to have a hard time up against Mozart's Paris Symphony. On the surface, the pieces are similar: both are composed in an extrovert style. But the abundance of Mozart's invention eclipses anything in Gossec's piece - and any of Mozart's previous symphonies. The OAE responded to McGegan's dynamic direction with a vigorous performance. Haydn's Symphony No 82, The Bear, composed for Paris in 1787, completed McGegan's programme with a burst of wit.

fields.headline: Shaky foundations bring down The Walls
fields.standfirst:
The Walls
National Theatre
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
The Walls
National Theatre
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
As he proved at London's Gate theatre with Marathon and Cuckoos, Colin Teevan is a first-rate translator. But his new play at the Cottesloe Theatre, The Walls, feels like a piece of dated Dublin Ionesco. In applying the techniques of 1950s Absurdism to middle-class Irish life Teevan allows the play's spontaneous energy to be crushed under the weight of an oppressive symbolism.

The title itself has a double significance. The action takes place on Christmas Eve in the Walls's Dublin home as they await the arrival of their exiled son, Joseph, and his English wife Mary. When the pair turn up a crippled, paedophiliac Jesuit neighbour greets them, just in case we missed the point, with the cry: "No room at the inn!" Teevan's idea that Dublin life is filled with flaws is visually embodied by the disappearance of the house's walls. There are even references to the missing fourth wall with the mother's apprehensive glances at the audience.

It is perfectly legitimate to expose the hypocrisies of the Irish middle-classes, but I am staggered by the programme's claim that this is new territory - writers such as Tom Murphy, Hugh Leonard and Conor McPherson have all been there before. The problem is that Teevan builds his symbolic edifice on the shakiest realistic foundations. We learn a little about the Walls: we hear of the collapse of the father's underpants factory, the loss of his investments owing to Joseph's fiscal ineptitude and discover the incestuous consequences of the mother's adultery. But instead of allowing the symbolism to grow out of observed reality, Teevan imposes it from the start, so that the characters seem like walking abstractions.

And yet the plays Teevan has translated took the opposite approach; the metaphorical meaning of Marathon arose naturally from the characters' obsessive running. Here one admires the visual ingenuity of Mick Gordon's production and Dick Bird's design, and one feels sorry for the actors left trying to put flesh on a series of authorial pawns. Clare Higgins embodies maternal survival tactics against the odds, Michael Culkin is her plumply complacent husband, and Tony Rohr a raffish civil servant. They work hard but they are up against Teevan's perverse theatrical structure. He appears to have started with the message he wished to convey, then found the characters who would illustrate it.

 In rep. Box office: 020-7452 3000.

fields.headline: David Mamet's fancy phrasework
fields.standfirst:
Boston Marriage
Donmar Warehouse
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Boston Marriage
Donmar Warehouse
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
"It is easier to write great dialogue than to write great plots," David Mamet once confessed. To prove the point his latest play is packed with a mix of exquisite literary banter and subversive modernism that sets the mind reeling - but the dazzling repartee is slightly in excess of the actual narrative incident.

As if to answer the charge that his plays are often hermetically male, Mamet has here come up with a work exclusively female. The title refers to the intimate relationship between two women fashionable in late 19th-century New England; Mamet deals with the point of crisis in just such a marriage. Anna, for fiscal reasons, has taken a married male lover from whom she has acquired a stipend and an emerald necklace. Her partner, Claire, is besotted with a young girl whom she has invited to the house for the purpose of seduction. The shock revelation comes from the realisation that Anna's lover and Claire's inamorata are themselves closely connected.

But the plot is the least impressive aspect of Boston Marriage. Mostly, Mamet is having a high old time exposing the raw, demotic urges that underlay the polite circumlocutions of cultivated New England drawing rooms. Anna, in particular, affects a Jamesian periphrasis which she suddenly punctures with phrases such as "what a vast and pointless shithole it all is". To add spice to the mixture Mamet endows Anna with an Orcadian maid who is a vehicle of much lewd innuendo.

It is all very funny, and yet makes a serious point: just as Mamet's petty hoods mask their fear under a barrage of profanity, so the genteel American classes camouflaged their sexual and financial rapacity under sculpted literary language. Mamet also cleverly suggests that something is at stake under the arch linguistic games: the ageing Anna's desperate attempt to hold onto the younger Claire. But too much hinges on a last-minute twist that makes you reconsider what you have been watching. What works cleverly in Mamet's movie The Spanish Prisoner here seems over-contrived.

Even if the dialogue is better than the plot, Phyllida Lloyd's well-paced production, set in a chintz-covered drawing room, boasts three excellent performances. Zoe Wanamaker is brilliant as Anna precisely because she belongs convincingly to a world of whaleboned snobbery and crooked little fingers, and also one of emotional desperation. She handles the language with kid gloves while coming out with phrases such as "tell it to the marines". Anna Chancellor's Claire is also a hilarious mix of straight-backed social refinement and predatory lust and Lyndsey Marshal as the maid neatly blends naivete with a shrewd grasp of sexual power-play. All language, Mamet suggests, is a facade: his skill lies in exposing the painful reality under the fancy filigree phrases.

 Until April 14. Box office: 020-7369 1732. A version of this review appeared in later editions of Saturday's paper.

fields.headline: Belle
fields.standfirst:
Gate
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Gate
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
In the aftermath of the American civil war, Belle and Bowlyn, the children of slaves, make their way north dreaming of a better life. But the "numb, ice blue Yankees" are not as welcoming as they had hoped, money is short and the baby, which spends its day on Belle's back while she spends her day on her knees cleaning white women's floors, needs feeding.

The pair get mixed up with Nance, a poor little rich girl and suffragette, who persuades them to join her in an alliance to fight for votes for women and blacks. Soon Bowlyn is involved in full-time politicking while Belle still spends her days on her knees earning enough money to feed the baby.

The different needs of men and women, black and white, rich and poor come to the fore in Florence Gibson's play about the way political necessity turns to political expediency and how the little people are always at the mercy of institutions. Bowlyn is recruited to join the Republican Party to help it secure the black vote, but then rejected. Nance is no better, ultimately ditching her "sister" when she gets the first sniff of power.

It is hard not to fall for Belle, either the character - who is played here with a simple, direct assurance by Tina Gambe - or the play. Gibson's drama, not typical Gate fare by any means, may have the soft-bellied feel of one of those sweeping family sagas, but it is highly watchable and is distinguished by a use of language that is always interesting. Belle, Bowlyn and Belle's sister Althea speak in a rich, dark, mossy dialect that hails from the Georgia swamplands; it intimately connects thought and emotion, unlike the dissembling northern speech, in which the gap between what is said and done widens as the play continues.

The production makes some curious choices, not least in the set design that breaks up the auditorium, and constantly has the actors popping up in different places. The result is a jumpy rather than fluid feel to the evening. And there is no getting away from the fact that Gibson too often falls back on monologue and melodrama.

But it is an easy, entertaining evening and if it doesn't quite fill you with the rage that it should, it provides a welcome and haunting glimpse into a world where the legacies of the past are like weeds that choke the future.

 Until March 31. Box office: 020-7229 0706 .

webTitle: World music review: King Wasiu Ayinde

fields.headline: A king of Nigerian dance music
fields.standfirst:
King Wasiu Ayinde
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
King Wasiu Ayinde
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
There have been some notable exceptions (King Sunny Ade, Fela Kuti and now Femi Kuti), but Nigerian bands have never found playing in Britain easy. Partly, it has been a question of cost - Nigerians love big bands, which are not cheap to tour. Partly it's the fault of Nigeria itself: promoters were reluctant to deal with this often chaotic country, particularly through the years of military rule. As a result, there are great Nigerian musicians who have never had a chance to perform here, despite the popularity of world music in general, and West African music in particular.

Take the case of King Wasiu Ayinde, who once called himself Barrister Wasiu (in respect to Sikiru Ayinde Barrister, the best-known exponent of the Fuji dance style), and is now also known, with an apparent nod to the military, as King Wasiu Ayinde Marshal. He has been recording for over two decades, and during the 1990s emerged as one of the true leaders not only of the Fuji dance style but of all Nigeria's many musical monarchs. He has sold albums by the truckload on the local market and been voted artist of the year four times in the past six years. King Ayinde is now in his early 40s, but had never given a concert in Britain until this appearance.

For the Nigerians by the foot of the stage, his appearance was cause for celebration and dancing from the very start; even so, this was a show that lumbered slowly into life. Ayinde came on in sandals and a long brown robe, surrounded by a band that consisted of a keyboard player, a saxophonist, and a massive rhythm section. The bass guitarist was flanked by a drummer with a conventional kit and five other percussionists banging away on talking drums and sakara tambourine drum. Fuji (which takes its name, mysteriously, from the mountain in Japan) is based on traditional Yoruba drumming and chanting, but has a contemporary edge, and makes no use of guitars.

It's a stirring but subtle style, but in the first set the band were hampered by atrocious, echoing sound, and Ayinde seemed to be merely cruising, making far less effort than his frantically raunchy female dancers. It wasn't until he returned for the second set, now dressed in a zebra-striped jump suit, that he justified those claims that he is the "golden voice" of Nigeria. He switched easily between passages of pop balladry and jazz to sections of stirring, sometimes trance-like, often Arabic-sounding call-and-response chanting, driven along by the massed percussion and punctuated by frantic talking drum solos. It was a long time coming, but when the band sorted out the sound problems and found their form, the result was exhilarating.

webTitle: Classical review: The Maiden in the Tower

fields.headline: The Maiden in the Tower
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall
Manchester
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall
Manchester
Rating: **
fields.body:
In the great song of Sibelius's life, The Maiden in the Tower was no more than a clearing of the throat. For a brief period in the 1890s it seemed as though the young Finnish composer would achieve with the Nordic legends what Wagner had with the Teutonic myths - until he travelled to Bayreuth, saw Parsifal and panicked. This crisis-of-confidence resolved, Sibelius buried himself in the scores of Liszt and set out his stall as a future symphonist.

All but forgotten, The Maiden in the Tower has awaited a full British performance until now. The BBC Philharmonic acquitted themselves stoically under the extremely capable hands of the excellent Estonian conductor Paavo Jarvi. But regrettably, like the opera's titular heroine, it might have been kinder not to let it out.

Whereas Sibelius's more promising early operatic essay, The Building of the Boat, never made it to the water, The Maiden in the Tower did reach completion, probably because it was commissioned as a benefit in aid of the Helsinki Philharmonic Society in 1896. There is scarcely a bar, however, in which Sibelius went beyond the call of duty. A slim-line rescue opera in an almost indecent hurry, the heroine is abducted, incarcerated, calumnied, rescued and redeemed, all in 40 hectic minutes. It is unactable, and with Rafael Hertzberg's libretto including lines as wretched as "for gold and gloss her honour and her faith she lost", it was a mercy that the four soloists were singing in Swedish.

With the rising young baritone Garry Magee and the eloquent Norwegian soprano Solveig Kringelborn on the platform there were some fine voices here; it's a pity Sibelius didn't want you to hear them. The problem of balance was not something that the young composer had addressed, nor that Jarvi could do much about. The fussiness of Sibelius's vocal accompaniments meant that by the time the contralto arrives like a haughty schoolmistress to tell everyone to behave themselves, it was impossible for Lilli Paasikivi to make an impression. Only the brightness of Lars-Erik Jonsson's Helden-tenorish tone occasionally broke through the orchestral clouds. Sibelius devotees can hear the concert repeated on Radio 3. Everyone else can happily wait another 100 years for the next revival.

 This concert is broadcast on Radio 3 tomorrow.
